Check your provider

Topics Warnings&sanctions Complaints
Check your provider
If a person or company is offering you financial services or products, always check that they hold an authorization for that purpose.
In any event, it is advisable to check, using the search function, whether:
The person or company contacting you holds an authorization to make you this offer.
A warning has been published by the FSMA or by other supervisory authorities against the person or company contacting you.
Search function
If you cannot find the provider or if you still have doubts, contact us using this form so that the FSMA can conduct a check.
As well, feel free to notify us of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.
A person or company that cannot be clearly identified should never be trusted.
Even if you think you know the provider, check twice. Many fraudsters usurp the names of well known or authorized companies. These are called “cloned firms". Click here for more information about this type of fraud.
In any case, if you have been contacted without having taken any prior initiative yourself, if your contact person is particularly insistent, if you are promised very high returns, if you are promised a capital guarantee or “risk free” investments, or if you are asked to pay money into bank accounts abroad (and/or in countries other than the one where the company is supposedly registered), this could be an additional indication of fraud. For more information, please see our web pages How to recognize and avoid fraud en Have I been the victim of fraud?
Don’t be duped! Consult the FSMA website for more information regarding the most frequent forms of investment fraud.

Calculateurs, conseils pratiques, checklists
10e édition de La Semaine de l’Argent - Les jeunes veulent en savoir encore plus sur l’argent
Les jeunes âgés de 18 à 25 ans aimeraient en apprendre encore davantage à l’école sur les questions d'argent. Les cryptomonnaies intéressent particulièrement la jeune génération, mais les impôts, la gestion du budget et les investissements figurent également en bonne place sur la liste de leurs souhaits.
En savoir plus
Le mandat de protection extrajudiciaire
Vous souhaitez régler vos questions financières à l’avance ? Votre santé décline et vous craignez de ne plus être capable à un moment donné de gérer seul vos affaires? Un mandat de protection extrajudiciaire peut dans ce cas s’avérer judicieux.
En savoir plus
Inscrivez-vous dès maintenant à notre lettre d’information Wikifin pleine de conseils fiables sur l’argent
* champ obligatoire
Adresse e-mail :
Voir les éditions précédentes
La FSMA traitera vos données à caractère personnel conformément à sa politique de protection de la vie privée. Vous pouvez retirer votre consentement à tout moment.
Vous êtes enseignant(e) ?
Inscrivez-vous à la lettre d’information Wikifin School pour être tenu(e) au courant de l’actualité de notre offre à utiliser dans votre classe.
Vous inscrire maintenant
School
Inspirez-vous de notre offre pédagogique variée d’éducation financière et à la consommation responsable
Wikifin School met gratuitement à disposition des enseignants du matériel pédagogique varié et des formations pour les aider à faire de l’éducation financière et la consommation responsable en classe.
Des pistes pédagogiques pour les élèves et des ressources théoriques pour les enseignants
Des quiz en ligne, des vidéos, des simulateurs…
Indépendant et fiable
Découvrir notre offre pédagogique
Lab
Une expérience unique et interactive pour mieux comprendre l’argent
Les élèves du secondaire expérimentent gratuitement diverses situations financières de la vie quotidienne, lors d’une immersion ludique qui dure 2h45.
Les thèmes abordés lors du parcours éducatif sont variés : la gestion budgétaire, la sécurité sociale en passant par les techniques d’influence…
Conforme aux référentiels de l’enseignement et aligné avec les programmes scolaires.
Votre sécurité avant tout !
Toutes les mesures en matière de sécurité et d’hygiène sont prises pour vous assurer une visite en toute sécurité.
Le Wikifin Lab est ainsi entièrement désinfecté entre 2 visites.
En savoir plus sur le Wikifin Lab

Privacy policy
The personal data which you have provided to the FSMA via the applications below will be processed by the FSMA as set out in its Privacy Policy.
Privacy policy
Information about web browsers
Information about web browsers
FINPRO
PRIIPS KIIDS Notification
FINPRO is intended for the electronic notification of PRIIPs KIDs to the FSMA.
FINPRO
eCorporate - FiMiS Survey
eCorporate - FiMiS Survey
eCorporate: uploading of mandatory reports (documents), provision of company information (identification sheet) and mandatory reporting list. 
FiMiS Survey: entering and/or uploading of mandatory reports (structured financial tables).
eCorporate
FiMiS Survey
eMT
Online notification of managers’ transactions
eMT is intended for the notification – by managers – of their transactions to the issuer concerned and to the FSMA. The issuers must confirm the notifications received via EMT and report them to the FSMA.
eMT
eManex
Online notification and management of the external mandates of directors who are subject to regulations on the incompatibility of certain mandates
Online notification and management of directors’ external mandates who are subject to an incompatibility regime.
eManex
Intermediaries and Lenders
Online registration and management of your registration as an intermediary or your authorization as a lender
This online application makes it possible to request enrolment in the register of consumer credit intermediaries or to apply for authorization as a mortgage and/or consumer credit provider.
Intermediaries and Lenders
STORI
The official Belgian central storage mechanism for regulated information
STORI contains the regulated information submitted by issuers to the FSMA since 1 January 2011.
The FSMA was designated by the Royal Decree of 23 February 2010 as the institution that, as from 1 January 2011, is responsible for the central storage of regulated information within the meaning of the Transparency Directive.
STORI

How to make a complaint?
If you have a complaint about a financial service or product, you can contact the authority that specializes in the subject matter of your complaint for a free assessment. The information below is provided in order to guide you through the complaints process.
You have a complaint about:
If you wish to complain about a financial product or service, you can lodge your complaint with any of the authorities designated to handle such a complaint, although it may also be advisable to take legal action.
Banking, credit, or investment service
Insurance
Consumer credit
Mortgage loan
Supplementary occupational pensions
A suspicious email or message
Crowdfunding service providers (crowdfunding platforms)
Questions about investment fraud?

Warnings & sanctions
On this page you can find the warnings published against the companies or persons active within Belgium without holding the specific authorization required to offer credit or investment products/services in or from within Belgium.
These warnings are published by the FSMA or by other supervisory authorities with a view to warning the public against companies or persons who are operating illegally or even fraudulently. If a warning has been published against the person or company contacting you, do not make any payment!
Warnings by
FSMA
ESMA
IOSCO
Please note: the absence of a warning about a company does not guarantee that the company in question holds a valid authorization.
The FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner. It can happen, however, that the FSMA has not yet been informed of a company that is engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market. That is the case, for example, with companies that regularly change names. It is therefore possible that the FSMA has not yet published warnings about certain companies that are operating illegally within Belgium.
In any event, it is advisable to check, using the search function, whether:
The company contacting you holds an authorization to make you this offer.
A warning has been published against the company contacting you.
Don't be duped! Consult the FSMA website for more information regarding the most frequent forms of investment fraud.
Administrative sanctions

Accessibility Statement
The FSMA is committed to making this website accessible in compliance with the Law of 19 July 2018 on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.
This accessibility statement applies to https://www.fsma.be 
Compliance status
This website is partially compliant due to the non-compliances and exemptions listed below.
Preparation of this accessibility statement
An external accessibility audit was carried out, involving a simplified analysis.
The simplified audit report is available (in French, Dutch and German) on : https://scan.accessibility.belgium.be/nl/report/2023/www.fsma.be
Disproportionate burden
The FSMA publishes educational material on Wikifin School in the form of documents such as Word files. These documents do not always meet accessibility requirements. If you encounter any access problems, please contact us using our Consumer Contact fom.
Non-accessible content
A number of pages still have several technical shortcomings in terms of accessibility.
On some pages, the contrast ratio between the text (and images of text) and its background is insufficient.
 Buttons and links are not always correctly defined in some forms.
Contact details
For questions or feedback on the accessibility of our website, please contact the FSMA
FSMA
rue du Congrès 12-14
1000 Brussels
Consumer Contact form
  If you are not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Federal Ombudsman.
Proposed alternatives
Alternatives are not always available for non-accessible elements.
Improvement plan
The website provider will analyze the problems identified and draw up an improvement plan that will be assessed taking into account the cost and workload involved.
  This statement was prepared on 18/10/2023.
This statement was last reviewed on 18/10/2023.

  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-6</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular FSMA_2025_05 (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_05_fr.pdf"><u>French</u></a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_05_nl.pdf"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;only) informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</span></p>
</description>

  <title>Guidelines on stress test scenarios under the Money Market Funds Regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-stress-test-scenarios-under-money-market-funds-regulation-1</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA informs the companies concerned that it has incorporated the ESMA guidelines on stress scenarios under the Money Market Funds Regulation into its supervisory practice.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read FSMA_2025_04 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_04_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_04_fr.pdf">French</a> only); <span lang="EN-US">the ESMA guidelines are available in </span><a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/2023-12/ESMA50-43599798-9011_Final_Report_MMF_ST_Guidelines.pdf"><span lang="EN-US">English</span></a><span lang="EN-US">.</span></p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title> Advertisements with celebrities spotted on social media? Beware of fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/advertisements-celebrities-spotted-social-media-beware-fraud-0</link>
  <description>
<p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is once again drawing the public’s attention to the dangers posed by fraudulent trading platforms. These platforms lure investors online with promises of quick and easy earnings. Their offers look attractive, but often they are nothing more than sophisticated scams that can lead to significant losses.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2>How does a fraudulent trading platform work? (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_q4_schema_en.pdf">flowchart</a>)</h2><ol><li><p><strong>Modes of contact</strong></p><p>Fraudsters use various techniques to contact their targets.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>A <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/warning-can-you-get-rich-just-few-clicks">fake advertisement</a> in which a celebrity is mentioned;&nbsp;</li><li>a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-trading-platforms-how-fraudsters-obtain-your-data">website intended to 'recruit' victims</a>;</li><li>a fake profile on social media or on a dating app;</li><li>a message that you have received allegedly by accident (SMS, WhatsApp, etc.).&nbsp;</li></ul><p>In each case, the platform tries to lure investors by promising them very high returns in an extremely short time, often well beyond the sorts of gains that are actually achievable.</p></li><li><p><strong>Registration</strong></p><p>Interested investors register on the platform and deposit funds to their trading account. Generally, investors begin with a relatively small sum, such as 250 euros. Sometimes the swindlers offer to help their victims by taking over their device remotely in order to make certain transfers on their behalf, which of course allows them to download viruses or spyware.</p></li><li><p><strong>Manipulation and pressure tactics</strong></p><p>Once the funds have been deposited by the victim, the platform manipulates the transactions to give the impression that significant profits have been achieved. However, these earnings are fictitious and the funds have not really been invested. The fraudsters then put pressure on their victims to invest more money. They do so by means of repeated phone calls, time-limited offers to which investors must respond quickly, or by issuing threats.</p></li><li><p><strong>Withdrawals seem impossible</strong></p><p>To gain victims’ trust, fraudsters sometimes allow them once to withdraw a small amount. However, once an investor wishes to withdraw a larger amount, the fraudsters use various pretexts not to have to pay back any money (high costs, taxes, etc.). In the end, the fraudulent platform disappears completely, taking with it all the investors’ money.</p></li></ol></div><p><strong>The FSMA has noted that the following websites were putting consumers in contact with fraudulent trading platforms:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Gas Folex&nbsp;</strong>(https://the-nft-profit.com);</li><li><strong>Immediate Apex&nbsp;</strong>(https://bitcoin-revolution.software, https://immediate-apex.com, https://immediateapexai.com);</li><li><strong>Immediate DexAir&nbsp;</strong>(https://immediatedexair.net);</li><li><strong>Immediate GPT&nbsp;</strong>(https://immediategp.com, https://immediategp.org, https://immediate-gpt.com, https://immediategpt.org);</li><li><strong>Oil Folex&nbsp;</strong>(https://gasfolex.com);</li><li><strong>Proficator </strong>(https://proficator.com).</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to offers made by the following trading platforms:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Aevo Limited&nbsp;</strong>(https://aevo.ltd);</li><li><strong>Agile Traders&nbsp;</strong>(https://agile-traders.com);</li><li><strong>AlgosOne </strong>(https://algosone.ai);</li><li><strong>Amibit&nbsp;</strong>(https://www.amibit.cfd);</li><li><strong>Apex Trade&nbsp;</strong>(https://apex-trade.capital, https://platform.apex-trade.app);</li><li><strong>Arbitrum Invest&nbsp;</strong>(https://arbitruminvest.com);</li><li><strong>BlingXE&nbsp;</strong>(https://blingxe.com, http://blingxeglobal.com);</li><li><strong>Cexcapitals </strong>(https://cexcapitals.com);</li><li><strong>CryptoAllDay </strong>(https://cryptoallday.com);</li><li><strong>CryptoLogicIQ</strong> (https://cryptologiciq.com);</li><li><strong>Curion Finance&nbsp;</strong>(https://curion-finance.com);</li><li><strong>Deal Markets&nbsp;</strong>(http://deal-markets.com);</li><li><strong>Finflex </strong>(https://finflex.org);</li><li><strong>Global CIM</strong> (https://globalcim.com);</li><li><strong>Guru4invest&nbsp;</strong>(https://guru4invest.io, https://platform.pltf-tchg.io, https://guru4invest.com);</li><li><strong>ICL Markets&nbsp;</strong><span>(https://iclmarkets.com, http://iclmarkets1.com, http://iclmarkets3.com, http://iclmarkets5.com, http://icl-markets.com);</span></li><li><strong>Innvester </strong>(https://innvester.com);</li><li><strong>KeyWealth</strong> (https://keywealthltd.com, https://keywealthltd.net);</li><li><strong>Link-Traders </strong>(https://link-traders.com);</li><li><strong>Market Makers&nbsp;</strong>(https://marketmakers.cc, https://marketmakers.website);</li><li><strong>Pexotera</strong> (https://www.pexotera.com);</li><li><strong>Platinum Stock</strong> (https://platinum-stock.com);</li><li><strong>Private Soft Solutions&nbsp;</strong>(https://privatesoftsolutions.com);</li><li><strong>Pulse Trade&nbsp;</strong>(https://pulse-trade.io, https://webtrader.pulse-trade.ac, https://pulse-trade.cc);</li><li><strong>QuantumWins&nbsp;</strong>(https://www.quantumwins.com);</li><li><strong>RIMCgroup </strong>(https://rimcgroup.com);</li><li><strong>Robo Global Markets (Clone)&nbsp;</strong>(https://cfd.r-globalmarkets.info, https://cfd.robo-globalmarkets.net);</li><li><strong>Six Digital Markets / Six Digital Exchange (Clone)&nbsp;</strong>(https://sixdigitalexchange.com, https://sixdigitalmarkets.ai);</li><li><strong>TheProfitSupp </strong>(https://theprofitsupp.com, https://theprofitsupp.net);</li><li><strong>VT markets&nbsp;</strong>(https://www.vtmarkets.com, https://www.vtmarkets.net);</li><li><strong>Xfers Capital (Clone)&nbsp;</strong>(https://www.xfer-capital.com).</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>I’ve fallen victim. What should I do?</strong></h2><ol><li><strong>Stop making any transactions and break off all contact with the platform</strong>: don’t deposit any more money and don’t provide any additional personal or financial information. Break off all contact with the fraudsters. They may try to manipulate you in order to take even more money from you.</li><li><strong>Contact your bank</strong>: inform your bank immediately if you have made any payments to the fraudulent platform.</li><li><strong>Report the fraud to the competent authorities</strong>:&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">Contact the FSMA</a> and file a complaint with the police.</li><li><strong>Document all exchanges of data and transactions</strong>: gather all evidence of your exchanges of data with the platform, including emails, messages, account statements and screen shots of the transactions. These items will, of course, be very valuable when you report the fraud.</li><li><strong>Beware of ‘recovery rooms’</strong>: fraudsters contact victims of a previous scam and offer to help them – for a fee – recover their lost money.&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">Often this constitutes yet another attempt at fraud</a>.</li></ol><p>For more recommendations on how to avoid investment fraud, please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">‘How to recognize and avoid fraud’</a> page on the FSMA website. Please watch our awareness-raising videos as well (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/preventiefilms">Dutch</a> and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-prevention">French</a> only).</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-03-19T09:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">484236</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>10th edition of Money Week – Young people want to learn more about money</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/10th-edition-money-week-young-people-want-learn-more-about-money</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Young people between the ages of 18 and 25 would like to learn more in school about money matters. The younger generation is particularly interested in cryptocurrencies, but taxes, budgeting and investment are also at the top of their wishlist. These are findings from a large-scale study</strong><a href="https://web-bypass.fsmanet.be/nl/node/485816#_ftn1"><strong><sup>[1]</sup></strong></a><strong> among 1,000 young people aged 18-25 that the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) conducted in the framework of the tenth anniversary of Money Week. In the coming years, the FSMA will continue, via Wikifin, its financial education programme, to launch specific initiatives for this age group.</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/485816"><u>French</u></a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/485816"><u>Dutch</u></a>&nbsp;site.</p><p>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><div><hr><div><p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a> Profacts, a market research agency, conducted the research using an online questionnaire. The survey took place between 24 January and 14&nbsp; February 2025. 1,000 young people between the ages of 18 and 25 in Flanders, Wallonia and the Brussels Capital Region were surveyed.</p></div></div><p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-03-17T18:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">485816</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Record participation in the tenth edition of Money Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/record-participation-tenth-edition-money-week</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Monday, 17 March marks the beginning of the tenth edition of Money Week. This anniversary edition sets a record, with more than 170,000 pupils registered to participate. European Commissioner Maria Luís Albuquerque and Deputy Prime Ministers David Clarinval and Jan Jambon will attend the celebratory opening. On this occasion, the FMSA will present the results of its study on ‘Young people want to learn more about money’ and its future initiatives.</strong></span></p><h2><span lang="EN-GB">Record number of pupils participate</span></h2><p><span lang="EN-GB">The Belgian Money Week, which takes place this year from 17 to 21 March, is an annual thematic week organized by Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme. During Money Week, the FSMA seeks each year to provide opportunities to talk about money matters as widely as possible and to devote extra attention to the importance of financial education.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">In the course of Money Week, a total of more than <strong>170,000</strong> elementary and secondary school pupils will participate in a variety of activities. That is a <strong>record</strong>, and represents an increase of 45,000 over last year.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">In <strong>elementary schools</strong>, pupils learn by playing the successful board games ‘The ABCs of the Budget’, ‘The Budget Game’ and ‘Just’in Budget’ how to manage a budget and that one euro can be spent only once. Many FSMA staff members go into the schools during Money Week to lead one of these games in class.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">In <strong>secondary schools</strong>, pupils compete with each other in the Wikifin Quiz, which tests their knowledge of topics like budget management, saving money, means of payment, and fraud. Wikfin is launching a new online game, also for secondary school pupils, called ‘Talking Money’, in which pupils familiarize themselves in a fun way with financial concepts.</span></p><h2><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>European Commissioner Maria Luís Albuquerque and Deputy Prime Ministers David Clarinval and Jan Jambon to open the anniversary edition</strong></span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></h2><p><span lang="EN-GB">In order to lend greater visibility to the anniversary edition of Money Week, the event will have a celebratory launch on 17 March in the Wikifin Lab, the FSMA’s financial education centre in Brussels. European Commissioner for Financial Services and the Savings and Investments Union Maria Luís Albuquerque and Deputy Prime Ministers David Clarinval and Jan Jambon will open the anniversary edition. The winners of the Wikifin Challenge, a competition for secondary schools, will receive their prize personally from the Commissioner.</span></p><blockquote><p><span lang="EN-GB">Maria Luís Albuquerque, European Commissioner for Financial Services and the Savings and Investments Union: </span><em><span lang="EN-GB">“Financial literacy is a key priority of my mandate under the umbrella of the Savings and Investments Union (SIU). Drawing inspiration from good examples when designing financial literacy strategies will help us go further. In this regard, initiatives like Wikifin and Belgian Money Week stand out as positive examples, offering valuable lessons for all Member States to learn from. Knowledge is power and the key for the freedom to make informed choices about our finances.”</span></em></p></blockquote><blockquote><p><span lang="EN-GB">David Clarinval, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Employment, Economy and Agriculture: </span><em><span lang="EN-GB">“Financial education is an essential lever for a strong and balanced economy. By providing citizens with the tools to understand, anticipate, and make informed financial choices, we strengthen their autonomy and their ability to act. I welcome the initiatives that the FSMA has been undertaking for several years to raise public awareness and provide the necessary tools for responsible financial management.”</span></em></p></blockquote><blockquote><p><span lang="EN-GB">Jan Jambon, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finances and Pensions: </span><em><span lang="EN-GB">“A good understanding of savings, pension funds, investments, dividends, interest rates, profits, losses, and so on is important to protect young people, especially vulnerable ones, against the increasing risks of advertising, social media, and scams. Financial literacy is crucial for young people who have to make ends meet on a limited budget. Where wrong or risky decisions often have very serious consequences. The Arizona government's coalition agreement highlights this ambition. I look forward to working with FSMA to further improve the financial literacy of our population with initiatives such as the Belgian Money Week.”</span></em></p></blockquote><blockquote><p><span lang="EN-GB">Jean-Paul Servais, FSMA Chairman: </span><em><span lang="EN-GB">“Over the past ten years, more and more youngsters between 6 and 18 years of age have been taking part in the Money Week activities. This record edition, with more than 170,000 pupils registered, confirms that increasing numbers of teachers are making use of the Wikifin materials and that financial education is attracting ever more interest. The FSMA will, in the years to come, continue along this path and expand its pioneering work in the area of financial education, with increased attention devoted in particular to the 18-25 age group.</span></em></p></blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-03-14T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">485818</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Voluntary public takeover bid by Koinon NV on Roularta Media Group NV</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/voluntary-public-takeover-bid-koinon-nv-roularta-media-group-nv</link>
  <description>

<item>
  <title>Regular reporting by Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/regular-reporting-institutions-occupational-retirement-provision</link>
  <description>
<p>This handbook describes the reporting procedures to be used by Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision governed by Belgian law.</p><p>&nbsp;Reporting by institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) to the FSMA can be split up into two main components:</p><ul><li>first, the reports that the FSMA requests in order to fulfil its task as prudential supervisor; these reports are referred to in this handbook as the ‘prudential component’ or ‘prudential reporting’;</li><li>second, the reports that are intended to enable the FSMA and the NBB to meet their own reporting obligations to EIOPA and to the ECB respectively (under the terms of the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) and the Eurosystem); the said reporting is henceforth referred to in this handbook as the ‘European component’ or ‘European’ reporting.</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in FSMA Handbook 2025_03 (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_03_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-03/fsma_2025_03_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-03-13T14:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">485625</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title> The FSMA warns against certain companies suspected of recovery room fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-certain-companies-suspected-recovery-room-fraud-0</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The FSMA is again warning the Belgian public against certain companies suspected of recovery room fraud.&nbsp;</strong></span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Recovery room fraud is a practice whereby fraudsters offer to help&nbsp;<strong>victims of investment fraud</strong>&nbsp;to obtain compensation for their losses or to&nbsp;<strong>recover their lost assets</strong>.&nbsp;</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Generally, the fraudsters contact their victims by phone or by e-mail. The FSMA has noted, however, that victims sometimes come into contact with the so-called ‘recovery rooms’ while conducting internet searches or via social media. When introducing themselves, fraudsters and their companies pass themselves off as law firms or accountants, and sometimes as police services or financial supervisors. The fraudsters do not hesitate to misuse the identity information of existing companies or official institutions in order to appear trustworthy.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">The fraudsters charge a&nbsp;<strong>fee</strong>&nbsp;for their services. Victims of investment fraud must&nbsp;<strong>pay the fee in advance</strong>. This is a clear indication that it is a recovery room. The payment is demanded, for example, allegedly to cover certain administrative or legal costs or to pay taxes. These are purely&nbsp;<strong>fictitious costs</strong>, however.&nbsp;</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">In some other cases, fraudsters pretend to offer <strong>free&nbsp;</strong>services. The victim only has to give an access to her computer via a remote desktop application (such as Anydesk). In this way, fraudsters can install spywares on the consumers’ computers or access their PC-Bankings.&nbsp;</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Fraudsters also sometimes ask their victims to create and activate a wallet on a cryptoplatform.&nbsp;</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">In all cases, fraudsters manage to steal money from consumers. Once the fraudsters have received the fees, they disappear without a trace and it is almost impossible to recover the amounts paid. <strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers.</strong></span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</span></p><ul><li>Bunkerwallet (<span>https://bunkerwallet.io/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Financial Recovery Ltd or Financial Recovery Services LTD</span></li><li>Fiscor (https://fiscor.org/<span>)</span>&nbsp;</li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">G&amp;P Consulting or G&amp;P Consulting Group, or GNP Consulting or Goldman and Partners Consulting Group (https://gnp.consulting/ or https://gnpconsulting.cc or https://gnpconsulting.com)&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Krypton (https://krpton.bz or https://krypton.so or&nbsp;https://krypton.sx/ or https://krypton.ec/)</span></li><li>Mrkt4trd (<span>https://mrkt4trd.com)&nbsp;</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-US"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">The FSMA recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several known entities to deceive consumers. The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:</span></p><ul><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Crypto.com or Subcryptob, namely using a website “https://supcryptob.com/”</span></li><li>Payward LTD</li><li>Refundee</li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB">The fraudsters also impersonate <strong>public or control authorities</strong> in order&nbsp;</span><span lang="EN-US">to give consumers the impression that they are legitimate</span><span lang="EN-GB">: either they pretend to be those official bodies; either they pretend to collaborate with them.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">***</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">Victims of investment fraud are often targeted twice by the same fraudsters: first the latter perpetrate investment fraud, and thereafter, recovery room fraud. The persons behind the investment fraud may also sell their victims’ contact information on to other fraudsters.&nbsp;<strong>Anyone who has ever been a victim of investment fraud needs to be aware that fraudsters may target their victims again or sell their personal data on to others.</strong></span></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h3><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>How can you recognize and avoid recovery room fraud?</strong></span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"></span></strong></h3><ul><li><span lang="EN-GB">If you have been a victim of investment fraud, we advise you always to&nbsp;<strong>file a complaint</strong>&nbsp;with the local police.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB">Be extremely careful if you find an advertisement on&nbsp;<strong>social media or the internet</strong>, which offers to recover funds you have lost.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB">If you receive&nbsp;<strong>unsolicited phone calls&nbsp;with an offer</strong> to recover funds you have lost, be sure to ask how that person found out that you have lost money. Reports of fraud are shared only with the judicial authorities and not with private companies.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB">If you are asked to&nbsp;<strong>pay a set fee in advance</strong>, <strong>to access your computer or to activate a wallet on a cryptoplatform</strong>, don’t respond but terminate all contact.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Financial supervisors&nbsp;</strong>such as the FSMA are not authorized to recover lost money and would therefore not take the initiative to contact victims of investment fraud.</span></li></ul><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span lang="EN-GB">search function</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud"><span lang="EN-GB">consumer contact form</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-03-13T09:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">484237</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>AMLCO Newsletter: Fighting money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/amlco-newsletter-fighting-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-amlcft</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In this first AMLCO newsletter of 2025, the FSMA is focusing on the third edition of its AMLCO Day. This took place virtually &nbsp;on 11 December 2024 and took the ‘AML Package’ as its central topic. The FSMA is delighted at the success of the third edition. More than 2300 people attended the webinar.</strong></p><p>During the event, the FSMA drew the attention of all AMLCOs to the principal changes in the new regulatory texts as regards the obligations applicable to their entities for the struggle against money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT). The FSMA also enjoyed the collaboration of the National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Belgian Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CTIF-CFI). The NBB focused on the functioning and competencies of the future European Authority for Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism (AMLA). The CTIF-CFI addressed the impact of the new texts on financial intelligence processing units.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-02/2025-02-07_newsletter_amlco_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-02/2025-02-07_newsletter_amlco_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-02-07T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">478626</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Fraudsters usurp the name of the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudsters-usurp-name-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA)&nbsp;warns the public against the activities of scammers who usurp the name and the logo of the&nbsp;FSMA and other financial supervisors to mislead consumers. This is a well-known fraud technique, for which ESMA also published a&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/investor-corner/frauds-and-scams#:~:text=Fraudsters%20often%20use%20ESMA&amp;apos;s%20name,attempt%20to%20copy%20ESMA&amp;apos;s%20website."><strong>warning</strong></a><strong>.</strong></p><p>Fraudsters claim that the FSMA can help victims of investment fraud to recover or unblock the money they lost. For this service, the fraudsters ask the victims for compensation or for the payment of a tax to the FSMA.&nbsp;In some cases, the scammers even claim that fraud victims would have to pay a fine to the FSMA.&nbsp;This form of fraud is called&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">recovery room fraud</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>In particular, consumers are often contacted by <strong>Protectionline</strong>, a phantom company operating through the website https://protectionline.net/. This company contacts victims of investment fraud and claims it can help them recover lost funds. To this end, the victim must submit a claim for compensation to be supposedly approved by the FSMA. The victim is then redirected to websites that look exactly like the FSMA website: <strong>https://regulatory-legal.systems/, https://regulatory-payout.systems/&nbsp;</strong>and <strong>https://regulatory-transfer.systems/</strong>. These websites are <strong>completely fake and have no connection with the FSMA</strong>. The URL of the FSMA’s official website is <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>www.fsma.be</strong></a>.</p><p>The FSMA also noticed that its logo is sometimes added to fraudulent websites to give the impression that a given entity is authorized by the FSMA to offer financial services.</p><p>The scammers use the following websites and email addresses:&nbsp;</p><ul><li><strong>datapotection@fsma-sup.cc</strong></li><li><strong>fsma1@europe.com</strong></li><li><strong>fsma@service-inf.com</strong></li><li><strong>info@monetarydemands.site</strong></li><li><strong>r.keppler@fsma-financial.com</strong></li><li><strong>support@fsma-regulatory.net</strong></li></ul><p><strong>Emails from these or similar addresses are fraudulent</strong>. Do not respond to such emails but delete them. The emails do not come from the FSMA. The official email addresses of the FSMA always end with <strong>@fsma.be</strong>.</p><div class="box box-info"><p><strong>The FSMA will never contact you out of the blue or ask you to transfer money. Nor will it ever ask you for confidential information such as the PIN code of your bank card or a password.&nbsp;</strong></p></div><p><strong>Consumers who receive unsolicited emails must be extremely careful.</strong> Be sure not to respond to any requests to transfer money for (financial) services or products that the FSMA is said to offer.</p><p><strong>The FSMA is not competent to recover lost investments&nbsp;</strong>or to ask for payment for any such a service. Nor is it competent to demand payment for taxes. It will never contact investors in this regard. The FSMA will also never ask consumers to provide their financial information or to pay for any services.</p>
<div class="box box-tip"><h2>Any doubts about the person who has contacted you? Check the information about the FSMA here.</h2><h3>These are the official contact details for the FSMA:</h3><ul><li>Website: <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">www.fsma.be</a></li><li>Adress: <span>Rue du Congrès/Congresstraat 12-14, 1000 Brussels</span></li><li>Company number: 0544.279.965</li><li>Our phone numbers always begin with +32 (0)2 220 XX XX.&nbsp;</li><li>Our emails end with @fsma.be.&nbsp;</li></ul><h3>These are the FSMA’s official social media addresses:</h3><ul><li>LinkedIn:&nbsp;<a href="https://be.linkedin.com/company/fsma">linkedin.com/company/fsma</a></li><li>X (Twitter):&nbsp;<a href="https://twitter.com/FSMA_info">twitter.com/FSMA_info</a>&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">contact form</a>.</p></div></description>
  <pubDate>2025-02-03T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">476646</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>In need of quick cash? Be cautious</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/need-quick-cash-be-cautious</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-US"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></span><span lang="EN-US"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-US">The FSMA <strong>has identified 18 new fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer fake credit to Belgian consumers via the internet. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.) or find advertisements <strong>online</strong>.&nbsp;</span><span lang="EN-GB">Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions.&nbsp;In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>cloned firm</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB">’ fraud.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</span></p><ul><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE"><strong>Beauliard Groupe</strong> (www.beauliard-groupe.com); &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>BS Kredit&nbsp;</strong>(www.best-servicekredit.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Cash Lening</strong> (www.cashlening.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Finance Antalex</strong> (www.finance.antalex.net);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE"><strong>Finaura</strong> (www.finaura-group.com);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Kredit Inter</strong> (www.kredit-inter.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Laverdiesten</strong> (www.laverdiesten.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span><strong>Lening Plus Krediet</strong> (www.leningplus.com);</span></li><li><span><strong>LF Krediet Snel Groep</strong> (www.lfkredietsnelgroep.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Neovixunion</strong> (www.neovixunion.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span><strong>Pirabk financieringsmaatschappij</strong> (www.pirabk.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE"><strong>Plus Finanzen</strong> (www.plusfinanzen.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE"><strong>Pret Collaboratif</strong> (www.prtcorporatif.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span><strong>Snel Financiering financieringsmaatschappij</strong> (www.snelfinanciering.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Snellening</strong> (www.snellening.be);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE"><strong>Solidariteit Dienst Financien</strong> (www.solidariteit-dienstfinancien.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Swift Fundings</strong> (www.swiftfundings.com);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span><strong>Universum Krediet</strong> (www.universumkredit.com).&nbsp;</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-US">***</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><span>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></h2><ul><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span lang="EN-US"><strong>search function</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-US">&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person.&nbsp;</span><span lang="EN-GB">But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB"> on its website. As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</span></p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-31T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">476909</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: The FSMA warns the public against Derwent Investments (https://derwentinv.com/)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-derwent-investments-httpsderwentinvcom</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of Derwent Investments, a company engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>Derwent Investments&nbsp;is <strong>not an authorized&nbsp;</strong>investment firm in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in Belgium.</p><p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by&nbsp;Derwent Investments and <strong>against transferring money</strong> to any account number it might mention.</p><p>Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>.</p><p><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong>&nbsp;is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p><p>Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p><p>As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p><p>The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term "boiler room"), insisting that they keep making further payments.&nbsp;<strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p><p>More information on this form of fraud is available in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-new-unauthorized-activities">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 11 December 2024.</p><p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-29T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">476711</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing – Observations coming out of inspections of currency exchange offices</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-observations-coming-out-inspections</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA conducted inspections of 8 currency exchange offices registered in Belgium, in order to verify compliance with the legislation to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing (“ML/FT”). The inspections covered the entire Belgian sector of currency exchange offices.</strong></p><p>The ensuing report sets out the main elements of the applicable legal framework, goes into the most significant observations made by the FSMA and emphasizes good practices that contribute to compliance with the preventive ML/FT legislation.</p><div class="box box-small box-info"><p>Read the observations (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2025_constats_bureauxdechange_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2025_vaststellingen_wisselkantoren_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-24T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">475959</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches a quarterly dashboard with key figures on the activity of Belgian retail investors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-quarterly-dashboard-key-figures-activity-belgian-retail-investors</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has published the first edition of the quarterly </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2024_q3_retail_investor_dashboard.pdf"><strong>FSMA Retail Investor Dashboard</strong></a><strong>, with key figures on equity trading, ETF trading and bond trading by Belgian retail investors at entities under FSMA supervision.</strong></p><p>As of early 2018, the FSMA has been receiving information on transactions in financial instruments in the context of the European MiFIR Regulation. Following upon previous studies on the behaviour of Belgian investors, the FSMA is now launching the first edition of the FSMA Retail Investor Dashboard. This new publication, which will be released every three months, is part of the FSMA's ongoing monitoring of the developments on financial markets. The dashboard begins with a number of fixed core charts&nbsp;(which will be updated with each periodic publication), followed by a variable section with changing content. The first edition contains data up to and including the third quarter of 2024.</p><h2><strong>Growing investor interest in the first half of 2024</strong></h2><p>In the first half of 2024, there were more active equity investors and ETF investors than in 2023. In the second quarter of 2024, around 170,000 Belgian investors traded listed shares, a 15% increase compared to the same period in 2023. The number of ETF investors also increased significantly: a record high 57,000 Belgian investors traded ETFs, a number almost double that of the second quarter of 2023.&nbsp;By contrast, about 21,000 Belgian investors traded bonds, which represents a decrease of 30% compared to the second quarter of 2023.</p><h2><strong>Followed by a slowdown in investor activity in the third quarter of 2024</strong></h2><p>In the third quarter of 2024, the number of active equity investors decreased to approximately 142,000, a decline of more than 15% compared to the previous quarter. The number of ETF investors remained stable. During that quarter, 14,000, 12,000, and 4,000 Belgian investors traded for the first time in listed shares, ETFs or bonds respectively. Compared to the same period in 2023, this represents a stabilization for equities, a sharp increase for new ETF investors and a strong decrease for bonds.</p><p>In the third quarter of 2024, Belgian retail investors, as a group, remained net buyers of stock, ETFs and bonds: for each of these three types of financial instruments, there were more buy transactions than sell transactions. In total, Belgian retail investors carried out around 1,060,000 stock transactions in the third quarter of 2024. This group also carried out about 166,000 ETF transactions and almost 30,000 bond transactions. There are significantly higher transaction numbers for stocks, despite the clearly increasing success of ETFs. Since the beginning of 2024, approximately 50% more ETF transactions have been carried out each quarter compared to the end of 2023. By contrast, investing in individual bonds seems to have peaked: since the beginning of 2024, bond transaction numbers fell by about 30% on a quarterly basis compared to the last quarter of 2023.</p><h2><strong>Median transaction value highest for bonds</strong></h2><p>The FSMA strives to conclude each edition of the FSMA Retail Investor Dashboard with an editorial section that looks in greater detail at a specific target group, trend or development. This gives the FSMA the opportunity to cover a current topic or inform the public about a broader subject. The focus in the first edition indicates that the median transaction value of a stock order is about 1,500 euros, compared to 1,100 - 1,300 euros for a typical ETF transaction and 10,000 to 13,000 euros for a typical bond transaction. The average bond investor is in his or her sixties, the average stock investor&nbsp;in his or her fifties and the average ETF investor&nbsp;in his or her forties. Over time, the age gap between stock and ETF investors in particular has increased, due mostly to a sharp decline in the average age of ETF investors.</p><blockquote><p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, commented: “The new FSMA Retail Investor Dashboard demonstrates the FSMA’s ability to apply advanced data analysis techniques to big data, thus publishing key figures that provide the market with a clear overview of stock, ETF and bond trading.”</p></blockquote><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Find out more about this in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2024_q3_retail_investor_dashboard.pdf">dashboard</a> and in our videos (short version (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/1049293188">French</a> - <a href="https://vimeo.com/1049290308">Dutch</a> only) and full video (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/1049285538">French - Dutch</a> only)).</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-23T08:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">473265</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Details regarding the submission of registers of ICT third-party service providers and of reports on major ICT-related incidents</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/details-regarding-submission-registers-ict-third-party-service-providers-and-reports-major-ict</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) for the financial sector officially took effect on 17 January 2025.</strong></span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has taken this opportunity to issue a publication detailing the obligations of financial entities to <strong>maintain information registers</strong> of their ICT third-party service providers and to <strong>report on major ICT-related incidents</strong>.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">The FSMA’s publication sets out in detail the scope of the Regulation and the specific rules for complying with those obligations.</span></p><p><span>This news article is not available in English. Please consult the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/news/precisions-sur-la-collecte-du-registre-dinformations-sur-les-prestataires-tiers-et-sur-les"><span lang="EN-US"><u>French</u></span></a><span lang="EN-US"> or</span><span> </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/news/nadere-toelichting-bij-het-opvragen-van-het-informatieregister-over-derde-dienstaanbieders-en"><span lang="EN-US"><u>Dutch</u></span></a><span lang="EN-US"> site.</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-21T14:40:35+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">475512</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA publishes update on costs in the second and third pillar pensions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-update-costs-second-and-third-pillar-pensions</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has today published an update to its report on costs in the second and third pillar pensions (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/etudecouts_2022_2_3pillier.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/kostenrapport_2022_2_3pijler.pdf">Dutch</a> only). The new data indicate that the costs charged by financial institution for pension products have generally remained stable. Reporting on costs enables the FSMA to identify the insurance products with the highest costs. The legislation and regulations in this area require insurance companies to offer products that provide consumers with sufficient ‘value for money’. The FSMA has therefore started to examine the practices of insurance companies that offer the most expensive pension products. High costs have a significant impact on the return on the product, and thus require particular attention.</p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/470869"><u>French</u></a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/470869"><span><u>Dutch</u></span></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-20T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">470869</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Results of the second survey on the entry into force of the DORA Regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/results-second-survey-entry-force-dora-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p>In November 2024, the FSMA conducted a second survey to determine how prepared financial entities are for the application of the EU regulation known as DORA (Digital Operational Resilience Act), which begins on 17 January 2025. The DORA Regulation sets ambitious objectives in the area of digital operational resilience. The aim of the Regulation is to protect financial entities and their clients.</p><p>The results of the survey indicate that many financial entities are on the right track to meet the objectives laid down in DORA, but still need to make significant efforts to be fully in compliance with this Regulation.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip">Read more in Communication FSMA_2025_01 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/fsma_2025_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/fsma_2025_01_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-17T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">474694</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Half-yearly dashboard on investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/half-yearly-dashboard-investment-fraud-1</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="GSW-FR"><strong>One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. It publishes a </strong></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/20250116_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf"><span lang="GSW-FR"><strong>dashboard</strong></span></a><span lang="GSW-FR"><strong> that provides statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it is publishing the&nbsp;dashboard&nbsp;for the second semester of 2024, which will also include the figures for the whole year 2024.</strong></span></p><p><span lang="GSW-FR">This edition of the dashboard focuses notably on the following items:</span></p><p><span lang="GSW-FR">For the second semester:</span></p><ul><li><span lang="GSW-FR"></span><span lang="GSW-FR">Consumers’ reports concerning cryptocurrency scams or fraudulent trading platforms account once again for <strong>about half</strong>&nbsp;of the reports with regard to fraud handled by the FSMA.&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="GSW-FR"></span><span lang="GSW-FR">Between July and December 2024 Belgian consumers reported having collectively lost <strong>15,904,356.38 euros</strong> due to fraud.</span></li></ul><p><span lang="GSW-FR">For the whole year:</span></p><ul><li><span lang="GSW-FR"></span><span lang="GSW-FR">In 2024, the FSMA received a total of&nbsp;<strong>2621</strong>&nbsp;reports regarding unauthorized activities, a 20%&nbsp;increase&nbsp;from 2023.</span></li><li><span lang="GSW-FR"></span><span lang="GSW-FR">Throughout 2024, the FSMA published a total of 16 warnings regarding a total of 297 fraudulent entities and 396 websites.</span></li></ul><p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/20250116_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf"><span lang="EN-GB">The&nbsp;dashboard&nbsp;is available on the website of the FSMA.</span></a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-16T10:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">473034</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA assists the sector as the banker’s oath enters into force</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-assists-sector-bankers-oath-enters-force</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 15 January 2025, the banker’s oath enters into force for the fit &amp; proper persons and the executives responsible for managing banks. On this occasion, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is publishing an explanatory video and opening the registration platform for the oaths that are to be sworn at its premises.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/473266"><u>French</u></a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/473266"><u>Dutch</u></a>&nbsp;site.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-15T11:49:01+01:00</pubDate>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Asset management and NBFI are important components of the future European Savings and Investment Union (SIU). The NBB and the FSMA closely monitor the risks associated with these activities in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/asset-management-and-nbfi-are-important-components-future-european-savings-and-investment</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) today published an&nbsp;update of their report&nbsp;on</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2025_update_assetmanagement.pdf"><strong> asset management and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium</strong></a><strong>. The NBB and the FSMA consider that the risks associated with these activities in Belgium are currently limited. However, a number of events and incidents in other countries point to vulnerabilities that need to be addressed. International organisations such as the FSB and IOSCO have published recommendations and policy proposals to that end. A further follow-up of this work is essential, also in light of the further development of the European Savings and Investment Union.</strong></p><p>In 2017, the FSMA and the NBB published a first comprehensive report on asset management and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium.&nbsp;The fifth update of this report, which includes recent figures and an analysis of major national and international developments, is now available.&nbsp;</p><p>The main objective of this joint report is to keep a finger on the pulse, paying particular attention to the risks associated with these activities and their interconnectedness with other sectors.</p><h2><strong>A risk-based approach to delineate the NBFI sector</strong></h2><p>'Non-bank financial intermediation' or 'NBFI' may refer to a very diverse set of entities and activities outside the banking system. In a broad context, NBFI may refer to entities such as insurance companies, pension funds, investment funds and central counterparties, as well as to less or non‑regulated entities such as family offices.&nbsp;</p><p>In this report, the NBB and the FSMA adopt a risk-based approach to delineate the NBFI. The focus is on a narrower subset of NBFI: entities involved in credit intermediation activities that may pose bank-like financial stability risks, notably because they use leverage or are involved in liquidity transformation. Several methods can be used to narrow down the sector and estimate its size. According to the method proposed by the FSB, the sector amounted to €172 billion in assets at the end of 2023.&nbsp;</p><p>Furthermore, the report pays specific attention to asset management. 'Asset management' refers to the segment of the financial industry that is involved in the management of financial assets on behalf of investors. The focus is on collective management through investment funds, although asset management may also comprise the discretionary management of an individual investor’s portfolio. At the end of 2023, Belgian investment funds accounted for €215 billion in net assets, while Belgian asset managers had roughly €208 billion in assets under management.</p><h2><strong>Developing of the European Savings and Investments Union (SIU)</strong></h2><p>A well-developed, diversified and resilient financial sector is vital to ensure stable financing of the real economy and to meet the needs of savers and investors. For companies, governments and households, financial intermediation outside the banking system may provide a source of funding that is a valuable alternative to credit supply by banks. At the same time, it offers them broader investment opportunities.&nbsp;</p><p>Strengthening the single market is high on the agenda today to help meet the financing needs of the European economy within the context of geo-economic developments and climate change. The development of the European Savings and Investments Union&nbsp;(SIU) may lead to the transfer of savings from bank accounts to long term investments in capital markets.</p><p>These developments reinforce the importance of financial stability and consumer protection in the NBFI sector.</p><h2><strong>Size of the sector limited compared to other developed countries&nbsp;</strong></h2><p>At the end of last year, the FSB also published its <a href="https://www.fsb.org/2024/12/global-monitoring-report-on-non-bank-financial-intermediation-2024/">annual report on non-bank financial intermediation</a>. According to FSB estimates, the size of the global NBFI sector reached $70.2&nbsp;trillion.</p><p>Compared to other countries, the size and importance of the Belgian non‑bank financial intermediation sector is limited. The sector accounts for less than 0.5% of the global aggregate and around 1% of the total for EU countries. Whereas the sector accounts for 98% of GDP in other developed economies, the estimate of €172 billion in assets in Belgium accounts for only 29% of GDP.</p><p>These are mainly assets held by investment funds that do not qualify as equity funds. The vast majority of these funds are subject to supervision by the Belgian authorities.</p><p>The relatively limited size of the non-bank financial intermediation sector in Belgium confirms that credit intermediation is still dominated by banks. It also reflects a relatively strong interconnectedness of Belgian entities with non-bank financial intermediation outside Belgium, particularly in other European countries.</p><h2><strong>International cooperation is crucial</strong></h2><p>A number of events and incidents in other countries, such as the failure of the Archegos family office in 2021 and the tensions in the British gilt market in 2022, have provided evidence of vulnerabilities in the NBFI sector. Most of these relate to liquidity, the use of leverage and interconnectedness within the financial system.&nbsp;</p><p>To identify and address vulnerabilities, and thus promote financial stability, international organizations such as the FSB and the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) developed a comprehensive work programme. They have already published recommendations and policy proposals in this respect.&nbsp;</p><p>In Europe, the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) carried out analytical and policy work on NBFI while the European Commission launched a targeted consultation to seek views on the macroprudential framework for NBFI.</p><p>In Belgium, the NBB and the FSMA did not identify material risks arising from the size and nature of non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium or from the interconnectedness of Belgian entities with NBFI entities outside Belgium, but they do highlight the importance of the European and international regulatory framework to safeguard financial stability.</p><p>The NBB and the FSMA therefore continue to actively participate in international work to gain a better view of European and global developments in the NBFI sector and, where necessary, to strengthen the regulatory framework.</p><blockquote><p><em>NBB Governor Pierre Wunsch: 'The NBB-FSMA report confirms that the Belgian asset management and non-bank financial intermediation market can be considered fundamentally sound. The sector remains thus well‑armed to face a challenging environment and provides a solid foundation to help enable the envisioned strengthening of the future European Savings and Investment Union. This solid starting position must be maintained in order to secure the crucial role of this sector in financial intermediation in Belgium also in the future.&nbsp; Given the rapid developments in this sector, supervisory authorities must therefore remain vigilant.&nbsp;Regular updates to the published analysis will continue to form part of this continuous monitoring.'</em></p></blockquote><blockquote><p><em>FSMA and IOSCO Chair Jean-Paul Servais: 'This initiative demonstrates that good cooperation between authorities, at both national and international level, is essential. We observe that different regulators often face similar problems. This is why the National Bank and the FSMA have been proactively working together for several years to identify risks in the non-banking sector. This cooperation was also much appreciated by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) when it conducted its Financial Sector Assessment Program (FSAP) in Belgium in 2023. We are also taking a leading role internationally. Financial markets have no borders, nor do risks. Under my chairmanship, the cooperation between the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) and the Financial Stability Board (FSB) has grown into a true partnership. In this regard, we have published new international recommendations aimed at substantially strengthening liquidity risk management of investment funds.'</em></p></blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2025-01-13T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">473035</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Advice of the FSMA on two bills</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/advice-fsma-two-bills</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="GSW-FR">On 27 November 2024, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received a request from the&nbsp;Commission on Finances and Budget of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives&nbsp;to&nbsp;give an advice about two bills with a view to&nbsp;amend, respectively, the legislation aimed at introducing a basic exemption for income from savings and investments, and the&nbsp;Income Tax Code 1992 (ITC 1992)&nbsp;with regard to the introduction of a general basic exemption for income from&nbsp;movable goods and capital.&nbsp;</span></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p><span lang="GSW-FR">The full text of this advice is available on the FSMA website (in </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2025-01-09_advies_basisvrijstelling.pdf"><span lang="GSW-FR">Dutch</span></a><span lang="GSW-FR"> and </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2025-01/2025-01-09_avis_exonerationdebase.pdf"><span lang="GSW-FR">French</span></a><span lang="GSW-FR"> only).</span></p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>ESMA consults on proposals to digitalise sustainability and financial disclosures</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/esma-consults-proposals-digitalise-sustainability-and-financial-disclosures</link>
  <description>
<p>The Consultation Paper includes proposals for:</p><ul><li>&nbsp;Defining the marking up rules for sustainability reporting; with a phased implementation for ESRS sustainability statements in three steps, each lasting two years, and a full implementation for Article 8 disclosures; and</li><li>Redefining the marking up approach for the Notes to the IFRS consolidated financial statements.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>The Consultation Paper also proposes amendments to the Regulatory Technical Standards on the European Electronic Access Point.&nbsp;</p><p>Interested stakeholders are invited to submit their feedback <strong>by 31 March 2025</strong>.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/consultations/consultation-esef-rts-sustainability-reporting-and-amendments-eeap-rts">Read more ...</a></div>
</description>
