    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of investment offers presented as an alternative to traditional savings products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-investment-offers-presented-alternative-traditional-savings-products</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Belgian public is once again being approached by companies offering so-called investments in various assets. These offers are often made with the promise of very high returns. Remain vigilant, however, because swindlers often lie behind these tempting offers.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Victims reported to the FSMA that they had received investment offers (notably in<strong>&nbsp;</strong>precious metals and cryptocurrencies) presented as an alternative to traditional savings products, with promises of very high yields. Behind these tempting offers, however, often lie crooks whose sole aim is to steal your savings<strong>.</strong></p><p>Scam victims are often contacted by phone and email. Most of the time, the contacts follow on advertisements that appear on the internet, and in particular on social media and fake news sites.</p><p>Always remain vigilant if you are invited to invest in alternatives to traditional savings products. These investment offers may fall within the scope of the financial legislation that the FSMA is tasked with enforcing. They may thus not be offered to the public under just any conditions!</p><p><strong>In the course of the past few weeks, the FSMA has received reports about:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Estoque Invest (estoque-invest.com)</strong></li><li><strong>Ezio Capital (https://eziocapital.com/)</strong></li></ul><p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p><p>The FSMA thus <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial service made by the companies listed above and against transferring money</strong> to any bank account number they might mention.&nbsp;</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</h2><ul><li><strong>always check the identity of the company</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.). If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</li><li><strong>always verify&nbsp;if the company in question has the requisite authorization</strong>. To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘cloned firms’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</li></ul><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to <strong>file a complaint with the&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://www.police.be/en/"><strong>local police</strong></a><strong> or with the judicial authorities</strong>.</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-12-19T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">467062</guid>
    </item>

  <description>

  <description>
<p>The FSMA sent out a newsletter to intermediaries and credit providers on 17 December, reminding them of the report they are required to submit on the continuing professional education they completed in 2024. Intermediaries and credit providers are expected to submit their report at the latest by 31 March 2025, in their registration file in Cabrio. This functionality will be available in Cabrio as from 1 January 2025.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><ul><li>Read more in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-12/2024-12-17_newsletter_rapporteringbijscholing_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-12/2024-12-17_newsletter_reportingrecyclage_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</li><li>Consult our FAQ (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-12/faq_bijscholing_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-12/faq_recyclage_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</li></ul></div>

<item>
  <title>Institutions for occupational retirement provision: overview 2023</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/institutions-occupational-retirement-provision-overview-2023</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The overall balance sheet total of Belgian institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) increased last year by 13 per cent. This is the conclusion of the annual statistical overview prepared by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p><p>The FSMA is responsible for the supervision of IORPs, also known as pension funds. Every year, it publishes a summary of statistics regarding IORPs. The fourteenth edition of that statistical overview is now available.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>The most important elements of the overview are as follows:</p><ol><li>At the end of 2023, Belgium had 150 IORPs governed by Belgian law, compared to 159 pension funds in 2022.</li><li>Meanwhile, the number of members in IORPs rose by more than four per cent to 2.53 million.</li><li><p>The balance sheet total of all IORPs at the end of last year was 45.8 billion euros, a 13 per cent increase compared to the previous year. This increase came mainly due to the revival of financial markets after the poor performance as a result of the events in Ukraine and the resulting energy crisis in 2022.</p><figure class="media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/graph-1-evolution-2023_0.PNG?itok=Sc8iTWYB" width="808" height="458" alt="Graph 1: changes in balance sheet total" title="Graph 1: changes in balance sheet total" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</li><li><p>Belgian IORPs invested a little more than three-quarters of their assets in undertakings for collective investment (UCIs), mostly in share and bond funds. Taking into account the underlying assets of these UCIs, IORPs invested, directly and indirectly, 49 per cent in bonds and 41 per cent in shares. The return on all investments at the end of 2023 stood at 8.9 per cent.</p><figure class="media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/graph-2a-2b-overview2023.PNG?itok=dWZBVlnj" width="789" height="438" alt="Chart 2a: direct investments - Chart 2b: indirect investments (with breakdown of UCI) " title="Chart 2a: direct investments - Chart 2b: indirect investments (with breakdown of UCI) " class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
<p>We refer to the press release '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/annual-sectoral-overview-supplementary-pensions-0">Annual sectoral overview on supplementary pensions</a>' for additional information on the second pillar (which includes all Belgian supplementary pensions managed by insurers and pension funds).</p></li><li>At the end of 2023, the average coverage level was 119 per cent. It increased compared to 2022, mainly as a result of positive asset returns.&nbsp;<br><br>The coverage level indicates the volume of assets a pension fund has available to meet all its obligations. So, this represents a buffer of 19% compared to the conservative estimation of the liabilities.</li></ol><p>In addition to the 2023 overview, the annual financial statements and some additional statistics at sectoral level are available on the FSMA’s website (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/statistiques-des-operations-des-institutions-de-retraite-professionnelle"><span lang="EN-GB">French</span></a><span lang="EN-GB"> –&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/statistieken-van-de-verrichtingen-van-de-instellingen-voor-bedrijfspensioenvoorziening"><span lang="EN-GB">Dutch</span></a><span lang="EN-GB"> only).</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-12-12T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">465334</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Boiler rooms: The FSMA warns the public against new unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-new-unauthorized-activities</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>The companies are the following:</p><ul><li><strong>Bradford Venture Capital</strong> (https://www.bradfordventurecapital.com/)<u>&nbsp;</u></li><li><strong>KW Capital Group&nbsp;</strong>(www.kwcapitalgroup.com)&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Lamarck Group</strong> (https://www.lamarckgroup.com/)</li><li><strong>Millers Capital Investments</strong> (https://www.millers-capital.com/)&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Silverman Advisory Group&nbsp;</strong>(https://silvermanadvisorygroup.com/)</li><li><strong>Sis Capital Partners&nbsp;</strong>(https://www.siscp.com/)</li><li><strong>Union Wealth Management&nbsp;</strong>(www.unionwealthmanagement.com)</li></ul><p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p><p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services&nbsp;</strong>made by the companies listed above<strong>&nbsp;</strong>and<strong> against transferring money&nbsp;</strong>to any account number they might mention.</p><p>Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be “<strong>boiler rooms</strong>”.</p><p><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p><p>Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p><p>As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments.&nbsp;But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p><p>The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term "boiler room"), insisting that they keep making further payments.&nbsp;<strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2>In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations:</h2><ul><li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company&nbsp;</strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li><li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website –&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li><li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company&nbsp;offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.<br><br>On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the “<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>” published on the FSMA website.<br><br><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</li><li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li><li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li><li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li><li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li><li><strong>Be wary as well of "cloned firms"</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li><li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li><li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li><li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li></ul><p>If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-12-11T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">464208</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter for insurance intermediaries: Rules on sustainable finance for insurance intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-insurance-intermediaries-rules-sustainable-finance-insurance-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<h3>How is sustainability incorporated into insurance distribution by insurance intermediaries?</h3><p>Objectives of this newsletter</p><ul type="disc"><li>Assist insurance intermediaries in conducting their own analysis of the rules so as to determine its specific impact on their company.</li><li>Guide insurance intermediaries through the most important (delegated) regulations that contain sustainability rules that apply to them.</li></ul><p>Sustainability is incorporated into insurance distribution at three different levels.<br><br>The newsletter has an annex for each of the three levels of insurance distribution to which sustainability rules apply. These annexes are intended to help insurance intermediaries analyse their activities and determine which provisions apply to them.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>The full newsletter is available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-12/2024-12_nieuwsbrief_duurzame_financiering_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-12/2024-12_nieuwsbrief_finance_durable_fr.pdf">French</a> only.</p></div>
</description>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">463339</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter for intermediaries: Identity theft from Belgian intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-intermediaries-identity-theft-belgian-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The FSMA has received information in recent months about identity theft from Belgian intermediaries. English-speaking fraudsters are wrongfully using their names to trick consumers.</strong></span><br><br>The fraudsters usurp the name and other legal information of Belgian intermediaries. In most cases, the swindlers use a website with an internet address that gives the name and contact information of the intermediary in question.&nbsp;<br><br>The <span lang="EN-GB">FSMA knows of several cases of this form of fraud, in which the identity of legally registered intermediaries is stolen.</span></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-11/2024-11-28_newsletter_clonedfirms_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-11/2024-11-28_newsletter_clonedfirms_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-28T08:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">459651</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Identity theft from Belgian intermediaries: beware of fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/identity-theft-belgian-intermediaries-beware-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In the past few months, the FSMA has once again observed several cases of theft of the identity of Belgian insurance intermediaries by English-speaking fraudsters. The swindlers wrongfully use the registration of such intermediaries in the registers of the FSMA to gain consumers’ trust.</strong></p><p>Fraudsters usurp the names of insurance intermediaries that are registered with the FSMA, in order to make it seem as if they were authorized by the FSMA.</p><p>They fraudulently use the name and other legally required information of authorized companies. In order to convince you that they are duly authorized, they often refer to the FSMA’s official website. You will thus be tricked into thinking that you are dealing with a regulated company, whereas in fact this is a fraudster who has stolen the said company’s identity.</p><p>In most cases, the fraudsters create a website with a web address that corresponds to the name of the intermediary whose identity they have stolen.</p><h2><strong>What services do these fraudulent entities offer?</strong></h2><p>The FSMA distinguishes between two situations:</p><ul><li>The fraudsters contact consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, and offer them investments in shares or bonds. To this end, they use a professional-looking, English language website. But these are purely fictitious financial instruments.</li><li>The fraudsters contact victims of a previous investment fraud, offering to help them recover their lost investment. But in order for the victim to receive the promised assistance, he or she must first pay a fee. This is <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">recovery room fraud</a>.&nbsp;</li></ul><h2><strong>What do insurance intermediaries do?</strong></h2><p>Insurance intermediaries offer various services related to insurance, such as providing advice on insurance contracts, proposing and concluding insurance contracts, or helping manage and implement insurance contracts.</p><h2><strong>Do you have any doubts about the company that has contacted you?</strong></h2><p>This fraudulent practice may be difficult to detect and avoid. We therefore encourage you to take the following steps to ensure that your contact person is indeed who he or she claims to be:</p><ul><li>Be critical if you receive an <strong>unsolicited investment offer</strong> via social media or by phone, especially if you are being promised <strong>exorbitant returns</strong>. If a return seems too good to be true, it usually is! Ask<strong>&nbsp;</strong>your counterparty for<strong> clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest in a product if you do not fully understand what precisely is being offered.</li><li>Use a search engine to determine whether the <strong>authorized company has its own website</strong>.<br><br><strong>Beware!</strong>&nbsp;Swindlers often use an internet address that closely resembles that of the official website of the company whose identity they have stolen. For example, a slash may be added to the address, a different extension may be used (.com instead of .be), or <strong>the identity is stolen from an intermediary that does not have a website</strong>.</li><li><strong>Compare the information provided by your contact person with the registered intermediary’s official information.</strong> You can do so by consulting <a>the&nbsp;</a><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/search?s=">FSMA’s register</a> &nbsp;or the Belgian&nbsp;<a href="https://kbopub.economie.fgov.be/kbopub/zoeknummerform.html?lang=en">Crossroads Bank for Enterprises</a>.&nbsp;<br><br>For example, if your contact person claims to work for a company based in Belgium but is contacting you from a foreign phone number, this should serve as a warning sign. Similarly, you should be wary if the company’s website is in English <strong>only</strong>, although the company claims to be based in Belgium.</li><li>Be wary if you are asked to transfer money to a<strong> bank account in a country that is different from&nbsp;</strong>the one where you live or where the company’s registered office is said to be located.</li><li>If you have any doubts as to the identity of your contact person, feel free to <strong>contact the services of the FSMA</strong>. You can do so via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">contact form to report fraud</a>.</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>What can you do if, as an intermediary, you think you have been a victim of identity fraud?</strong></h2><ul><li>Be sure always to file a complaint with the local police or the judicial authorities. This can be done online via&nbsp;<a href="https://www.police.be/police-on-web/en/">Police on web</a>. We advise you to document your complaint as thoroughly as possible.</li><li>You can also report it to the FSMA via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/professionals-contact-form">contact form for professionals</a>. This information is very useful for our supervision.</li><li>If you receive questions from a (potential) victim of this type of investment fraud, please inform the person clearly that this is a case of fraud, and advise him or her to file a complaint with the local police.</li></ul></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-28T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">461898</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Information provision in the IFRS financial statements regarding inputs into real estate valuation models</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/information-provision-ifrs-financial-statements-regarding-inputs-real-estate-valuation-models</link>
  <description>
<p>For companies with a substantial volume of investment property on their balance sheet, such as Belgian regulated real estate investment companies (SIR/GVV), the fair value of these investments is a key determinant of the company’s value. It goes without saying that the information about how fair value is determined is considered important information for users of the annual financial statements.</p><p>The FSMA sets out its expectations regarding the disclosures on this topic in the IFRS financial statements. These expectations are based on the principles of IFRS 13.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip">Read <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/462096">FSMA_Opinion_2024_01</a></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-27T09:48:22+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">462296</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>New opinions of the Insurance Commission</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-opinions-insurance-commission</link>
  <description>
<p>At the request of Mr Pierre-Yves Dermagne, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Economy and Employment, the Insurance Commission has issued two opinions.</p><ul><li>The first opinion is dated 23 October 2024 (DOC/C2024/1) and addresses Article 156, 1° of the Law of 4 April 2014 on insurance regarding the freedom to choose legal counsel under legal expenses insurance.</li><li>On 12 November 2024, the Commission issued an opinion (DOC/C2024/4) on the draft Law amending Article 7 of the Law of 21 November 1989 on compulsory civil liability insurance in respect of motor vehicles and the draft Royal Decree amending Article 3 of the Royal Decree of 16 April 2018 establishing the terms and conditions for insurance contracts covering compulsory civil liability in respect of motor vehicles, as regards the claims-history statement.</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><ul><li>Please read Opinion <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-11/advice_c_2024_1.pdf">C/2024/1</a> (available in Dutch and French only)</li><li>Please read Opinion <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-11/advice_c_2024_4.pdf">C/2024/4</a> (available in Dutch and French only)</li></ul></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-26T09:55:07+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">462095</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Deletion of the registration of 19 insurance intermediaries on the basis of the Insurance Law</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/deletion-registration-19-insurance-intermediaries-basis-insurance-law</link>
  <description>
<p>(update 17/12/2024)</p><p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The registration of 19 insurance intermediaries has been deleted, on the basis of the Law of 4 April 2014 on insurance (‘Insurance Law’), because they have not remedied a shortcoming identified, namely, the failure to pursue continuing professional education for 2022 and/or 2023 on the part of the head(s) of distribution appointed by the said intermediaries.</strong></span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>&nbsp;</strong></span><span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/news/radiation-de-linscription-de-20-intermediaires-dassurance-sur-la-base-de-la-loi-assurances"><span>French</span></a><span> or </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/news/schrapping-van-de-inschrijving-van-20-verzekeringstussenpersonen-op-basis-van-de-wet"><span>Dutch</span></a><span> site.</span></p>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Advertisements with celebrities spotted on social media? Beware of fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/advertisements-celebrities-spotted-social-media-beware-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is once again drawing the public’s attention to the dangers posed by fraudulent trading platforms. These platforms lure investors online with promises of quick and easy earnings. Their offers look attractive, but often they are nothing more than sophisticated scams that can lead to significant losses.</strong></p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2>How does a fraudulent trading platform work? (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_q4_schema_en.pdf">flowchart</a>)</h2><ol><li><p><strong>Modes of contact</strong></p><p>Fraudsters use various techniques to contact their targets.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>A <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/warning-can-you-get-rich-just-few-clicks">fake advertisement</a> in which a celebrity is mentioned;&nbsp;</li><li>a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-trading-platforms-how-fraudsters-obtain-your-data">website intended to “recruit” victims</a>;</li><li>a fake account on social media or on a dating app;</li><li>a message that you have received allegedly by accident (SMS, WhatsApp, etc.).</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Registration</strong></p><p>Interested investors register on the platform and deposit funds to their trading account. Generally, investors begin with a relatively small sum, such as 250 euros. Sometimes the swindlers offer to help their victims by taking over their device remotely in order to make certain transfers on their behalf, which of course allows them to download viruses or spyware.</p></li><li><p><strong>Manipulation and pressure tactics</strong></p><p>Once the funds have been deposited by the victim, the platform manipulates the transactions to give the impression that significant profits have been achieved. However, these earnings are fictitious and the funds have not really been invested. The fraudsters then put pressure on their victims to invest more money. They do so by means of repeated phone calls, time-limited offers to which investors must respond quickly, or by issuing threats.</p></li><li><p><strong>Withdrawals seem impossible</strong></p><p>To gain victims’ trust, fraudsters sometimes allow them once to withdraw a small amount. However, once an investor wishes to withdraw a larger amount, the fraudsters use various pretexts not to have to pay back any money (high costs, taxes, etc.). In the end, the fraudulent platform disappears completely, taking with it all the investors’ money.</p></li></ol></div><p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>The FSMA has noted that the following websites were putting consumers in contact with fraudulent trading platforms:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>BitGPT&nbsp;</strong>(https://bitgpt.app, https://bit-gpt.app, https://bit-gpt-app.com);</li><li><strong>Immediate2.0 ProAir</strong> (https://immediateproair.ai, https://immediateproair.co, https://immediate-proair.co, https://immediateproair.com, https://immediatetradepro.com)</li><li><strong>Neoprofit</strong> (https://neoprofit.org, https://neoprofitai.com,&nbsp;https://the-neoprofit-app.net);</li><li><strong>Oil 4.4 Evex / Gas XP Evex</strong> (https://oilevexai.com).</li></ul><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to offers made by the following trading platforms:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>4AI</strong> (https://4ai.com, https://4ai.net);</li><li><strong>Aifactor</strong> (https://aifactor.ai, https://premiumaifactor.vip);</li><li><strong>Artosnomics</strong> (https:// artosnomics.com);</li><li><strong>Axemarket</strong> (https://axemarket.com);</li><li><strong>Axe Trade Capital&nbsp;</strong>(https://axetradecapital.com)</li><li><strong>Axia Group (Clone)</strong> (https://axiagroup.io, https://axiagroup.co);</li><li><strong>Bacco Capital</strong> (https://baccocapital.pro);</li><li><strong>Boley</strong> (https://boley.im);</li><li><strong>Bull-Markets</strong> (https://bull-markets.com);</li><li><strong>Capital Group Fund</strong> (https://capitalgroup-funds.com);</li><li><strong>Commondigital</strong> (https://commondigital.eu);</li><li><strong>Dax40</strong> (https://dax40trade.online, https://user.dax40trade.ltd/login), https://wt.dax40trade.info);</li><li><strong>Finance</strong> <strong>Wise Global Securities Pty Ltd</strong> (https://wiseglobal.info);</li><li><strong>Fina-Nova&nbsp;</strong>(https://fina-nova.com);</li><li><strong>FORE XF&nbsp;</strong>(https://forexf.cc, https://bdsu-fx.com);</li><li><strong>Forex SX&nbsp;</strong>(https://forexsxpro.com);</li><li><strong>FusionLots</strong> (https://fusionlots.com, https://platform.fusionlots-techp.com);</li><li><strong>Geminix</strong> (https://geminix.app, https://geminix.trade);</li><li><strong>Global Prime Treasury PTE. LTD</strong> (https://globalprimetreasury.com);</li><li><strong>Inside the Fund</strong> (https://insidethefund.com);</li><li><strong>Investing Ideas</strong> (https://investingideas.world);</li><li><strong>InvestiRay</strong> (https://investi-ray.com);</li><li><strong>Kimonsage</strong> (https://kimonsage.io)&nbsp;;</li><li><strong>Optimum Markets</strong> (https://optimum-markets.com);</li><li><strong>Premium Yields</strong> (https://premiumyields.com, https://premium-yields.com, https://premiumyields1.com, https://pytradingmarket.com, https://premiumyields2.com, https://premiumyields3.com);</li><li><strong>Quantumstar</strong> (https://quantumstar.net);</li><li><strong>Qwebank</strong> (https://qwebank.com);</li><li><strong>Rumblenomic</strong> (https://rumblenomic.co,&nbsp;https://rumblenomic.io/login);</li><li><strong>TheBiggestFuture</strong> (https://thebiggestfuture.com);</li><li><strong>TheMellonFX</strong> (http://themellonfx.com, http://themellonfx.net);</li><li><strong>Tradelly</strong> (https://tradelly.ai);</li><li><strong>TradeMasterCFD</strong> (https://trademastercfd.com);</li><li><strong>Traderoom24</strong> (https://traderoom24.com, https://app.traderoom24.com/login)</li><li><strong>Weinsteincorp</strong> (https://weinsteincorp.biz, https://weinsteincorp.com);</li><li><strong>WT Central</strong> (https://webtrader.wtcentral.org, https://wtcentral.com).</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>I’ve fallen victim. What should I do?</strong></h2><ol><li><strong>Stop making any transactions and break off all contact with the platform</strong>: don’t deposit any more money and don’t provide any additional personal or financial information. Break off all contact with the fraudsters. They may try to manipulate you in order to take even more money from you.</li><li><strong>Contact your bank</strong>: inform your bank immediately if you have made any payments to the fraudulent platform.</li><li><strong>Report the fraud to the competent authorities</strong>:&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/form/contactformulier-peri">Contact the FSMA</a> and file a complaint with the police.</li><li><strong>Document all exchanges of data and transactions</strong>: gather all evidence of your exchanges of data with the platform, including emails, messages, account statements and screen shots of the transactions. These items will, of course, be very valuable when you report the fraud.</li><li><strong>Beware of ‘recovery rooms’</strong>: fraudsters contact victims of a previous scam and offer to help them – for a fee – recover their lost money.&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">Often this constitutes yet another attempt at fraud</a>.</li></ol><p>For more recommendations on how to avoid investment fraud, please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">‘How to recognize and avoid fraud’</a> page on the FSMA website. Please watch our awareness-raising videos as well (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/preventiefilms">Dutch</a> and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-prevention">French</a> only).</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Jean-Paul Servais appointed Chair of the OECD Corporate Governance Committee</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/jean-paul-servais-appointed-chair-oecd-corporate-governance-committee</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the FSMA and of the IOSCO Board, Jean-Paul Servais, has been appointed Chair of the Corporate Governance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). His term of office will take effect on 1 January 2025 for a period of one year, renewable.</strong></p><p>The Corporate Governance Committee consists of representatives of OECD member states, G20 and Financial Stability Board jurisdictions and a number of international organizations. It serves as the central forum for corporate governance matters at the international level. It coordinates and oversees the work of the OECD in the areas of corporate governance, corporate finance and state-owned enterprises.&nbsp;</p><p>In addition, the Committee promotes and monitors implementation of the <em>G20/OECD Principles of Corporate Governance</em> (which are the international standard in this area) and maintains internationally recognized reference works such as the <em>OECD Corporate Governance Factbook</em> and new key publications on global corporate sustainability.&nbsp;</p><p>The committee engages in active dialogue with a wide range of stakeholders and to that end regularly carries out initiatives and holds conferences to further promote the dissemination of the G20/OECD Principles.&nbsp;</p><blockquote><p>“I am grateful and honoured to be entrusted with this role within this important committee. It is a great honour to succeed Mr. Masato Kanda, who played an instrumental role in ensuring the G20 endorsement of the OECD Revised Principles of Corporate Governance. The appointment is a recognition of the expertise and pioneering role of the FSMA in this area, and is also a fine illustration of the reinforced international impact of the FSMA, due to amongst others the chairmanship of IOSCO,” Jean-Paul Servais commented.</p></blockquote><p>The OECD is an international organization made up of 38 members that works to establish evidence-based international standards and promote public policies intended to address global economic, social and environmental challenges. Mr. Servais will succeed Mr. Masato Kanda, Special Advisor to the Cabinet of the Prime Minister of Japan and former Vice-Minister of Finance, whose current term as Chair of the OECD Corporate Governance Committee will end on 31 December, 2024.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-05T21:20:09+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">457756</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Theft of the identity of Belgian banks for fraudulent offers of term deposit accounts: beware of fraudsters</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/theft-identity-belgian-banks-fraudulent-offers-term-deposit-accounts-beware-fraudsters</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In recent months, the FSMA has observed several cases of theft of the identity of Belgian banks by German-speaking fraudsters. The swindlers act in such a way as to make consumers think their product offers are legitimate.</strong></p><p>German-speaking fraudsters are using the names of Belgian banks to make people believe that their fake offers of term deposit accounts to consumers are legitimate.</p><p>They do so by fraudulently using the name and other legally required information of intermediaries who are, for the most part, regulated in Germany or Switzerland, in order to try to convince consumers that they hold the necessary authorizations. They thus deceive consumers into thinking they are opening a term deposit account with a Belgian bank. The fraudsters use very detailed documentation to give the impression they are acting on behalf of and for the account of that bank. They often offer discounts or bonuses to their clients. Consumers are thus deceived, thinking they are dealing with regulated financial providers, when in reality these are fraudsters who have simply stolen their identity.</p><p>In some cases, the fraudsters create a website with a web address that corresponds to the name of the intermediary whose identity they have stolen.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>How to avoid the trap</strong></h2><p>This fraudulent practice may be difficult to detect and avoid. We therefore encourage you to take the following steps to ensure that your interlocutor is indeed who he or she claims to be:</p><ul><li>Verify the <strong>contact details</strong> provided on the websites of the various regulators to ensure that they are the same as the ones found on the website of the institution that has contacted you.<br><br><strong>Beware!</strong>&nbsp;Fraudsters frequently use the postal address of the authorized institution as well. Therefore, the fact that the correct postal address is used by your interlocutor is therefore not enough to confirm his or her identity!</li><li>Use online search engines to ensure that there is no other website under the name of the authorized institution in question.<br><br><strong>Beware!</strong>&nbsp;Swindlers often use a web address that is very close to that of the official site of the institution whose identity they have stolen, just adding a hyphen to the address, using a different extension (.com instead of .be, for example), etc., or they steal the identity of an institution that does not use a website.</li><li>Compare<strong> the official information with the facts you have been presented.</strong> For example, if your interlocutor claims to represent a foreign bank but offers you the products of an institution governed by Belgian law, make sure that the information provided is consistent (Are the rates offered realistic? Are the contract details up to date?). Similarly, if your interlocutor claims to represent a bank based in Belgium but is contacting you from a foreign phone number, this should serve as a warning sign.</li><li>Use the online tools available that allow you to verify <strong>the date when your interlocutor’s website was created</strong>. If the website is very recent, this is a significant indication that it may not be trustworthy.</li><li>If your interlocutor asks you to deposit money into an account opened in the name of another person or company, this is clear evidence of fraud.</li><li>If you have any doubt whatsoever about the identity of your interlocutor, please contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud">consumer contact form</a><u>.</u></li></ul></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-11-04T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">456815</guid>
    </item>

  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is competent to supervise and follow-up on the new regime governing the banker’s oath. Since the various stakeholders in the sector need to be able to prepare for the entry into force of this regime, the FSMA is providing additional information about its scope, the list of bank service providers that has to be submitted to the FSMA, as well as the oath certificate and the certificate confirming that the provider is not subject to a professional ban.</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/454012"><u>French</u></a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/454012"><u>Dutch</u></a> site.</p>

<item>
  <title>End of World Investor Week 2024</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week-2024</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The eighth edition of World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held from 7 to 13 October 2024. The aim of this week was to promote financial education and investor protection. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</strong></p><p>This year’s World Investor Week focused in particular on sustainable finance and crypto-assets. Other topics, such as online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to, were also featured. This thematic week offered yet another opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p><p>This initiative was once again supported by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), the chairman of which is also chair of the IOSCO Board. To mark the beginning of World Investment Week, the chairman took part in the ‘Ring the Bell’ ceremony at Euronext Brussels.</p><p>The FSMA drew attention to World Investor Week&nbsp; through its social media and also relaunched its digital awareness campaign on investment fraud and fraudulent offers to direct the public to its financial education website&nbsp;<a href="http://www.wikifin.be/">www.wikifin.be</a>,&nbsp;which offers all kinds of useful information and handy tools relating to money matters.</p><p>Additional information on the campaign (available in <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/fr/epargner-et-investir/fraudes-et-escroqueries-linvestissement/ne-vous-laissez-pas-pieger-par-les">French</a> - <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/nl/sparen-en-beleggen/fraude-en-oplichting-bij-beleggen/laat-je-niet-vangen-door-beleggingsfraude">Dutch</a> only) can be found on wikifin.be.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-10-14T08:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">450718</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Decision to change the bid price and orders issued to CMB</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/decision-change-bid-price-and-orders-issued-cmb</link>
  <description>
<p>In connection with CMB's mandatory takeover bid for Euronav NV/SA (presently ‘CMB.Tech’), the FSMA hereby makes public its decision to require that the price be increased by USD 0.52 per share. It also publishes the related orders to CMB to:</p><ul><li>pay a supplement over the offer price (for the benefit of shareholders who had already accepted the offer during the acceptance period that ran from 14 February 2024 to 15 March 2024); and</li><li>reopen the offer (for the benefit of shareholders who had not yet tendered their shares) at an offer price which, taking into account the distributions made since the event giving rise to the mandatory offer, currently amounts to USD 12.66.</li></ul><p>The FSMA considers this publication appropriate to ensure the proper functioning of the market.</p><p>The full text of the decision can be found <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-10/20241007_beslissing_cmb.pdf">here</a> (official version in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-10/20241007_beslissing_cmb.pdf">Dutch</a>, with free translation in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-10/20241007_decision_cmb.pdf">French</a>).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-10-08T07:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">452034</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>World Investor Week 2024</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week-2024</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The eighth World Investor Week (WIW)&nbsp;will take place from Monday 7 to Sunday 13 October 2024. It is organized by IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions. The aim of World Investor Week is to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas will be at the centre of attention.</strong></p><p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), whose chairman, Jean-Paul Servais, also chairs the IOSCO Board, once again lends its full support to this initiative. This morning, Mr Servais took part in the ‘Ring the Bell’ ceremony at Euronext Brussels to mark the beginning of World Investor Week. A similar ceremony was held in more than 50 stock exchanges worldwide on the occasion of the WIW.</p><p>World Investor Week 2024&nbsp;focuses, among other things,&nbsp;on sustainable finance and crypto-assets. Other topics, such as online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to, are also featured. Within this framework, the FSMA has&nbsp;relaunched its major awareness campaign against online investment fraud.</p><p>Watch <a href="https://vimeo.com/1017024863/560889b12e">the video message</a> by FSMA and IOSCO chairman Jean-Paul Servais on the occasion of World Investor Week.</p><p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org.</a></p>
<figure class="media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/world-investorweek.png?itok=Zv5bgsJ9" width="381" height="194" alt="World Investor Week: the logo of World Investor Week" title="World Investor Week: the logo of World Investor Week" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Update to the handbook on IDD rules of conduct</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-handbook-idd-rules-conduct</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>In January 2022, the FSMA published its handbook on the IDD rules of conduct. The handbook provides explanations of the rules of conduct that apply in the insurance sector.</strong></span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p>The FSMA has now updated this handbook in order, among other things, to provide greater clarity regarding:</p><ul><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">the division of responsibilities between insurance companies and insurance intermediaries for the provision of precontractual and periodic information to clients;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB">the principles applicable to storage of the data in the client file.</span></li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Please see the new version of the handbook (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/fsma_2022_06_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-10/fsma_2022_06_fr.pdf">French</a> only).</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against certain companies suspected of recovery room fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-certain-companies-suspected-recovery-room-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The FSMA is again warning the Belgian public against certain companies suspected of recovery room fraud.</strong></span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Recovery room fraud is a practice whereby fraudsters offer to help&nbsp;<strong>victims of investment fraud</strong>&nbsp;to obtain compensation for their losses or to&nbsp;<strong>recover their lost assets</strong>.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Generally, the fraudsters contact their victims by phone or by e-mail. The FSMA has noted, however, that victims sometimes come into contact with the so-called ‘recovery rooms’ while conducting internet searches or via social media. When introducing themselves, fraudsters and their companies pass themselves off as law firms or accountants, and sometimes as police services or financial supervisors. The fraudsters do not hesitate to misuse the identity information of existing companies or official institutions in order to appear trustworthy.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">The fraudsters charge a&nbsp;<strong>fee</strong>&nbsp;for their services. Victims of investment fraud must&nbsp;<strong>pay the fee in advance</strong>. This is a clear indication that it is a recovery room. The payment is demanded, for example, allegedly to cover certain administrative or legal costs or to pay taxes. These are <strong>purely&nbsp;fictitious costs</strong>, however.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">In some other cases, fraudsters pretend to offer <strong>free</strong> services. The victim only has to give an access to her computer via a remote desktop application (such as Anydesk). In this way, fraudsters can install spywares on the consumers’ computers or access their PC-Bankings.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Fraudsters also sometimes ask their victims to create and activate a wallet on a cryptoplatform.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">In all cases, fraudsters manage to steal money from consumers. Once the fraudsters have received the fees, they disappear without a trace and it is almost impossible to recover the amounts paid. <strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers.</strong></span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</span></p><ul><li>Akin (www.akin.com.co)</li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">Bitcity (https://bitcity.cc/ and https://bitcity.ac/)</span></li><li><span lang="FR-BE"></span><span lang="FR-BE">Concord Services (http://concord-services.org/)&nbsp;</span></li><li>Ledgible (https://ledgible.io/)&nbsp;</li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Recovery AI (https://recovery-ai.org/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Trade Control (www.tradecontrol.org)&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">World Blockchain Organization (https://uwnbo.info/; euwbo.com)</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB">The FSMA recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several known entities to deceive consumers. The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:</span></p><ul><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Atomics Wallets, using a website ‘atomicswallets.com’</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Belton Accounting, using a website ‘https://beltonaccounting.com/’</span></li><li>Certik</li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US">Guardian Limited, using a website ‘https://www.guardianltd.co.uk/’</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">Metatrader 4, Metatrader 5, MT5 Finance using a website ‘https://mt5finance.com’</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB">The fraudsters also usurp names of public or control authorities and therefore pretend to collaborate with those authorities in order&nbsp;</span><span lang="EN-US">to give consumers the impression that they are legitimate</span><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">***</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">Victims of investment fraud are often targeted twice by the same fraudsters: first the latter perpetrate investment fraud, and thereafter, recovery room fraud. The persons behind the investment fraud may also sell their victims’ contact information on to other fraudsters.&nbsp;<strong>Anyone who has ever been a victim of investment fraud needs to be aware that fraudsters may target their victims again or sell their personal data on to others.</strong></span></p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>How can you recognize and avoid recovery room fraud?</strong></span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"></span></strong></h2><ul><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">If you have been a victim of investment fraud, we advise you always to&nbsp;<strong>file a complaint</strong>&nbsp;with the local police.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">Be extremely careful if you find an advertisement on&nbsp;<strong>social media&nbsp;or the internet</strong>, which offers to recover funds you have lost.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">If you receive&nbsp;<strong>unsolicited phone calls&nbsp;</strong>with an offer to recover funds you have lost, be sure to ask how that person found out that you have lost money. Reports of fraud are shared only with the judicial authorities and not with private companies.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB">If you are asked to&nbsp;<strong>pay a set fee in advance, to access your computer or to activate a wallet on a cryptoplatform</strong>, don’t respond but terminate all contact.</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Financial supervisors&nbsp;</strong>such as the FSMA are not authorized to recover lost money and would therefore not take the initiative to contact victims of investment fraud.</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span lang="EN-GB">search function</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/questions-about-investment-fraud"><span lang="EN-GB">fraud contact form</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-10-03T08:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">450480</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA Chairman calls for international climate reporting framework during New York Climate Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-chairman-calls-international-climate-reporting-framework-during-new-york-climate-week</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Speaking at a New York Climate Week conference, where US President Joe Biden also took the floor, FSMA and IOSCO Chair Jean-Paul Servais met with President Biden and with Michael Bloomberg and called for the rapid implementation of an international framework for climate reporting, along the lines of what currently exists for financial reporting.</strong></p><p>Jean-Paul Servais, in addition to being Chairman of the FSMA, is also Chair of IOSCO, the global organisation of financial market regulators. IOSCO has over 130 members, which together control 95 per cent of financial markets.</p><p>As IOSCO Chair, Jean-Paul Servais participated last week in a host of conferences and meetings as part of New York Climate Week. The focus during this week was on climate data and reporting, topics in which IOSCO plays a central role as an international standard setter.</p><p>The aim is to make climate data equivalent to financial data in terms of quality, consistency and availability. An estimated 130,000 companies worldwide would eventually adopt the new climate data reporting standards.</p><p>The data could be used by investors, financial institutions, regulators as well as the companies themselves. Checking data quality and information on companies' transition plans towards greater sustainability are also topics IOSCO is currently working on and were discussed in New York.</p><blockquote><p>Jean-Paul Servais: ‘President Biden's participation underlines the importance of this New York Climate Week and of the implementation of a global framework for climate data and reporting. Promoting high-quality sustainability reporting is one of the key priorities for IOSCO to protect investors from greenwashing. Since IOSCO announced its endorsement of the first ISSB standards in July 2023, rapid progress has been made globally in implementing sustainability reporting requirements and I welcome this Climate Week's focus on this important topic’.</p></blockquote>
<figure class="media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/jps-biden-orig_0.jpg?itok=XtHzEnYD" width="1024" height="683" alt="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman FSMA and IOSCO - Joe Biden - Mike Bloomberg" title="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman FSMA and IOSCO - Joe Biden - Mike Bloomberg" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">448733</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>In the first six months of 2024, the number of notifications of online investment fraud increased by 50 percent</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/first-six-months-2024-number-notifications-online-investment-fraud-increased-50-percent</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Since the beginning of this year, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received nearly 50 percent more notifications of online investment fraud than in the same period last year. More and more people find their way to the FSMA not only to notify that they have become the victim of fraud, but also as a precautionary measure before actually deciding to make an investment. The FSMA steps up its efforts to increase people’s vigilance and to encourage them to notify fraud even faster.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/446792"><u>French</u></a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/446792"><u>Dutch</u></a><span> site.</span></p>
</description>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">446792</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Update of the handbook for IORPs on the implementation of the IORP II Directive and EIOPA’s opinions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-handbook-iorps-implementation-iorp-ii-directive-and-eiopas-opinions</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has published an update to its handbook for IORPs on the implementation of the IORP II Directive and EIOPA’s opinions on governance and risk management. This new handbook (FSMA_2024_17) replaces Handbook FSMA_2022_01 of 14 December 2021.</strong></p><p>The handbook as such was not substantially altered. In some places, a reference was introduced to the new annex on data management (see further). The opportunity was also taken to make some adjustments, among other things, to refer to&nbsp;DORA in the passage about the management of IT and cyber risks, and to adapt the passage about the internal whistleblowers’ procedure in order to take account of the&nbsp;law on the private sector.&nbsp;</p><p>A new annex (annex 7) on data management was added to the handbook. This annex mainly deals with some specific aspects on which the FSMA made findings during its inspection campaign into data management. It is indeed essential that identification, salary and career data are correct and complete. They form the basis for the calculation of the pension rights of the affiliates and beneficiaries. Securely managing these data is therefore crucial to guarantee an adequate management of the pension liabilities.</p><p>For the ease of the reader, the content modifications are indicated with a vertical line in the margin.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>To learn more, please refer to the Handbook FSMA_2024_17 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-09/fsma_2024_17_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-09/fsma_2024_17_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) of 10 September 2024 for IORPs on the implementation of the IORP II Directive and EIOPA’s Opinions on governance and risk management.</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-09-19T14:21:45+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">447056</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Evolution of Belgian investment funds in the second quarter of 2024</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/evolution-belgian-investment-funds-second-quarter-2024</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has published a new edition of its&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-09/2024_dashboard_q2.pdf"><strong><u>quarterly dashboard</u></strong></a><strong>&nbsp;of Belgian public open-ended investment funds, generally referred to as investment funds. The overview presented in this dashboard covers the first quarter of the year 2024.</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/446287"><u>French</u></a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/446287"><u>Dutch</u></a> site.</p>
</description>

  <title>Approval of the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/approval-modified-market-rules-regulated-markets-organized-euronext-nvsa-10</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-US">The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved&nbsp;on 26 June 2024 in accordance with Article 34, §1, of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU. These market rules enter into force as of 9 September 2024.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-US">The market rules are available on </span><a href="https://www.euronext.com/en/regulation/regulated-markets"><span lang="EN-US">Euronext</span></a><span lang="EN-US">'s website.</span></p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Look out for traps: beware of these fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/look-out-traps-beware-these-fraudulent-trading-platforms-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is once again drawing the public's attention to the phenomenon of fraudulent trading platforms and their dangers. These platforms are all over the internet, trying to lure investors with promises of quick and easy earnings. However, behind these tantalizing offers, there are often sophisticated scams that can lead to significant losses.</strong></p><h2><strong>How does a fraudulent trading platform work? (</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_q4_schema_en.pdf"><strong>flowchart</strong></a><strong>)</strong></h2><ol><li><strong>Modes of contact</strong>: Fraudsters use various techniques to contact their victims: a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/warning-can-you-get-rich-just-few-clicks">fake news article</a> that mentions a celebrity, <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-trading-platforms-how-fraudsters-obtain-your-data">online advertisements</a>, a fake account on social media, a dating app or even a “lost” message (text message, Whatsapp, …). In each case, the platform attracts investors by promising them very high returns in a short time, often well beyond the sorts of gains that are realistic.</li><li><strong>Registration</strong>: Interested investors register on the platform and deposit funds to their trading account. Most of the time, investors begin with a relatively small sum (e.g. €250). In some cases, the swindlers offer to help victims by taking over their computer remotely in order to make certain transfers on their behalf, which also allows them to use viruses and spyware, for example.</li><li><strong>Manipulation and pressure tactics</strong>: Once the funds have been deposited by the victim, the platform will manipulate the transactions to give the impression of significant profits. These earnings are fictitious, and the funds have not really been invested. The fraudsters then put pressure on their victims to invest more and more money (repeated phone calls, time-limited offers, threats, etc.).</li><li><strong>Withdrawals are impossible</strong>: An initial withdrawal of a small amount is sometimes possible, thereby giving victims more confidence. However, once an investor wishes to withdraw a larger amount, the fraudsters use various pretexts not to make it possible (high costs, taxes owing, etc.). In the end, the fraudulent platform disappears, taking with it all the investors’ money.&nbsp;</li></ol><h2><strong>The FSMA is warning today against different websites that have recently appeared.</strong></h2><p>The FSMA notes that the following websites were putting consumers in touch with fraudulent trading platforms:</p><ul><li><span lang="EN-US">Bitcoin Avage 500 (www.bitcoinavage500.com);</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Gas 4.0 Alrex/Gas Alrex Ai (https://the-official-website.net/gas-4-0-alrex/; https://www.btcrevolution.cloud/);</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Trade 7.0 sprix (https://techtonicterritory.com/; https://www.innovateinfinityisland.com/; https://innovativeideasisle.com/; https://www.aquamarinespasauna.com/index.html).</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li></ul><p>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by the following trading platforms:<span lang="EN-US"></span></p><ul><li><span lang="EN-US">24era (https://24era.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Abyss World Asset (https://www.abyss-world-asset.com/);</span></li><li>Antbit (www.antbitx.cc; www.antbit.cc);</li><li><span lang="EN-US">Axys Global (https://axysglobal.cc/; axysglobal.ltd);</span></li><li>Bit4eu (https://bit4eu.co/; bit4eu.io&nbsp;; https://bit4eu.cc/);</li><li><span lang="EN-US">Bit-wise (https://www.bit-wise.co/);&nbsp;</span></li><li>Coineuro Cap (https://coineurocapital.co/);</li><li>Delta24 (delta24.pro);</li><li>Finkea (www.finkea.com);&nbsp;</li><li><span lang="NL-BE">FX Tampa (https://www.fxtampa.net/; https://www.fxtampa.com; https://www.befxtampa.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Globalconnect24 (https://www.globalconnect24.net/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">High Forecast (https://www.hiforecast.com/; https://www.hiforecast.world/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Investment Peak (https://investmentpeak.com/; http://www.investmentpeak1.com/; http://investment1peak.com; https://investmentpeak4.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">JPMreview (https://www.jpmreview.net/);</span></li><li>Kucoine (www.kucoine.cc; www.kucoine.net);</li><li>Main BTC (https://main-btc.dev/; https://main-btc.com/);</li><li>Market2Trade (https://market2trade.com/);</li><li>Market4Trade (www.mrk4trd.com);</li><li><span lang="EN-US">Market Rate AI (https://mrate-ai.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Oxtrades (https://oxtrades.com);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Profit Gainer (www.profit-gainer.com; www.profit-gnr.com; www.finkanso.com);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Profitmarkets (https://profitmarkets.org/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">PrimeBanque (https://primebanque.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Robintrov (https://www.robintrov.com/; https://robintrov.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">STEcapital (https://stecapital.cc/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">SwissCoinCo (https://swisscoinco.com/, https://swiss-coin.co);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">tipo-group.com, Trading-Wave, Trading-Waves Tipo group (https://clientzone.trading-wave.com/fr/login; https://trading-wave.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Trade101.ai (https://trade101.ai/);</span></li><li>Trilophun Incoporations (https://trilophun.com/);</li><li><span lang="EN-US">Xtrader.Ca (www.xtrader.ca);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Wavestrader (https://wavestrader.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">WFM International (https://www.wfminternational.com/; https://wfminternational.vip/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">ZZ Trading (https://zztrading.io/).</span></li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>I’ve fallen victim. What should I do?&nbsp;</strong></h2><ul><li><strong>Stop making any transactions and break off all contact with the platform</strong>: Do not deposit any more money and do not provide any additional personal or financial information. Break off all contact with the fraudsters. They may try to manipulate you in order to take even more money from you.</li><li><strong>Contact your bank</strong>: Inform your bank immediately if you have made any payments to the fraudulent platform.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Report the fraud to the competent authorities</strong>:&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/form/contactformulier-peri">Contact the FSMA</a> and file a complaint with the police.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Document all the messages and transactions</strong>: Gather together all the evidence of communications with the platform, including emails, messages, account statements and screen captures of transactions. These items will be valuable when you report the fraud.</li><li><strong>Beware of “recovery rooms”:&nbsp;</strong>The latter is a practice that consists of contacting people who have been victims of a scam in the past and offering them services that will supposedly recover your lost money, for a fee. <a href="e/en/recovery-room">Often, these constitute yet another case of fraud.</a></li></ul><p>For more information, please consult the “<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud</a>” page on the FSMA website. The site provides additional tips to help you avoid investment fraud.&nbsp;Please watch our awareness-raising videos as well&nbsp;(available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-prevention">French</a> and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/preventiefilms">Dutch</a> only).</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-08-29T08:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">442372</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Findings regarding the liquidity stress tests conducted by Belgian fund managers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/findings-regarding-liquidity-stress-tests-conducted-belgian-fund-managers</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA examined the extent to which the Belgian management companies of UCIs or AIF managers are conducting liquidity stress tests for the funds they manage, what principles and assumptions they use in so doing, and how they organise the stress tests. The enquiry resulted in a number of findings, including both positive assessments and points requiring attention; the results can provide managers with insights into a number of good practices.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in communication FSMA_2024_14 (available in ( <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-08/fsma_2024_14_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-08/fsma_2024_14_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Update on the electronic submission of information for UCIs to the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-electronic-submission-information-ucis-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p>Undertakings for collective investment (UCIs) are required to provide information to the FSMA on a regular basis. They submit the information in question electronically, in the form of documents and data points, via the platforms that the FSMA provides for the purpose. This communication describes the practical procedures for submitting information via those platforms. The procedures are regularly updated in order to take into account new developments in connection with the information to be submitted, underlying technical changes to the platforms and procedural optimisation.</p><p>The most recent update adds procedures for submitting and updating the questionnaire on the appointment of a custodian for UCITS governed by Belgian law. The update also clarifies the procedure that UCIs are to follow to provide the details for various categories of contact persons, including the general contact persons, the persons authorized to provide certain items of information and the persons responsible for maintaining contacts with the FSMA for specific matters.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in the communcation FSMA_2022_18 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-05/fsma_2022_18_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-05/fsma_2022_18_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-08-26T08:35:48+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">442179</guid>
    </item>

The study now has an additional section that explains the main factors affecting those costs.</strong></span></p><p><span>This press release is not available in English. <item>
  <title>Amendments to the ML/TF Risk Factors Guidelines</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/amendments-mltf-risk-factors-guidelines</link>
  <description>
<p>The new guidelines amend the ML/TF Risk Factors Guidelines (EBA/GL/2021/02). They take into account the recent changes to the European Union’s legislation on preventing money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) and the new ML/TF risks associated with crypto-asset services. They include new guidance on risk assessments and on customer due diligence. In addition, they incorporate a number of sectoral guidelines.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>The ESA Guidelines are available <a href="https://www.eba.europa.eu/sites/default/files/2024-01/a3e89f4f-fbf3-4bd6-9e07-35f3243555b3/Final%20Amending%20%20Guidelines%20on%20MLTF%20Risk%20Factors.pdf">here</a></p></div>
</description>
