    </item>
<item>
  <title>Conduct of cross-border activities by management companies of UCITS and AIF managers under Belgian law</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/conduct-cross-border-activities-management-companies-ucits-and-aif-managers-under-belgian-law</link>
  <description>
<p>Efforts are made at European level to harmonize the form and content of the information to be notified by management companies of UCITS and AIF managers in respect of their cross-border activities.</p><p>There are new forms to be filled in in English by management companies of UCITS and/or AIF managers intending to carry out activities within the territory of another European Economic Area (EEA) Member State&nbsp;</p><ul><li>through establishing a branch in that other EEA Member State; or&nbsp;</li><li>through free provision of services.</li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in the communication FSMA_2024_12 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2024_12_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2024_12_nl.pdf">Dutch </a>only)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-07-24T14:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">435009</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Mexc Global LTD (www.mexc.com) - Order</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/mexc-global-ltd-wwwmexccom-order</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA orders Mexc Global LTD (www.mexc.com) to: cease providing all custodian wallet services in Belgium and to cease all distribution to retail clients in Belgium of financial products the return on which depends, directly or indirectly, on virtual money.</strong></p><p>Persons or firms governed by the law of a country that is not a member of the European Economic Area are prohibited from offering or providing, within Belgium, by way of a professional activity – even if supplementary or ancillary – exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies or custody wallet services.</p><p>Failure to comply with this prohibition is subject to criminal sanctions pursuant to Article 136 of the Belgian Law on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing.</p><p>The FSMA takes the view that by offering such services in Belgium from countries that are not members of the European Economic Area, namely the Seychelles, Mexc Global LTD is in violation of that prohibition.&nbsp;</p><p>Moreover,&nbsp;it is prohibited to distribute, on a professional basis, to one or more retail clients, a financial product the return on which depends, directly or indirectly, on virtual money.&nbsp;</p><p>The FSMA has serious indications that Mexc Global LTD distributes financial products in Belgium the return on which depends, directly or indirectly, on virtual money.</p><p>That is why the FSMA decided on 23 July 2024 to order Mexc Global LTD to:</p><ol><li>cease providing all custodian wallet services in Belgium. To this end, Mexc must transfer the wallets of its Belgian clients to a custodian wallet provider established within the European Economic Area that is duly authorized to carry on this activity,</li><li>cease all distribution to retail clients in Belgium of financial products the return on which depends, directly or indirectly, on virtual money.</li></ol>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-07-24T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">434167</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Regulated savings accounts offer simplified</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/regulated-savings-accounts-offer-simplified</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The range of regulated savings accounts on offer has been simplified, based on the agreement reached in 2023 between the Belgian government and the banking sector. The number of types of regulated savings accounts has been reduced, and the vast majority of the accounts that were no longer being marketed but were still held by some customers have been closed. This information comes from an analysis conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p><h2><strong>Maximum 4 different types of regulated savings accounts</strong></h2><p>The agreement reached in 2023 between the government and the banking sector provided that the number of regulated savings accounts that can be offered by a single credit institution (or under one brand name) would be limited to 4 different savings accounts, spread across 3 categories (A, B and C – see below). These 4 types of savings accounts are marketed under different names and/or offer different rate of return formulas for calculating the rate of return.&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Two thirds of all banks have had to adapt their offer of regulated savings accounts</strong></h2><p>Following the agreement, nearly two thirds of all banks had to adapt their offer of regulated savings accounts in order to take into account this limitation and the different categories.&nbsp;</p><p>The limitation to 4 types of accounts entered into force on 1 July 2024. As at that date, 28 banks/brands were marketing regulated savings accounts. In all, 83 different formulas for calculating returns are available from banks that have signed on to the agreement:</p><ul><li>37 formulas in category A. These are the ‘classic’ savings accounts, which offer combinations of a base interest rate and a loyalty premium, without any other conditions;</li><li>25 formulas in category B. These accounts have conditions relating to the amount deposited; that is, there is a maximum or a minimum amount to be held on the savings account, or a (possibly maximum or minimum) monthly deposit to be made to the savings account;</li><li>7 formulas in category C, which comprises savings accounts linked to a specific age group (e.g. young people);</li><li>14 formulas on accounts for rental deposits, or accounts designated as being for a third party. These formulas are not included in the limit of 4 accounts/formulas per institution.</li></ul><p>These 83 formulas for calculating returns represent 78 accounts, since 5 banks/brands offer an account comprising 2 different formulas (i.e. the base rate and the loyalty premium differ according to the amount on the account).</p><h2><strong>Fewer rate of return formulas</strong></h2><p>Most banks/brands offer fewer formulas than the maximum number provided for in the agreement. It should be noted that only one third of all banks/brands offer customers 4 different formulas for their regulated savings accounts, whereas another third of all banks/brands offer a single regulated savings account with one rate of return formula.</p><h2><strong>Closure of most accounts that are no longer being marketed</strong></h2><p>The banks that have signed on to the agreement decided to close the majority of their regulated savings accounts that were no longer being marketed but were still held by some customers. Some of these accounts offered lower returns than the accounts being actively marketed. Savers who held such accounts were offered the one-time opportunity to convert them into another regulated savings account. At present, only 3 savings accounts that are no longer being marketed are still held by customers of banks hat have signed on to the agreement.</p><h2><strong>New webpages that make it easier to compare the banks’ offers</strong></h2><p>Another major shift brought about by the entry into force of the agreement was the creation, by all the institutions concerned, of a standardized webpage that provides a uniform overview of the offer of regulated savings accounts by each credit institution active in Belgium. Thanks to this webpage, savers are now able to gain a concise overview of the offer by each institution, and thus to compare more easily the different accounts available on the market.</p><h2><strong>The FSMA’s savings account comparison tool has already been consulted more than 120,000 times&nbsp;</strong></h2><p>The returns on regulated savings accounts can also be easily compared thanks to the latest version of the regulated savings account comparison tool available on the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a> website. Since it was updated following the new agreement, the comparison tool has already been visited more than 120,000 times.</p><p>By way of reminder, there is an interbank mobility service that makes it easy and quick to switch banks. You can find more information on this topic in&nbsp;<a href="https://www.wikifin.be/fr/budget-payer-emprunter-et-assurer/compte-vue/comment-changer-de-banque#:~:text=Que%20permet%20le%20service%20de,transf%C3%A9r%C3%A9%20vers%20votre%20nouvelle%20banque.">French</a> and&nbsp;<a href="https://www.wikifin.be/nl/budget-betalen-lenen-en-verzekeren/zichtrekening/hoe-verander-je-van-bank">Dutch</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>Under the terms of its supervisory powers in respect of savings accounts, the FSMA verifies, among other things, whether the key information documents for savers and advertisements for savings accounts comply with the legislation and regulations in force. Over the past few months, the FSMA has, under the powers conferred upon it, also been actively monitoring the implementation of the provisions of the agreement. In order to facilitate the application of the agreement, the FSMA developed in advance, together with the banking sector, a model for the new standardized webpage. At the beginning of January 2024, the new webpages provided for in the agreement were published by the banks, after approval by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-07-23T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">431217</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Continuing Professional Training 2023 for accredited auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/continuing-professional-training-2023-accredited-auditors-0</link>
  <description>
<p>The continuing professional training programme for 2024 will take place in person at the premises of the FSMA (rue du Congrès/Congresstraat 12-14, 1000 Brussels). The programme is spread over two sessions on:</p><ul><li><strong>Tuesday, 19 November 2024</strong> from 2 pm to 5 pm: training session for institutions for occupational retirement provision;</li><li><strong>Tuesday, 26 November 2024</strong> from 2 pm to 5 pm: training session for undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment and regulated real estate companies.</li></ul><p>You can register for the continuing professional training sessions by filling in the attached form by friday <strong>25 October 2024</strong> at the latest and sending it to the following email address: <a href="mailto:eca@fsma.be">eca@fsma.be</a>.&nbsp;&nbsp;Registration is free.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Find out more in our Communication FSMA_2024_11 (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2023_11_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2024_11_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;only)</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Amendment of the FSMA Regulation on the recognition of compliance officers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/amendment-fsma-regulation-recognition-compliance-officers</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA Regulation of 20 December 2023 entered into force on 13 June 2024. It amends the FSMA Regulation of 27 October 2011 on the recognition of compliance officers.</strong></p><p>Today, the FSMA is publishing a communication that briefly points out the main amendments:</p><ul><li>the condition that candidate compliance officers must have at least three years of appropriate experience is relaxed in certain cases for small firms;&nbsp;</li><li><span lang="EN-US">the interim list of compliance officers is replaced by a single list with all relevant information.</span></li></ul><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Please read Communication FSMA_2024_10 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2024_10_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2024_10_fr.pdf">French</a>)</p></div>
</description>

  <description>
<p><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>The FSMA has made some technical updates to&nbsp;</strong></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>the questionnaire to be filled in by the senior management of self-managed beveks/sicavs (investment company with variable capital) for the purpose of reporting on internal control and to the occasional questionnaire for undertakings for collective investment which use the services of a management company.</strong></span></p><p><span lang="EN-US">The updates are intended to improve the data quality in the reports and to facilitate their analysis. The FSMA has also drawn up explanatory texts setting out the way these questionnaires are to be filled in.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-US">The new version of the questionnaires will come into effect for the reports on the financial year ending on 31 December 2024 or later.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>For more information, see FSMA_2019_23 <span lang="EN-US">(available in </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2019_23_fr.pdf"><span lang="EN-US">French</span></a><span lang="EN-US"> and </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2019_23_nl.pdf"><span lang="EN-US">Dutch</span></a><span lang="EN-US">)&nbsp;and&nbsp;FSMA_2019_25 (available in </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2019_25_fr.pdf"><span lang="EN-US">French</span></a><span lang="EN-US"> and </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/fsma_2019_25_nl.pdf"><span lang="EN-US">Dutch</span></a><span lang="EN-US">)</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></p></div>

<item>
  <title>Half-yearly dashboard on investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/half-yearly-dashboard-investment-fraud-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. It publishes a dashboard that provides statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it is publishing the&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/240704_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf"><strong>dashboard</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;for the first semester of 2024.</strong></p><p>This edition of the dashboard focuses notably on the following items:</p><ul><li>Fraudulent trading platforms and cryptocurrency scams still represent about <strong>half</strong> of the reports about unlawful activities received by the FSMA.&nbsp;</li><li>“Recovery room” fraud is on the rise (<strong>59</strong>% increase compared to the same period in 2023).</li><li>The FSMA has noticed a significant increase in the number of consumer reports about unlawful activities in the first half of 2024 (+ <strong>44</strong>% compared to the same period in 2023).</li></ul><p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-07/240704_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf">The&nbsp;dashboard&nbsp;is available on the website of the FSMA.</a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-07-04T08:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">429559</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>In need of quick cash? Don’t get caught</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/need-quick-cash-dont-get-caught</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></p><p>The FSMA <strong>has identified 14 new fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer fake credit to Belgian consumers via the internet. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.) or find advertisements <strong>online</strong>.&nbsp;Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</p><p>In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions.&nbsp;In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firm</strong></a>’ fraud.</p><p>The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</p><p>Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</p><p>Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</p><p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></p><p>The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</p><ul><li><strong>Barivex Union </strong>(www.barivexunion.com)</li><li><strong>Bldn Financing</strong>&nbsp;(www.bldnfinancing.com)</li><li><strong>CST Efinenciën</strong>&nbsp;(www.cst-efinancien.com)</li><li><strong>Dexia Finance</strong> (www.dexiafinance.com)</li><li><strong>Dior Kredit</strong> (https://www.dior-kredit.be)</li><li><strong>EU Consultant Ltd.</strong>&nbsp; (www.euconsultantltd.com)</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Hag Finance</strong> (www.hagfinance.com)</span></li><li><strong>Kaiser Finanz</strong> (https://kaiserfinanz.com)</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Mijn Direct Lening</strong>&nbsp;(https://mijn-directlening.com)</span></li><li><strong>Plus Lening</strong> (https://pluslening.com)</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Snel Direct Krediet</strong> (https://sneldirectkrediet.com)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Snel Geld</strong> (https://snel-geld.com/)</span></li><li><strong>Torfs Groups</strong> (https://torfscapital.com)</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Veilige Lening</strong> (https://veiligelening.com)</span></li></ul><p><span lang="NL-BE"></span></p><p>***</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</p><ul type="disc"><li>Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</li><li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</li><li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li><li><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li><li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person.&nbsp;But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</li></ul><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a> on its website. As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-07-01T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">428231</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title> Offers of investment in precious metals and “ecoparkings”: be vigilant</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/offers-investment-precious-metals-and-ecoparkings-be-vigilant</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Belgian public is once again being approached by companies offering so-called investments in various assets. Belgian consumers have recently been contacted to invest in precious metals or in the deployment of a network of charging stations for electric cars ("ecoparking"). These offers have been made with the promise of very high returns. Remain vigilant, however, because swindlers often lie behind these tempting offers. They do not even hesitate to take on the identity of major players of the energy industry!</strong></p><p>Victims reported to the FSMA that they had received investment offers in<strong>&nbsp;</strong>precious metals (with no physical delivery involved) as well as in ecoparking. These offers are presented as an alternative to traditional savings products, with promises of very high yields. Behind these tempting offers, however, often lie crooks who do not possess the required authorizations and whose sole aim is to steal your savings<strong>.</strong></p><p>Scam victims are often contacted by phone and email. Most of the time, the contacts follow on advertisements that appear on the internet, and in particular on social media and fake news sites.&nbsp;</p><p>Always remain vigilant when physical goods are offered in the form of instruments that make possible a financial investment. These alternative investment products may fall within the scope of the financial legislation that the FSMA is tasked with enforcing. They may thus not be offered to the public under just any conditions!</p><p><strong>In the course of the past few weeks, the FSMA has received reports about:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li><strong>fyamcapital.com</strong>:&nbsp;the fraudsters used the following email addresses:&nbsp;penelope.mary@fyamcapital.com ; finance@fyamcapital.com &nbsp;and elsa.mercier@fyamcapital.com</li><li><strong>monacces.shellrecharges.eu</strong>:&nbsp;the fraudsters used the following email address:&nbsp;serviceclient@shellrecharges.com</li><li><strong>plenitudeeurope.com</strong>:&nbsp;the fraudsters used the following email addresses:&nbsp; eni@plenitudeeurope.com&nbsp;and enisouscription@plenitude-europe.com.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li></ul><p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p><p>Take note: the scammers behind the websites&nbsp;Plenitudeeurope.com and Shellrecharges.eu <strong>take on the identity of, respectively, Eni and Shell, two major players of the energy sector</strong>.</p><p>The FSMA thus <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial service made by the companies listed above and against transferring money</strong> to any bank account number they might mention.&nbsp;</p><p>***</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</h2><ul><li><strong>always check the identity of the company</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.). If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</li><li><strong>always verify if the company in question has the requisite authorization</strong>. To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘cloned firms’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</li></ul><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to <strong>file a complaint with the&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://www.police.be/en/"><strong>local police</strong></a><strong> or with the judicial authorities</strong>.</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-06-28T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">426745</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA is pleased at the good PISA results in financial literacy achieved by Flemish students</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-pleased-good-pisa-results-financial-literacy-achieved-flemish-students</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Fifteen-year-old Flemish students excel in financial literacy, acording to the latest PISA results. The results presented today indicate that Flanders achieved the highest average score of all participating countries. The FSMA is delighted at these fine results and will continue in the coming years to invest a great deal of effort in financial education via its Wikifin programme.</strong></span></p><p><span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/427973"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/427973"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA has adopted a Regulation setting out the modalities for taking the banker’s oath and the applicable rules on the handling of ethical complaints</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-has-adopted-regulation-setting-out-modalities-taking-bankers-oath-and-applicable-rules</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is competent to oversee and follow up on the new legislation on the banker’s oath. On 8 May 2024, the FSMA adopted a Regulation setting out the modalities for taking the banker’s oath and for the acceptance, admissibility and handling of complaints submitted relating to this matter. On 20 June 2024, the Royal Decree approving this FSMA Regulation was published in the Belgian Official Gazette. The FSMA takes this opportunity to provide more detailed explanations as to the swearing of the banker’s oath and the operation of the complaints channel.</strong></p><p><span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/427477"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/427477"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-06-26T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">427477</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA publishes annual report and presents an analysis of the costs charged by funds and of investments made by retail clients</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-annual-report-and-presents-analysis-costs-charged-funds-and-investments-made</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has today published its annual report for 2023. During a webinar, the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, set out two key themes addressed in the report. The first involves the costs charged by investment funds, and the second is the use of data analysis to gain an overview of Belgian retail investors’ holdings in shares, ETFs and options.</strong></p><p>Consumers who wish to invest in funds need to take into account entry charges, management fees and other administrative or operating costs. These costs have considerable impact on the returns they can achieve. Costs contribute to determining the value for money that they can obtain.&nbsp;</p><p>The FSMA seeks to ensure that funds offer value for money. Fund providers are required to give consumers prospects of real returns and not charge unjustifiably high fees. Two years ago, the FSMA presented its first study of this subject. An update of that study illustrates the changes in these costs.&nbsp;</p><p>The FSMA recommends that consumers take a careful look at the funds they are considering investing in if they wish to obtain value for money. “In order to obtain value for their money, consumers need to compare the costs of various funds carefully and identify their impact on the final return,” according to Jean-Paul Servais.&nbsp;</p><p>On the occasion of the presentation of the annual report, the FSMA also set out statistics on the investments made by Belgian retail investors. The figures are based on a data analysis of stock market transaction reports. The study brings to light a number of striking developments:</p><ul><li>Investments in exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have become more and more popular. It is mainly young people who are increasingly investing in these index trackers.</li><li>Belgian retail investors have a very limited selection of shares in their portfolio. More than one in three traded in just one share.</li><li>Of the new investors who began to invest in shares during the Covid-19 crisis in 2020, only one-third were still actively investing in 2023.</li></ul><p>More information is available in the presentation of the webinar (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/20240621_presentation_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/20240621_presentatie_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>) and in a video message (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/manage/videos/964163862">French</a> - <a href="https://vimeo.com/manage/videos/964251165">Dutch</a>), in which Jean-Paul Servais sets out some of the most important topics in the annual report.&nbsp;</p><p>The 2023 annual report is available on the website of the FSMA (for now in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/rapports-anuels/rapport-annuel-2023">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/jaarverslagen/jaarverslag-2023">Dutch</a>).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-06-21T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">426496</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Insurance Commission opinion on a draft royal decree on the information obligations of insurers with regard to costs charged on insurance products eligible for tax reductions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/insurance-commission-opinion-draft-royal-decree-information-obligations-insurers-regard-costs</link>
  <description>
<p>At the request of Mr Pierre-Yves Dermagne, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Economy and Employment, the Insurance Commission issued an opinion on 24 May 2024 (DOC/C2024/2) on a draft royal decree on the information obligations of insurers with regard to costs charged on insurance products that are eligible for tax reductions as set out in Article 145<sup>1</sup>, 2° and 5° of the Income Tax Code 1992.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in Opinion C/2024/02… <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/advice_c_2024_2.pdf">(in Dutch and French only)</a>&nbsp;</p></div><p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">426030</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: FSMA’s operating costs 2024</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-fsmas-operating-costs-2024</link>
  <description>
<h3>Important information on the notices to pay issued to intermediaries.</h3><p>In this newsletter, the FSMA provides details about the notice to pay the contributions to the FSMA’s operating costs for the 2024 financial year.</p><p>You will receive such a notice to pay in the <strong>second half of the month of June 2024</strong>.</p><p>What is new in comparison to last year is that you will receive the notice to pay directly and individually at the work email address that you indicated in your registration file.<br>&nbsp;</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>More information is available in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/2024-06_nieuwsbrief_werkingskosten_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/2024-06_newsletter_fraisdefonctionnement_fr.pdf">French</a> only).</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Online advertising of savings products with very enticing returns? Watch out for scammers posing as banks</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/online-advertising-savings-products-very-enticing-returns-watch-out-scammers-posing-banks</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Fraudsters continue to usurp the identity of major banks and other financial institutions in order to catch consumers off guard. Despite several warnings against this phenomenon since 2021, the FSMA noticed that this type of fraud is still taking victims today.</strong></p><p>The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone or by email without having taken any prior initiative themselves or after having entered their contact details on an online form.&nbsp;Such forms are frequently offered to consumers on social media, via advertisements or sponsored publications.</p><p>The fraudsters then offer consumers&nbsp;<strong>savings plans</strong>&nbsp;with the promise of returns in excess of market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end, the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money.</p><p>Fraudsters usurp the names of well-known banks and financial institutions to deceive consumers.&nbsp;<strong>The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:</strong>&nbsp;</p><ul><li><strong>Axa Banque</strong>,&nbsp;using email addresses ending with&nbsp;@axa-europe-patrimoine.com;&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Banque Transatlantique</strong>,&nbsp;using email addresses ending with&nbsp;@transatlantique-patrimoine.com; &nbsp;</li><li><strong>Caixabank</strong>; &nbsp;</li><li><strong>Deutsche Bank</strong>;</li><li><strong>ING Bank</strong>, using the e-mail address ing-lu@clients-info.com;&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Trade Republic Bank</strong>, using the website https://web.app-traderepublic.com/ and email addresses ending with @contact-republic.com, @gestion-republic.com and @traderepublic-inv.com;</li><li><strong>Wise Europe</strong>, using the website https://acces.wtb-management.com/ and email addresses ending with @wtb-privatemanagement.com, @wiseconformite.com and wise@europeeligibilite.com.</li></ul><p>Fraudsters might also usurp the names of other financial institutions.</p><p>The fraudsters may also use this technique to offer other banking services to consumers, and in particular <strong>offers of</strong> <strong>credit</strong>. In the latter case, the scam is based on the payment of <strong>fees</strong> that are supposedly necessary to obtain credit. The FSMA refers consumers to its&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-watch-out-scams-0">warnings</a>&nbsp;against “fake credit” fraud.</p><h2><strong>How to avoid this trap?</strong></h2><ul><li>Be wary when you receive <strong>unsolicited investment proposals</strong> via social media or over the phone, especially when you are promised <strong>disproportionate returns</strong>. Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li><li><strong>Always ensure that you are in contact with the legitimate company</strong>. Compare contact details through the licensing register of the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/search?s=">FSMA</a> or the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.nbb.be/en/financial-oversight/general/search/search-intermediary-or-registered-company">National Bank of Belgium</a>. Always check the websites and e-mail addresses.&nbsp;</li><li>Be wary of requests to pay money into <strong>bank accounts in countries that have nothing to do</strong> with the supposed registered office of the company that approaches you, or your own place of residence.</li></ul><p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>, please feel free to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify the FSMA should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><h2><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></h2><p>If you think you have been the victim of fraud,&nbsp;make sure you&nbsp;<strong>do not pay any additional sums to your contact person</strong>.&nbsp;Please note, this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p><p>Also, <strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a>&nbsp;immediately to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA&nbsp;to the scam</strong>&nbsp;via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p><p>The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly</strong>&nbsp;and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-06-13T08:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">423540</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Jean-Paul Servais re-elected Chairman of IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/jean-paul-servais-re-elected-chairman-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, has been re-elected Chairman of the Board of IOSCO, the international organisation of financial markets supervisors. He has held this position since 2022 and his new term will be for two years.</strong></p><p>The International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) is currently holding its annual meeting in Athens, where Jean-Paul Servais was re-elected. Before becoming Chairman in 2022, he had been Vice-Chairman of the organisation since 2016.</p><p>IOSCO was founded in 1983 and brings together 130 authorities supervising 95% of the world's financial markets. The purpose of the organisation is to promote cooperation between market supervisory authorities and to develop standards and best practices at international level.&nbsp;</p><p>Jean-Paul Servais was also re-elected this year as Chairman of IOSCO's European Regional Committee (ERC), one of the organisation's four regional committees. He has held this position since 2014. The European Regional Committee brings together the 52 European members of IOSCO.&nbsp;</p><p>After his re-election, Jean-Paul Servais thanked the IOSCO Board for its confidence and looked ahead to his new mandate:</p><blockquote><p>“<em>When I was first elected, I highlighted the importance of moving at pace on priorities such as sustainability disclosures and the crypto-asset market. I am proud to say IOSCO achieved its objectives. Under my second mandate, we will need to persevere including through a focus on implementation of our newly established standards. It is a privilege to serve IOSCO’s Board as its Chair and I am honoured to have been re-elected for a further term. I would like to thank the members of the Board for their confidence and I look forward to continuing our collaboration. The renewal of my mandate as Chairman of IOSCO is also recognition of the quality of FSMA's work and the excellent reputation it enjoys internationally</em>.”</p></blockquote><p>See also&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS733.pdf?v=1">the IOSCO press release</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-05-28T13:54:27+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">421321</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Look out for traps: beware of these fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/look-out-traps-beware-these-fraudulent-trading-platforms</link>
  <description>
<p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is once again drawing the public's attention to the phenomenon of fraudulent trading platforms and their dangers. These platforms are all over the internet, trying to lure investors with promises of quick and easy earnings. However, behind these tantalizing offers, there are often sophisticated scams that can lead to significant losses.</strong></p><p>&nbsp;</p><div class="box"><h3><strong>How does a fraudulent trading platform work? (</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_q4_schema_en.pdf"><strong>flowchart</strong></a><strong>)</strong></h3><ol><li><strong>Modes of contact:</strong> Fraudsters use various techniques to contact their victims: a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/warning-can-you-get-rich-just-few-clicks">fake news article</a> that mentions a celebrity, <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-trading-platforms-how-fraudsters-obtain-your-data">online advertisements</a>, a fake account on social media, a dating app or even a “lost” message. In each case, the platform attracts investors by promising them very high returns in a short time, often well beyond the sorts of gains that are realistic.</li><li><strong>Registration: </strong>Interested investors register on the platform and deposit funds to their trading account. Most of the time, investors begin with a relatively small sum (e.g. €250). In some cases, the swindlers offer to help victims by taking over their computer remotely in order to make certain transfers on their behalf, which also allows them to use viruses and spyware, for example.</li><li><strong>Manipulation and pressure tactics:</strong> Once the funds have been deposited by the victim, the platform will manipulate the transactions to give the impression of significant profits. These earnings are fictitious, and the funds have not really been invested. The fraudsters then put pressure on their victims to invest more and more money (repeated phone calls, time-limited offers, threats, etc.).</li><li><strong>Withdrawals are impossible:</strong> An initial withdrawal of a small amount is sometimes possible, thereby giving victims more confidence. However, once an investor wishes to withdraw a larger amount, the fraudsters use various pretexts not to make it possible (high costs, taxes owing, etc.). In the end, the fraudulent platform disappears, taking with it all the investors’ money.&nbsp;</li></ol></div><p><strong>The FSMA is warning today against different websites that have recently appeared:</strong></p><p>The FSMA has noted that the following websites were putting consumers in touch with fraudulent trading platforms:</p><ul type="disc"><li><strong>Algo Education</strong> (http://algoeducation.io/);</li><li><strong>Bitcode Method</strong> (https://bitcode-method.com/; https://bitcodemethod.org/; https://bitcode-ai.live/);</li><li><strong>Immediate Peak</strong> (https://immediatepeak.io/;&nbsp;https://immediatepeak.com; https://immediatepeak.net; https://immediatefuture.io; immediate-peak.com; https://immediatepeak.org);</li><li><strong>Immediate Intal</strong> (https://immediateintal.com/; https://immediate-intal.co/; https://immediateintalai.com/);</li><li><strong>Immediate Vortex</strong> (https://immediatevortex.io; https://immediate-vortex.com/; https://immediatevortex.co/).</li></ul><p>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by the following trading platforms:</p><ul type="disc"><li><strong>4xai</strong> (https://4xai.net/);</li><li><strong>BFTCapitals/BFTCapitalspro</strong> (http://bftcapitals.com; https://www.bftcapitalspro.com/);</li><li><strong>Bitlet</strong> (https://bitlet.net/);</li><li><strong>Bitnomics</strong> (https://bitnomics.co);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>BNP Groups</strong> (cloned firm) (https://bnpgroups.co.uk/);</li><li><strong>Chronovalor</strong> (https://www.chronovalor.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>CMCapitals</strong> (cloned firm) (https://cmcapitals.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Coinsbit</strong> (https://coinsbit.io/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>CryptoCom</strong> <strong>AI</strong> (cloned firm) (https://crypto-com.ai);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>DCY Markets</strong> (https://dcymarkets.com/);</li><li><strong>Easy Trade</strong> (http://easy-trade.uk/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Fortnomics</strong> (https://www.fortnomics.com/);</li><li><strong>FX Margine</strong> (https://fxmargine.com/);</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>GMT Direct</strong> (https://gmtdirect.com/);&nbsp;</span></li><li><strong>High BTC Stock</strong> (https://www.highbtcstock.com/);</li><li><strong>Invotrade</strong> (https://invotrade.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Lasbert</strong> (https://lasbert.net/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Omega Capital Markets</strong> (https://omegacm.net; https://www.omega-cm.net/);</li><li><strong>Opti Market Exchange</strong> (https://ome1.vip; http://www.ome2.vip/);</li><li><strong>Parenta Financal Services Ltd</strong> (https://www.parentafinancialservicesltd.com/);</li><li><strong>Promarket AI</strong> (https://promarket-ai.com/; https://promrk-ai.com/; https://tradingacc-globalic.com/en; https://web.halving-trade.org/; https://web.hlv-trade.com/auth/login; https://pro-mrketai.com/);</li><li><strong>Quopi</strong> (https://quopi.ai/; https://quopi.app/);</li><li><strong>Sense traders</strong> (https://sense-traders.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Sfcap/Safecap Investments/Finalto </strong>(https://webtrader.sfcap.trade/)</li><li><strong>SkyTarget Ltd</strong> (https://www.skytargetltd.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Swiss-Vests</strong> (https://swiss-vests.com/);</li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>TigersFM</strong> (https://www.tigersfm.com/);</span></li><li><strong>Titanwealth24</strong> (https://www.titanwealth24.com/);&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Tradex4u</strong> (https://tradex4u.com/);</li><li><strong>Verify Markets</strong> (www.verify-markets.com);</li><li><strong>Vourteige</strong> (https://www.vourteige.com/, http://www.vourteige.capital/);</li><li><strong>XHPX</strong> (https://xhpxpro.com/).</li></ul><p><strong>I’ve fallen victim. What should I do?&nbsp;</strong></p><ol type="1"><li><strong>Stop making any transactions and break off all contact with the platform:</strong> Do not deposit any more money and do not provide any additional personal or financial information. Break off all contact with the fraudsters. They may try to manipulate you in order to take even more money from you.</li><li><strong>Contact your bank: </strong>Inform your bank immediately if you have made any payments to the fraudulent platform.</li><li><strong>Report the fraud to the competent authorities:</strong>&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">Contact the FSMA</a> and file a complaint with the police.</li><li><strong>Document all the messages and transactions:</strong> Gather together all the evidence of communications with the platform, including emails, messages, account statements and screen captures of transactions. These items will be valuable when you report the fraud.</li><li><strong>Beware of 'recovery rooms':&nbsp;</strong>The latter is a practice that consists of contacting people who have been victims of a scam in the past and offering them services that will supposedly recover your lost money, for a fee.&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">Often, these constitute yet another case of fraud.</a></li></ol><p>For more information, please consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud</a>' page on the FSMA website. The site provides additional tips to help you avoid investment fraud.&nbsp;Please watch our awareness-raising videos as well&nbsp;(available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-prevention">French</a> and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/preventiefilms">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-05-16T08:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">416202</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA participates in extensive prevention campaign against online investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-participates-extensive-prevention-campaign-against-online-investment-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p>Fraudulent investment offers are increasingly being made online, mainly via social media. Every year, consumers lose vast sums of money to this widespread phenomenon.</p><p>According to reports received by the FSMA, Belgian consumers have already lost more than 2 million euros to online fraud in the first quarter of 2024. Like other players in the sector, the FSMA is actively seeking to combat this phenomenon by both preventive and punitive measures taken on various fronts.</p><h2><strong>Extensive prevention campaign&nbsp;</strong></h2><p>The FSMA recently joined forces with other authorities involved in combatting online investment fraud. Together, they prepared a video to raise awareness among the public and help them avoid falling into the traps laid by fraudsters. The video is a joint initiative by the Belgian professional association representing the banking sector, Febelfin; the Federal Judicial Police; Safe on Web; and the FSMA.</p><p>You can watch the report below. There is also a&nbsp;<a href="https://vimeo.com/manage/videos/939443689">teaser</a>.</p>
<div>&nbsp;</div></description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-26T11:32:42+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">414262</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against recovery room fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-recovery-room-fraud-1</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is again warning the Belgian public against recovery room fraud.&nbsp;</strong></p><p class="rtejustify"><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">Recovery room fraud </a>is a practice whereby fraudsters offer to help&nbsp;<strong>victims of investment fraud</strong>&nbsp;to obtain compensation for their losses or to&nbsp;<strong>recover their lost assets</strong>.&nbsp;</p><p class="rtejustify">Generally, the fraudsters contact their victims by phone or by e-mail. The FSMA has noted, however, that victims sometimes come into contact with the so-called ‘recovery rooms’ while conducting internet searches or via social media. When introducing themselves, fraudsters and their companies pass themselves off as law firms or accountants, and sometimes as police services or financial supervisors. The fraudsters do not hesitate to misuse the identity information of existing companies or official institutions in order to appear trustworthy.</p><p class="rtejustify">The fraudsters charge a&nbsp;<strong>fee</strong>&nbsp;for their services. Victims of investment fraud must&nbsp;<strong>pay the fee in advance</strong>. This is a clear indication that it is a recovery room. The payment is demanded, for example, allegedly to cover certain administrative or legal costs or to pay taxes. These are purely&nbsp;<strong>fictitious costs</strong>, however.&nbsp;</p><p class="rtejustify">In some other cases, fraudsters pretend to offer <strong>free</strong> services. The victim only has to give an access to her computer via a remote desktop application (such as Anydesk). In this way, fraudsters can install spywares on the consumers’ computers or access their PC-Bankings.&nbsp;</p><p class="rtejustify">Fraudsters also sometimes ask their victims to create and activate a wallet on a cryptoplatform.&nbsp;</p><p class="rtejustify">In all cases, fraudsters manage to steal money from consumers. Once the fraudsters have received the fees, they disappear without a trace and it is almost impossible to recover the amounts paid. <strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p><ul><li>Apag-Audit AG (https://apag-audit.org/)</li><li>Claim Justice (https://claim-justice.com/)&nbsp;</li><li>Crypto Conduct Authority (https://commission-cca.com/)</li><li>Etoro (Torocoin – Cloned firm) (https://toroc.io/)</li><li>FXVC (Cloned Firm)</li><li>Global Get Back (http://globalgetback.com/)</li><li>IFP Center (https://ifp.center/; www.ifp.center)</li><li>NCSC (Cloned Firm)</li><li>Trading Center (http://trading-center.co/)&nbsp;</li><li>Ucoin Capital (https://ucoincapital.com)&nbsp;</li><li>VaxCo (www.vaxco.io; www.vaxco.co; www.vaxco.org)</li></ul><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">Victims of investment fraud are often targeted twice by the same fraudsters: first the latter perpetrate investment fraud, and thereafter, recovery room fraud. The persons behind the investment fraud may also sell their victims’ contact information on to other fraudsters.&nbsp;<strong>Anyone who has ever been a victim of investment fraud needs to be aware that fraudsters may target their victims again or sell their personal data on to others.</strong></p><h3><strong>How can you recognize and avoid recovery room fraud?</strong></h3><ul type="disc"><li>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, we advise you always to&nbsp;<strong>file a complaint</strong>&nbsp;with the local police.</li><li>Be extremely careful if you find an advertisement on&nbsp;<strong>social media or the internet</strong>, which offers to recover funds you have lost.</li><li>If you receive&nbsp;<strong>unsolicited phone calls&nbsp;</strong>with an offer to recover funds you have lost, be sure to ask how that person found out that you have lost money. Reports of fraud are shared only with the judicial authorities and not with private companies.</li><li>If you are asked to&nbsp;<strong>pay a set fee in advance, to access your computer or to activate a wellet on a cryptoplatform,</strong> don’t respond but terminate all contact.</li><li><strong>Financial supervisors&nbsp;</strong>such as the FSMA are not authorized to recover lost money and would therefore not take the initiative to contact victims of investment fraud.</li></ul><p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-25T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">413607</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA launches cost calculator for pension products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-cost-calculator-pension-products</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Today, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is launching an online tool that provides an overview of the costs of pension products. The tool was developed following a study carried out by the FSMA at the request of the Belgian government in which it looked at the costs charged by financial institutions for their pension products. The study examined both second and third pillar pensions. The report presenting the findings of the study is available on the FSMA website (in </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/2024_etude_couts_pillier2-3.pdf"><strong>French</strong></a><strong> and </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/2024_onderzoek_kosten_pijler2-3.pdf"><strong>Dutch</strong></a><strong> only).</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/410854">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/410854">Dutch</a> site.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-24T13:52:01+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

  <title>Authorization for statutory auditors – call for applications</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/authorization-statutory-auditors-call-applications</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA is conducting a process for the authorization of statutory auditors who intend to carry out an audit mandate at undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment, regulated real estate companies and institutions for occupational retirement provision.&nbsp;</p><p>Applications must be submitted to the FSMA by mail to the following address: <a href="mailto:eca@fsma.be">eca@fsma.be</a>, <strong>by 2 September 2024 at the latest.</strong> This e-mail shall include all documents of the application file.</p><div class="box box-tip"><p><span>Read more in the communication FSMA_2024_09 (available in </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/fsma_2024_09_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/fsma_2024_09_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p></div>

<item>
  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-5</link>
  <description>
<p><span>This circular FSMA_2024_08 (available in&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/fsma_2024_08_fr.pdf"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/fsma_2024_08_nl.pdf"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;only) informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</span></p>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudsters claim to be employees of the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudsters-claim-be-employees-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against fraudsters who claim to be employees of the FSMA.</strong></p><p>These fraudsters claim that the FSMA can help victims of investment fraud to recover or unblock the money they lost. For this service, the fraudsters ask the victims for compensation or for the payment of a tax to the FSMA. This form of fraud is called&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-room">recovery room fraud</a>. The fraudsters also usurp the FSMA’s logo in order to engage in ‘phishing’, in an attempt to elicit personal or confidential information from consumers.</p><p>The fraudsters contact victims by telephone or email. They claim to be a staff member or director of the FSMA. In an attempt to lend credibility to their claim, they use the FSMA’s logo in their documents.</p><div class="box box-info"><p><strong>The FSMA will never contact you out of the blue or ask you to transfer money. Nor will it ever ask you for confidential information such as the PIN code of your bank card or a password.&nbsp;</strong></p></div><p>The fraudsters use the following email addresses, among others: info@fsmacontact.online, support@billingfsma.com and support@fsma.co. <strong>Emails from these or similar addresses are fraudulent</strong>. Do not respond to such emails but delete them. The emails do not come from the FSMA. The official email addresses of the FSMA always end with <strong>@fsma.be</strong>. <span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p><strong>Consumers who receive unsolicited emails must be extremely careful.</strong> Be sure not to respond to any requests to transfer money for (financial) services or products that the FSMA is said to offer. <span lang="EN-GB"></span></p><p>The FSMA is not a financial institution. It does not offer consumers any financial services or products. The FSMA is not competent to recover lost investments or to ask for payment for any such a service. Nor is it competent to demand payment for taxes. It will never contact investors in this regard. The FSMA will also never ask consumers to provide their financial information or to pay for any services.&nbsp;</p>
<div class="box box-tip"><h2>Any doubts about the person who has contacted you? Check the information about the FSMA here.</h2><h3>These are the official contact details for the FSMA:</h3><ul><li>Website: <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">www.fsma.be</a></li><li>Adress: <span>Rue du Congrès/Congresstraat 12-14, 1000 Brussels</span></li><li>Company number: 0544.279.965</li><li>Our phone numbers always begin with +32 (0)2 220 XX XX.&nbsp;</li><li>Our emails end with @fsma.be.&nbsp;</li></ul><h3>These are the FSMA’s official social media addresses:</h3><ul><li>LinkedIn:&nbsp;<a href="https://be.linkedin.com/company/fsma">linkedin.com/company/fsma</a></li><li>X (Twitter):&nbsp;<a href="https://twitter.com/FSMA_info">twitter.com/FSMA_info</a>&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">electronic consumer contact form</a>.</p></div></description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-18T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">412236</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter for AML compliance officers: Anti-money laundering and combating the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-aml-compliance-officers-anti-money-laundering-and-combating-financing-terrorism</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In the latest edition of the AMLCO newsletter, the FSMA draws your attention to the communication published by the Belgian Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CTIF-CFI) regarding its new web portal for reporting suspicious transactions. The FSMA also wishes to inform you that the European Banking Authority (EBA) has amended its Guidelines on risk-based supervision and its Guidelines on ML/TF risk factors, in order to take into account upcoming risks in the crypto-asset service sector. The FSMA takes these guidelines into consideration in its risk-based supervision. The guidelines on risk factors also apply to you and you are required to take every possible measure to comply with them. Lastly, the FSMA announces the launch of its 2024 questionnaire about preventing ML/TF and reminds you, under the heading of “miscellaneous” that as an entity under supervision, you have electronic access to the UBO register.</strong></p><ul type="disc"><li><span lang="EN-US">New 'goAML' portal for reporting suspicious transactions to the Belgian Financial Processing Unit (CTIF-CFI)</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Amendments to two EBA guidelines in order to take into account specific risks in the crypto-asset service sector</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE">Periodic questionnaire for 2024 on preventing ML/TF</span><span lang="NL-BE"></span></li><li><span>Miscellaneous&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><ul type="circle"><li><span lang="EN-US">Your access, as an entity under supervision, to the UBO register</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">A word about AML/CFT colleges</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li><li><span lang="EN-US">Evaluation of Belgium by the FATF-GAFI</span><span lang="EN-US"></span></li></ul></li></ul><div class="box box-small box-info"><p>Find out more in the newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/2024-04-16_newsletter_amlco_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-04/2024-04-16_newsletter_amlco_fr.pdf">French</a>)</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-16T09:59:12+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">411783</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA launches the ‘FSMA Academy’, an innovative training programme!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-fsma-academy-innovative-training-programme</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In order to contribute to raising the awareness of professionals in the financial sector of the rules subject to its competence, the FSMA is launching its own training programme: the&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://academy.fsma.be"><strong>FSMA Academy</strong></a><strong>. In ten sessions, participants will be given a chance to deepen their knowledge about key topics in the current financial landscape: sustainable finance, crypto-assets, rules of conduct, markets, investment funds, etc. The sessions will be taught by experts from among the FSMA staff as well as by top national and international speakers. Registration is now open.</strong></p><p>As part of its mandate to serve the public interest, the FSMA has designed an innovative training programme for professionals in the financial sector. In ten evening sessions between September and December 2024, which take place at the premises of the FSMA, participants will learn more about various topics that are crucial to working in the current financial landscape:</p><ul><li>The role, mandates and challenges of the FSMA</li><li>Sustainable finance and the fight against greenwashing</li><li>Data analytics and financial supervision</li><li>Cryptocurrencies</li><li>The financial markets</li><li>Combatting money laundering and terrorist financing</li><li>Investment funds</li><li>Rules of conduct</li><li>Financial education</li><li>Hot topics</li></ul><p>Participants will receive presentations by experts from among the FSMA staff as well as national and international guest speakers invited for the occasion.</p><p>This innovative initiative on the part of the FSMA is aimed at raising awareness among professionals of the various rules in force in the financial sector. Participants in the programme will also have the opportunity of engaging in discussions with each other and share good practices.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p><strong>Registration is now open:&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://academy.fsma.be"><strong>academy.fsma.be</strong></a><strong>. Space is limited.</strong></p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-16T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">410606</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Updated Fit & Proper handbook for IORPs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/updated-fit-proper-handbook-iorps</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published an update to its Handbook on the fit &amp; proper questionnaires for regulated functions at an institution for occupational retirement provision (‘IORP’).</p><p>The new handbook (FSMA_2024_06) replaces Handbook FSMA_2019_16 dated 17 July 2019 (titled “Questionnaires to be used for appointments of members of operational bodies and key function holders and when appointing a statutory auditor and liquidator”).</p><p>The update was needed in order to take into account experience on the ground in recent years, but does not contain any substantially new elements. In the handbook, the FSMA explains how to use the questionnaires that IORPs have to fill in in order to enable the FSMA to assess whether members of governing bodies and key function holders at the IORP have the necessary professional integrity and appropriate expertise to be able to carry out their functions. The Handbook also contains practical guidelines and clarifications on a number of frequently asked question in this regard.</p><div class="box box-small box-tip"><p>Read more in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-06/fsma_2024_06_en.pdf">Handbook FSMA_2024_06</a>&nbsp;</p></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-04-03T07:23:57+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">408661</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Queen Mathilde teaches young pupils via a game how to handle money</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/queen-mathilde-teaches-young-pupils-game-how-handle-money</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-US"><strong>On the occasion of Money Week, Her Majesty Queen Mathilde visited two primary schools today. With the pupils, she discovered the new Wikifin game called ‘The ABCs of Budgetting’. In this game, pupils in years one and two of primary school learn to handle money in a fun way. With her visit to the schools, Her Majesty emphasizes the importance of financial education from the youngest age and lends her support to Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme.</strong></span></p><p><span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/404949"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/404949"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
<figure class="media media--image">

<item>
  <title>Approval of the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/approval-modified-market-rules-regulated-markets-organized-euronext-nvsa-9</link>
  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved on 27 February 2024 in accordance with Article 34, §1, of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU. These market rules enter into force as of 18 March 2024.&nbsp;</p><p>The market rules are available on <a href="https://www.euronext.com/en/regulation/regulated-markets">Euronext's website</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-03-18T11:21:18+01:00</pubDate>
