    <guid isPermaLink="false">410605</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>In need of quick cash? Beware of fake credit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/need-quick-cash-beware-fake-credit-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></p><p>The FSMA <strong>has identified 56 new fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer fake credit to Belgian consumers via the internet. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.) or find advertisements <strong>online</strong>.&nbsp;Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</p><p>In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions.&nbsp;In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firm</strong></a>’ fraud.</p><p>The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</p><p>Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</p><p>Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</p><p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></p><p>The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</p><ul><li><span><strong>Acarix Groupe</strong> (https://acarix-groupe.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Andenne Assur</strong> (cloned firm) (https://andenne-assur.com)</span></li><li><span><strong>Axu Finance</strong> (https://axu-finance.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Balaskas Krediet</strong> (https://k-balaskas.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Batys &amp; services</strong> (https://batyx-services.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Be Snel financien</strong> (https://be-snelfinancien.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Bosphore Credit Sprl/Finloan Services</strong> (www.finloan-services.com)</span></li><li><span><strong>CF Services plus</strong> (https://cf-services-plus.com)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Chrono Inter Krediet</strong> (https://chronointerkrediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Consulting lener</strong> (https://consulting-lener.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Courtage Express</strong> (https://courtage-express.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Credipex</strong> (https://credipex.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL"></span><span lang="NL"><strong>Direct Geldkrediet</strong> (https://direct-geldkrediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL"></span><span lang="NL"><strong>EGS Geld</strong> (https://egs-geld.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Esay Loan</strong> (https://www.esayloan-online.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Eurlening&nbsp;</strong>(https://eurleningltd.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Evok Finances</strong> (https://evok-finances.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Extramex Geld</strong> (https://extramexgeld.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Finaid Services</strong> (www.finaid-services.com)</span></li><li><span><strong>Financement Rapid</strong> (http://financement-rapid.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Financial Network</strong> (https://www.financial-network.net/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Finanza espresso</strong> (https://finanza-espresso.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Fino Concept</strong> (https://finoconcept.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Flexibel Financieren</strong> (https://flexibelfinancieren.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Geld snel krediet</strong> (https://geldsnel-krediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Geno Krediet</strong> (https://geno-krediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Groot Krediet</strong> (https://grootkrediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Grueland</strong> (https://www.grueland.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>inb-service</strong> (https://inb-service.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Invest Group Finance</strong> (https://investgroupfinance.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Joafino</strong> (https://www.joafino.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Krediet consolidatie</strong> (https://kredietconsolidatie.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Krediethub</strong> (https://krediethub.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Kredit Express</strong> (https://www.mykreditexpress.com)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Kredit Service</strong> (https://kredietservice24h.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Kreditline</strong> (https://kredit-line.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Kredits Now</strong> (https://www.kreditsnow.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Lenen Krediet</strong> (https://lenen-krediet.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Mevakelunix</strong> (https://mevakelunix.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Mijn Krediet Devoght</strong> (https://mijn-kredietdevoght.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Mirakel Compass</strong> (https://mirakelcompass.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Mosaic Credit Solutions</strong> (https://creditmosaicsolutions.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Mutuel Group</strong> (https://mutuel-finances-groupe.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>My Best Finance</strong> (https://mybest-finance.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Navex Group</strong> (https://navex-group.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Network Influences</strong> (https://networkinfluences-invest.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Prestatie Financieel</strong> (https://prestatie-fiancieel.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Prestig Unie</strong> (https://prestig-vereniging.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Prestige Krediet</strong> (https://prestigekrediet.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Prêteur privé Gautier</strong> (https://preteurprive-gautier.eu/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Sanlem krediet</strong> (https://sanlem-krediet.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>SNF Solution</strong> (https://cfnsolution.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Social Finance Plus</strong> (https://socialfinanceplus.com/)</span></li><li><span><strong>Viari Services</strong> (https://viariservices.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"></span><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Vlot lenen</strong> (https://bkrvrijleven.com/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"></span><span lang="EN-US"><strong>World Start Bank</strong> (http://worldstartbk.com/)</span><span lang="EN-GB"></span></li></ul><p>***</p><p>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</p><ul type="disc"><li>Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</li><li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</li><li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li><li><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li><li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person.&nbsp;But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</li></ul><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a> on its website. As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Money Week 2024: more than 125,000 pupils to take part and Wikifin goes on the road across the country</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/money-week-2024-more-125000-pupils-take-part-and-wikifin-goes-road-across-country</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The ninth edition of Money Week will begin next Monday. This is an annual themed week organized by Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme. The purpose of the week is to provide opportunities to talk about money matters as widely as possible and to devote extra attention to the importance of financial education. During this year’s Money Week, the FSMA will launch a roadshow during which Wikifin will criss-cross Belgium over several months. In addition, a total of more than 125,000 elementary and secondary school pupils will take part in various activities on the theme of money. This is an increase of 25,000 over the number of participants last year. A brief overview of all the activities is available in </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/401953"><strong>French</strong></a><strong> and </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/401953"><strong>Dutch</strong></a><strong>.</strong></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-03-15T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">401953</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The Chairman of the Belgian Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) and IOSCO Board Chair Jean-Paul Servais has been re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee of the international organization IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-belgian-financial-services-and-markets-authority-fsma-and-iosco-board-chair-jean-paul</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The members of the IOSCO European Regional Committee have re-elected Jean-Paul Servais for a two-year term as chair of the European Regional Committee. He&nbsp;combines this responsibility with the Chairmanship of the IOSCO Board since October 2022.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>The ERC convenes 52 members across Europe and enables information sharing and promotes cooperation. The ERC provides an opportunity to discuss issues in relation to IOSCO’s policy work on digital and sustainable finance. It is an influential voice within IOSCO for risk identification purposes as well as an important channel to promote implementation of IOSCO standards. The ERC is also a forum to&nbsp;learn from each other, as the recent&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-european-regional-committee-fsma">ERC Workshop on Supervisory Technologies</a> (SupTech) demonstrated. During the workshop organised at the FSMA in December 2023, ERC Members shared experiences on real-world cases in which they successfully apply new technologies in supervisory activities.&nbsp;</p><blockquote><p>Jean-Paul Servais: “<em>It is an honour to be re-elected for a new term as Chair of the European Regional Committee. This important position allows the FSMA to play an active role in the international debates about financial regulation that is constantly evolving and has an impact on Belgian financial regulation. I truly believe my responsibilities, as IOSCO Board Chair and ERC Chair are complimentary and mutually beneficial for the ERC and the IOSCO Board</em>.”</p></blockquote><p>IOSCO was founded in 1983 and comprises 130 supervisory authorities, which are involved in various capacities in the supervision of 95% of the global financial sector. The objective of the organization is to promote cooperation among market supervisors and to develop international standards and best practices.</p><p>IOSCO has four regional committees. The European Regional Committee brings together the 52 European members of IOSCO. The Committee discusses IOSCO initiatives that relate to the strengthening of worldwide standards for financial markets, with particular attention to matters that are of relevance to Europe.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-03-14T10:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">403874</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of these new fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-these-new-fraudulent-trading-platforms-3</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA has continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Such trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a specific investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts. Furthermore, many trading platforms use WhatsApp and Telegram.</p><p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/pyramid-schemes">pyramid scheme</a>.</p><p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;They often claim to hold an authorization by a fake financial authority, displaying it so as to seem trustworthy. Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p><p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p><ul><li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li><li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li></ul><p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the investors’ funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their money because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p><p>***</p><p>The FSMA noticed that the following websites for trading softwares and courses refer to fraudulent online trading platforms:</p><ul><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Bitcoineer</strong> (https://btceer.com/; https://bitcoineer-official.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Admirria&nbsp;</strong>(https://admirria.com/; https://admirria.tech/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Immediate Alpha</strong> (https://immediatealphaapp.com/; https://immediate-alpha-app.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Immediate Bitwave</strong> (https://immediatebitwave.com/);&nbsp;</span></li><li><strong>Traderai</strong> (https://traderai.me/, https://traderai.io).</li></ul><p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p><ul><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Absolutecoinmarkets</strong> (https://absolutecoinmarkets.com);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Advanced Traders</strong> (https://advanced-traders.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Arbitrage Genius&nbsp;</strong>(https://arbitrage-genius.ai/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Assets Premium</strong> (cloned firm) (https://assets-premium.com)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>ATB Markets Pro</strong> (http://www.atbmarketspro.com/; https://atbmarkets.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Bitcoin Knight</strong> (cloned firm) (https://trade.bitcoin-knight.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>CFX Fund</strong> (https://cfxfund.com/; https://www.cfx-fund.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>City Markets</strong> (www.city-markets.com; www.city-markets.io);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Coinexmax</strong> (cloned firm) (https://coinexmax.org/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Coscoin</strong> (https://coscoins.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>CTRL Investments</strong> (https://www.ctrl-investments.cc/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Dax.Pro</strong> (https://www.dax.pro/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Digital Century</strong> (http://digital-century.net/; http://digital-century.co/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>DOEX</strong> (cloned firm) (https://doexgf.co/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>EdgeFinance</strong> <strong>Ltd</strong> (https://edgefinance.ltd/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Equities Reserves</strong> (https://equitiesreserves.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Exopip</strong> (https://www.exopip.com/);</span></li><li><strong>Flaregain</strong> (http://flaregain.com/; https://platform.flaregain-tech.com/; https://flaregain.io/);</li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>FMasters</strong> (https://fmasters.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Fundiza</strong> (https://fundiza.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>FVP Trade</strong> (https://fvptrade.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Golden Currencies</strong> (http://(client.)golden-currencies.net/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Hfinvest</strong> (https://hfinvest.net/; https://hedgefunds.website/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Ibplatform</strong> (http://ibplatform.tech/; http://ibplatform.info/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Intrafund</strong> (https://www.intrafund.com/; https://www.intrafund2.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Ixxen</strong> (https://ixxen.com/);</span><strong><span lang="EN-US"></span></strong></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>JBY Capital&nbsp;</strong>(https://jbycapital.com/; https://jbycapital.net);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>JSS Investments</strong> (https://www.jss-investment.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Ltd Capital</strong> (https://www.ltd-capital.com; https://www.ltdcapital.com; https://www.ltdcapital1.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Market2cap</strong> (https://market2cap.com/; https://mrk2cap.com)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Merrix</strong> (cloned firm) (https://merrix.pro/)</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Mobatrade</strong> (http://mobatrade.com/; https://www.mobatrade.co/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Naristech</strong> (https://naristech.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>NFG Finance</strong> (https://www.nfgfinance.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Onewiex</strong> (https://onewiex.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Parallel Investment</strong> (https://parallelinvestment.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>PrimefinanX</strong> (https://primfinanx-flow.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>QCFinances</strong> (https://qcfinances.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>SGX Digital</strong> (http://www.sgx.digital/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Skyhigh Traders</strong> (https://skyhigh-traders.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Tpc Invest</strong> (https://tpcinvest.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>TradeAI</strong> <strong>Group</strong> (https://tradeai-group.com/; https://platform.tradeai-group.net/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>TradeCryptoMasters</strong> (https://www.tradecryptomasters.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Trademay</strong> (https://trademay.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Tradiora</strong> (https://tradiora.com/);&nbsp;</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Uxcoins</strong> (https://uxcoins.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Vivoholding</strong> (https://vivoholding.io/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Wells Trader</strong> (https://wellstrader.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Wisewealth</strong> (https://wisewealth.ai/);</span></li><li><span lang="EN-US"><strong>Xtrader365</strong> (https://www.xtrader365.com/);</span></li><li><span lang="NL-BE"><strong>Zertom</strong> (https://www.zertom.com/).</span></li></ul><p>***</p><p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</p><p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p><p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p><p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, change your passwords.</p><p>***</p><p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="e/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns consumers against shadow investment game</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-consumers-against-shadow-investment-game</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA warns the public against the risks associated with the activities of so-called prop trading firms. The latter are parties that trade for their own account and offer consumers the opportunity to play a shadow investment game, a practice that costs money and can lead to reckless behaviour.&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Prop trading (short for proprietary trading) firms make it possible for consumers to trade in financial products such as shares, bonds, commodities, cryptocurrencies, CFDs and forex products without having to use their own money to do so.</p><h3><strong>Prop trading firms oblige consumers to take expensive courses</strong></h3><p>Before consumers are allowed to trade in financial products for a prop trading firm, they have to meet a series of challenges. These courses are not easy, not cheap and often consumers have to take, and pay for, several of them before they can successfully complete them. There is a good chance that some consumers never pass the courses. This is how prop trading firms earn money from them.&nbsp;</p><p>A consumer who has successfully completed the challenges receives a ‘certificate’ - a diploma that the firm itself issues - and can begin trading. This involves playing a game of shadow investment. The consumer never makes any actual trades. He or she plays on a demo account with the prop trading firm. The latter may decide to carry out one or more demo transactions for a consumer on an actual trading platform. If such a copied transaction does prove profitable, then the consumer gets a commission.&nbsp;</p><p>However, the prop trading firm alone decides under what conditions consumers may use their platform, and what simulated transactions it will copy. It is therefore difficult for a consumer to determine whether he or she is entitled to any commissions and if so, how much. A consumer may thus spend a lot of time and energy without any recompense.&nbsp;</p><h3><strong>Advertising for prop trading firms is increasing</strong></h3><p>The FSMA is receiving ever more questions about such firms. It has been observing an increase in advertisements for prop trading firms on social media. Various websites are also popping up that offer paid courses to help consumers succeed in the prop trading firms’ “challenges”.&nbsp;</p><p>The firms encourage trading in complex financial instruments, such as&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cfd">CFDs and forex-products</a>. These products are highly risky, and consumers often lose their entire investment. This tendency concerns the FSMA.</p><p>The FSMA therefore warns the public against the activities of such prop trading firms. It also warns against the ecosystem of any firm that ride on the coattails of the popularity of prop trading firms. They offer services linked to the latter’s activities, such as courses or trading software used for training.&nbsp;</p><h3><strong>The playful element of prop trading can drive people to engage in reckless behaviour</strong></h3><p>The FSMA emphasizes that prop trading companies do not hold any authorization and therefore are not allowed to provide investment services. The same is true for prop traders. The definition of the latter is consumers who have successfully completed a course.</p><p>Many studies have shown that the gaming element in prop trading can lead to overconfidence and recklessness among users, both in shadow investment and in actual transactions in which they use their own money.&nbsp;</p><p>Would you like to check if a <a>proposed transaction</a> complies with the financial legislation?&nbsp;If so, please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website.&nbsp;You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-03-07T08:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">399384</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches a collaborative programme with the academic sector</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-collaborative-programme-academic-sector</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>With a view to strengthening its ties with the academic world, the FSMA is launching in 2024 a collaborative programme with the academic sector and establishing a documentation centre devoted to the areas of its competence for financial regulation and supervision. The FSMA wishes to offer researchers the opportunity to access databases available to supervisory authorities and to examine topics that are top priorities for supervisors of the financial sector. The FSMA itself hopes thereby to augment its knowledge of the latest developments in scholarly research related to its areas of competence.</strong></p><p>&nbsp;<span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/397111"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/397111"><u>Dutch</u></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>On the occasion of a major international conference, the FSMA and the European Commission stressed the key role of financial education in the life of each citizen</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/occasion-major-international-conference-fsma-and-european-commission-stressed-key-role</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), together with the European Commission, held a high-level international conference today at the FSMA’s premises in Brussels on the subject of financial education, resilience and inclusion in this area. More than 250 people attended the event, which could also be followed online. Those present also explored the Wikifin Lab, the FSMA’s interactive financial educational centre. The centre is known internationally as a model of financial education for young people. The conference was organised under the aegis of the Belgian Presidency of the Council of the European Union.</strong></p><p>Acquiring at an early age the right reflexes in the area of finance and the ability in this way to make good choices thanks to financial education are the key aims of both the FSMA and the European Commission. It is with this shared aim in view that the FSMA and the European Commission jointly held a high-level conference on this topic at the premises of the FSMA. The conference was attended by Mairead McGuinness, European Commissioner for Financial Services, Financial Stability and Capital Market Union, Vincent Van Peteghem, Belgium’s Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, and Alexia Bertrand, Belgium’s State Secretary for Budget and Consumer Protection.</p><p>A great many international experts in this field spoke on the occasion: professors and researchers, representatives of the OECD and of the international organization IOSCO, representatives of the European institutions, experts from foreign supervisory authorities, key figures from civil society organisations, etc.</p><p>During the various discussions, topics such&nbsp;as the importance of being a catalyst for&nbsp;financial education in the area of financial resilience, the various opportunities and good practices in the field, and the important role that digitalization may play were put to discussion among experts.</p><p>Mairead McGuinness, European Commissioner for Financial Services, commented: “We need to talk more about money - how to manage it, save it, invest it and make it work for us. Because money matters. Research shows that financial literacy skills in Europe are not what they should be. Now is the time to address this – to help people make informed decisions about their money.&nbsp; So, I’m very happy that together with the Belgian Presidency we are bringing together global experts, policymakers, regulators, financial institutions, civil society and academics to discuss ways to boost financial literacy levels in the EU and exchange best practices. This is not only good for individual citizens but for society as a whole.”</p><blockquote><p>According to Vincent Van Peteghem, Belgium’s Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance: “In order to put citizens’ savings to work, we should focus on improving retail participation in financial markets. If we wish to mobilise private savings, financial literacy is crucial. According to an&nbsp;OECD survey, about half of the EU adult population does not have a good enough understanding of basic financial concepts.&nbsp;The issuance of a Belgian government bond last year pointed towards a similar lack of financial knowledge. Households without a good understanding of financial concepts will not actively invest in financial markets.”&nbsp;</p></blockquote><blockquote><p>&nbsp;“Financial literacy has been recognised at a global level as a core life skill. It is essential for both individuals and society. Within the Capital Markets Union Action Plan, financial literacy is one of the priorities and I welcome the efforts made by the European Commission and the OECD in this field. The FSMA's work in this area in Belgium with the Wikifin Lab, among others, are also very valuable and appreciated internationally.”</p></blockquote><blockquote><p>As Alexia Bertrand, State Secretary for Budget and Consumer Protection, observed: “Financial literacy plays an important role in consumer protection. This conference has shown that various stakeholders have to be involved to achieve this objective. I have thus had frequent occasions to collaborate with the FSMA and its financial education programme, Wikifin. Our aim is that every consumer can BE.COCO, BE a COnscious COnsumer.”</p></blockquote><blockquote><p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and of IOSCO, noted: “It is with great pleasure and pride that I welcomed this high-level conference at the premises of the FSMA, and in particular in our Wikifin Lab, our interactive financial education centre. This is a tangible example of how a regulator can effectively engage in financial education. The Wikifin Lab already stands&nbsp;internationally as a model of innovative initiatives that allow young people to develop skills that are crucial to avoiding financial problems when they grow up. Improving the level of financial education of the general public is a key theme for the FSMA and the European Commission alike, which accounts for this joint large-scale initiative!”</p></blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-02-20T17:10:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">396871</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Fraudulent trading platforms: how fraudsters obtain your data</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-trading-platforms-how-fraudsters-obtain-your-data</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Most investment fraud begins on social media. One can certainly find many advertisements there promising the world to those who are willing to try their luck. These ads take you to a website that vaunts the merits of a very interesting service: a trading platform, an app (artificial intelligence), a training course, etc. that enables you to get rich quick and without risk! To do so, all you need is to fill out the contact form.</strong></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>This is what might happen if you sign up:</p><ol><li>A few minutes later, you will get a phone call from an “expert”;</li><li>The person on the line will reassure you and guide you through the various payment steps;</li><li>Next, you are put in touch with a “trader” who helps you open an account on an ;&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms">online trading platform</a>;</li><li>This “trader” then tries to create a bond of confidence with you so as to encourage you to invest ever more money;</li><li>You see your earnings rise rapidly, and the platform looks very professional;</li><li>Everything seems fine. You even manage to recover part of your earnings;</li><li>However, when you try to make subsequent withdrawals, unexpected problems emerge. You will have to pay unforeseen “taxes”, to which additional fees are added, and so on. And on and on;</li><li>You begin to doubt the legitimacy of this platform and tell the so-called “trader” of your concerns;</li><li>From that point on, the tone changes and your contact person starts to be threatening;</li><li>You are no longer able to reach him or her, or worse, you are subject to daily harassment;</li><li>In the end, you never recover the total amount invested.</li></ol><p>The FSMA has noted that victims of fraudulent trading platforms had entered their contact information on the following sites:</p><ul><li><strong>Bit 2.0 Urex</strong> (https://the-bit2urex.com;&nbsp;https://bit2urex.com/)</li><li><strong>Bitcoin 360 Ai</strong> (https://bitcoin360ai.com;&nbsp;https://bit-indexai.com;&nbsp;https://the-bitcoin360-ai.com;&nbsp;https://bitcoin-360-ai.org)</li><li><strong>Bitcoin Bot&nbsp;</strong>(https://bitcoin-bot.app;&nbsp;https://bitcoin-bot-pro.com)</li><li><strong>BitiCodes</strong> (https://biticodes.com;&nbsp;https://the-biticodes.com;&nbsp;https://biticodes-app.com)</li><li><strong>Bitindex Prime</strong> <item>
  <title>The FSMA has published an opinion on the loyalty bonus on regulated savings accounts</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-has-published-opinion-loyalty-bonus-regulated-savings-accounts</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received three requests for an opinion on the loyalty bonus on regulated savings accounts. The requests came from the Secretary of State for the Budget and Consumer Protection, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for the Economy, and the chairperson of the Finance and Budget Committee of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives, respectively. For the first time since its creation in 2011, the FSMA was asked to give its opinion on the very principle of the loyalty bonus. In response to the request, it has now prepared and published its opinion. In it, the FSMA outlines the history of the successive developments regarding regulated savings accounts and examines the origins of the concepts of ‘basic interest rate’ and ‘loyalty bonus’.</strong></p><p><span>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/395647"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/395647"><span><u>Dutch</u></span></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-02-12T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">395647</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA announces the entry into force of the Belgian bankers’ oath and the associated ethical rules</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-announces-entry-force-belgian-bankers-oath-and-associated-ethical-rules</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 7 February 2024, the Royal Decree on the bankers’ oath was published in the Belgian Official Gazette (available in </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-02/2024-01-28_kb_ar.pdf"><strong>Dutch and French</strong></a><strong> only). The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is responsible for the supervision and enforcement of this new legislation. On the occasion of the publication of the Royal Decree, the FSMA confirms the date of entry into force of the bankers’ oath and has published the applicable ethical rules on its website.</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/391759"><u>French</u></a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/391759"><u>Dutch</u></a>&nbsp;site.</p>

<item>
  <title>Preparing financial entities for the entry into force of the DORA Regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/preparing-financial-entities-entry-force-dora-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The financial sector is every more dependent on the smooth operation of IT infrastructure and services. Given the increasing risks as regards computer security and the growing number of cybercrime attacks, the European DORA (Digital Operational Resilience Act) Regulation sets out ambitious objectives as regards digital operational resilience. These objectives are intended to protect financial entities and their clients. They supplement existing legislation. A survey conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) shows that many financial entities have not yet taken all the measures necessary to prepare themselves for the entry into force of DORA. Those entities are asked to familiarize themselves with the provisions of that Regulation that apply to them, to determine what steps they have to take in order to gradually come into compliance with those provisions, and to take the necessary measures in a timely manner.</strong></p><p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/393603"><u>French</u></a><span>&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/393603"><span><u>Dutch</u></span></a><span>&nbsp;site.</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-02-02T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">393603</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Half-yearly dashboard on investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/half-yearly-dashboard-investment-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. It publishes a dashboard that provides statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it is publishing the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-01/20240110_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf">dashboard</a> for the second semester of 2023, which will also include the figures for the whole year 2023.</strong></p>

<p>This edition of the dashboard focuses notably on the following items:</p>

<p>For the second semester:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Consumers’ reports concerning cryptocurrency scams or fraudulent trading platforms account once again for <strong>slightly more than half</strong> of the reports with regard to fraud handled by the FSMA.&nbsp;</li>
 <li>The number of such reports surged in October, partly a result of the launch that same month of an <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/fr/epargner-et-investir/fraudes-et-escroqueries-linvestissement/ne-vous-laissez-pas-pieger-par-les">awareness campaign</a> specifically targeting this type of fraud.</li>
</ul>

<p>For the whole year:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Belgian consumers reported having collectively lost more than <strong>EUR 15,482,000 </strong>to fraudulent trading platforms in<strong> </strong>2023.</li>
 <li>The FSMA received a total of <strong>2,170</strong> reports regarding unauthorized or fraudulent activities. This figure has been steadily increasing since 2017.</li>
</ul>

<p>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2024-01/20240110_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf">dashboard</a> is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2024-01-11T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">383792</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>CNR Invest</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/cnr-invest</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of CNR Invest, a company that offers investment services to the public in Belgium.</strong></p><p>CNR Invest offers consumers investments which they promise will bring substantial profits.</p><p>The websites it uses are as follows: access.base‐gestion‐cl.com/preview and accesglobalgg.com.</p><p>In many cases, consumers are contacted by a person calling himself Tom Bogaerts (tom.bogaerts@cnr‐invest.com).</p><p>This company and this person do not have the authorization necessary to offer investment services in Belgium.</p><p>This firm has also misused the name of the Luxembourg company named CNR Invest.</p><p>The FSMA&nbsp;thus strongly advises against responding to any offers made by CNR Invest&nbsp;and against transferring money&nbsp;to any account number that the company might mention.</p><p>***</p><p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a> only).</p><p>We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-21T14:22:22+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">386432</guid>
    </item>
<item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns the public against BTC20.com</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-public-against-btc20com</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has become aware of the website https://btc20.com, which distributes the BTC20 virtual currency. Btc20.com indicates that it has an address in Belgium. However, any advertising disseminated as part of a mass media campaign to promote virtual currencies in Belgium must be notified in advance to the FSMA. BTC20.com has not filed a notification with the FSMA.</strong></p>

<p>Moreover, there are several indications that this is a purely fraudulent offer:</p>

<ul>
 <li>The FSMA has received several complaints from consumers who state that they have been unable to recover the funds they invested;</li>
 <li>The contact information given by btc20.com does not appear to be valid;</li>
 <li>BTC20.com has not responded to repeated requests for information made by the FSMA.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises against responding to any offers made by this firm.</strong></p>

<p><strong>***</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA wishes to recall that <strong>investment fraud</strong> often lies behind firms that are active in the virtual currency sector.</p>

<p>In order to avoid this type of fraud, the FSMA reiterates its recommendation to investors always to check the identity (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) of the company offering them an investment. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-20T18:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">383791</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO European Regional Committee at the FSMA </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-european-regional-committee-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA convened more than 80 participants from the IOSCO European Regional Committee (ERC) for two days of meetings in Brussels for a Workshop on New Supervisory Technology on December 18 and the ERC Plenary meeting on December 19. </strong></p>

<p>During the workshop ERC Members shared experiences on real-world cases in which they successfully apply new technologies in supervisory activities. These use-cases were related to social media monitoring, market surveillance, artificial intelligence and ways to address greenwashing through technology.<br>
During the ERC plenary meeting members exchanged experiences on policies of common interest, such as Sustainable Finance, Fintech, crypto assets and Suptech. These in-depth discussions provide valuable feedback and regional perspectives to the global work coordinated by IOSCO.</p>

<p>ERC Members also visited the FSMA’s financial education centre, the Wikifin Lab, and learned about the FSMA’s efforts to contribute to the financial education in Belgium.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais, ERC and IOSCO Board Chair and Chairman of FSMA Belgium said: “<em>The ERC provides an important forum for our 57 members in Europe for information sharing and promoting cooperation. The ERC plenary meeting held in Brussels gave members an opportunity to discuss issues in relation to IOSCO’s policy work on digital and sustainable finance and to</em><em> learn from each other about the SupTech skills and expertise that our members have built. &nbsp;</em><em>I was also happy to welcome our colleagues to our financial education centre as a model for financial regulators to contribute to financial literacy.”</em></p>
</blockquote>
<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/erc-group.png?itok=LkOSW4xT" width="750" height="499" alt="IOSCO European Regional Committee" title="IOSCO European Regional Committee" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-19T16:34:19+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">386436</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Accreditation of training poviders and FAQs on continuing professional education</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-accreditation-training-poviders-and-faqs-continuing-professional-education</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published the regulation of 31 October 2023 on the accreditation of training providers. This regulation lays down the conditions for obtaining and maintaining an accreditation as a training provider. It enters into force on 1 January 2024. The regulation provides for a transitional period of six months to allow training providers to adapt the courses they offer for continuing professional education (CPE) and the certificates of attendance to the new rules. You can consult this regulation on the FSMA website.<br>
<br>
In addition to the regulation, the FSMA published a completely new set of FAQs on continuing professional education, providing answers to questions on different topics, such as courses eligible for continuing professional education, double counting of hours, digital learning formats, transfer of CPE hours to the following CPE year, ... You can consult the FAQs on the FSMA website.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our Newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-12/2023-12-19_newsletter_recyclage_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-12/2023-12-19_newsletter_bijscholing_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>) only</p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Warning: Can you get rich in just a few clicks?</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/warning-can-you-get-rich-just-few-clicks</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Many Belgian citizens have got rich thanks to a revolutionary new system. You don’t need any experience, as a trader will guide you throughout this adventure. You can start investing with as little as €250. This is a limited offer, so hurry and sign up via our online form.</strong></p>

<p>Did you believe this message? If so, you could have fallen into the trap of a tried and tested <strong>fraud</strong>. Several such advertisements are circulating on social media. They generally use the image of various celebrities, who sing the praises of a get-rich-quick scheme.</p>

<p>In October 2023, the FSMA conducted a communication campaign to raise public awareness of investment fraud. The campaign has led to a more than 80% increase in the number of consumer questions received in October and November 2023, as compared to the same period the previous year. These included questions from consumers who had doubts about a possibly fraudulent offer as well as reports of actual cases of fraud. This considerable increase emphasizes the importance of raising awareness of investment fraud and attests to the trust that consumers place in the FSMA. The FSMA wishes once again to stress the importance of remaining alert and promptly recognizing fraudulent service providers.</p>

<p>What does this kind of fraud look like? We’ll explain it all, step by step.</p>

<ol>
 <li>First of all, an advertisement appears on your Facebook feed with a catchy title. For example: <strong><em>XXX (a famous celebrity) urges all Belgians to seize the opportunity!</em></strong> or <strong><em>XXX’s new project has the world and banks in awe! </em></strong>Some fraudsters go so far as to create video clips showing a fake interview.</li>
 <li>Intrigued, you click on the link and are redirected to an article that seems to have appeared in a well-known newspaper. The article begins with a catchy headline and the photo of a celebrity or prominent individual.<br>
 -&gt;<em>&nbsp;Tip: Always check that the URL to the article really belongs to the newspaper in question. If it is a different URL address, this is a fake article.</em></li>
 <li>You will then read that a TV presenter tried to interview the person about his or her secret for getting rich quick. However, the broadcast was interrupted by a major Belgian bank.<br>
 -&gt;&nbsp;<em>Tip: Take a careful look at the contents of the article. The text of a fake article is often inconsistent and has spelling or grammar mistakes.</em></li>
 <li>Nevertheless, the article continues, the newspaper succeeded in obtaining an exclusive interview in which the celebrity was able to reveal their secret. The famous individual got rich thanks to an investment programme or platform dealing in cryptocurrencies!<br>
 -&gt;&nbsp;<em>Tip: Never invest in products you do not understand.</em></li>
 <li>Several people are said to have tested the system: it works! Thanks to XXX, they got rich in just a few weeks.<br>
 -&gt;&nbsp;<em>Tip: If an offer is too good to be true, it most probably is.</em></li>
 <li>Lastly, the article explains how to sign up. It seems quite easy and all you need is €250&nbsp;to start investing. Moreover, you don’t need any experience trading. But there are only a few spots left, it says, so hurry and sign up!<br>
 -&gt;&nbsp;<em>Tip: Be wary of an offer that creates a sense of urgency or implies this is something rare or exclusive. </em></li>
</ol>

<p>Have you nevertheless signed up? This is what might happen:</p>

<ol>
 <li>You fill in a <strong>contact form</strong>. A few minutes later, you receive a phone call from an “expert”;</li>
 <li>The person at the end of the line <strong>reassures you and guides you </strong>through the various steps to make a payment;</li>
 <li>Next, you are put in touch with a “trader” who helps you open an account on an <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms"><strong>online trading platform</strong></a>;</li>
 <li>This “trader” then tries to create a bond of confidence with you so as to <strong>encourage</strong> you to invest ever more money;</li>
 <li>You see your earnings rise rapidly, and the platform looks very professional;</li>
 <li><strong>Everything seems fine.</strong> You even manage to recover part of your earnings;</li>
 <li>However, when you try to make subsequent withdrawals, <strong>unexpected problems</strong> emerge. You have to pay unforeseen “taxes”, to which additional fees are added, and so on. And on and on;</li>
 <li>You begin to <strong>doubt</strong> the legitimacy of this platform and tell the so-called “trader” of your concerns;</li>
 <li>From that point on, the tone changes and your <strong>contact person starts to be threatening</strong>;</li>
 <li><strong>You are no longer able to reach him or her, </strong>or worse, you are subject to daily harassment;</li>
 <li>In the end, you never recover the total amount invested.</li>
</ol>

<p>For more information, please see our flow chart <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_q4_schema_en.pdf">Investment fraud: the “classic” scenario</a>, as well as the page on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud</a>. Please take a look at our awareness-raising videos (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-prevention">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/preventiefilms">Dutch</a> only).</p>

<p><strong>Do you think you may have fallen victim?</strong> Feel free to contact the FSMA directly via its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. The FSMA also advises you to lodge a complaint with the local police or judicial authorities.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-14T09:20:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">373533</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Institutions for occupational retirement provision: overview 2022</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/institutions-occupational-retirement-provision-overview-2022</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The overall balance sheet total of Belgian institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) fell last year by 14 per cent. This is the conclusion of the annual statistical overview prepared by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA is responsible for the supervision of IORPs, also known as pension funds. Every year, it publishes a summary of statistics regarding IORPs. The thirteenth edition of that statistical overview is now available.</p>

<p>The most important elements of the overview are as follows:</p>

<ol>
 <li>At the end of 2022, Belgium had 159 IORPs governed by Belgian law, compared to 169 pension funds in 2021.</li>
 <li>Meanwhile, the number of members in IORPs rose by 13 per cent to 2.43 million.</li>
 <li>The balance sheet total of all IORPs at the end of last year was 40.4 billion euros, a 14 per cent decrease compared to the previous year. This decrease is due mainly to the poor performance of the stock market as a result of the events in Ukraine and the resulting energy crisis.<br>
 &nbsp;
 <figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/changes_balancesheet_2022.PNG?itok=5NzFipX8" width="734" height="316" alt="Graphic: Changes in balance sheet total" title="Graphic: Changes in balance sheet total" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>

 </li>
 <li>Belgian IORPs invested a little more than three-quarters of their assets in undertakings for collective investment (UCIs), mostly in share and bond funds. Taking into account the underlying assets of these UCIs, IORPs invested, directly and indirectly, 48 per cent in bonds and 41 per cent in shares. The return on all investments at the end of 2022 stood at -14.9 per cent.<br>
 &nbsp;
 <figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/graphique_2a_2b_overview_2022_en.png?itok=LPCp3jft" width="687" height="354" alt="Pensions : graphic of direct investments and indirect investments" title="Pensions : graphic of direct investments and indirect investments" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>

 </li>
 <li>The average coverage level was 113 per cent. This is down compared to 2021. The decrease is due mainly to poor stock market performance and to the fall in the market value of bonds as a result of rising interest rates. Moreover, inflation has had a negative impact on defined-benefit (DB) plans: in the case of (DB) plans where salaries are linked to inflation, pension obligations rose more than in previous years.<br>
 <br>
 The coverage level indicates the volume of assets a pension fund has available to meet all its obligations. DB plans are pension plans that promise to pay out a fixed amount of supplementary pension.</li>
</ol>

<p>In addition to the 2022 overview, the annual financial statements and some additional statistics at sectoral level are available on the FSMA's website (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/statistiques-des-operations-des-institutions-de-retraite-professionnelle">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/statistieken-van-de-verrichtingen-van-de-instellingen-voor-bedrijfspensioenvoorziening">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-13T11:23:45+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">385041</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA welcomes IMF assessment of the Belgian financial sector and of its regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-welcomes-imf-assessment-belgian-financial-sector-and-its-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In 2023, Belgium underwent the five-yearly assessment of its financial sector and of its regulation under the International Monetary Fund's Financial Stability Assessment Program (FSAP). The FSMA was closely involved in this exercise in the framework of its statutory supervisory mandates and welcomes the IMF's findings.</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2023/12/07/Belgium-Financial-Sector-Assessment-Program-Financial-System-Stability-Assessment-542059">final report of the mission</a> was approved and published by the IMF Board and contains the findings and recommendations of the IMF team that led the mission. In this report, the IMF recognizes the quality of financial sector supervision in Belgium.</p>

<p>The mission found that the FSMA has a well-developed framework for product and conduct supervision of banks, as well as a comprehensive Belgian regulatory framework for the conduct supervision of insurance companies.</p>

<p>Based on a liquidity stress test, the mission found that the Belgian investment fund sector, where liquidity management tools are widely available, is resilient and able to absorb large shocks. The FSMA will conduct this type of test periodically, as recommended by the IMF, to quickly identify any structural vulnerabilities in the investment fund sector.</p>

<p>The mission noted that within the Belgian twin peaks supervisory model, the National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) work closely together. In this regard, the NBB and the FSMA have already followed up on the Fund's recommendation to expand data-sharing arrangements for investment funds.</p>

<p>The FSMA particularly appreciates the joint work with the IMF teams and the exchange of expertise during the mission and will take forward the report's recommendations.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-08T16:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">384178</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Offers of investment in wine and precious metals: be vigilant!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/offers-investment-wine-and-precious-metals-be-vigilant</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has received new complaints from consumers who have been approached by companies offering investments in wine or precious metals. The FSMA is once again warning consumers, since the people behind these tantalizing offers are often fraudsters!</strong></p>

<p>Alternatives to traditional savings products, with promises of high yields, are once again increasingly being offered to the general public. At the moment, these are mostly offers of investment in various products such as precious metals, wine or champagne.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>The formula being offered for such investments is generally as follows:</strong><strong> </strong></li>
</ul>

<p>The asset is offered as an alternative for investing one’s capital and is accompanied by promises of high yields. The formula involves a website that takes the form of an online trading platform; no physical delivery is involved. Contacts take place by phone and email. Most of the time, the contacts follow on advertisements that appear on the internet, and in particular on social media.</p>

<p>In the course of the past few weeks, the FSMA has received reports about:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Pontils-alinau.com</li>
 <li>www.pratholding.com</li>
 <li>Primalgold&nbsp;/&nbsp;Myeffico Finance<em> </em></li>
 <li>www.silva-investissements.com</li>
 <li>www.walletpremium.com</li>
</ul>

<p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p>The FSMA thus<strong> strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial service made by the companies listed above </strong>and <strong>against transferring money</strong> to any bank account number they might mention.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA recommends that investors: <strong>always check the identity of the company</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) that is offering them an investment. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always check</strong> if the company in question has the requisite authorization. To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a> on the website of the FSMA will do. Be careful! Always beware of ‘cloned firms’. Such companies pass themselves off as other, authorized, companies, although they have no connection to them. To avoid this type of fraud, take a close look at the email addresses or contact details of the companies in question, as this information may prove useful to detect this type of fraud.</p>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. Feel free to inform the FSMA as well if you are contacted by a suspect company about which it has not yet published a warning.</p>

<p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to <strong>file a complaint with the local police or the judicial authorities</strong>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-12-08T08:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">381549</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Newsletter for insurance intermediaries - Cooperation with the Insurance Ombudsman</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-insurance-intermediaries-cooperation-insurance-ombudsman</link>
  <description>
<p>The Insurance Ombudsman plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of and the confidence in the insurance sector. As an independent body, the Insurance Ombudsman handles complaints from policyholders and mediates in disputes. The interaction between the Ombudsman, the insurance companies and the insurance intermediaries contributes to a fair and efficient treatment of complaints and disputes. It is therefore in the interest of the entire sector to cooperate with the Ombudsman.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-11/2023-11-30_newsletter_ombudsman_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-11/2023-11-30_newsletter_ombudsman_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-11-30T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">382280</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of these new fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-these-new-fraudulent-trading-platforms-2</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA has continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Such trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a specific investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts. Furthermore, many trading platforms use WhatsApp and Telegram.</p><p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">pyramid scheme</a>.</p><p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;They often claim to hold an authorization by a fake financial authority, displaying it so as to seem trustworthy. Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p><p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p><ul><li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li><li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li></ul><p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the investors’ funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their money because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p><p>***</p><p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p><ul><li><strong>7solutions</strong> (https://7solutions.uk/);</li><li><strong>AES</strong> (www.aestotal.com);</li><li><strong>Appex Finance</strong> (https://appexfinance.com/; https://appex-finance.com/);</li><li><strong>ARP Trade</strong> (http://arptrade.com/);</li><li><strong>Audemars Group</strong> (https://audemarsgroup.com/);</li><li><strong>Bitbinx</strong> (http://bitbinx.net/);</li><li><strong>Bitgetinvest </strong>(https://www.bitsgetinvest.com/);</li><li><strong>Cap Traders</strong> (https://cap-traders.com; https://captraders.net/);</li><li><strong>Capital B Market</strong> (https://capitalbmarket.com/);</li><li><strong>Coinex.la</strong> (cloned firm&nbsp;; https://coinex.la/);</li><li><strong>CorsairControl</strong> (https://corsaircontrol.pro/);</li><li><strong>Cryptomerge</strong> (https://cryptomerge.com/);</li><li><strong>Dax-Financial </strong>(https://www.dax-financial.com/, https://dax-financial.de/);</li><li><strong>DBG Investment</strong> (cloned firm; https://www.dbginvestment.org/);</li><li><strong>Direct Stock </strong>(https://direct-stock.com/);</li><li><strong>ECTraders / ECdgTraders</strong> (https://www.ectraders.com/);</li><li><strong>Elbitrader</strong> (https://www.elbitrader.com/; https://elbi-trader.com/)</li><li><strong>Emarket-24</strong> (https://emarket-24.com/);</li><li><strong>EMG Prime</strong> (https://emgprime.com/);</li><li><strong>E-Secure.io</strong> (https://e-secure.io/; https://e-secure.app/);</li><li><strong>ETHprofits</strong> (http://ethprofits.com/);</li><li><strong>Extonglobal</strong> (https://www.extonglobal.com/, https://www.extonglobal.capital/; https://www.extonglobal.io; https://extonglobal.org);</li><li><strong>Financewise </strong>(www.financewise.cc);</li><li><strong>FortunaInvest</strong> (cloned firm&nbsp;; https://fortuna-invest.com/);</li><li><strong>FuturBTC </strong>(https://www.futurbtc.com/);</li><li><strong>FXP360</strong> (http://www.fxp360.com/);</li><li><strong>Gastrade</strong> (https://gastrade.co/; https://gastrade.company/);</li><li><strong>Gateway Capital CG/Capital Gateway CG</strong> (https://gatewaycapitalcg.com/; https://capital-gatewaycg.com/);</li><li><strong>Global ICM</strong> (cloned firm; http://icm-global.com/; global-icm.com; glbl-icm.com; https://www.global-icm.net/);</li><li><strong>Global Mining Hub</strong> (https://www.globalmininghub.com);</li><li><strong>Invox Trade</strong> (https://invox.trade);</li><li><strong>KTXENR </strong>(https://web.ktxenr.com/; https://web.ktxenr.net/);</li><li><strong>LPL Financing</strong> (cloned firm)</li><li><strong>MetaSwissX </strong>(https://www.metaswissx.net/; https://www.metaswissx.org);</li><li><strong>NFG Finance</strong> (https://www.nfgfinance.com/);</li><li><strong>Obcai</strong> (https://obcai.cc/; http://www.obcai.com/; http://www.obcai.net/, https://obihams.com/);</li><li><strong>Omers Finance</strong> (cloned firm, https://omersfinance.ltd/);</li><li><strong>Quaero Capital</strong> (https://quaerocapital.pro/; https://quaerocapital.trade/);</li><li><strong>Quantia</strong> (https://quantia.cc/)</li><li><strong>Safity</strong> (http://safity.pro/; https://www.privat.bet/index.html);</li><li><strong>SSC Investment</strong> (www.sscinvestment.com);</li><li><strong>Tangent Capital</strong> (https://tangent-capital.pro/);</li><li><strong>Terallix</strong> (www.Terallix.com);</li><li><strong>Terrarobo</strong> (https://www.terrarobo.pro/);</li><li><strong>Tools4deals</strong> (https://tools4deals.com/; http://tools-4deals.com/);</li><li><strong>Topeu</strong> (https://topeu.net/, www.topeu.com);</li><li><strong>Traderup</strong> (https://www.traderup.com/, http://www.traderup5.com/; http://www.traderup7.com, http://www.traderup9.com);</li><li><strong>Tradespeck</strong> (www.tradespeck.com);</li><li><strong>Truemarket</strong> Trading (https://truemarket-trading.com/);</li><li><strong>Trustbit</strong> (https://www.trustbit.trade/);</li><li><strong>Trustly</strong> (cloned firm; http://www.trustly.io/; https://trustly.pro/);</li><li><strong>Wise-Markets</strong> (https://wise-markets.com/);</li><li><strong>Wisevests</strong> (https://wisevests.com/fr/home-fr/).</li></ul><p>***</p><p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</p><p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p><p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p><p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, change your passwords.</p><p>***</p><p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>
