<item>
  <title>Conclusions of the FSMA investigation into the first overall risk assessment (ORA) reports and the expectations for future reports </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/conclusions-fsma-investigation-first-overall-risk-assessment-ora-reports-and-expectations</link>
  <description>
<p>One of the objectives of the IORP II Directive is to urge institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) to conduct active risk management. This means IORPs must carry out their own risk assessment (ORA) at least every three years. The ORA is intended to provide an overall assessment of all risks to which the IORP is or may be exposed, and of their risk management.</p>

<p>The IORPs have now submitted their first complete ORA report to the FSMA. The FSMA has analyzed the quality of the ORA reports via a representative sample. The FSMA set out the main findings of its analysis and its expectations as regards future ORA reports in a webinar on 13 November 2023. The IORPs have now submitted their first complete ORA report to the FSMA. The FSMA has analyzed the quality of the ORA reports via a representative sample. The FSMA set out the main findings of its analysis and its expectations as regards future ORA reports in a webinar on 13 November 2023.&nbsp;</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>The presentation of the webinar is available on our website via the following link (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-11/2023_orawebinar_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-11/2023_orawebinar_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-11-24T13:56:12+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">381101</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Updated FAQs on the entry into force of the Delegated Regulation supplementing the Sustainable Finance Disclosures Regulation (SFDR)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/updated-faqs-entry-force-delegated-regulation-supplementing-sustainable-finance-disclosures</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published an update of its Communication on the entry into force of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1288 of 6 April 2022 supplementing the SFDR with regulatory technical standards. The Communication takes the form of FAQs and covers, for example, the content and presentation of the information relating to the promotion of environmental or social characteristics and objectives for sustainable investments in precontractual documents, on websites and in periodic reports.</p>

<p>These FAQs bring together the clarifications published by the European Commission and the European Supervisory Authorities on the subject and sets out the FSMA’s expectations in this regard. A new question has also been added in this updated version.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in Communication FSMA_2023_01...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/fsma_2023_01_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/fsma_2023_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-11-13T12:16:16+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">379258</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Have you received an attractive credit proposal? Beware of fake credit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-beware-fake-credit</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></p>

<p>Over the past few months, the FSMA has once again received many enquiries about the activities of <strong>fraudulent lenders</strong> in Belgium. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or find <strong>advertisements</strong> on social media. Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</p>

<p>In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions. In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firm</strong></a>’ fraud.</p>

<p>The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</p>

<p>Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></p>

<p>The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Alle Financien</strong> (https://alle-financien.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Best Finance Group </strong>(https://bestfinance-group.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Cassert Financement</strong> (https://cassert-financement.fr/)</li>
 <li><strong>Cosedoo</strong> (https://www.cosedoo.eu/)</li>
 <li><strong>Direct Krediet</strong> (https://www.direct-krediet.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finance Enterprise</strong> (https://finance-enterprise.com)</li>
 <li><strong>FSEI-GROEP</strong> (http://www.fsei-groep.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Hiterkredit</strong> (https://hiterkredit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Kreditaas</strong> (https://kreditaas.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Leen-Dienst</strong> (https://leen-dienst.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>ONG Aide Solution</strong> (https://ong-aide-solutions.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Onlinekrediethub</strong> (https://www.onlinekrediethub.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Oxi Financiel </strong>(https://oxi-financiel.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Pluskredite</strong> (https://pluskredite.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Sine Kredit </strong>(https://sinekredit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Smart Krediet</strong> (https://smartkrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Sodik Kredit </strong>(http://sodik-kredit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Volda Financiering</strong> (https://voldafinanciering.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person. But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a> on its website.</p>

<p>As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-11-10T09:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Voluntary and conditional public takeover bid in cash by European Real Estate Holdings NV on Intervest Offices & Warehouses NV</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/voluntary-and-conditional-public-takeover-bid-cash-european-real-estate-holdings-nv-intervest</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>NOTIFICATION MADE PUBLIC BY THE FSMA IN APPLICATION OF ARTICLE 7 OF THE ROYAL DECREE OF 27 APRIL 2007 ON PUBLIC TAKEOVER BIDS</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA announces, in accordance with Article 7 of the Royal Decree of 27 April 2007 on public takeover bids (the “<strong><em>Takeover Decree</em></strong>”), the notification that it received pursuant to Article 5 of the Takeover Decree, on 16 October 2023 (the “<strong><em>Notification Date</em></strong>”), regarding the intention of European Real Estate Holdings NV, a public limited liability company (<em>naamloze vennootschap</em>) incorporated under the laws of Belgium, having its registered office at Avenue Marnix 23, fifth floor, 1000 Brussels, Belgium, and registered with the Crossroads Bank for Enterprises under number 1000.335.957 (RLE Brussels, Dutch-speaking section) (the “<strong><em>Offeror</em></strong>”), to launch a voluntary and conditional public takeover bid in cash (the “<strong><em>Offer</em></strong>”) for the shares issued by Intervest Offices &amp; Warehouses NV, a public regulated real estate company under Belgian law, in the form of a public limited liability company (<em>naamloze vennootschap</em>), having its registered office at Uitbreidingstraat 66, 2600 Berchem, and registered with the Crossroads Bank for Enterprises under number 0458.623.918 (RLE Antwerp, Antwerp division) (the “<strong><em>Target Company</em></strong>”), and whose shares are listed on Euronext Brussels.</p>

<p>The Offer price is EUR 21 per share in cash.</p>

<p>The Offer relates to all the shares of the Target Company with voting rights and which are not already owned by the Offeror. The Offeror currently owns 311,841 shares of the Target Company, so that the Offer relates to the 30,513,281 shares of the Target Company which are not already owned by the Offeror.</p>

<p>If the Target Company approves or makes a distribution to its shareholders (whether such distribution takes the form of an annual dividend or interim dividend, a capital reduction, a capital repayment or any other form (whether in cash or in kind)) in relation to the shares, where the right to such distribution falls prior to the acquisition of the shares by the Offeror as a result of the Offer, then the Offer price will be reduced by the total amount of such distribution (prior to withholding of any taxes).</p>

<p>As at the date of the notification by the Offeror to the FSMA in accordance with Article 5 of the Takeover Decree, the Target Company has not issued any securities with voting rights or giving access to voting rights other than shares.</p>

<p>The Offer is subject to the following conditions precedent, stipulated for the exclusive benefit of the Offeror, which may waive them in whole or in part:</p>

<ul>
 <li>as a result of the Offer, the Offeror holds 50% + 1 of the shares at the end of the initial acceptance period, including, for the avoidance of doubt, the 311,841 shares owned by the Offeror as at date hereof;</li>
 <li>approval by the Belgian Competition Authority in phase 1;</li>
 <li>as from the Notification Date and during the period preceding the date on which the results of the initial acceptance period of the Offer are announced:
 <ul>
  <li>(i) the closing price of the BEL-20 index has not decreased by 15% or more as compared to the closing price of the BEL-20 index on the business day preceding the Notification Date (i.e. the BEL-20 index has not decreased below 2,981.26 points) (the “<strong><em>BEL-20 Threshold</em></strong>”) and (ii) the closing price of the FTSE PRA/NAREIT Developed Europe Index (the “<strong><em>EPRA Index</em></strong>”) has not decreased by more than 15% compared to the closing price of the EPRA Index on the business day prior to the Notification Date (i.e. the EPRA Index has not decreased below 1,182.25 points) (the “<strong><em>EPRA Index Floor Threshold</em></strong>”) ); and/or</li>
  <li>no fact, event or circumstance (including any force majeure event) has occurred that results in, or is reasonably likely to result in (in such cases, as determined by an independent expert), solely or jointly with any other fact, event or circumstance, a negative impact of more than 10% of the EPRA NTA per share of the Target Company (i.e. EPRA NTA per share not lower than EUR 20.01 (being more than EUR 2.22 given an adjusted&nbsp; pro forma EPRA NTA per share equal to EUR 22.23 per 30 June 2023)), calculated in accordance with the method applied in the latest consolidated half-year results of the Target Company as per 30 June 2023, compared to the EPRA NTA per share as reflected in the consolidated half-year results of the Target Company as per 30 June 2023 (being EUR 22.49), adjusted pro forma for the most recent capital increase with issuance of new shares on 2 August 2023 (resulting in a pro forma EPRA NTA per share equal to EUR 22.23).</li>
 </ul>
 </li>
</ul>

<p>If the Offeror does not withdraw the Offer within 5 business days of the closing price of the BEL-20 index being below the BEL-20 Threshold, or the closing price of the EPRA Index being below the EPRA Index Floor Threshold (it being understood that this will be at the latest on the publication date of the results of the initial acceptance period), and the closing price subsequently rises again above the relevant BEL-20 Threshold or the EPRA Index Floor Threshold, respectively, the Offeror will no longer be able to invoke this earlier and temporary decrease of the closing price. The potential decision of the Offeror to maintain the Offer during a period where the closing price of the BEL-20 index has temporarily fallen below the BEL-20 Threshold, or the EPRA Index has temporarily fallen below the EPRA Index Floor Threshold, does not affect the Offeror's right to still invoke the condition and withdraw the Offer should the closing price of the BEL-20 index or the EPRA Index, after a recovery, subsequently fall again below the BEL-20 Threshold or the EPRA Index Floor Threshold, respectively, in which case the Offeror shall again have 5 business days to decide whether to withdraw the Offer, it being understood that the Offeror shall do so at the latest on the publication date of the results of the initial acceptance period.</p>

<p>If, following the initial or any subsequent acceptance period, the Offeror (together with its affiliated persons and persons with whom it is acting in concert at any time) holds at least 95% of the shares of the Target Company, the Offeror reserves the right (which it intends to exercise) to launch a simplified squeeze-out in accordance with Articles 42 and 43 <em>juncto</em> 57 of the Takeover Decree and Article 7:82, §1 of the Companies and Associations Code, in order to acquire the shares not yet acquired by the Offeror, on the same terms as those of the Offer.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-17T09:11:09+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">375228</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Scammers pass themselves off as banks: beware of fraud!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/scammers-pass-themselves-banks-beware-fraud-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB">Fraudsters continue to usurp the identity of major banks in order to catch consumers off guard. Despite several warnings against this phenomenon since 2021, the FSMA noticed that this type of fraud is still taking victims today.</span></strong></p>

<p>The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone or by email without having taken any prior initiative themselves or after having entered their contact details on an online form.&nbsp;Such forms are frequently offered to consumers on social media, via advertisements or sponsored publications.</p>

<p>The fraudsters then offer consumers&nbsp;<strong>savings plans</strong>&nbsp;with the promise of returns in excess of market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end, the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money.</p>

<p>The FSMA recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several banks to deceive consumers.&nbsp;<strong>The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:</strong>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>BGL BNP Paribas Fortis</strong>, using email addresses ending with '@bglgestionprivee.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Bunq</strong>, using email addresses ending with '@epargnebunq.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Fineco, </strong>using email addresses ending with '@fib-gestion.com'&nbsp;and 'bfigestion.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Revolut-épargne, </strong>using email addresses ending with '@revolut-epargne.com' and '@consulting-revo.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Triodos, </strong>using email addresses ending with '@triodos-europe.com'&nbsp;and '@triodos-finance.com';</li>
 <li><strong>London Stock Exchange</strong>, using email addresses ending with '@lse-gestion.com', and a website 'www2.lse-private.com'.</li>
</ul>

<p>Fraudsters might also usurp the names of other financial institutions.</p>

<p>For more information on how these fraudulent schemes work, consumers are invited to consult the FSMA’s warning of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/scammers-pass-themselves-banks-beware-fraud">27 July 2022</a>.</p>

<p>The fraudsters may also use this technique to offer other banking services to consumers, and in particular <strong>offers of</strong> <strong>credit</strong>. In the latter case, the scam is based on the payment of <strong>fees</strong> that are supposedly necessary to obtain credit. The FSMA refers consumers to its <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-watch-out-scams-0">warnings</a> against 'fake credit' fraud.</p>

<p><strong>How to avoid this trap?</strong></p>

<p><strong>The FSMA also encourages you to see the recommendations it made in its&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67423"><strong>previous warning</strong></a><strong> on the subject.</strong></p>

<p>In particular, the FSMA urges you to look very carefully at the email addresses or contact details of the companies who are contacting you.</p>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>, please feel free to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify the FSMA should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></p>

<p>If you think you have been the victim of fraud,&nbsp;make sure you&nbsp;<strong>do not pay any additional sums to your contact person</strong>.&nbsp;Please note, this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p>

<p>Also, <strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a>&nbsp;immediately to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA&nbsp;to the scam</strong>&nbsp;via the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p>

<p>The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly</strong>&nbsp;and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-09T14:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">373159</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>End of the World Investor Week 2023</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week-2023</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The seventh edition of World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held from 2 to 8 October 2023. The aim of this week was to promote financial education and investor protection. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</strong></p>

<p>This year’s World Investor Week focused in particular on sustainable finance and crypto assets. Other topics, such as online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to, were also featured. This thematic week offered yet another opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p>

<p>This initiative was once again supported by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), the chairman of which is also chair of the IOSCO Board.</p>

<p>On the occasion of the World Investor Week, Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA welcomed Carmine di Noia, Director for Financial and Enterprise Affairs at the OECD, at the Wikifin Lab in Brussels. The chairman also spoke via a video message at the World Investor Week launch event in Warsaw.</p>

<p>The FSMA drew attention to World Investor Week through its social media and also launched a digital awaraness campaign on investment fraud and fraudulent offers to direct the public to its financial education website <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/"><span lang="EN-GB">www.wikifin.be</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">, which offers all kinds of useful information and handy tools relating to money matters.</span></p>

<p>Additional information on the campaign can be found on wikifin.be (available in <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/fr/epargner-et-investir/fraudes-et-escroqueries-linvestissement/ne-vous-laissez-pas-pieger-par-les">French</a> - <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/nl/sparen-en-beleggen/fraude-en-oplichting-bij-beleggen/laat-je-niet-vangen-door-beleggingsfraude">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-09T08:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">369541</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Press release on the suspension of trading in Intervest Offices & Warehouses</title>

<item>
  <title>Product governance requirements under MiFID II: implementation by the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/product-governance-requirements-under-mifid-ii-implementation-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has updated its guidelines on MiFID II product governance requirements. The guidelines are intended to achieve better investor protection and more convergence in the interpretation and supervision of the MiFID II requirements as regards product governance, namely, by requiring the manufacturers and distributors to identify the potential target markets for their products. </strong></p>

<p>The guidelines clarify the various elements that both manufacturers and distributors must take into consideration to determine whether the products they sell and the market strategies the employ are in line with the objectives and needs of their clients, depending on the types of products concerned. They take into account the latest regulatory developments, in particular as regards sustainable finance, and the increasing digitalization of marketing and distribution practices.</p>

<p>The FSMA considers that these guidelines make it possible to provide useful clarifications on the implementation of certain legal and regulatory provisions, and will therefore include it among its supervisory instruments and in its practice.</p>

<div class="box box-info box-small">
<p>The ESMA Guidelines are available <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/2023-08/ESMA35-43-3448_Guidelines_on_product_governance.pdf">here</a>.</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-05T20:59:46+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">373000</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA study on costs associated with structured debt instruments</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-study-costs-associated-structured-debt-instruments</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has conducted <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-10/fsma_2023_23_en.pdf">a study</a> to evaluate the costs of structured debt instruments. Based on this study, it has set out several recommendations for the sector. As part of its aim to better inform consumers, the FSMA publishes information to help consumers better understand and assess the costs associated with such products. </strong></p>

<h2><strong>What are structured debt instruments?</strong></h2>

<p>Structured debt instruments are complex financial products with a pre-established duration, offering a return linked, according to a more or less complex formula, to the performance of an underlying asset such as an equity index or an interest rate. The majority of structured debt instruments marketed in Belgium offer a right to repayment of the capital (except for entry fees) on maturity.</p>

<h2><strong>Analysis of the costs over the past 5 years</strong></h2>

<p>The FSMA has conducted an analysis based on 806 structured debt instruments offered to the public in Belgium between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2022, for which the Key Information Document (‘KID’) was notified to the FSMA. The FSMA found that the costs on average remained relatively stable between 2018 and mid-2022 with a slight downward trend, which reversed at the end of 2022, in parallel to the interest rates going up.&nbsp; In the recommendations it addresses to the sector, the FSMA encourages costs not to be increased, even in an economic context of higher interest rates or better market conditions.</p>

<p>The FSMA considers that the characteristics of a product should not influence the margin of the issuer or the distributor and that the price paid for the additional risk taken by the investor should be fully devoted to structuring a more attractive potential return.</p>

<p>When a structured product is distributed, the FSMA will continue to ensure that the costs inherent to structured products remain at a level at which customers’ interests are properly taken into account.</p>

<h2><strong>Better informing consumers on the costs of structured debt instruments</strong></h2>

<p>As part of its task of protecting and educating financial consumers, the FSMA wishes to continue to better inform consumers. As it already did with the publication of its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-study-costs-associated-investments-funds">study</a> of the costs associated with investments&nbsp; in funds, the FSMA is now providing consumers with information to allow them to better understand the costs of structured debt instruments.</p>

<p>Parallel to its recommendations&nbsp;to the sector, it is also publishing a communication&nbsp;aiming to:</p>

<ul>
 <li>explain the main characteristics of structured debt instruments;</li>
 <li>detail the costs associated with structured debt instruments;</li>
 <li>explain how the annual cost impact indicator works, which investors can find in the Key Information Document<sup><a href="#1">[1]</a></sup>;</li>
 <li>communicate to investors the average costs charged by issuers/distributors of structured debt instruments offered to the public</li>
</ul>

<p>The communication can be consulted on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-10/2023_study_costs-debt-instrument_en.pdf">the FSMA’s website</a>.</p>

<p><sup><a name="1">[1]</a> </sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Key Information Document (‘KID’) is a legal document that must be prepared in accordance with the provisions of the PRIIPs Regulation(Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products). The aim of the KID is to give retail consumers essential information about an investment product. It must be provided to investors before they subscribe to a product.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-03T09:29:32+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">370024</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches a new awareness campaign against online investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-new-awareness-campaign-against-online-investment-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Since the beginning of this year, fraudsters have used online platforms to steal as much as 10.89 million euros from unsuspecting Belgian investors, or an average of 1.21 million euros per month. And that is only the tip of the iceberg, since many cases of fraud go unreported. In the effort to call a halt to such online swindles, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) together with Wikifin, its financial education programme, is launching a new awareness campaign. “We want to make investors aware that trust in the provider has to be one of the most important factors in their choice. We are therefore offering them tools they can use to steer clear of fraudsters in the future”, according to Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA.</strong></p>

<p>Belgians are increasingly seeking out online investment platforms. But along the way, they are sometimes led astray and find themselves the target of well organized fraudsters. This year, the FSMA has already received 1403 reports of fraudulent practices, an average of five per day. That is up by a quarter over the same period last year.</p>

<p>Investigation has enabled the FSMA to identify 172 deceptive entities this year alone. Unfortunately, far too often, investment fraudsters are unmasked only once the harm is done. The reports received by the FSMA indicate that the average amount that victims have been swindled out of is 17,134 euros. The damage is therefore significant, and makes this form of fraud particularly lucrative for swindlers.</p>

<h2><strong>Professionals</strong></h2>

<p>It is worth noting that that many Belgians still think that online fraudsters are just lone wolves and that their attempts are often so amateurish that they can easily be recognized.</p>

<p>Yet, it is clear that the fraud is committed increasingly by well organized gangs, who behave like a company, with a call centre, graphic designer, manager, etc. Often, they work at an international level. It is important that Belgian investors have access to clear and accurate information so they can avoid falling into the hands of such organizations.</p>

<h2><strong>New campaign with useful tips</strong></h2>

<p>This is why Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme, is launching a large-scale online awareness campaign: “Don’t be duped by investment fraudsters”. There is an accompanying campaign video, in which the ‘CEO’ of one of these gangs of fraudsters gives you a tour of his fake company and reveals how he leads investors up the garden path.</p>

<p>The campaign is designed for people of all ages. The figures indicate that the main target group for online fraudsters is Belgians between the ages of 40 and 70. One of the reasons for this is that this group generally has more financial resources.</p>

<blockquote>
<p><em>'However, people in their twenties and thirties are just as likely to be duped. Online fraudsters are particularly inventive and use all sorts of methods, often very professional in appearance, to hoodwink someone and gain their trust. They may do so by email or phone, via fake advertisements on social media, etc. Therefore, we are providing a set of helpful tips on our website to enable consumers to be alert and steer clear of fraudsters', </em>says Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Wikifin’s new awareness campaign runs from 2 October to 12 November 2023. More information is available on the website <a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a>.</p>

<h3><strong>Tip 1: Check the identity of the provider</strong></h3>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/check-your-provider">Always check your provider</a>! You can never be too careful. The FSMA publishes lists of companies that hold an authorization to offer financial products and services. If the provider is not on one of those lists, be particularly careful and don’t just accept their offer. Be sure to check first whether their name may be on the FSMA’s list of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">companies</a> that are operating unlawfully.</p>

<h3><strong>Tip 2: Beware of fraudsters who present themselves as well-known companies</strong></h3>

<p>Even if you think you are familiar with the provider, double check and verify the contact information of the entity who contacted you. Many fraudsters deceptively use the name of a renowned company that does hold an authorization. These are also known as ‘cloned firms’. More information is available <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies">here</a>.</p>

<h3><strong>Tip 3: Don’t transfer money to a foreign account before checking</strong></h3>

<p>Never respond immediately to an offer. Play for time or say ‘no’. This will give you the time to gather all the information you need about the provider. Be sure to take a close look at the URL and the email address. An address abroad, especially if it is outside the European Union, makes it difficult to get back in touch with the provider if you encounter any problems later.</p>

<h3><strong>Tip 4: Be critical of every offer</strong></h3>

<p>Be critical of every offer you receive. If it seems too good to be true, it probably is. Be sure you know what you are buying and how your money will be used. Be extra wary if someone wants to sell you complicated investment products that you don’t fully understand.</p>

<h3><strong>Tip 5: In case of doubt, contact the FSMA</strong></h3>

<p>You can always ask the FSMA about an investment offer you suspect may be fraudulent. Do you have any doubts? Feel free to fill in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. The FSMA will get back to you as soon as possible.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-10-02T07:40:52+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">370897</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>World Investor Week 2023</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week-2023</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The seventh World Investor Week will take place from Monday 2 to Sunday 8 October 2023. It is organized by IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions. The aim of World Investor Week is to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas will be at the centre of attention.</strong></p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again lends its full support to this initiative. This year’s World Investor Week focuses on sustainable finance and crypto assets. Other topics, such as online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to, are also featured. Within this framework, the FSMA will be launching a major awareness campaign against online investment fraud.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-09-29T08:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">369540</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Guidelines on policies and controls for the effective management of ML/TF risks when providing access to financial services</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-policies-and-controls-effective-management-mltf-risks-when-providing-access</link>
  <description>
<p>The guidelines concern the general phenomenon of ‘de-risking’. This term refers to cases where (certain groups of) customers are refused access to financial services because of higher ML/TF risks.The guidelines explain that a customer can only be refused services on grounds of ML/TF risk factors after various other options have first been considered (such as increasing the intensity of monitoring measures). The guidelines also set out the steps that institutions must take when considering refusing or terminating a business relationship with a customer on grounds of ML/TF risk factors (such as documenting its decisions). The guidelines also clarify the interaction between access to financial services and compliance with the AML/CFT obligations in situations where customers have justifiable reasons for not being able to meet the traditional requirements of customer due diligence (CDD).</p>

<p>The FSMA considers that these guidelines help clarify the application of certain provisions of the Law of 18 December 2017 and of the FSMA Regulation of 3 July 2018. The FSMA will therefore incorporate these guidelines into its supervisory policy <strong>as from 3 November 2023</strong>, and will use them, in particular, when assessing the adequacy of the risk assessments and of the policies and procedures relating to combating money laundering and terrorist financing that have been drawn up by the entities under the FSMA’s supervision.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
 <li><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>See the <a href="https://www.eba.europa.eu/sites/default/documents/files/document_library/Publications/Guidelines/2023/1054144/Guidelines%20on%20MLTF%20risk%20management%20and%20access%20to%20financial%20services.pdf">EBA Guidelines of 13 March 2023</a></span></span></span></li>
 <li>Read more in Circular FSMA_2023_20 on policy and monitoring with a view to effective management of ML/FT risk factors when granting access to financial services (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-09/fsma_2023_20_fr.pdf">French </a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-09/fsma_2023_20_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)</li>
 <li>Read more in Circular FSMA_2023_21 on non-profit organizations (available in <a href="&lt;a href=">French </a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-09/fsma_2023_21_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-09-28T11:12:15+02:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">372058</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Beware of these new fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-these-new-fraudulent-trading-platforms-1</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA has continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Such trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a specific investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts. Furthermore, many trading platforms use WhatsApp and Telegram.</p><p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/pyramid-schemes">pyramid scheme</a>.</p><p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;They often claim to hold an authorization by a fake financial authority, displaying it so as to seem trustworthy. Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p><p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p><ul><li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li><li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li></ul><p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the investors’ funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their money because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p><p>***</p><p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p><ul><li><strong>Amos Limited</strong> (https://amoslimited.co/, https://am-s.cc/login, http://am-s.pro/)</li><li><strong>Binetrix</strong> (www.binetrix.com)</li><li><strong>Bitmarket</strong> Trader (https://bitmarket-trader.com/)</li><li><strong>BT Invest</strong> (https://b-tinvest.com, https://b-tinvest.dev/, https://privateacc211.com/en/platform)</li><li><strong>BTYEX</strong> (https://btyex.co/)</li><li><strong>Buycryptomarket</strong> (https://www.buycryptomarket.com)</li><li><strong>CapitalBMarket</strong> (<span lang="NL-BE">https://capitalbmarket.com/)</span></li><li><strong>CED Capital Ltd (cloned firm)</strong> (<span lang="EN-GB">https://www.cedcapitalltd.com/)</span></li><li><strong>Coinex-VIP </strong>(https://www.coinex-vip.com/)</li><li><strong>Crypto-Tech</strong> (https://crypto-tech.io)</li><li><strong>Crystals Capitals</strong> (https://crystalscapitals.info/; https://crystalscapitals.com/)</li><li><strong>EconomyPair</strong> (https://economypair.com/, https://ecnmpair.com/)</li><li><strong>ETOFXOPTIONS / ACAFXOPTIONS</strong> (https://www.etofxoptions.com/, https://www.etofx.cc/)</li><li><strong>Financeslab</strong> (https://financeslab.com/, financeslab.org, financeslab.net)</li><li><strong>Gainful Markets</strong> (https://gainfulmarkets.com/, https://platform.gainfulmarkets-tech.com/, https://gainful-markets.com/, https://m.gainfulmarkets-tech.com/)</li><li><strong>Intellect trades</strong> (www.intellecttrades.org)</li><li><strong>Investwise</strong> (https://investwise.cc/)</li><li><strong>MarketsInvest</strong> (https://marketsinvest.net, https://marketsinvest.com)</li><li><strong>Megainvestco</strong> (https://www.megainvestco.com/)</li><li><strong>MGM Global</strong> (https://mgmglobal.com/)</li><li><strong>Mondial Investments (cloned firm)</strong> (https://www.mondialinvestmentsltd.vip, https://www.mondialinvestmentsltd.com)</li><li><strong>Mtcapitals</strong> (www.mtcapitals.ai, www.mtcapitals.com)</li><li><strong>Opticapital</strong> (https://opticapital.com/, www.opticapital4.com)</li><li><strong>Otrade</strong> (https://otrade.io/; http://ptrade.io/, http://ootrade.io/, uotrade.io, https://tradeou.io/)</li><li><strong>Phoenixtb</strong> (https://www.phoenixtb.io, https://webtrader.phoenixtb-platform.com, http://phoenixtb.pro, https://www.phoenix-tb.com)</li><li><strong>Pioneer Markets</strong> (https://pioneer-markets.net/)</li><li><strong>Platinum-Markets</strong> (https://platinum-markets.com/, https://platinum-markets.io/)</li><li><strong>Primenox</strong> (https://primenox.com/, https://primenox.io/)</li><li><strong>Statehills</strong> (http://www.statehills.com/)</li><li><strong>Swiss-win</strong> (https://swiss-win.com/)</li><li><strong>Tradercode</strong> (https://tradercode.com/, https://trader-code.com/)</li><li><strong>Tradingexpo</strong> (www.tradingexpo.net)</li><li><strong>TRC</strong> (https://trcl0.com/mobile/about.html, https://trc1o.com/mobile/index.html)</li><li><strong>Universy invest</strong> (https://universyinvest.com/)</li><li><strong>Upstream Market</strong> (https://upstream-market.com/)</li></ul><p>***</p><p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</p><p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p><p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p><p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, change your passwords.</p><p>***</p><p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>FSMA press release regarding Binance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-press-release-regarding-binance</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has taken note of Binance’s decision to stop providing any services from a third country (outside the European Economic Area) and to offer its Belgian clients the option of working with Binance Poland. Under Belgian law, there is no obstacle to services being offered in Belgium by Binance Poland.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has nevertheless asked that the transfer of clients to Binance Poland be subject to an individual agreement with each of the clients concerned. In the case of clients who do not consent to a transfer to Binance Poland, Binance will need to ask them for instructions to transfer their assets to another platform based in the European Economic Area (EEA) that is authorized on the basis of its national legislation to offer services in Belgium.</p>

<p>Moreover, the FSMA wishes to recall the following information:</p>

<ul>
 <li>within the EEA, the activity of provider of exchange services between virtual currencies and fiat currencies and of wallet custody services (Virtual Asset Service Providers, VASP) currently remains an unregulated activity, except as regards the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing (AML);</li>
 <li>while awaiting the entry into force of European Regulation 2023/1114 of 31 May 2023 on markets in crypto-assets, known as the MiCA Regulation, the legal framework for carrying out activities relating to virtual currencies differs from one European state to another;</li>
 <li>Binance Poland is not subject to any obligation other than those arising from the 5<sup>th</sup> Anti-Money Laundering Directive. In application of that Directive, Binance Poland is registered with the Polish Ministry of Finance. The registration is not, as in many other EEA countries, subject to prudential requirements or an examination of the fitness or propriety of the directors or senior managers of the entities applying for registration. The Polish Ministry of Finance registers applicants within 14 days of their application; the latter process involves the provision of standard information and a declaration on their honour that the information provided by the applicant VASP is correct;</li>
 <li>the Polish Financial Supervision Authority (the KNF) does not currently have any powers vis-à-vis Binance Poland.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-08-28T17:22:31+02:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">366626</guid>
    </item>

<p>South Pass Partners is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p>Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/365996">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 28 August 2023.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by South Pass Partners and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p>South Pass Partners uses the website <strong>www.southpasspartners.com </strong>and the following contact details:</p>

<p>South Pass Partners has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of Japan (<a href="https://www.fsa.go.jp/en/refer/cold/202212-1.pdf">FSA Japan</a>).</p>

<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: The FSMA warns the public against unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-unauthorized-activities-3</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>The companies are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/365997"><strong>IWL Consulting</strong></a> (www.iwlconsulting.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/365998"><strong>May Capital Group</strong></a> (www.maycapitalgroup.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/365999"><strong>South Pass Partners</strong></a> (www.southpasspartners.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above<strong> </strong>and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p>Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be '<strong>boiler rooms'</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p>

<p>Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p>As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p>

<p>The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term 'boiler room'), insisting that they keep making further payments. <strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p>

<p>In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.<br>
 <br>
 On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>'&nbsp;published on the FSMA website.<br>
 <br>
 <strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p>If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-08-28T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO Chair welcomes European Commission’s publication of ESRS, integrating ISSB standards as endorsed by IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-chair-welcomes-european-commissions-publication-esrs-integrating-issb-standards-endorsed</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span>Jean-Paul Servais, Chair of IOSCO, has today welcomed the European Commission’s adoption of the ESRS and, in particular, the announcement by the European Commission that it has integrated the ISSB Standards into them. &nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The announcement illustrates the importance of the ISSB standards, which were recently endorsed by IOSCO as a global framework for sustainability-related disclosures in the interest of investors and issuers.</span></span></p>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais stated that '<span lang="EN-GB"><span>coming just after the recent endorsement of the ISSB standards by IOSCO, this announcement by the European Commission means that the EU, which is such an important part of global financial markets, takes significant steps towards integrating ISSB disclosure requirements and adds the 27 Member States of the European Union to the global wave of support for the ISSB standards around the world, and it does so at a crucial time</span></span>'</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-31T13:21:03+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">362290</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Publication by ESMA of a statement relating to sustainability disclosures in prospectuses</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-esma-statement-relating-sustainability-disclosures-prospectuses</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA wishes to draw the attention of issuers and their advisors to ESMA’s public statement on sustainability disclosures in prospectuses.</p>

<p>The statement is intended to provide clarity about the disclosure requirements that issuers must fulfil with respect to sustainability-related matters in both equity and non-equity prospectuses that have an “ESG” component (environmental, social and governance criteria, typically in ‘green’ bonds), based on the Prospectus Regulation&nbsp;and its delegated regulations. Final terms are also addressed.</p>

<p>Although the statement is addressed to supervisory authorities, ESMA invites issuers and their advisors to take them into consideration when drawing up prospectuses, especially as regards information relating to sustainability.</p>

<div class="box box-info box-small">
<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/fsma_2023_18_en.pdf">Read more in our Communication FSMA_2023_18...</a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-27T15:16:40+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">362192</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The global regulatory body IOSCO announces its endorsement of the implementation of the first ISSB sustainability-related financial disclosure standards </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/global-regulatory-body-iosco-announces-its-endorsement-implementation-first-issb</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Speaking at an international press conference held today, 25 July 2023, on the premises of the FSMA in Brussels, the Chairman of the International Organization of Securities Commissions, Jean-Paul Servais, announced that IOSCO has decided to endorse the first sustainability-related financial disclosure standards recently finalized by the International Sustainability Standards Board<em> </em>(ISSB). The ISSB standards have been designed to provide investors with reliable information, helping companies to communicate how they identify and manage the sustainability-related risks and opportunities they face.</strong></p>

<p>Emmanuel Faber, Chair of the ISSB, and Erkki Liikanen, Chair of the IFRS Foundation Trustees, also took the floor to reflect on this landmark event, commensurate to the emergence of the IFRS accounting standards 20 years ago.</p>

<p>The assessment of the ISSB Standards by IOSCO follows up on an explicit request from the G20, the G7 and the <em>Financial Stability Board</em> (FSB). The latter bodies requested IOSCO, whose membership regulates more than 95% of the world's securities markets, to review the new ISSB Standards to determine whether they adequately meet the needs of investors and market participants for sustainability-related financial information.</p>

<p>IOSCO worked closely with the ISSB over the last two years, allowing for the completion of a comprehensive and independent review of the final version of the ISSB Standards. After conducting a detailed independent analysis, IOSCO has concluded that the ISSB Standards are appropriate to serve as a framework for capital markets to develop the use of sustainability-related financial information in both capital raising and trading transactions.</p>

<p>Further details can be found in <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS703.pdf">the press release</a>&nbsp;and <a href="https://vimeo.com/849060366">video</a> published today by IOSCO.</p>
<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/2023-07-25-iosco-group.jpg?itok=gGgluP9U" width="1024" height="681" alt="The global regulatory body IOSCO announces its endorsement of the implementation of the first ISSB sustainability-related financial disclosure standards" title="The global regulatory body IOSCO announces its endorsement of the implementation of the first ISSB sustainability-related financial disclosure standards" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-25T14:34:22+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">361450</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Agreed settlement - Biocartis Group</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/agreed-settlement-biocartis-group</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The agreed settlement consists of the payment of 200,000&nbsp;euros and the publication, by name, on the website of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter for the AML compliance officers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-aml-compliance-officers-0</link>
  <description>
<p>AML compliance officers (ALMCO) play a key role in combatting money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT). Given the importance of their tasks, the FSMA wishes to increase opportunities for exchanging information with AMLCOs, in particular by publishing newsletters and organizing events specifically for them.</p>

<p>In line with this aim, the FSMA has published a newsletter for AMLCOs, to inform them of recent developments regarding AML/CFT and of upcoming events. These include, in particular, the second edition of the 'AMLCO Days', intended this year for the Asset Management sector, that will take place on 17 October 2023, and the publication of the EBA Guidelines on the use of remote customer onboarding solutions and of the FATF Report on countering ransomware financing.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/2023-07-18_newsletter_amlco_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/2023-07-18_newsletter_amlco_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-18T09:57:04+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">361129</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Rules on sustainable finance – Insurance intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/rules-sustainable-finance-insurance-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<p>New European rules on sustainable finance have been in the making since 2019. They are gradually coming into force. The FSMA wishes to draw the insurance intermediaries’ attention to the sustainability rules that are or will be applicable to them. It has drawn up a document (available in Dutch or French only) outlining these rules in brief. It is the insurance intermediaries’ responsibility to conduct their own analysis of the rules in order to ascertain their precise impact on their activities.</p><div class="box box-info box-small"><p>Read more in our Communication FSMA_2023_16 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/fsma_2023_16_nl_0.pdf">Dutch</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/fsma_2023_16_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</p></div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA publishes its vade-mecum on Product Oversight and Governance (POG) regarding insurance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-its-vade-mecum-product-oversight-and-governance-pog-regarding-insurance</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA provides the sector with its vade-mecum containing various recommendations and expectations regarding the implementation of the product surveillance and governance (‘POG’) requirements for the themes ‘value for money’ and ‘exclusions’. These recommendations and expectations result from the findings of various control actions conducted by the FSMA into life and non-life insurance products.</p>

<div class="box box-tip">
<p>Read more in Communication FSMA_2023_17 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/fsma_2023_17_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/fsma_2023_17_fr.pdf">French</a> only).</p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Half-yearly dashboard on investment fraud: Identity thefts on the increase</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/half-yearly-dashboard-investment-fraud-identity-thefts-increase</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-US">One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. Since last July, it has been publishing a dashboard that provides statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it is publishing the dashboard for the first semester of 2023.</span></strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>This edition of the dashboard focuses on the following items:</span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span>Consumers’ reports concerning cases of identity theft account for a little under <strong>one in six questions</strong> with regard to fraud handled by the FSMA. This trend is on the rise.</span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span>Reports of 'recovery room'&nbsp;fraud cases have increased by more than 160% compared to the same period last year.</span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span>Reports to the FSMA of unauthorized or fraudulent activities have increased by 20% compared to the first semester of 2022. During the first six months of the current year, the FSMA received a total of 924&nbsp;reports regarding such practices.</span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span>48% of these reports are complaints from consumers who have lost money.</span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-07/230706_dashboard_investment_fraud.pdf"><span>dashboard</span></a> is available on the website of the FSMA. </span></span></span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-06T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">358101</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>In need of quick cash? Beware of fake credit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/need-quick-cash-beware-fake-credit</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA <strong>has identified 47 new fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer fake credit to Belgian consumers via the internet. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.) or find advertisements <strong>online</strong>. Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</p>

<p>In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions. In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firm</strong></a>’ fraud.</p>

<p>The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</p>

<p>Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></p>

<p>The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</p>

<ul>
 <li>As-Admino (asadmino.be)</li>
 <li>BFICI (bfici.com)</li>
 <li>Bsi-Credit (bsi-credt.com)</li>
 <li>Capital Infusion / Capital Infusion LLC (capital-infusion.com)</li>
 <li>CashPay (cash-credit.fr)</li>
 <li>Cea Credits (cea-credits.ch)</li>
 <li>Creditpont (creditpont.com)</li>
 <li>Dalaxy Service (dalaxyservice.com)</li>
 <li>De lening voor iedereen Group (de-lening-voor-iedereen.com,&nbsp;<span lang="NL-BE"><span><span>snelle-leenservice.be</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li>EGS Union (https://egs-union.com)</li>
 <li>E-Loan Sodex (e-loansodex.com)</li>
 <li>Erinter-Service (erinter-service.com)</li>
 <li>Euro Finanz Welt (https://www.eurofinanzwelt.com)</li>
 <li>Fiinz Snelle Financiering (www.fiinz-snelle-financiering.fr)</li>
 <li>Get Finance (getfinanceltd.com)</li>
 <li>Gilvesty-Service / Gilvesty-Services (gilvesty-service.com)</li>
 <li>Globaluni Bank / Worldbank Kredit (globalunibnk.com)</li>
 <li>Goldservices-Bk / Golden Bank Services (goldenservices-bk.com)</li>
 <li>Harc Union Credit (https://www.harc-unioncredit.com/)</li>
 <li>Hpinvest Finance (hpinvestfinance.com)</li>
 <li>Innovate (beste-und.com)</li>
 <li>Kredit Official (kreditofficial.com)</li>
 <li>Kymco/ Kymco Services (kymco-services.com)</li>
 <li>Legal Compagny (legal-compagny.com)</li>
 <li>Lenen Direct / Lenen Direct Bank (lenendirect.com)</li>
 <li>Mavetixcompass (https://mavetixcompass.com/)</li>
 <li>Myrx Services (myrx-service.com)</li>
 <li>NM Venture Kapital (nm-venture-kapital.com)</li>
 <li>Only-Finance (only-finance.com)</li>
 <li>Ooreka Inter (oorekainter.com)</li>
 <li>Opunilo (opunilo.com)</li>
 <li>Perfecte Krediet (perfectekrediet.nl)</li>
 <li>Pluskredi (pluskredi.com)</li>
 <li>Privaatfund (privaatfund.nl)</li>
 <li>Record Finance (record-finance.com)</li>
 <li>Rocket-Money&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;(https://rocket-money.ch)</li>
 <li>Saberis Credit Group / Saberis Kredit (saberiskredit-group.com)</li>
 <li>Sarpaas / Ensar (sarpaas.com)</li>
 <li>Snelle Online Lening (snelle-online-lening.com)</li>
 <li>Snelle-Lening Group (snelle-lening.net)</li>
 <li>Solidariteit Krediet / Solidariteit Kreidiet (solidariteit-krediet.nl)</li>
 <li>Solunex Finances (solunex-finances.com)</li>
 <li>SoxyGroup (soxygroug.com)</li>
 <li>Torfsgroups (torfsgroups.com)</li>
 <li>Tresorerie Express (tresorerie-express.com)</li>
 <li>Vergas finance / Vergas finance Credit (vergasfinan-bnk.com)</li>
 <li>Witler Finance Groups (witlerfinancegroups.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person. But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a> on its website. As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-07-03T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">354601</guid>
    </item>
