<item>
  <title>FSMA orders Binance to cease immediately all offers of virtual currency services in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-orders-binance-cease-immediately-all-offers-virtual-currency-services-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has noted that Binance is offering and providing exchange services in Belgium between virtual currencies and legal currencies, as well as custody wallet services, from countries that are not members of the European Economic Area. The FSMA has therefore ordered Binance to cease, with immediate effect, offering or providing any and all such services in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>Persons or firms governed by the law of a country that is not a member of the European Economic Area are prohibited from offering or providing, within Belgium, by way of a professional activity – even if supplementary or ancillary – exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies or custody wallet services.</p>

<p>Failure to comply with this prohibition is subject to criminal sanctions pursuant to Article 136 of the Belgian Law on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>

<p>The FSMA takes the view that by offering such services in Belgium from countries that are not members of the European Economic Area, Binance is in violation of that prohibition. By way of its decision dated 23 June 2023, the FSMA has therefore decided to order Binance to cease, with immediate effect, offering or providing any exchange services in Belgium between virtual currencies and legal currencies, as well as custody wallet services.</p>

<p>Binance does not dispute that it offers such services in Belgium. On the basis of the general terms and conditions that apply to Belgian clients of the Binance.com platform, these services appear to be provided by <em>Binance Operators</em> that are not otherwise identified in the said contractual terms and conditions. There are apparently 27 such companies involved in the operational and/or technical aspects of the provision of these services, of which 19 appear to be based outside the European Economic Area.</p>

<p>Despite several requests for information made to Binance, the latter has not been able to demonstrate to the requisite legal standard that the legal entities that carry out the services of the above-mentioned type in Belgium are in fact based in the European Economic Area and are authorized, based on their domestic law, to provide such services in Belgium. By entities that carry out the services of the above-mentioned type, we mean entities that effectively perform (with their own funds) exchange operations between virtual currencies and legal currencies and entities that act as legal depositaries for digital assets/keys of Belgian clients.</p>

<p>As a result, it must be concluded that, in spite of the opportunities offered to Binance on several occasions, the latter has failed to demonstrate, with due documentation and proof, that the exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies and the custody wallet services that it offers and provides within Belgium are carried out by means of a legal entity governed by the law of another member state of the European Economic Area that is duly authorized by its home member state to carry out these activities, including within Belgium.</p>

<p>In addition to the order to cease their activities in Belgium immediately, the FSMA has demanded that Binance take immediate measures, after contacting their clients and taking into account any instructions the latter may give, to return to the Belgian clients in question all cryptographic keys and/or all virtual currencies that Binance holds for their account, or to transfer these to entities governed by the law of an EEA member state and duly authorized by their domestic law to carry out such activities, including within Belgium; in the latter case, Binance is to take every precaution that may be useful to guarantee the security of such transfers.</p>

<p>The Crown Prosecutor of Brussels has been informed of the acts that are liable to constitute a criminal offence.</p>

<p>****</p>

<p>The FSMA is acting in this matter pursuant to its mandate to protect consumers from illegal activities conducted within Belgium.</p>

<p>The FSMA wishes to recall that the activity of provider of exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies and of custody wallet services (VASP) remains an unregulated activity, except as concerns combating money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/TF). With regard to those aspects, the Belgian parliament has transposed the 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which introduced new obligations on the virtual currencies sector as regards combating against money laundering. This situation is therefore comparable to that in effect in the other European Union member states.</p>

<p>The EU’s MiCA Regulation (published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 9 June 2023) will introduce more general rules, and in particular prudential rules, governing activities relating to crypto-assets. These rules, with direct effect in Belgian law, will enter into force in January 2025.</p>

<p>In the absence of specific regulations at this time, it is the common law that applies, and where applicable, the relevant provisions of the Belgian Criminal Code.</p>

<p>In the meantime, the warnings against the risks associated with the use of virtual currencies that have been published by national (including the FSMA) and European supervisors remain in effect.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-23T16:03:08+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">355084</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA publishes its annual report and provides update on its future projects</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-its-annual-report-and-provides-update-its-future-projects</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has today published its annual report for 2022. On this occasion, the chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, gave an overview of its future projects.</strong></p>

<p>The core mission of the FSMA is to contribute to an honest and fair treatment of financial consumers. Last year, it launched 20 new projects for even more robust consumer protection. In these times of change and uncertainty, this is very much needed.</p>

<p>The projects offer solutions to address risks associated with virtual currencies and greenwashing, among others. They are aimed at better implementation of the conduct of business rules and shareholder protection. The projects strive for simple and cost-transparent financial products, which are easier to compare amongst themselves. For consumers and investors who have been duped, there are suggestions for pursuing a more efficient legal remedy. There are also plans to expand the FSMA’s financial education programme.</p>

<p>Three-quarters of these 20 new projects have now been completed or are in progress. For instance, new rules have recently come into force governing the supervision of advertisements for virtual currencies. Other projects, such as the introduction of a bankers’ oath and the simplification of fire insurance policies, are underway.</p>

<p>In a webinar, the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, provided an initial overview of the progress of the projects. He also addressed several key themes of the annual report. More information is available in the presentation of the webinar and in a video message in which Jean-Paul Servais sets out some of the most important topics in the annual report.</p>

<p>The complete 2022 annual report is available on the FSMA website (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/rapports-annuels">French</a>&nbsp;-&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/jaarverslagen">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-23T00:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">353516</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Speech of the Chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO at a conference organized by Better Finance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/speech-chairman-fsma-and-iosco-conference-organized-better-finance</link>
  <description>
<p>On 20 June 2023 Jean-Paul Servais, the chairman of IOSCO and of the FSMA, gave a speech at the conference organized by Better Finance, the European Federation of Investors and Financial Services Users, about the recent proposals of the European Commission as part of its retail investment strategy (RIS). In his capacity of chairman of IOSCO, Jean-Paul Servais pointed out that:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Retail investor protection represents a core objective for IOSCO and is key to maintaining retail investors’ trust in capital markets;</li>
 <li>The increased digitalization of financial services offers fraudsters and scammers an opportunity to also use these digital channels. Regulators worldwide should master those new and digital tools in order to effectively combat ever-changing forms of fraud;</li>
 <li>The significant risks associated with crypto-assets should be addressed at a global level, according to the principle: ‘same activity, same risk, same rules’. The public consultation organised by IOSCO on this subject is available <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS693.pdf">here</a>.</li>
 <li>Supporting financial education initiatives should enable retail investors to better understand the opportunities but also the risks associated with investing.</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-06/2023-06-20_better_finance.pdf">Jean-Paul Servais' full speech is available here</a></p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-20T16:17:42+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">354368</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Annual Meeting of IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/annual-meeting-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p>The International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) held its 48th Annual Meeting, this week. The meeting was hosted by the Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand, in Bangkok, and was chaired by Jean-Paul Servais, the chairman of IOSCO and of the FSMA.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The financial supervisors that are members of IOSCO regulate more than 95% of the world’s financial markets across 130 jurisdictions. The IOSCO Annual Meeting serves as a platform for IOSCO members to convene, discuss market developments, share knowledge, and foster collaboration.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais welcomed the work done and emphasized the important progress made in recent months on some key topics : “<em>Our meetings of the IOSCO Board and other IOSCO committees this week have been the occasion to monitor recent market developments and to highlight the work realized in relation to the three fundamental priorities we identified during our previous Annual Meeting in Marrakech in October 2022, namely crypto assets, sustainable finance and financial stability.”</em></p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS696.pdf">Read the IOSCO press release.</a></p>
</div>
<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/2023-bangkok1.png?itok=R6oqR-te" width="350" height="206" alt="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO on the The IOSCO 48th Annual Meeting in Bangkok" title="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO on the The IOSCO 48th Annual Meeting in Bangkok" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-15T19:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

  <title>FSMA launches comparison tool for family civil liability insurance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-comparison-tool-family-civil-liability-insurance</link>
  <description>
<p>A free tool (available in <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/fr/comparateur-dassurances-rc-familiale">French</a> - <a href="https://www.wikifin.be/nl/vergelijkingstool-verzekeringen-ba-familiale">Dutch</a> only) now available on the website <a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a> makes it easy to compare the coverage and premiums for family civil liability insurance. <item>
  <title>Questionnaires on professional integrity and appropriate expertise of candidates for regulatory functions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/questionnaires-professional-integrity-and-appropriate-expertise-candidates-regulatory</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published an update to Communications FSMA_2019_27 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2019/fsma_2019_27_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-04/fsma_2019_27_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) and FSMA_2019_30 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2019/fsma_2019_30_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2019/fsma_2019_30_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) . Changes have been made to the existing questionnaires for portfolio management and investment advice companies, management companies of UCITS and AIFs, and investment firms, and some new questionnaires have also been drawn up. As from now, these questionnaires must be used for all new application files.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Beware of these new fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-these-new-fraudulent-trading-platforms-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA has continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Such trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a specific investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts. Furthermore, many trading platforms use WhatsApp and Telegram.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">pyramid scheme</a>.</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;They often claim to hold an authorization by a fake financial authority, displaying it so as to seem trustworthy. Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the investors’ funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their money because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Assets-Access</strong> (https://www.assets-accessltd.com; https://asset-access.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>A-trade International</strong> (https://atrintl.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BingX </strong>(https://bingsaub.com/). <em>This website is a malicious clone of UAB BingX EU (https://bingx.com/) and is entirely unconnected with this company.</em></li>
 <li><strong>Bitelitgroup</strong> (https://bitelitgroup.com/; https://bitelitgrp.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Bitradercode</strong> (https://bitradercode.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Common Investments</strong> (https://commoninvestments.co/)</li>
 <li><strong>Comovest</strong> (https://comovest.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>DBSINVESTING</strong> (https://dbsinvesting.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>ECB crypto </strong>(https://ecbcrypto.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Enduring Markets</strong> (https://enduring-markets.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Erzinex</strong> (https://www.erzinex.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Finextrader</strong> (https://finextrader.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Fivoro</strong> (https://fivoro.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>GlobalX</strong> (https://globalx.company/)</li>
 <li><strong>Intelligence Prime Capital</strong> (http://www.intelligenceprimecapital.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Invest Dominate Group</strong> (https://invest-dg.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Invest Ehub</strong> (https://invest-ehub.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Ip-t.trade</strong> (https://ip-t.trade/)</li>
 <li><strong>Keller Finance</strong> (https://www.kellerfin.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Librapros</strong> (https://www.librapros.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Linitybase</strong> (https://linitybase.com/; https://linitybase.info/)</li>
 <li><strong>MIT-IC</strong> (https://www.mit-ic.com; https://www.mit-ic.net/)</li>
 <li><strong>Nextonbid</strong> (https://nextonbid.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Pocket Option</strong> (https://pocketoption.com/en; https://po.trade/en; https://pocketoption.app/)</li>
 <li><strong>Polar BTC</strong> (https://www.polarbtc.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>PrimeOlympicPro</strong> (https://primeolympicpro.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="EN-GB">Priority-Trading</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"> (https://priority-trading.com/, </span>https://www.priority-trading.net<span lang="EN-GB">)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Sallix Capital</strong> (https://sallixcapital.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Seastock-24 </strong>(https://seastock24.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>SolidusX</strong> (https://solidusx.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Spotinvest</strong> (https://www.spotinvest.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Stockswide</strong> (https://stockswide.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>SwissFxBank</strong> (http://swissfxbank.com/; https://www.swissfxbank.live/)</li>
 <li><strong>T4trade</strong> (https://www.t4trade.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="EN-GB">Topologyfis</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"> (https://topologyfis.com/en/) </span></li>
 <li><strong>Torocoin</strong> (https://torocoin.io/; https://toroc.io/)</li>
 <li><strong>Torrocapital</strong> (https://torrocapital.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="EN-GB">Winvestock</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"> (https://winvestock.com/; https://winvestock.net/) </span></li>
</ul>

<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA makes the following recommendations to investors:</p>

<p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact you may have had with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p>

<p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="https://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-05T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">349882</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA elected to preside over the work of IFREFI for the next two years</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-elected-preside-over-work-ifrefi-next-two-years</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Francophone Institute of Financial Regulation (IFREFI) is the organization of financial market authorities in the French-speaking world. IFREFI’s mission is to promote training, coordination and technical cooperation among its members, and to study any matter relating to financial regulation.</strong></p>

<p>The 21<sup>st</sup> annual meeting of IFREFI was held in Tunis in hybrid format on 31 May, 1 and 2 June 2023. On the occasion of this annual meeting, the FSMA was elected to preside over the work of IFREFI for the next 2 years.</p>

<p>A dialogue with Tunisian financial market players held on 31 May focused on the topic of “Information quality: a challenge for companies, a necessity for investors”. Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) and of IOSCO (International Organization of Securities Commissions) spoke during a panel addressing “the Challenges of extra-financial information and performance”. His remarks addressed, among other things, the work done at international level by IOSCO and the ISSB to protect investors by mitigating the risk of greenwashing on financial markets, and by contributing to drawing up standards for sustainability reporting that will benefit issuers and investors alike.</p>

<p>The 21<sup>st</sup> annual meeting also provided an opportunity for supervisors to exchange views on the crowdfunding regimes currently in force in the various jurisdictions.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-06-02T14:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">349883</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudsters pretend to be employees of the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudsters-pretend-be-employees-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against fraudsters that usurp its name and logo to mislead consumers and commit recovery room fraud.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has learned that fraudsters who put themselves forward as employees of the FSMA are contacting victims of investment fraud, promising that they can recover the money they lost. They ask the consumers to pay a fee for this purpose. This is known as <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/recovery-rooms">recovery room</a> fraud.</p>

<p>The fraudsters send <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/images/fsma-employees-eng.png">letters</a> to this effect to their potential victims:</p>

<figure class="height-auto align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/fsma-employees-eng.png?itok=cAQJU0Cd" width="608" height="796" alt="Example of letter - Fraudsters pretend to be employees of the FSMA" title="Example of letter - Fraudsters pretend to be employees of the FSMA" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>


<p>They do so using the following email addresses: <strong>no-replyfsma@outlook.com, ldavis@finglobalsolution.com and recovery@tfsma.com</strong>. Emails originating from such addresses do <strong>not</strong> come from the FSMA and must be considered fraudulent. The FSMA advises consumers who receive an email from such an email address <strong>not to respond but simply to delete the email</strong>.</p>

<p>The fraudsters usurp the identity of the FSMA in an attempt to take money from their victims or to trick them into revealing information. The FSMA has therefore forwarded this information to the judicial authorities.</p>

<p>The FSMA advises consumers to be extremely careful if they receive unsolicited messages and, in particular, not to respond to any requests to transfer money for financial services or products that are supposedly offered by the FSMA. <strong>The FSMA is not a financial institution</strong> and does not offer consumers any financial services or products. Moreover, financial supervisors such as the FSMA <strong>are not authorized to recover lost investments.</strong> They would thus never contact victims of investment fraud. Lastly, the FSMA wishes to emphasize that it never asks consumers to provide their financial information or to pay for any services. If you have the least doubt, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-30T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">347006</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>ESMA Guidelines on remuneration requirements</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/esma-guidelines-remuneration-requirements</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has drawn up guidelines on certain aspects of the MiFID II remuneration requirements.</strong></p>

<p>The aim of the guidelines is to provide better investor protection and more convergence in the interpretation and supervision of the MiFID II requirements, on the one hand in terms of remuneration and on the other hand as regards conflicts of interest and conduct of business rules, by emphasizing a number of important aspects.</p>

<p>The FSMA takes the view that these guidelines will provide clarity as to the application of certain legal and regulatory provisions of MiFID II. It will include them in its supervisory tool kit and practice.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>For more information, please see the <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/2023-04/ESMA35-43-3565_Guidelines_on_certain_aspects_of_the_MiFID_II_remuneration_requirements.pdf">ESMA guidelines</a> or the summary by the FSMA (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-05/fsma_2023_15_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-05/fsma_2023_15_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-26T10:42:53+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">349093</guid>
    </item>

  <description>
<p>As every year, you will shortly receive a request to pay a contribution to the FSMA's operating expenses. All intermediaries, lenders and regulated undertakings carrying out direct distribution activities will receive such a request.</p>

<ul>
 <li>When do I receive the payment request from the FSMA?</li>
 <li>Do all intermediaries receive their own payment request(s)?</li>
 <li>On which basis are the contributions to the operating expenses calculated?</li>
 <li>The situation described in my registration dossier has evolved since 1 January 2023. What now?</li>
 <li>I have multiple registrations as an intermediary. Will I receive one single payment request or several?</li>
 <li>Is your registration dossier still up-to-date? Special attention to the professional email address</li>

<item>
  <title>New rules on advertisements for virtual currencies enter into force</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-rules-advertisements-virtual-currencies-enter-force</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA has issued a Regulation governing the distribution of virtual currencies to consumers. This&nbsp;Regulation was approved by Royal Decree of 8 February 2023 (Belgian Official Gazette of&nbsp;</strong><strong>17 March 2023). It entered into force this Wednesday, 17 May 2023.</strong></p>

<p>The Regulation imposes various obligations, including:</p>

<ul>
 <li>rules as to content, to ensure that advertisements are not inaccurate or misleading;</li>
 <li>the insertion of mandatory statements and, in particular, the brief warning 'Virtual currency, real risks. The only guarantee in crypto is risk.', as well as a longer warning summing up the main risks associated with an investment in virtual currencies;</li>
 <li>the obligation to notify to the FSMA all advertisements to be used in a mass media campaign at least 10 days before their dissemination, in the form in which they will be disseminated.</li>
</ul>

<p>From 17 May onwards, every new advertisement that is disseminated in connection with a distribution of virtual currencies to consumers has to comply with these rules, regardless of the channel used for the dissemination (social media, internet sites, physical medium).</p>

<p>The Regulation includes a transitional regime for advertisements that have already been disseminated before the entry into force of the Regulation. These advertisements must comply with the Regulation by 17 June 2023. Cases targeted by the transitional regime are notably websites or mobile applications of service providers to carry out transactions on a platform and that have already been disseminated on 17 May 2023.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>More information on the Regulation and on the practical modalities can be found <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/crypto">here</a>.&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-17T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">347134</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO publishes a report on SPACs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-publishes-report-spacs</link>
  <description>
<p>The Board of the International Organization of Securities Commissions today published a final report on Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs), which aims to help IOSCO members review or improve their approach to these companies.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority and Chair of the IOSCO Board, said: “The SPAC boom of the last couple of years raised a host of issues related to investor protection and fair, orderly and efficient markets. While the boom may be over, it is important that we now take stock of whether there are any lessons to be learnt from the recent experiences with SPACs. This report in particular develops a toolkit that IOSCO members may use to help them to monitor, assess or review their approach to SPACs and will be of use when issues around SPACs arise again in the future.”</p>

<p>The press release of IOSCO is available via this <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS691.pdf">link</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-10T15:40:03+02:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">346279</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Guidelines on the use of remote customer onboarding solutions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-use-remote-customer-onboarding-solutions</link>
  <description>
<p>These guidelines, published by the European Banking Authority, set out the steps credit and financial institutions should take to comply with their customer due diligence obligations under the AML Directive when choosing or assessing remote customer onboarding solutions. The guidelines also set out the policies and procedures they should put in place when choosing remote customer onboarding solutions and the procedures they should apply to assess the continued adequacy and reliability of such tools. Finally, the guidelines set out the steps credit and financial institutions should take when relying on third parties and the information to gather to ensure customer due diligence and verify the authenticity and integrity of such data.</p>

<p>The FSMA considers that these guidelines provide useful details on the application of certain provisions of the Law of 18 September 2017 and of the FSMA Regulation of 3 July 2018, and will therefore incorporate these guidelines into its supervisory policy from 2 October 2023, in particular for the purpose of evaluating the adequacy of the governance arrangement and the compliance function put in place by the obliged entities to combat money laundering and terrorist financing in the context of remote customer onboarding solutions.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in FSMA_2023_11... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-05/fsma_2023_11_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-05/fsma_2023_11_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-10T12:31:37+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">346281</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA imposes an order – Hendrik Boonen</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-imposes-order-hendrik-boonen</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA orders Mr Hendrik Boonen to immediately cease all insurance distribution activity.</strong></p>

<p>Mr Hendrik Boonen’s registration as an insurance broker was deleted from the register of insurance intermediaries on 31 May 2022. This means that, as of that date, Mr Hendrik Boonen has been prohibited from perpetrating acts of insurance distribution.</p>

<p>Mr Hendrik Boonen uses the trading name ‘Hypodroom’ and is based at Lodewijk Van Berckenlaan 51, 2600 Antwerp. His website is <a href="http://www.hypodroom.com">www.hypodroom.com</a>.</p>

<p>According to information available to the FSMA, after his de-registration as an insurance broker, Mr Hendrik Boonen continued to perform acts of insurance distribution, such as making changes to insurance policies and issuing insurance certificates.</p>

<p>It is therefore possible that certain risks that were apparently insured by Mr Hendrik Boonen after 31 May 2022, are not actually insured. When in doubt, the FSMA therefore advises clients of Mr Hendrik Boonen to contact their insurance company. If, as a customer, you have transferred funds that you cannot recover, we advise you to file a complaint with the judicial authorities.</p>

<p>Do you have any doubts about providers of financial services and products? Always consult the registers of the FSMA by using the search function on our <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/check-your-provider">website</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-09T16:06:27+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">346125</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Regulatory framework applicable to VASPs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/regulatory-framework-applicable-vasps</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>For the record, the FSMA wishes to remind the public that the provision of exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies and of custody wallet services remains unregulated to this day, except for purposes of combating money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT).</strong></p>

<p>AML/CFT requirements were introduced into Belgian law by a Law dated 20&nbsp;July 2020 transposing the Fifth Money Laundering Directive. This Law implemented a registration requirement for Virtual Asset Service Providers (VASPs) and designated the FSMA as the authority responsible for supervising their activities.</p>

<p>Providers already operating prior to the coming into force of the new legislation on 1&nbsp;May 2022 were able to benefit from a so-called <em>grandfathering</em> scheme (organized by Royal Decree). Under that transitional scheme, already operating entities were permitted to continue their operations on a provisional basis until the FSMA had made a decision about their application to be enrolled in the register of VASPs, on the double condition of notifying&nbsp; the FSMA of the exercise of their activity before 1&nbsp;July 2022 and of applying for registration as VASP before 1&nbsp;September 2022.</p>

<p>Operating since 2018, Bit4You made use of this option and was therefore automatically included in the list of companies benefiting from a provisional authorization.</p>

<p>In reviewing Bit4You's application for registration, FSMA has taken all necessary steps to ensure that Bit4You complied with all requirements imposed by the Fifth Money Laundering Directive.</p>

<p>Bit4You had to change its entire governance structure in response to irregularities found by the FSMA in its application for registration. Following the subsequent insolvency of CoinLoan, Bit4You suspended its activities and ultimately withdrew its application for registration on 2&nbsp;May 2023. As a result, it automatically lost the benefit of the provisional authorization. The FSMA had previously notified Bit4You of its intention to refuse its application for registration and had informed the Public Prosecutor of the irregularities found on the part of the former management.</p>

<p>More comprehensive, and in particular prudential, rules regarding crypto activities will be introduced by the European MiCA Regulation, that is expected to come into force in early 2025. In the meantime, warnings about the risks associated with the use of crypto-currencies issued by Belgian and European supervisory authorities (including the FSMA) remain applicable.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-05-08T17:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>Eurofi 2023 Conference in Stockholm</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/eurofi-2023-conference-stockholm</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>From 26-28 April 2023, the Chairman of IOSCO and of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, participates in the half-yearly Eurofi conference. This three-day event takes place in Stockholm.</span></span></span></strong></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The Eurofi conference offers representatives of the public sector and stakeholders (financial institutions, investors representatives,&nbsp;...) a platform for the exchange of views on financial regulation and trends in the financial sector. </span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>Today Jean-Paul Servais held a keynote speech in his capacity as IOSCO chair. In this speech, he addressed key issues on IOSCO's agenda. In particular, he explained IOSCO's work on fostering resilience in Non Bank Financial Intermediation, delivering on the Sustainable Finance agenda, and achieving a first globally consistent set of standards on Crypto-Assets from a securities markets perspective.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>In the margins of the conference, Jean-Paul Servais has multiple bilateral meetings with representatives of international organizations, supervisory authorities and other stakeholders.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The text of the keynote speech of Jean-Paul Servais is available <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-04/Keynote%20Eurofi%202023%20Stockholm.pdf">here</a>. </span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/eurofi%20magazine.png?itok=viT08sbI" width="736" height="1024" alt="The Eurofi Magazine" title="The Eurofi Magazine" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>

</description>
  <pubDate>2023-04-26T09:04:48+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">343768</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-4</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular FSMA_2023_09 (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-04/aml_fsma_2023_09%20_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-04/aml_fsma_2023_09_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</p>
</description>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-contributions-fsmas-operating-expenses</link>
  <description>
<p>Important message for the intermediaries previously registered under a central institution’s responsibility.</p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>On which basis are the contributions to the operating expenses calculated?</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>The situation described in my registration dossier has evolved since 1 January 2023. What now?</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>When do I receive the payment invitation from the FSMA?</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>I have multiple registrations as an intermediary. Will I receive one single payment invitation or several?</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>Is your registration dossier still up-to-date?</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span><span>Special attention to the professional email address</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<item>
  <title>Voluntary and conditional takeover bid by Liberty Global Belgium Holding B.V. on Telenet Group Holding NV</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/voluntary-and-conditional-takeover-bid-liberty-global-belgium-holding-bv-telenet-group-holding</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB">NOTIFICATION MADE PUBLIC BY THE FSMA IN APPLICATION OF ARTICLE 7 OF THE ROYAL DECREE OF 27 APRIL 2007 ON PUBLIC TAKEOVER BIDS </span></strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">The FSMA announces, in accordance with Article 7 of the Royal Decree of 27 April 2007 on public takeover bids (the <strong>Takeover Decree</strong>), the notification that it received pursuant to Article 5 of the Takeover Decree on 13 April 2023, showing </span><span lang="EN-US">Liberty Global Belgium Holding<strong> </strong></span><span lang="EN-GB">B.V., a private limited liability company </span><span lang="EN-GB">(<em>besloten vennootschap</em>) </span><span lang="EN-GB">&nbsp;under the laws of the Netherlands, with registered office at Boeing Avenue 53, 1119 PE Schiphol-Rijk, the Netherlands, and registered with the Dutch Chamber of Commerce under number 33256392 (the <strong>Offeror</strong>), intends to launch a voluntary and conditional takeover bid in cash (the <strong>Offer</strong>) for shares (consisting of the Ordinary Shares (as defined below), the Golden Shares (as defined below) and the Liquidation Dispreference Shares (as defined below) of Telenet Group Holding NV, a public limited liability company (<em>naamloze vennootschap</em>), under the laws of Belgium, with registered office at Liersesteenweg 4, 2800 Mechelen and registered with the Crossroads Bank for Enterprises under number 0477.702.333 (LER Antwerp, division Mechelen) (the <strong>Target Company</strong>). The Ordinary Shares of the Target Company are admitted to trading on Euronext Brussels. The Golden Shares and Liquidation Dispreference Shares are not admitted to trading on any regulated market.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">The Offer relates to all shares issued by the Target Company, which are not already owned by the Offeror or persons affiliated with the Offeror (the <strong>Shares</strong>), being a total of 42,267,437 Shares or 37.70% of all shares issued by the Target Company, comprising:</span></span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">42,267,391 Ordinary Shares out of a total of </span><span lang="EN-US">112,015,127 Ordinary Shares (i.e. 37.73% of the Ordinary Shares)</span><span lang="EN-GB">;</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span lang="NL-BE">All 30 Golden Shares; and</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">16 Liquidation Dispreference Shares out of a total of 94,843 Liquidation Dispreference Shares (i.e. 0.02% of the Liquidation Dispreference Shares). </span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">The offer price is EUR 22.00 in cash per Share (i.e. </span><span lang="EN-US">for each Ordinary Share, Golden Share and Liquidation Dispreference Share which is subject to the Offer) (the <strong>Offer Price</strong>)</span><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">“<strong>Ordinary Shares</strong>” </span><span lang="EN-US">are the 112,015,127 ordinary fully paid-up shares of the Target Company (excluding Liquidation Dispreference Shares and Golden Shares) with voting rights, without nominal value.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">“<strong>Golden Shares</strong>” are the 30 shares of the Target Company held by six intermunicipalities offering them, in addition to the rights attached to Ordinary Shares, the right to appoint representatives to the Target Company’s regulatory board (<em>regulatoire raad</em>) and the right to appoint an observer to the board of directors of the Target Company. </span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">“<strong>Liquidation Dispreference Shares</strong>” are the 94,843 shares of the Target Company held by Interkabel Vlaanderen CV (as to 16 such shares) and the Offeror (as to 94,827 such shares) and which are subject to a liquidation dispreferential treatment in the case of a liquidation of the Target Company. The Liquidation Dispreference Shares are otherwise identical to and participate in the capital, voting rights and profits in the same manner as the Ordinary Shares. </span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">If the Target Company’s ordinary general meeting of 26 April 2023 approves the payment of a gross dividend of EUR 1.00 per share as proposed by the Target Company’s board of directors and the ex-dividend date (3 May 2023) falls prior to the date of payment of the Offer Price, the Offer Price per Share will be reduced by the total gross amount of such dividend (before any applicable tax deduction), resulting in an amount of EUR 21.00 per Share.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">As at the date of the notification by the Offeror to the FSMA in accordance with Article 5 of the Takeover Decree, the Target Company has not issued any securities with voting rights or giving access to voting rights within the meaning of the Takeover Decree other than the securities mentioned above. </span></span></span></span></p>

<p>The Offer is subject to the following conditions:</p>

<ol>
 <li>(a) as <span lang="NL-BE"><span>a result of the Offer, the Offeror, together with the persons affiliated with the Offeror, collectively own at least 95% of the shares in the Target Company (this condition, the <strong>Acceptance Threshold Condition</strong>); and</span></span></li>
 <li>(b)&nbsp;as <span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">from 13 April 2023, being the date of the notification of the Offeror to the FSMA in accordance with article 5 of the Takeover Decree (the <strong>Notification Date</strong>), and during the period preceding the date on which the results of the initial acceptance period of the Offer are announced:</span></span></span></span>
 <ol>
  <li>(i) the <span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">closing price of the BEL-20 index </span><span lang="EN-GB">(ISIN: BE0389555039) has not decreased </span><span lang="EN-GB">17.5% or more as compared to the closing price of the BEL-20 index on the business day preceding </span><span lang="EN-GB">the Notification Date (i.e. BEL-20 index is not lower than 3,136.39 points); and/</span><span lang="EN-GB">or</span></span></span></span></li>
  <li>(ii) the <span lang="NL-BE"><span>closing prices of&nbsp;both (x) the shares in Proximus NV/SA as listed on Euronext Brussels (ISIN: BE0003810273) and (y) the shares in Orange Belgium NV/SA as listed on Euronext Brussels (ISIN: BE0003735496) have not decreased 17.5% or more&nbsp;compared to their respective closing price as listed on Euronext Brussels on the business day preceding the Notification Date (i.e. Proximus NV/SA closing price is not lower than EUR 7.38 per share and Orange Belgium NV/SA closing price is not lower than EUR 12.94 per share), </span></span></li>
 </ol>
 </li>
</ol>

<p>each of the so calculated closing prices as set forth in (i) and (ii), a <strong>MAC Threshold</strong>.</p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">If the Offeror does not withdraw the Offer at a time when (i) the closing price of the BEL-20 index and/or (ii) both the closing price of Proximus NV/SA and the closing price of Orange Belgium NV/SA, are below the relevant MAC Threshold, and such relevant closing prices subsequently rise again above the relevant MAC Threshold, the Offeror will not be able to invoke this earlier and temporary decrease of such relevant closing prices thereafter. The possible decision of the Offeror to maintain the Offer during a period where (i) the closing price of the BEL-20 index and/or (ii) both the closing price of Proximus NV/SA and the closing price of Orange Belgium NV/SA, have temporarily fallen below the relevant MAC Threshold does not affect the Offeror’s right to still invoke the condition and withdraw the Offer should (i) the closing price of the BEL-20 index and/or (ii) both the closing price of Proximus NV/SA and the closing price of Orange Belgium NV/SA, after a recovery, subsequently again fall below the relevant MAC Threshold.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">The Offeror may withdraw the Offer if any of these conditions precedent has not been met. These conditions are exclusively for the benefit of the Offeror who reserves the right to waive any of these conditions, in whole or in part. The Offeror may acquire Shares even if the number of tendered Shares is lower than what is specified in the Acceptance Threshold Condition. If any of the above conditions are not met, the Offeror will announce its decision whether or not to waive this condition (or these conditions) no later than at the time of announcement of the results of the initial acceptance period. </span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">The Offeror intends to launch a simplified squeeze-out offer, in accordance with Article 7:82, §1 of the Belgian Code of Companies and Associations and Articles 42 and 43 of the Takeover Decree, if the conditions for such simplified squeeze-out are met after expiration of the initial (or a subsequent) acceptance period for the Offer, in order to acquire the Shares not yet acquired by the Offeror on the same terms as those of the Offer.</span></span></span></span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-04-13T18:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">340672</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO publishes report on retail market conduct</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-publishes-report-retail-market-conduct</link>
  <description>
<p>The Board of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) published its Report on Retail Market Conduct, in response to the evolving retail trading landscape, influenced by changing macro conditions, demographic trends, and technological developments.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA and of IOSCO said: <em>“Safeguarding the interests of retail investors is a core objective for IOSCO and a pre-requisite to help sustain retail investors’ interest and trust in capital markets. As a result of their increasing share in the overall trading volume, the retail market segment is increasingly influencing price formation and market trends. This in turn can make retail investors more vulnerable to misconduct by wrongdoers via a wide range of sophisticated tactics to exploit vulnerabilities. In today’s digital world, fraud patterns are increasingly cross-border and have no jurisdictional boundaries. IOSCO’s Retail Market Conduct Report is an overarching and global response to evolving misconduct trends and fraud patterns. As the IOSCO Board Chair, I would recommend the Toolkit suggested in the Report to regulators and supervisors around the world. IOSCO will continue to work on these issues.”</em></p>

<p>Find more information in the <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS687.pdf">IOSCO press release</a><em>.</em></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-04-03T12:16:57+02:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>Classification of fractional investments as investment instruments</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/classification-fractional-investments-investment-instruments</link>
  <description>
<p>The active marketing and sale of what are known as ‘fractional shares’ by (foreign) financial institutions to retail clients is an attractive new phenomenon that is gaining in popularity in Belgium as well.</p>

<p>Fractional investing enables investors to determine the amount they wish to invest in an underlying share. In exchange, investors acquire a right to part of a share. Shares that are traded at high prices thus become more accessible to retail investors. This form of investment also makes it easier to diversify one’s investment portfolio. However, this type of investment does not have advantages only. Fractional investors need to be aware that in many cases they are not investing directly in the share itself, but in another type of investment instrument that is issued or created by an entity that is separate from the issuer of the share, with legal and economic characteristics that are substantially different from the share itself. The risks and costs associated with fractional investing may differ significantly from the risks and costs of the underlying share.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-03/fsma_2023_06_en.pdf">Read more about the topic in our Communication FSMA_2023_06...</a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-30T08:35:17+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Having to pay to receive your loan? Beware of fake credit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/having-pay-receive-your-loan-beware-fake-credit</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer consumers fake credit.</strong></p>

<p>Over the past few months, the FSMA <strong>has identified 28 fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer fake credit to Belgian consumers via the internet. Consumers come into contact with such providers in a variety of ways: they receive <strong>unsolicited messages</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.) or find advertisements <strong>online</strong>. Given the current economic situation, consumers often search for extra funds in the form of credit, and as a result may come into contact with questionable players.</p>

<p>In practice, these involve <strong>fake credit</strong> that is offered to consumers in order to coax consumers into giving them money. The fraudsters claim to be authorized lenders or registered credit intermediaries, and do not hesitate to use the names or logos of well-known credit institutions. In such cases, this is considered to be a case of ‘<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firm</strong></a>’ fraud.</p>

<p>The fraudsters offer loans at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, the credit provider claims to lend large amounts at a low interest rate. It also claims that there will be no credit check on the consumer to determine whether he or she is a poor payer who has taken out loans in the past which he or she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>Consumers who accept the credit offer are asked to pay some <strong>costs</strong> associated with the credit up front. These may be presented as an insurance premium to cover the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, administrative costs, etc. But these are all fictitious costs.</p>

<p>Once the consumers have paid these so-called costs, the ‘lender’ disappears into thin air and it is nearly impossible to recover the sums paid.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such credit offers.</strong></p>

<p>The illegally operating companies against which the FSMA warns the public are as follows:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Adelan Finances (https://adelanfinances.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Akoue (https://www.akoue.eu/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>BNC Finance (http://bnc-finance.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Cerberus (https://cerberusplus.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>CK Kredit (https://www.ckkredit.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>CLC Bank (https://clcbank.org/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Crédit Belge (https://creditbelge.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Credit Express (https://credit-express.net)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Earing Group Ltd (www.earinggroup-ltd.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Eerst Krediet (https://eerstkrediet.com) </strong></li>
 <li><strong>Europa Finanzierung (http://europafinanzierung.com/) </strong></li>
 <li><strong>Fianc Emprunts 24 (https://fiancemprunts24.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Fouranexwork (https://fouranexwork.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Infilrux Financial (https://infilruxfinancial.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>KashSpeed (https://www.kashspeed.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Kredit Line Ltd (https://kreditlineltd.info/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Kymco Krediet Bank (https://kymco-krediet.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Legal Finance global (https://esayfinance.com) en (https://legalfinanceglobal.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Mixatelwort (https://mixatelwort.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>My Financial Group (https://my-financialgroup.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Opunilo Financial (https://www.opunilo.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Pro-Lening (http://pro-lening.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Rabo Krediet (https://rabo-krediet.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Roalix-Finance (https://roalix-finance.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Snel Lenen (https://snel-lenen.com/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Snelle-lenen (https://snelle-lenen.nl) </strong></li>
 <li><strong>Sokredinet (https://sokreditnet.com) </strong></li>
 <li><strong>Volkrediet (https://volkrediet.com/)</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA has a number of <strong>general recommendations</strong> to enable you to recognize such fraudulent credit offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be suspicious if you are <strong>suddenly offered credit out of the blue</strong> via the internet or social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on very favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer’s financial situation, at a very low interest rate or with an unusually long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be available from authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender makes the credit subject to the payment of a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before the credit will be granted</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, file handling costs, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the ‘lender’ disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Enquire whether the lender has the necessary authorization or registration.</strong>&nbsp;Via the<br>
 <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website, you can easily determine whether this person has the necessary authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by the same person. But remain alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the company itself in order to gain the confidence of consumers.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a> on its website. As well, please feel free to notify the FSMA of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-27T07:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">334941</guid>
    </item>

  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved on 22 March 2023 in accordance with Article 34, §1, of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU.</p>

<item>
  <title>Virtual currencies: the FSMA steps up its action to protect consumers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/virtual-currencies-fsma-steps-its-action-protect-consumers</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>New rules governing advertisements for virtual currencies (also known as cryptocurrencies) will enter into force in less than 2 months. The rules are intended, among other things, to ensure that the risks associated with virtual currencies are sufficiently prominent in such advertisements. The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) will supervise compliance with those rules. In addition, the FSMA will be investing even more in financial education about virtual currencies, including via an educational video that it is launching today on the occasion of the start of the 8th edition of Money Week.</strong></p>

<p>Virtual currencies are all the rage at the moment, but they involve considerable risk. There is no legal framework yet governing these products, and they have no underlying assets in the ‘real’ world. They are often subject to wild price fluctuations and are vulnerable to fraud and IT-related risks.</p>

<p>For these reasons, the FSMA requested and was granted a new power by the government to regulate advertisements for virtual currencies. The FSMA issued a Regulation to this end that was published on 17 March 2023 in the Belgian Official Gazette (Moniteur belge/Belgisch Staatsblad) and will enter into force on 17 May 2023. The Regulation has three main aspects:</p>

<ul>
 <li>The basic principle that advertisements must be accurate and not misleading</li>
 <li>Advertisements must contain mandatory information that points out the risks</li>
 <li>Mass media campaigns must be notified to the FSMA in advance</li>
</ul>

<p>The Regulation sets out conditions that all advertisements must meet. So, for example, advertisements may not emphasize the potential advantages without also providing an accurate indication of the risks, limitations or conditions. Nor may advertisements contain any statements about the future value or return, and must be written in comprehensible language.</p>

<p>In addition to these conditions, advertisements must also contain a short and punchy warning: '<strong><em>Virtual currencies, real risks.</em> <em>The only guarantee in crypto is risk</em></strong><em>.</em><em>'</em> All advertisements must also contain a broader warning or a link or reference to such a warning. The broader warning should sum up the various risks in greater detail.</p>

<p>Lastly, mass media campaigns must be notified to the FSMA at least ten days in advance. Mass media campaigns are campaigns that disseminate advertisements to at least 25,000 consumers. The prior notification is intended to enable the FSMA to intervene, if necessary, before the campaign actually begins.</p>

<p>In addition to its new supervisory power, the FSMA is also investing in providing more financial education about virtual currencies. It has developed a new educational video on virtual currencies, which is part of a series of four videos produced in a format that appeals to young people. The videos, in combination with an information sheet for teachers and a quiz for pupils, constitute a complete lesson package. The videos will be launched at the Wikifin Lab by this week, on the occasion of Money Week, by several federal government ministers.</p>

<p>The FSMA is also working on a new game module for the Wikifin Lab, its financial education centre. The module is intended to make young people aware of the risks associated with virtual currencies. A first draft of the new module is currently being tested; it will be launched at the beginning of the next school year.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>'<em>Some consumers want to earn money quickly by trading in virtual currencies. This goes hand in hand with great risks. In order to better protect consumers, the FSMA is stepping up the pace when it comes to supervision and financial education</em>,' says Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA. '<em>Thanks to the new Regulation, the FSMA will be able to check whether advertisements for virtual currencies are accurate and not misleading, and whether the advertisements contain the compulsory warnings of risk.'</em></p>
</blockquote>

<p><em>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ******</em></p>

<p>In light of its new powers, the FSMA has carried out a study of investor behaviour in Belgium. It engaged the IPSOS market research firm to survey 1000 investors in November 2022. These are people who invest money in something other than a savings account, a term deposit account or an individual pension plan. We present here the main findings of the survey as regards virtual currencies, based on the answers given by the participants.</p>

<p><strong>It is chiefly young people who buy virtual currencies</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>Young people (aged 16-29) are the best represented among the group of investors who buy virtual currencies. 34 per cent of investors between the ages of 16 and 29 trade in virtual currencies. But higher age groups are also active in virtual currencies: 30 per cent of those between 30-39, 17 per cent of the 40-49 age group, and 11 per cent of investors between the ages of 50 and 59.</li>
 <li>Trading in virtual currencies is most popular among men and in Flanders. 80 per cent of those who invest in virtual currencies are men. 63 per cent live in Flanders, 22 per cent in Wallonia and 15 per cent in Brussels.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Mainly for quicker earnings</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>Making money quickly (43 per cent) and the pleasure and excitement of trading in innovative products (36 per cent) are the main reasons for trading in virtual currencies.</li>
 <li>Investors who do not trade in virtual currencies say it is because of the high risk (58 per cent) or because they don’t believe in it or don’t see the point (46 per cent).</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Large group invest small amounts in virtual currencies</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>The amounts traded in virtual currencies are smaller than in traditional investments.</li>
 <li>More than 60 per cent of traders bought less than 2500 euros’ worth of virtual currencies; 31 per cent bought less than 500 euros’worth. Only 15 per cent bought more than 10,000 euros’ worth of virtual currencies.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>‘Cryptowinter’ has not caused believers to waver</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>The cryptowinter and the bankruptcy of FTX has hardly affected faith in virtual currencies. Only 7 per cent say that they will no longer trade in virtual currencies as a result.</li>
 <li>More than 60 per cent consider recent events a ‘temporary correction’ or will continue trading in virtual currencies.</li>
 <li>16 per cent of crypto traders even consider this an opportunity and are trading even more in virtual currencies than before.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Friends, family, mobile apps and robo-advice important for people trading in crypto</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>Both crypto and non-crypto traders get most of their information from newspapers and product sheets.</li>
 <li>Friends and family as well as mobile apps and robo-advice are sources of information for 27 per cent of people trading in crypto, as compared to 18 and 13 per cent respectively of non-crypto traders.</li>
</ul>

<blockquote>
<p><em>'These figures are useful to help guide the FSMA’s actions</em>. They also indicate the usefulness of the FSMA’s approach and strengthen its resolve to continue to take a proactive attitude in this area,' concludes Jean-Paul Servais.</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-20T07:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">332431</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Wikifin’s 10th anniversary is something to celebrate: more than 100,000 pupils to participate in Money Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/wikifins-10th-anniversary-something-celebrate-more-100000-pupils-participate-money-week</link>
  <description>
<p>The celebration of the 10<sup>th</sup> anniversary of Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme, will kick off this year’s edition of Money Week next Monday. This is an annual themed week organized by Wikifin. The purpose of the week is to provide opportunities to talk about money matters as widely as possible and to devote extra attention to the importance of financial education. During Money Week, a total of more than 100,000 elementary and secondary school pupils will participate in a variety of activities. A brief overview.</p>

<item>
  <title>Court of Cassation overturns the Market Court’s judgment annulling a decision by the Sanctions Committee on a case of market manipulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/court-cassation-overturns-market-courts-judgment-annulling-decision-sanctions-committee-case</link>
  <description>
<p>In <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-03/2023-02-10_cassatiearrest.pdf">its decision of 10 February 2023</a>, the Court of Cassation ruled that the FSMA’s appeal against the Market Court’s judgment of 23 March 2022 was well founded. The Market Court’s judgment had annulled <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-03/2020-10-06-sanctieprocedure.pdf">the decision of 6 October 2020 taken by the FSMA’s Sanctions Committee</a> to impose a fine for an infringement of the prohibition against market manipulation. The Court of Cassation has now overturned the judgment of the Market Court and sent the case back to the Market Court, sitting in a different configuration.</p>

<p>The Court of Cassation’s decision accepts the sole plea invoked by the FSMA against the Market Court’s judgment. The first element of that plea was essentially that the Market Court wrongfully held that there was a breach of the legality principle, the proportionality principle and the obligation to provide material justification, inasmuch as the FSMA did not have a previously announced policy on fines or a rulebook setting out in detail the criteria for the application of the sanction. The second element of the plea was that by deciding that it is not sufficient for the alleged perpetrator to be able to oppose the fine called for by the Management Committee, but that the Sanctions Committee must, before imposing the sanction, inform the alleged perpetrator of the sanction that it plans to impose, the Market Court violated the legally mandated organic separation between the investigation and prosecution on the one hand, and the decision on the merits on the other hand, which is intended to guarantee the independent and impartial treatment of the case. The Court of Cassation found in favour of the FSMA on both elements.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-14T17:50:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">332428</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>IFRS Monitoring Board meets in Tokyo</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/ifrs-monitoring-board-meets-tokyo</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, the chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) and the International Organisation of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), is passing on the torch after six years of chairing the IFRS Monitoring Board. At a meeting in Tokyo, the Monitoring Board elected Takashi Nagaoka of the Japanese Financial Services Agency as its new chairman.</strong></p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais joined the Monitoring Board as vice-chairman of IOSCO. He was first elected chairman of the Monitoring Board in 2017 and was subsequently re-elected twice, each time for a two-year term.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>'It was an honour to chair the Monitoring Board for six years. Very important work has been done during that period, including the establishment of the International Sustainability Standards Board, ISSB. As new IOSCO chair it is one of my priorities to interact with the IFRS Foundation, in particular in view of a possible IOSCO endorsement of the first sustainability related corporate disclosure standards,' Jean-Paul Servais said.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The Monitoring Board oversees the proper functioning of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation. This non-profit organisation oversees the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), which drafts global IFRS accounting standards, and the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB), which develops global standards for reporting on climate or other sustainability issues.</p>

<p>Read the Monitoring Board's press release <a href="https://www.iosco.org/about/monitoring_board/pdf/Press-20230303-1.pdf">here</a>.</p>
<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/jean-paul-servais-japan2.png?itok=gbQ7EG14" width="305" height="205" alt="Jean-Paul Servais, the chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO and Takashi Nagaoka of the Japanese Financial Services Agency" title="Jean-Paul Servais, the chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO and Takashi Nagaoka of the Japanese Financial Services Agency" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-09T00:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
