    </item>
<item>
  <title>AB INVESTMENT</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/ab-investment</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of AB Investment, a company that offers investment services to the public in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>AB Investment offers consumers investments in binary options, futures or options which they promise will bring substantial profits.</p>

<p>The websites it uses are as follows:</p>

<ul>
 <li>ab-investment-acces.net</li>
 <li>ab-investment.net</li>
 <li>https://cbcgroup-lu.com/login</li>
</ul>

<p>In many cases, consumers are contacted by a person calling himself Paul Willems (paul.willems@ab-investment.net or paul.willems@cbcgroup-lu.net).</p>

<p>These companies and this person do not have the authorization necessary to offer investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p>On 22 July 2022, AB Investment was the subject of a <a href="https://www.cssf.lu/en/2022/07/warning-concerning-fraudulent-activities-by-persons-misusing-the-name-and-address-of-the-luxembourg-law-company-ab-investment-s-a/">warning</a> published by the CSSF (the Luxembourg supervisory authority).</p>

<p>This firm has also misused the name of the Luxembourg company named AB Investment S.A.</p>

<p>The FSMA <strong>thus strongly advises against responding to any offers made by AB Investment</strong> <strong>and against transferring money</strong> to any account number that the company might mention.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>

<p>We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-03-08T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">330923</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Opinion about deadlines and sanctions regarding the payment of claims by insurers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/opinion-about-deadlines-and-sanctions-regarding-payment-claims-insurers</link>
  <description>
<p>At the request of Mr Pierre-Yves Dermagne, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Economy and Employment, the Insurance Commission issued an opinion on 23 December 2022 about deadlines and sanctions regarding the payment of claims by insurers (DOC/C2022/8). This opinion contains a draft law to cover all branches of insurance not yet governed by any legislation regarding the payment of insurance claims, as well as a draft law to replace Articles 13 and 14 of the Law of 21 November 1989 on the compulsory civil liability insurance in respect of motor vehicles.</p>

<item>
  <title>Beware of these new fraudulent trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-these-new-fraudulent-trading-platforms</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent online trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">pyramid scheme</a>.</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the invested funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their funds because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Asia Coinin</strong> (www.asia-coinin.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Binotrader</strong> (binotrader.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Buxberg</strong> (buxberg.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Cedar Financial </strong>(cedarfinancial.ltd)</li>
 <li><strong>Central Margins</strong> (centralmargins.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Coinclick</strong> (coinclickex.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Coins Crossing</strong> (coinciros.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Coins Trades</strong> (coinstrades.com)</li>
 <li><strong>GLE Markets</strong> (glemarkets.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>gle-markets.com,&nbsp;https://glemarkets3.com/</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>Globale-Invest</strong> (www.globale-invest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Grow Deposits</strong> (trade.growdeposits.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Itoro-Capital / ItoroStocks</strong> (itoro-capital.com; itoro-capital.co; itoro-capital.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Mega Markets</strong> (megamarkets.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>mega-markets.com</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>RXK Capital</strong> (rxkcapital.com; www.rxkcapital.org)</li>
 <li><strong>STB Markets</strong> (stbmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Stocks Views</strong> (stocks-views.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Thinvest</strong> (thinvest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ulian Pro</strong> (ulianpro.site)</li>
 <li><strong>Webull Investing</strong>&nbsp;(cloned firm) (webullinvesting.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Wilton Option</strong> (wiltonoption.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Xpoken</strong> (xpoken.com)</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:</p>

<p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p>

<p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-02-23T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">327434</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA’s treatment of whistleblower reports</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsmas-treatment-whistleblower-reports</link>
  <description>
<p>Circular FSMA_2023_03 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-02/fsma_2023_03_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-02/fsma_2023_03_fr.pdf">French</a> only) sets out and clarifies the procedural rules for the receipt and treatment of reports of infringements of the legislation with which the FSMA is tasked with supervising compliance. This circular also clarifies the protective measures that apply in this context. The circular implements Article 14, §5 of the law of 28 November 2022 on the protection of whistleblowers reporting infringements of European Union or national law identified within a legal entity in the private sector, which enters into force today.</p>

<p>The FSMA has also updated its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/51851">Frequently Asked Questions</a> on the website for the FSMA’s Whistleblowers’ point of contact in light of this new Law.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-02-15T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">326565</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Meeting of the European Regional Committee of IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/meeting-european-regional-committee-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the international Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) and of the FSMA Belgium today chaired the meeting of the European Regional Committee (ERC) of IOSCO in Athens.</strong></p>

<p>«&nbsp;More than 50 representatives gathered to discuss global developments in key areas such as sustainable finance, Fintech and crypto assets and their relevance for the protection of investors and the integrity of the markets in the region. These discussions will provide valuable feedback to the global work coordinated by IOSCO,&nbsp;» said Jean-Paul Servais after the meeting.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais expressed his gratitude to the host of the meeting, Mrs. Vassiliki Lazarakou, who is the chair of the Hellenic Capital Market Authority (HCMC). On the occasion of his election as chairman of the IOSCO Board, Ms Lazarakou presented Jean-Paul Servais with a statue of the ship of the Odyssey, as a symbol of leadership and cooperation.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="http://www.hcmc.gr/vdrv/elib/aa2cc7655-4420-4d09-a4bb-a236c7ed63f4-92668751-0">Read more in this press release of the HCMC.</a></p>
</div>

<item>
  <title>Consultation on a guide to information notes</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/consultation-guide-information-notes</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has prepared a guide to the content and publication of information notes relating to the offer of investment instruments.</p>

<p>Unlike a prospectus, an information note is not subject to ex ante supervision by the FSMA. Given the limited size of the operations for which an information note has to be drawn up, those responsible for the information note do not always receive external advice or professional assistance. This guide is intended to help those responsible for drawing up information notes for such smaller-scale operations.</p>

<p>More specifically, the FSMA wishes via this guide to set out the applicable rules and the interpretations, expectations and recommendations of the FSMA regarding the content and publication of information notes. The guide should enable those responsible for preparing the information note to provide the public with high-quality and timely information notes, thereby contributing to the protection of investors.</p>

<p>The FSMA is conducting a consultation regarding this guide, to run from 01/02/2023 to 15/03/2023. It is addressed to the entire financial sector, and in particular to representatives of issuers who publish information notes. Those who wish to submit their responses are asked to do so via the email address <a href="mailto:consult1@fsma.be">consult1@fsma.be</a>.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/7130">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/7130">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-02-01T14:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">325591</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against issues of convertible bonds by companies in need of financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-warns-against-issues-convertible-bonds-companies-need-financing</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Listed companies in financial difficulty are increasingly issuing convertible bonds in order to meet their financing needs. The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns shareholders of such companies of the major risk such issuances entail for them. </strong></p>

<p>A convertible bond offers the holder the right to convert the bond into shares. The conversion occurs at a conversion price set in advance. Usually, the conversion price will be higher than the market price of the issuing company at the time the convertible bond is issued.</p>

<p>However, the conversion price is in some cases lower than the market price at the time of conversion. It is in that case that this type of financing entails significant risks for shareholders. The conversion into shares then often results in significant dilution. Moreover, it can also create strong downward pressure on the share price.</p>

<p>The FSMA has identified 9 companies under its supervision that rely on such convertible bonds to meet their financing needs. The majority of these issuers are biotech or medtech companies.</p>

<p>Parties who offer this type of financing are chiefly foreign investment funds that specialize in this type of transaction. In exchange for their financing, they receive high fees and an attractive conversion price. They can convert their bonds into shares at a discount from market value at the time of conversion.</p>

<p>The discounts are usually around 5 to 8% but can in some cases reach 20%. As soon as the conversion has taken place, the investment funds sell the shares on the stock exchange. Most do not intend to become shareholders of the company.</p>

<p>The FSMA wishes to draw investors’ attention to the risks associated with this type of financing. It recommends that they take note of the relevant information made available by issuers. This will enable them to better assess the risks of downward pressure on the share price and of significant dilution, and to raise critical questions at the general meeting of shareholders regarding this type of financing.</p>

<p>The FSMA asks listed companies and their directors to think carefully before they issue these sorts of convertible bonds and to be aware of the responsibility they are assuming by doing so. Providers of this type of financing must be especially careful not to engage in market manipulation when selling the shares.</p>

<p>More information on this topic can be found in this <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-02/fsma_2023_02_eng.pdf">communication</a> on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-02-01T12:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">325590</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Q&A about the entry into force of the Delegated Regulation supplementing the Sustainable Finance Disclosures Regulation (SFDR)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/qa-about-entry-force-delegated-regulation-supplementing-sustainable-finance-disclosures</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published a Communication on the entry into force of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1288 of 6 April 2022 supplementing the SFDR with regulatory technical standards. The Communication takes the form of Q&amp;As and covers, for example, the content and presentation of the information relating to the promotion of environmental or social characteristics and objectives for sustainable investments in precontractual documents, on websites and in periodic reports.</p>

<p>These Q&amp;As bring together the clarifications published by the European Commission and the European Supervisory Authorities on the subject and sets out the FSMA’s expectations in this regard.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in Communication FSMA_2023_01...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/fsma_2023_01_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/fsma_2023_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Quarterly dashboard on investment fraud: 'recovery room' scams continue to increase</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/quarterly-dashboard-investment-fraud-recovery-room-scams-continue-increase</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. Since last July, it has been publishing a quarterly dashboard that provides statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it is publishing the dashboard for the fourth quarter of 2022, which will also include the figures for the whole year 2022. </strong></p>

<p>This edition of the dashboard focuses on the following items:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>“Recovery room” fraud is increasing.</strong> The FSMA wishes to draw the attention of the public to this type of fraud, which targets people who have already been victims of fraud in the past.</li>
 <li>To illustrate the workings of “recovery room” fraud and investment fraud more generally, the FSMA has incorporated into the dashboard a <strong>diagram representing the “classic” way these scams work.</strong></li>
 <li>The FSMA has published warnings against <strong>267 fraudulent entities and 301 websites </strong>over the year 2022.</li>
 <li>A large majority of these warnings concerned fraudulent trading platforms <strong>(149 fraudulent entities)</strong> and <strong>fraudulent offers of credit (95)</strong>.</li>
 <li>The majority of consumers who contacted the FSMA about fraud in 2022 were Dutch-speaking men residing in Belgium. Various age groups are represented, but the largest of these was the 50-59 age group.</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2023-01/2022_dashboard_fraud_q4_en.pdf">The dashboard is available on the website of the FSMA.</a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-01-26T11:39:30+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">324230</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA and of IOSCO speaks at the Asian Financial Forum</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-and-iosco-speaks-asian-financial-forum</link>
  <description>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), gave an online talk at the <a href="https://www.asianfinancialforum.com/conference/aff/en/programme?firstCriteria=all"><em>Asian Financial Forum</em></a><em> </em>held in Hong Kong on 11 and 12 January 2023. The event brought together global leaders in government, finance and business to share ideas and information. Each year, the <em>Asian Financial Forum </em>gathers thousands of participants from numerous countries around the world.</p>

<p>During his online speech, Jean-Paul Servais notably elaborated on the challenges facing the global financial sector and the role played by IOSCO in this area. He went on to underline IOSCO’s priorities for 2023:</p>

<ul>
 <li>sustainable finance and mitigating greenwashing, in particular by developing global reporting standards in this area;</li>
 <li>digital&nbsp; finance, with a focus on providing a framework for crypto-assets;</li>
 <li>global cooperation to tackle risks stemming from non-bank financial intermediation<em> </em>(NBFI).</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2023-01-12T08:02:29+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">323113</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Findelbank (www.findelbank.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/findelbank-wwwfindelbankcom</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is warning the public about the activities of Findelbank, which irregularly offers financial services and credit in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>Findelbank is falsely using an existing Belgian address to offer financial services and credit to consumers.</p>

<p>Moreover, Findelbank is not licensed to offer financial services and products and credit in Belgium. For all these reasons, the FSMA therefore advises against accepting offers from Findelbank. More information on investment and credit fraud can be found on the FSMA's website.</p>

<p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Participation of a regulated real estate investment company in specialised property investment funds</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/participation-regulated-real-estate-investment-company-specialised-property-investment-funds</link>
  <description>
<p>The principal activity of a regulated real estate investment company (GVV/SIR) is making properties available to occupants. This is an operational activity and not an investment activity.</p>

<p>The question therefore arose as to whether the units held by a GVV/SIR in entities that are not AIFs within the meaning of the AIFM Directive but explicitly opted for the status of specialised property investment fund, could still qualify as shares or units with voting rights issued by real estate investment companies. In that case, these participations would not be limited by the 20% threshold provided for in Article 7, § 1, b) of the GVV/SIR Law.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in FSMA_Opinion_2022_03 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/opinion/participation-detenue-par-une-societe-immobiliere-reglementee-dans-des-fonds">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/opinion/deelname-door-een-gereglementeerde-vastgoedvennootschap-gespecialiseerde">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>NBB and FSMA publish update on asset management and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/nbb-and-fsma-publish-update-asset-management-and-non-bank-financial-intermediation-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) today published an <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/2022_update_assetmanagement.pdf">update of the report</a> on asset management and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium. This update forms part of both institutions' periodic monitoring of these activities and focuses, inter alia, on the development of non-bank financial intermediation in our country, a €161&nbsp;billion market.</strong></p>

<p>In 2017, the FSMA and the NBB published a first comprehensive report on asset management and shadow banking in Belgium. The fourth update of this report, which includes recent figures and an analysis of national and international developments, is now available.</p>

<p>The initial report and its updates address the evolution towards a more market-oriented financial system. This mode of financing offers an alternative to raising money from banks and helps support the real economy. This fits with the call in Europe to become less dependent on banks to finance the economy. But non-bank financial intermediation (NBFI) - like other financial activities - can also give rise to systemic risks, which can affect the stability of the financial system.</p>

<p>Financing through markets can take several forms. In the report, the supervisory authorities analyse asset management activities and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium. The main objective of the report is to keep a finger on the pulse, paying particular attention to the risks associated with these activities and their interconnectedness with other sectors.</p>

<p>Based on the definition of the Financial Stability Board, the organisation overseeing financial sector reforms on a global scale for the G-20, the FSMA and the NBB calculated the size of non-bank financial intermediation activities in Belgium. At the end of June 2022, total financial assets in this category amounted to € 161 billion. These are mainly assets held by investment funds that do not qualify as equity funds. The vast majority of these funds are subject to supervision by the Belgian authorities.</p>

<p>Having held up well during major market shocks in March 2020 and the COVID crisis, Belgian investment funds once again demonstrated their shock-absorption capacity in 2022. Indeed, financial markets were severely tested by uncertainty due to the military conflict in Ukraine, a sharp rise in inflation and&nbsp; interest rates, and a worsened outlook for economic growth. These developments were accompanied by significant losses on financial assets held in Belgian investment funds but did not trigger disorderly or forced asset sales. This resilience of Belgian investment funds to market shocks attests to the generally prudent risk management of such funds, which is also promoted by the regulatory framework.</p>

<p>In recent years, the FSMA and the NBB have taken actions and supported initiatives both nationally and internationally aimed at</p>

<ul>
 <li>better monitoring of developments in this segment of the financial sector,</li>
 <li>a healthier management of risks by the financial institutions active in this sector,&nbsp;</li>
 <li>adjustment, where necessary, of the regulatory framework.</li>
</ul>

<p>For instance, liquidity management tools (LMTs) can be very useful in stressed market conditions and in case of potential liquidity problems. Today, virtually all sub-funds for which the FSMA has recommended the introduction of LMTs have at least one LMT at their disposal. The use of LMTs promotes equal treatment of investors and reduces the risk of a forced sale of less liquid assets. Because LMTs reduce the potential mismatch between the liquidity of an UCI's investment portfolio and the liquidity offered by that UCI to its investors, they also promote financial stability.</p>

<p>As things stand, no material risks have been identified in relation to asset management and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium that threaten financial stability. However, the development of those two activities in Belgium and their linkages with other sectors of the economy, including possible reputational risk in financial services groups, should be closely monitored.</p>

<p>In addition, risks in the global NBFI sector should not be overlooked. The vulnerabilities in certain sub-segments of this global NBFI sector - as illustrated during the "dash for cash" in March 2020 or by the investment vehicle Archegos to which banks had extended excessive credit - may threaten the smooth functioning of financial markets and the stability of the financial institutions involved. The NBB and the FSMA therefore continue to actively participate in international work to gain a better view of European and global developments in the NBFI sector and, where necessary, to strengthen the regulatory framework.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>NBB Governor Pierre Wunsch: 'The NBB-FSMA report confirms that the Belgian asset management and non-bank financial intermediation market can be considered fundamentally sound. The sector was thus well armed to face the challenging market developments that characterised 2022. This solid starting position must be maintained in order to secure the crucial role of this sector in financial intermediation in Belgium also in the future.&nbsp; Given the rapid developments in this sector, supervisory authorities must therefore remain vigilant. Regular updates to the published analysis will continue to form part of this continuous monitoring.'</p>
</blockquote>

<blockquote>
<p>FSMA Chairman Jean-Paul Servais: 'In order to monitor and understand trends and risks in the NBFI sector, good cooperation between authorities, both at national and international level, is essential. This report, already in its fifth edition, is an excellent example of this. As the new Chairman of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), one of my priorities will be to maintain and strengthen the cooperation with the Financial Stability Board (FSB). The FSB and IOSCO are committed to continuing to work together globally to address the systemic risks of NBFI.'</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-21T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">310985</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) – role and responsibilities of compliance officers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-anti-money-laundering-and-countering-financing-terrorism-amlcft-role-and</link>
  <description>
<h2>Good governance arrangements are essential for effectively combating money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT)!</h2>

<p>In this second issue of the AMLCO newsletter, the FSMA provides details about the latest developments in the anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT), and in particular about the publication of the <a href="https://www.eba.europa.eu/regulation-and-policy/anti-money-laundering-and-countering-financing-terrorism/guidelines-role-amlcft-compliance-officers">EBA Guidelines on the role, tasks and responsibilities of AML compliance officers</a> (known as ‘AMLCOs’).</p>

<p>The FSMA offers a recapitulation of the legal framework, provides general explanations of the EBA guidelines and clarifies its expectations regarding the role of the senior management, the senior manager responsible for AML/CFT and the AMLCO.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">Read more in our newsletter ... (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/2022-12-21_newsletter_amlco_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/2022-12-21_newsletter_amlco_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</div>

<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA and of IOSCO speaks at the 2022 Summit of the A4S organization in London</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-and-iosco-speaks-2022-summit-a4s-organization-london</link>
  <description>
<p>King Charles III of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland founded in 2004 the <em>Accounting For Sustainability</em> (A4S) organization with a view to developing modern reporting standards that can rise to the challenges of the 21st century, chiefly as regards developing towards more sustainable finance. Every year, it holds a Summit that gathers a large number of participants from the global financial community to explore trends and the concrete actions that can be taken to build a resilient, sustainable economy.</p>

<p>On 13, 14 and 15 December 2022, A4S held its 2022 Summit.</p>

<p>On Tuesday, 13 December, Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), gave a online talk on the latest global developments in the global sustainability-related reporting by companies. He stressed the important role played by IOSCO in this area and set out the priorities to be implemented in order to achieve high-quality reporting and audit standards that can help combat greenwashing and thereby contribute to strengthening consumer confidence in the financial system.</p>

<p>On Thursday, 15 December, Jean-Paul Servais attended the Summit in London in person, participating in a round table on sustainability-related financial reporting. Joining him at the round table were CFOs, company directors, investors and other members of the international accounting and financial community. During their discussions, he emphasised the importance of seizing to the full the opportunity offered by the establishment of global sustainability-related reporting standards. When the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) will have finalised its standards, IOSCO will attentively examine them. The support of IOSCO could considerably speed up the dissemination of the new standards worldwide, as was the case at the time of the adoption of the IFRS standards.</p>

<p>You can re-watch the Chairman's speech <a href="https://vimeo.com/781526102">here</a>.&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-15T09:10:18+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">306303</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against Validus</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-validus</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA warns the public against Validus, a platform situated abroad which is selling training in Belgium intended to teach people to trade in complex financial instruments such as forex derivatives.</strong></p>

<p>Anyone who signs up for such training, is given access to instructional videos, webinars and live chat sessions with all sorts of information about how the forex market works. They explain what forex derivatives are, how exactly you can trade in them, what type of orders you can place and what software you can download for the purpose. The message is that forex trading offers opportunities on condition that you have thoroughly studied and have a full understanding of how it works.</p>

<p>Apart from the fact that the FSMA has concerns about the quality of these training courses, a number of other issues arise.</p>

<p>First, the FSMA wishes to remind you that distribution of derivative instruments traded on an electronic trading system and involving leverage (including certain forex instruments) is prohibited in Belgium.</p>

<p>Secondly, such training materials are often distributed via a pyramid structure. In general, these are referred to as ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing) schemes, in which consumers are incentivized to bring in new members. In exchange, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the training.</p>

<p>Such MLM networks appear to be active on social media via countless (private) groups. It appears that these schemes mainly target young people. The message is that everyone can afford a luxurious lifestyle provided they bring in enough new members and make the appropriate investment in the training on offer.</p>

<p><strong>Offers of instruments on forex via internet are very risky and open to fraud:</strong> anyone who invests in instruments on forex runs the risk of losing the entire sum invested.&nbsp;The chance of loss is far greater than the chance of profit: surveys by other European supervisors among investors show that at least 75% to 89% of investments in derivative products, such as in forex derivatives, are loss-makers! These products are appropriate only for those who really wish to speculate, are ready to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and are familiar with derivative financial products.&nbsp;<strong>There have also been many cases of fraud with these instruments.</strong> In a number of cases, it turned out that no actual transactions were ever made by the offeror.</p>

<p>Validus uses the following websites:</p>

<ul>
 <li>https://teamvalidus.com/</li>
 <li>https://www.validusofficial.com/</li>
 <li>https://teamvalidus-official.com/</li>
 <li>https://validus-team-official.com/</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>Have you received an offer of an investment and would like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud">Beware of fraud</a>’.</p>

<p>We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-14T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">304877</guid>
    </item>
<item>

The exercise tested for the first time the resilience of the European IORP sector against a climate change scenario.</strong></p>

<item>
  <title>FAQs about marketing communications for UCIs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/faqs-about-marketing-communications-ucis</link>
  <description>
<p>A royal decree was published today laying down new rules governing advertisements for UCIs offered in Belgium. The FSMA has prepared a Communication on the subject. It deals with several topics in the form of FAQs.</p>

<p>The FAQs provide explanations of the advertising rules that apply in various situations and of the FSMA’s supervision of advertisements.</p>

<p>They also go into greater depth on certain aspects specific to marketing communications that concern a pulic offer of public open-ended UCIs. So, for example, they provide answers to questions about what exactly is meant by ‘marketing communications’ and what rules must be followed when indicating returns and sustainability aspects.</p>

<p>They also describe the procedures for obtaining the FSMA’s prior approval of marketing communications for such UCIs. The new procedure according to which changes can be made without prior approval by the FSMA are also discussed.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in Communication FSMA_2022_29... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/fsma_2022_29_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/fsma_2022_29_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-12T12:23:29+01:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">305297</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Client demands and needs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-client-demands-and-needs</link>
  <description>
<p>Before an insurance distributor can write an insurance contract, it must identify its client’s demands and needs in terms of insurance. This is known as the mandatory “needs analysis”.</p>

<p>Although this is not a new obligation, the FSMA has observed that this rule of conduct often gives rise to questions. We briefly set out the main lines of this rules of conduct in a series of Frequently Asked Questions.</p>

<ol>
 <li>What is the aim of the needs analysis?</li>
 <li>What does the needs analysis involve?</li>
 <li>May insurance distributors use a standard questionnaire?</li>
 <li>Who determines the client’s demands and needs?</li>
 <li>When is the needs analysis carried out?</li>
 <li>Which insurance products require a needs analysis?</li>
 <li>Does the needs analysis differ depending on whether or not the insurance distributor provides advice?</li>
 <li>Does the needs analysis have to be carried out if an offer is made digitally (website, application, platform, etc.)?</li>
 <li>Is the insurance distributor required to keep the needs analysis?</li>
</ol>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the newsletter... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/2022-12-07_newsletter_exigences_besoins_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-12/2022-12-07_newsletter_behoefteanalyse_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-07T12:19:01+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">303872</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Guidelines on the role, tasks and responsibilities of AML/CFT compliance officers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-role-tasks-and-responsibilities-amlcft-compliance-officers</link>
  <description>
<p>These guidelines, published by the European Banking Authority, set out the role, tasks and responsibilities of the management body, the senior manager responsible for this area and the compliance officer in combatting money laundering and terrorist financing (hereafter AML/CFT), as well as the expectations in terms of policies and procedures for ensuring compliance with the AML/CFT obligations.</p>

<p>The FSMA considers that these guidelines provide useful details on the application of certain provisions of the Law of 18 September 2017 and of the FSMA Regulation of 3 July 2018, and has therefore incorporated these guidelines into its supervisory policy, in particular for the purpose of evaluating the adequacy of the governance arrangement and the compliance function put in place by the obliged entities to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="https://www.eba.europa.eu/sites/default/documents/files/document_library/Publications/Guidelines/2022/EBA-GL-2022-05 GLs on AML compliance officers/1035126/Guidelines on AMLCFT compliance officers.pdf">Read more in the ESA Guidelines. </a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-06T20:54:05+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">304515</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Financial Stability Board meeting</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/financial-stability-board-meeting</link>
  <description>
<p>The <a href="https://www.fsb.org/about/organisation-and-governance/members-of-the-financial-stability-board/">Financial Stability Board (FSB)</a> Plenary met in Basel to discuss the outlook for global financial stability, including issues of particular relevance to emerging market and developing economies, and any actions needed to address identified vulnerabilities in the global financial system.</p>

<p>The Plenary reviewed policy work in several areas, including crypto-assets and decentralised finance (DeFi) and climate-related financial risks. The Plenary also agreed the FSB’s work programme for 2023.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="https://www.fsb.org/2022/12/fsb-plenary-meets-in-basel-2/">Read the FSB press release</a>.</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-06T16:26:34+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">304523</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA hosts meeting of international audit Monitoring Group </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-hosts-meeting-international-audit-monitoring-group</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 21 November 2022, the FSMA hosted a meeting of the international audit Monitoring Group&nbsp;(MG). The MG is a group of international institutions committed to fostering high‑quality international audit and ethics standards. Members are the Financial Stability Board (FSB), the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS), the World Bank, the European Commission, the International Forum of Independent Audit Regulators (IFIAR), the International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) and IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions. Jean-Paul Servais, Chair of the FSMA and of IOSCO, co-chairs the MG on behalf of IOSCO, together with the SEC, the American Securities and Exchange Commission.</strong></p>

<p>The meeting of 21 November held at the FSMA’s premises focused on the work currently undertaken by the MG to strengthen the independence and efficiency of the international audit and professional ethics standard-setting process.</p>

<p>Timely, high‑quality and inclusive audit standards, as well as the associated rules of independence and professional ethics, are crucial to the profession to ensure investor confidence in financial and sustainability reporting. ‘<em>I welcome the great progress made in implementing the reform of the governance of international standard setting in the area of audit and professional ethics</em>.<em> In close cooperation with the various stakeholders, the members of the MG</em> <em>will maintain their efforts to ensure that these standards meet the needs of the various financial market participants while also keeping the public interest in mind at all times. The FSMA, which houses the Belgian Audit Oversight Board, is honoured to contribute to these initiatives</em>,’ stated Jean-Paul Servais, chair of the FSMA and co-chair of the MG.</p>

<p>A more detailed press release is available on the <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS675.pdf">website of the Monitoring Group</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-12-02T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">303876</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies new fraudulent online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-3</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past few weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent online trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p><p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media or online video platforms</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also sometimes use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often offer a virtual currency, trading software or a training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts.</p><p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms offer a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">pyramid scheme</a>.</p><p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p><p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p><ul><li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li><li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li></ul><p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>. Fraudsters not only act without the necessary authorizations, but they also divert the invested funds. In such cases, investors are unable to recover their funds because these illegal service providers are generally located abroad.</p><p>***</p><p>Various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p><p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p><ul><li><strong>ApexCryptoLive </strong>(apexcryptolive.com)</li><li><strong>Asset Management</strong> (assetmanagement.co.com)</li><li><strong>BatCoin</strong> (www.batcns.vip)</li><li><strong>Bid-IV</strong> (bidiv.com)</li><li><strong>Bitnexltd </strong>(bitnexltd.com)</li><li><strong>Bn93</strong> (www.bn93.com)</li><li><strong>Caplita</strong> (caplita.com)</li><li><strong>Capital365 </strong>(capital365.fm)</li><li><strong>Capital-Whale</strong> (capital-whale.com, <span lang="EN-GB">capital-whales.com</span>)</li><li><strong>Coine-ex</strong> (coine-ex.com) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li><li><strong>Coinsdesk </strong>(coinsdesk.org) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li><li><strong>FHN Capital</strong> (fhn-capital.com)</li><li><strong>FortuneFX </strong>(fortunefx.io)</li><li><strong>FTMTrade</strong> (www.ftmtrade.com)</li><li><strong>GlobalOneMarkets </strong>(www.globalonemarkets.com)</li><li><strong>GMT investments</strong> (gmtinvestments.com)</li><li><strong>Invest Think</strong> (investtg.com)</li><li><strong>Marlpark LTD</strong> (www.marlparkltd.com)</li><li><strong>Martyn Service</strong> (www.martynservice.com, webtrader.martynservice.trade, www.martynservice.net, www.martyn-services.net) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li><li><strong>ProfitsVision</strong> (profitsvision.com, <span lang="NL-BE">profitsvision.org</span>)</li><li><strong>RCE Banque</strong> (rcebanque.com)</li><li><strong>Roisea </strong>(roisea.com)</li><li><strong>Spotchains</strong> (www.spotchains.com)</li><li><strong>Traderactive </strong>(traderactive.com, traderactive.net)</li><li><strong>TSXOTC</strong> (tsxotc.com)</li><li><strong>Uni-co</strong> (uni-co.org, uni-co.io, uni-co.ltd, uni-co.tech)</li><li><strong>Vestapros</strong> (www.vestapros.com)</li><li><strong>Vexxsel</strong> (vexxsel.online)</li><li><strong>XproGlobal</strong> (xproglobal.com)</li></ul><p>***</p><p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:</p><p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p><p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website will do. Take note! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p><p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, the FSMA advises you to file a complaint with the local police or with the judicial authorities.</p><p>Moreover, should fraudsters manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p><p>***</p><p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Brexit: feedback statement for insurance intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/brexit-feedback-statement-insurance-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<p>In response to Brexit, some companies under Belgian law that are associated with or linked to a British insurance intermediary have applied for registration with the FSMA as insurance intermediaries. Among these, the FSMA has selected six intermediaries, on the basis of a risk model, and sent them a questionnaire to ensure that they are compliant with the relevant European and Belgian regulations.</p>

<p>From the responses of the intermediaries surveyed, the FSMA noted that these intermediaries make use of secondment contracts. This type of contract, originating under British law, provides for a Belgian intermediary to take on internally staff from the British intermediary. The feedback statement reminds readers, on the one hand, of the consequences of Brexit for insurance intermediaries, and, on the other hand, of the regulatory framework in force. The FSMA draws the attention of insurance distributors in particular to the prohibition against using the services of unregistered intermediaries and the consequences if this prohibition is not respected.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-11/2022_brexit_feedbackstatement_eng.pdf">Read more in feedback statement ...</a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-11-22T13:45:26+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">302889</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Warning Bancassurance EIOPA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/warning-bancassurance-eiopa</link>
  <description>
<p>With this warning EIOPA&nbsp;is calling on insurers and banks (acting as insurance distributors) to ensure CPI&nbsp;products offer fair value to consumers by:</p>

<ul>
 <li>taking action to address issues with high remuneration paid by insurance manufacturers to insurance distributors for the sale of credit protection insurance (CPI) products , and</li>
 <li>preventing detrimental conflicts of interest in the context of bancassurance business models from arising.</li>
</ul>

<p>This warning&nbsp;follows a&nbsp;<a href="https://www.eiopa.europa.eu/document-library/report/thematic-review-credit-protection-insurance-cpi-sold-banks_en"><span><span>thematic review</span></span></a>&nbsp;on the functioning of the EU market for CPI products sold with mortgages, consumer credits and credit cards, which revealed a number of practices that could cause detriment to consumers.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="https://www.eiopa.europa.eu/document/download/86343478-edb9-46d1-acc2-5375fa709305_en?filename=EIOPA%20warning%20to%20insurers%20and%20banks%20on%20Credit%20Protection%20Insurance.pdf">Read more in the warning ...</a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-11-22T13:14:28+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">302952</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>FSMA Opinion on financial planning</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-opinion-financial-planning</link>
  <description>
<p>This Opinion clarifies how the FSMA understands the concept of ‘advice on financial planning’. By way of reminder, both independent financial planners authorized by the FSMA and regulated companies may provide advice on financial planning in Belgium. In its Opinion, the FSMA also briefly outlines the main obligations of those who offer advice on financial planning.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">Read more in the FSMA’s Opinion 2022_02&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/opinion/quest-ce-quune-consultation-en-planification-financiere">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/opinion/wat-raad-ovhttps:/www.fsma.be/nl/opinion/wat-raad-over-financiele-planninger-financiele-planning">Dutch</a> only)</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Less administrative work for intermediaries and lenders</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-less-administrative-work-intermediaries-and-lenders</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has introduced a series of changes in its CABRIO online application for intermediaries and lenders.</p>

<p>Read more in the Newsletter.</p>

<ul>
 <li>Are you moving? Notifying the FSMA of your change of address is no longer necessary.</li>
 <li>For insurance intermediaries and intermediaries in banking and investment services: simplified management of your CABRIO registration file for Belgian branches.</li>
 <li>Shorter and simpler document templates.</li>
 <li>Faster processing of requests for straightforward adjustments.</li>
 <li>Your registration file must be kept up‑to‑date at all times.</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-11/2022-11-18_newsletter_cabrio_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-11/2022-11-18_newsletter_cabrio_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Supervisory statement EIOPA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/supervisory-statement-eiopa</link>
  <description>
<p>EIOPA expects insurers to consider systemic events during the Product Oversight Governance process and when drafting policy conditions, in particular when drafting exclusions.</p>

<p>The description of coverage and exclusions should be clear and aligned with the needs of the target market.</p>

</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>At COP27, IOSCO outlines its priorities for sustainability disclosures</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/cop27-iosco-outlines-its-priorities-sustainability-disclosures</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and Chair of the Board of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), today outlined at the Climate Change Conference in Sharm El-Sheikh (COP27) the initiatives IOSCO is undertaking to enhance sustainability disclosures by companies, promote well-functioning carbon markets, and address greenwashing in financial markets. </strong></p>

<p><strong>Sustainability disclosure standards</strong></p>

<p>Disclosure of company information underpins valuations in financial markets. Sustainability disclosures will, in future, play a similar role. IOSCO expects companies to be able, from the end of 2024 onwards, to draw on sustainability disclosure standards.</p>

<p>The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB), whose creation was announced in 2021 at the Climate Change Conference in Glasgow (COP26), is working on developing international standards for sustainability disclosures.</p>

<p>‘In 2023, the ISSB will issue its standard for climate-related disclosures and general sustainability requirements. IOSCO will move promptly to decide on a possbiel endorsement”, according to Jean-Paul Servais, Chair of the IOSCO Board. “If IOSCO endorses the standards, it will develop a support programme for its members to assist them in moving forward immediately.”</p>

<p>Interoperability around the world of climate-related disclosure standards will be an important factor in IOSCO’s decision to endorse them, Jean-Paul Servais emphasized.</p>

<p>The Chairman of the FSMA and IOSCO Chair took part in and spoke at several panels attended by ministers and other top officials at the Climate Conference in Sharm El-Sheikh.</p>

<p><strong>Fair and efficient carbon markets</strong></p>

<p>The Chair of the IOSCO Board also stressed the importance of well-functioning carbon markets. "Carbon markets have major role to play in moving us to net zero, but they must be made efficient, liquid and free from conflicts of interest and undue political interference”, he stated.</p>

<p>In order to reach this goal, IOSCO today published a consultation paper setting out its recommendations on how to establish sound and well-functioning carbon markets. It accompanied this with a discussion paper seeking stakeholders views on the role that could be played by financial market regulators in this regard.</p>

<p><strong>Addressing greenwashing in the financial markets</strong></p>

<p>Greenwashing is the practice of incorrectly presenting investments as sustainable. Countering this phenomenon is, according to IOSCO, essential in order to ensure investors’ trust in sustainable finance. It is for this reason that addressing greenwashing is one of IOSCO’s priorities.</p>

<p>IOSCO called upon all associations operating in the financial markets to promote specific good practices among their members to counter the risk of greenwashing on the part of asset managers and ESG rating and data providers.</p>

<p>Voluntary initiatives have thus far played an important role in building the foundations of well- functioning sustainable financial markets. However, IOSCO believes that their actions are no longer sufficient. Governments and regulatory authorities must take further measures. IOSCO will work with its members to help build sound and well-functioning sustainable finance markets.</p>

<p>Read also <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS669.pdf">the press release published by IOSCO</a>.</p>
<figure class="align-center media media--image">
  
  
  
    <img loading="lazy" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/styles/extra_large/public/images/cop27-3.jpg?itok=rBbnSL_D" width="768" height="1024" alt="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA" title="Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA" class="image-style--extra-large">




</figure>


<figure class="align-center media media--image">

</figure>
</description>

<item>
  <title>CMTpro (www.cmtpro.com, www.cmt-pro.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/cmtpro-wwwcmtprocom-wwwcmt-procom</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of CMTpro which irregularly offers investment services in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>CMTpro is a fraudulent online trading platform that is operating on the Belgian market. More information about this kind of fraud is available on the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms">website of the FSMA</a></p>

<p>Furthermore, CMTpro is not authorized to offer financial services and products in Belgium.</p>

<p>For all these reasons, the FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by CMTpro.</p>

<p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-11-09T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">300912</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Jean-Paul Servais elected new chair of international organization of securities commissions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/jean-paul-servais-elected-new-chair-international-organization-securities-commissions</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), has been elected the new chair of IOSCO, the international organization of securities commissions. This is the first time a Belgian has been chosen to chair this international body.</strong></p>

<p>IOSCO is a network of more than 130 national supervisory authorities, which are legally responsible for supervising financial markets and for conduct and product supervision. The organization was established in 1983 and its membership regulates 95% of the international financial sector.</p>

<p>At the annual meeting of IOSCO in Marrakech, the chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, was elected chair of the IOSCO Board for a two-year term.</p>

<p>“My election is a token of appreciation of the work the FSMA has already done at both national and international levels. The fact that the Belgian supervisory authority was chosen to lead IOSCO is a sign of the confidence of its fellow supervisors in the FSMA’s know-how. I would like to thank the members of the IOSCO Board for their support and their trust,” Jean-Paul Servais stated after the vote.</p>

<p>The chairman of the FSMA has been very active within IOSCO in recent years. He has held the post of vice-chair of the organization since 2016. He also chairs the European Regional Committee, was chair of the IOSCO Finance and Audit Committee, and headed up a working group on the regulation of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs). On behalf of IOSCO, he chairs the <em>IFRS Foundation’s Monitoring Board, which oversees the work on sustainability reporting done by the </em>International Sustainability Standards Board. He is also co-chair of the <em>Monitoring Group </em>responsible for monitoring international audit standard-setting.</p>

<p>IOSCO’s objective is to promote fair and sound market practices worldwide and thereby to contribute to investor protection and the integrity of the financial markets. To this end, it works to intensify collaboration among market supervisors, in particular by enforcing financial legislation and exchanging information about matters such as market abuse. It also develops standards and makes recommendations about good practices for the use of national supervisors.</p>

<p>In recent years, IOSCO has worked closely with the Financial Stability Board (FSB), the international body that monitors the stability of the financial system. Under Jean-Paul Servais’ chairmanship, IOSCO will further strengthen the ties with the FSB and work together on topics such as shadow banking, the digitalization of financial services, cryptoassets and financial risks due to climate change.</p>

<p>The members of the new IOSCO Board are:</p>

<item>
  <title>Presentation of a toolbox to the Belgian Investor Relations Association</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/presentation-toolbox-belgian-investor-relations-association</link>
  <description>
<p>On 13 October, the FSMA presented, at a meeting of the Belgian Investor Relations Association (BelIR), a toolbox designed to provide persons in charge of investor relations with a number of guidelines for their interaction with the FSMA.</p>

<p>Listed companies are subject to information disclosure obligations laid down by international and national laws and regulations. In order to shed light on these topics, the FSMA publishes circulars, communications, handbooks, FAQs, etc. In line with this pedagogical approach, the FSMA decided to put together a toolbox, available on its website, covering a number of topics it thinks will be of interest for investor relations.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/294346/">Toolbox</a>...</p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA has been awarded a third star as an 'Ecodynamic Organisation’ and is redoubling its efforts to reduce its environmental impact</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-has-been-awarded-third-star-ecodynamic-organisation-and-redoubling-its-efforts-reduce-its</link>
  <description>
<p>The numerous steps the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has taken in recent years to reduce its environmental impact have earned it the third star of the 'Ecodynamic Organisation Label’ awarded by Leefmilieu Brussel/Bruxelles-Environnement. With energy prices soaring, the FSMA intends to go even further and is taking more far-reaching measures to move towards a sustainable future.</p>

<p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/293136">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/293136">Dutch</a>&nbsp;site.</p>

<item>
  <title>End of the World Investor Week 2022</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week-2022</link>
  <description>
<p>The sixth edition of World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held from 3 to 9 October 2022. The aim of this week was to promote financial education and investor protection. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</p>

<p>This year’s World Investor Week focused in particular on online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to. Other topics, such as sustainable finance and crypto assets, were also featured. This thematic week offered yet another opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p>

<p>This initiative was once again supported by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), the chairman of which is vice-chair of IOSCO and chair of IOSCO’s European Regional Committee (ERC).</p>

<p>As chair of the ERC, the chairman of the FSMA spoke via a video message at the World Investor Week’s launch events in Paris and Warsaw. The FSMA drew attention to World Investor Week through its social media and also launched a campaign there to direct the public to its financial education website <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/">www.wikifin.be</a>, which offers all kinds of useful information and handy tools relating to money matters.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-10-10T15:08:37+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">293925</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Are you struggling financially? Be careful who you consult with</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/are-you-struggling-financially-be-careful-who-you-consult</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credit to consumers.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has detected <strong>19 fraudulent lenders </strong>who offer false credit to Belgian consumers via the Internet in recent months.</p>

<p><strong>The current economic situation</strong> is leading consumers to look for extra budget in the form of credit and thus come into contact -often through <strong>advertisements on social media</strong>- with providers of false credit.</p>

<p>However, in reality, these are&nbsp;<strong>false offers</strong> of credit&nbsp;made in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be authorized lenders or credit intermediaries and they do not shy away from using the names and logos of legitimate financial service providers. These are cases of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies">cloned firms</a>.</p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers credit at <strong>very&nbsp;attractive conditions</strong>. For example, a lender claims to extend substantial loans at a low interest rate. The lender may also claim not to check whether the consumer is a poor payer and has taken out loans in the past that he/she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain&nbsp;<strong>payments</strong>&nbsp;supposedly to cover&nbsp;<strong>costs&nbsp;</strong>relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly&nbsp;impossible to recover the amounts paid.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</strong></p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ol>
 <li>Efin Lening (https://efin-lening.com/)</li>
 <li>International Finance BK (https://international-finance-bk.com/)</li>
 <li>Lefebre Krediet Snel (https://lefebrekrediet-snel.com/)</li>
 <li>Prestige Financial (https://prestigefinancial-beheer.com/)</li>
 <li>Leninggroep (https://qreditszone.com/)</li>
 <li>Rabo Help (https://rabo-help.com/ )</li>
 <li>Trustly Investment (https://trustlyinvestment.com/)</li>
 <li>Weber Loan (https://wloanltd.com/)</li>
 <li>AllPark Loan (https://allpark-loan.com)</li>
 <li>Get Loan ltd (https://getloanltd.com/)</li>
 <li>Efinance 24H (https://efinance24h.com/)</li>
 <li>Snelle Geld Lening (https://snellegeldlening.com/) &nbsp;</li>
 <li>Holvoet Financiën (https://holvoetfinancien.com/)</li>
 <li>Socialegroups (https://socialegroups.com/)</li>
 <li>Vim Wahel (https://vimwahel.com/nl)</li>
 <li>Oplossingen voor financiële problemen (https://oplossingvoor-fp.com/)</li>
 <li>Bad Interinvestmentcompanies (https://badinterinvestmentcompanies.com/)</li>
 <li>Kredit Snel (https://kreditsnel.com/)</li>
 <li>Firsteuros België (https://firsteuros-belgie.be/)</li>
</ol>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA offers the following&nbsp;<strong>general recommendations</strong>&nbsp;for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be wary if (out of the blue) you receive an&nbsp;<strong>unsolicited credit offer</strong>&nbsp;via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on unusually favourable terms</strong>&nbsp;(a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you first pay a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan</strong>.&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Find out whether the lender has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;Via the&nbsp;<strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a></strong>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>.&nbsp;You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a></strong>.&nbsp;As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-10-07T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">293923</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Investment fraud occurs mainly via online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/investment-fraud-occurs-mainly-online-trading-platforms</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>One of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is to combat unlawful activities in the area of financial investments. In July, the FSMA published a new quarterly dashboard with statistics and an overview of the main trends regarding investment fraud. Today, it publishes the dashboard about the third quarter of 2022. </strong></p>

<p>This edition of the dashboard focuses more specifically on the following elements:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>The previously identified fraud trends tend to be confirmed</strong>: in 2022, the two main fraud phenomena are fraudulent trading platforms and fake credit scams.</li>
 <li>In the third quarter of 2022, <strong>almost 50% of the questions received by the FSMA about fraud related to fraudulent trading platforms.</strong></li>
 <li>The collaboration between the FSMA and the judicial authorities resulted in <strong>234 fraudulent websites being blocked </strong>since the beginning of the year.</li>
 <li>September saw a <strong>sharp increase in the number of fraud notifications received by the FSMA</strong>. The majority thereof were submitted by Dutch-speaking consumers, which could mean that, currently, fraudsters are specifically targeting the Dutch-speaking public.</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-10/202210_dashboard_investmentfraud.pdf">You can consult the dashboard on the website of the FSMA.</a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-10-05T13:49:45+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">292691</guid>
    </item>
