<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches 20 projects for the future</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-20-projects-future</link>
  <description>
<p>On the occasion of the annual World Investor Week and the 20th anniversary of the Financial Supervision Law, the FSMA is launching 20 projects for the future. The projects have been selected based on the experience gained by the FSMA in its various areas of supervision, and are intended to encourage debate on the issues addressed. The projects cover seven topical matters. The common thread that runs through these projects, is to provide even more far-reaching protection of financial consumers and shareholders.</p>

<p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/293829">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/293829">Dutch</a>&nbsp;site.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>World Investor Week 2022</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week-2022</link>
  <description>
<p>The sixth World Investor Week will take place from Monday 3 to Sunday 9 October 2022. It is organized by IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions. The aim of World Investor Week is to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas will be at the centre of attention.</p>

<p>This year’s World Investor Week focuses on online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to. Other topics, such as sustainable finance and crypto assets, are also featured. This thematic week also offers one more opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p>

<p>As vice-chair of IOSCO and chair of the IOSCO European Regional Committee (ERC), the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again lends its full support to this initiative. As chair of the ERC, the chairman of the FSMA spoke via video message at the World Investor Week launch events in Paris and Warsaw.</p>

<p>Furthermore, the FSMA has launched a campaign via social media to encourage the public to visit its financial education website <a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a>, which offers all kinds of useful information and helpful tools related to money matters. &nbsp;</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>EIOPA and ESMA documents about the suitability test</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/eiopa-and-esma-documents-about-suitability-test</link>
  <description>
<p>Since 2 August 2022, the client’s sustainability preferences figure among the information to be collected as part of the suitability test under MiFID II.</p>

<p>The Boards of Supervisors of EIOPA and ESMA, in which the FSMA participates, have respectively approved a ‘<a href="https://www.eiopa.europa.eu/media/news/eiopa-publishes-guidance-integrating-customer%E2%80%99s-sustainability-preferences-suitability_en">guidance</a>’ and ‘<a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-publishes-final-guidelines-mifid-ii-suitability-requirements-0/">guidelines</a>’ about this subject which are aimed at facilitating the implementation of those new requirements by the financial institutions. You can find those texts on the websites of <a href="https://www.eiopa.europa.eu/sites/default/files/publications/reports/guidance_on_integration_of_customers_sustainability_preferences_under_idd.pdf">EIOPA</a> and <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/library/esma35-43-3172_final_report_on_mifid_ii_guidelines_on_suitability.pdf">ESMA</a>.</p>

<p>The ESMA guidelines will be translated and the competent national authorities will have two months to confirm whether they intend to integrate these guidelines into their supervisory practices.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-09-27T14:54:12+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">292692</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The Future Trade</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/future-trade</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of The Future Trade which irregularly offers investment services in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>The Future Trade is a platform where professional traders trade Forex and crypto currencies with the money invested by consumers in the name and on behalf of these consumers.</p>

<p>In addition, the firm offers its members advantages and compensation that increase the more new members they recruit.</p>

<p>The Future Trade is not, however, authorized to offer financial services and products in Belgium. Moreover, the system proposed by The Future Trade exhibits features characteristic of a pyramid scheme. More information about this form of fraud is available on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/pyramid-schemes">website of the FSMA</a>.</p>

<p>For all these reasons, the FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by The Future Trade.</p>

<p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-09-21T08:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">291522</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies new fraudulent online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-2</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent online trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing&nbsp;<strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use&nbsp;<strong>mobile applications</strong>&nbsp;to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). Other trading platforms contact consumers through <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps">dating apps</a> and fake social media accounts.</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>.&nbsp;Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li>finding themselves <strong>unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply&nbsp;<strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong>&nbsp;with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of&nbsp;<strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms propose a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">pyramid scheme</a>&nbsp;or at any rate of a Ponzi scheme.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA noticed that the following websites for trading softwares and courses refer to fraudulent online trading platforms:<strong> </strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>BiTraderPro</strong> (bitraderpro.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Trading Central</strong> (tradingcentrals.com). This website is a clone of Trading Central S.A. (www.tradingcentral.com) and is entirely unconnected with this company.</li>
</ul>

<p>Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitalpha AI</strong> (bitalpha-ai.io, bitalpha-ai.nl&nbsp;and bitalpha-ai.org)</li>
 <li><strong>Bitopps</strong> (www.bitopps.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Bullden</strong> (bullden.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Capital Forex Live Limited</strong> (capitalforex.live)</li>
 <li><strong>Capital One Markets</strong> (capitalonemarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Capitals Trade Fx</strong> (capitalstradefx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Cedar Signals</strong> (cedarsignals.live)</li>
 <li><strong>Crypto1Capital</strong> (platform.crypto1capital-trade.com and crypto1capital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Cryptoneyx</strong> (www.cryptoneyx.com and www.cryptoneyx.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Definite Area</strong> (definitearea.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>definite-area.com</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>DGTL-Trade</strong> (dgtl-trade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ejinvesting</strong> (ejinvesting.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finutrade</strong> (finutrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>FX EliteTrader</strong> (fx-elitetrader.io)</li>
 <li><strong>GFE Markets</strong> (gfemarkets.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>gfemarket.com</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>Gigachains</strong> (www.gigachains.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Green Capitalz</strong> (greencapitalz.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Greenlinepro</strong> (greenlinepro.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Gstock</strong> (gstocklegal.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Hubblebit</strong> (<span lang="AF">hubblebit.com&nbsp;and <span lang="AF">hubblebit.vip)</span></span></li>
 <li><strong>Icorp Securities</strong> (icorpsecurities.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Inetmarkets</strong> (inetmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>JH Group</strong> (hk-atf.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Marketsbank</strong> (marketsbank.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>markets-b.com</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>MiningFXbitcoin</strong> (miningfxbitcoin.com)</li>
 <li><strong>NABCrypto.io</strong> (nabcrypto.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Onotex</strong> (onotextrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Plus12</strong> (plus12.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Priority Markets</strong> (priority-markets.com, <span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>priority-markets.net</span></span></span>)</li>
 <li><strong>Profi Trade 24/7</strong> (profitrade247.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Quantrix-Capital</strong> (www.quantrixcapital.net and www.quantrix-capital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Quantum AI </strong>(quantum-ai-trading.com, https://quantum-ai.io/, https://quantumaitrading.net/)</li>
 <li><strong>Skynettrades</strong> (skynettrades.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Smart Trade Group</strong> (smart-trade-group.com&nbsp;and smart-trade-group.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Swisschains</strong> (www.swisschains.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Tandem Markets</strong> (www.tandemmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>TradeBaionics</strong> (www.tradebaionics.com and www.tradebaionics.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Trade-Coin</strong> (trade-coin.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Uniglobal Invest</strong> (uniglobal-invest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>UXTrades</strong> (uxtrades.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:</p>

<p>Always <strong>check the identity</strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify if the company in question&nbsp;has the requisite authorization</strong>.&nbsp;To this end, an easy&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a>&nbsp;on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Eurofi 2022 Financial Forum in Prague</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/eurofi-2022-financial-forum-prague</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 8 September, the Chairman of the FSMA and Vice-Chairman of IOSCO, Jean-Paul Servais participated in the 2022 Financial Forum, the half-yearly Eurofi conference. This three-day event took place in Prague and was attended by more than 1,000 people.</strong></p>

<p>The Eurofi Financial Forum offers representatives of the public sector and stakeholders (financial institutions, investment representatives, ...) a platform for the exchange of views on financial regulation and trends in the financial sector. This year, the Financial Forum was organized in collaboration with the Czech Presidency of the Council of the European Union.</p>

<p>In Prague, Jean-Paul Servais spoke at a debate on retail investing. He called for an increased retail investor participation in the European capital market, and said that, in his view, supervisors can contribute in many ways to the achievement of this goal. One of those ways is by streamlining the requirements on the disclosure to retail investors throughout the European Union.</p>

<p>Furthermore, Jean-Paul Servais pleaded for the adaptation of the regulation to the digital age. Retail investors should be able to invest in a digital-friendly way. Regulation should also be adapted in order to make it easier for retail investors to invest in sustainable products. Supervisors should contribute to enhancing retail investors’ financial literacy by enshrining financial education in their mission statements.</p>

<p>The text of the presentation of Jean-Paul Servais is available <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-09/2022-eurofi.pdf">here</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-09-08T15:41:50+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">288641</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of fraudulent crypto trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-fraudulent-crypto-trading-platforms</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA warns consumers against fraudulent online platforms purportedly specialized in crypto trading, and reminds the public that scammers are very inventive and take advantage of trendy financial products to make new victims. </strong></p>

<p>Fraudulent crypto trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity <strong>by contacting them on social media</strong> (notably via Telegram, Instagram and WhatsApp). These platforms promise that you will get rich by investing in cryptocurrencies and claim that your funds can be withdrawn at any time or that they are guaranteed. However, these offers are <strong>too good to be true</strong>. Be vigilant, since despite these promises, you will never get your money back!</p>

<p>These platforms offer investment services connected solely with cryptocurrencies. That is where they differ from other trading platforms, against which the FSMA has already warned investors, that not only offer to invest in cryptocurrencies but also in other products such as binary options, CFDs or forex products (see our <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-1">warning of 8 June 2022</a>).</p>

<p>Victims lured into investing with these platforms complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>,</li>
 <li><strong>simply not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money, or</li>
 <li>being pressured to make <strong>additional payments</strong> (supposedly to cover levies or taxes).</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services </strong>made by the following trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li>https://cryptoprofitfx.com/</li>
 <li>www.tenndex.com</li>
 <li>www.xmsite.live and www.xmsite-coin.com</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Be careful</strong>,<strong> </strong>don’t trust the 'professional' appearance of the website to which you are referred; the swindlers do everything they can, of course, to appear as legitimate as possible. Moreover, some victims report that these platforms go as far as suggesting that they are authorized by featuring the logo of financial supervisory authorities such as the FSMA on fake documents.</p>

<h3><strong>How to avoid the trap?</strong></h3>

<p>In order to avoid such cases of fraud, the FSMA urges you to exercise utmost prudence and advises you to remain alert to any indication of investment fraud. It offers a few recommendations to this end:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns</strong>.<strong> </strong>If a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company who is contacting you</strong> (company identity, home country, etc.). If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. Find out as well when the company website was set up: if the company’s website is relatively new, this could be an additional sign of investment fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary if you are asked to deposit money to bank accounts in countries without any connection to the country where the company contacting you is said to be registered</strong> or with your own country of residence. Be wary as well if you are asked to deposit money into accounts whose beneficiary is someone other than the company itself.</li>
</ul>

<p>In any case, if your contact person comes across as particularly insistent, this is an additional indication of fraud.</p>

<p>If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-09-08T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">288410</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, received Mr Erkki Liikanen and Mr Emmanuel Faber </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-jean-paul-servais-received-mr-erkki-liikanen-and-mr-emmanuel-faber</link>
  <description>
<p>In his capacity as chairman of the IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board, Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA and vice-chairman of IOSCO, received Mr Erkki Liikanen and Mr Emmanuel Faber in Brussels. Mr Liikanen is chairman of the IFRS Foundation Trustees and Mr Faber is chairman of the ISSB (International Sustainability Standards Board).</p>

<p>They discussed the priorities of the ISSB, among which, inter alia, developing sustainability related corporate disclosure standards with a high sense of momentum through quality processes, and truly embedding global inclusiveness and adoption considerations in the work from inception.</p>

<p>This visit was also the opportunity for Mr Erkki Liikanen and Mr Emmanuel Faber to discover the Wikifin Lab, the fully digital centre for financial education of the FSMA, and to discuss the close links between financial education and sustainable finance.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-09-02T09:05:18+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">287643</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of fraudulent offers of wealth management</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-fraudulent-offers-wealth-management</link>
  <description>
<p><strong><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of five new companies that make fraudulent offers of wealth management. </strong></strong></p>

<p>As part of such fraudulent offers of wealth management, the fraudsters contact you by phone, without you having requested it or after you entered your contact details on an online form. A ‘specialist’ then offers to manage your assets, touting interest rates that are much higher than market rates, and usually offering a capital guarantee. However, these offers are too good to be true. Be vigilant, since if you put your trust in these fraudsters, you will never get your money back!</p>

<p>The FSMA has identified 5 new companies making such offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>ab-investment-acces.net</li>
 <li>besttradingspecialists.com</li>
 <li>gestioneuropecapital.com</li>
 <li>Javius.com</li>
 <li>lj-invest.net</li>
</ul>

<h2><strong>How does the fraud scheme begin? </strong></h2>

<p>You may be approached <strong>after having expressed an interest in an advertisement</strong> dangling the promise of high interest rates published on social media or other websites. In the following days, you will receive a call from a telephone salesperson, who will offer to manage your assets.</p>

<p>You may also be <strong>contacted by phone without you having taken any initiative</strong> at all. This ‘cold calling’ technique is widely used in investment fraud. You will then be invited to consult the website of their ‘company’ and open a personal account. Sometimes you are also offered a contract. Contacts will continue by email, phone, text message or via WhatsApp.</p>

<p><strong>Be careful, </strong>don’t rely on the ‘professional’ appearance of the website to which you are referred; naturally, the fraudsters do everything to make their site seem as serious as possible.</p>

<h2><strong>What are you being offered?</strong></h2>

<p>Testimonies by consumers indicate that they are often offered <strong>wealth management contracts</strong>. In short, you entrust your money to your interlocutor, who will manage it for you, promising high returns that may even come with a guaranteed rate.</p>

<h2><strong>How to avoid the trap?</strong></h2>

<p>The FSMA <strong>invites you to heed the following recommendations in order to avoid fraudulent schemes</strong>:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Take the&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud"><strong>test</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong>on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</li>
</ul>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns. </strong>Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Don’t accept uncritically the information provided by these companies. </strong>It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization </strong>by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.<strong> Be wary as well of ‘cloned firms’. </strong>The latter are companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this<strong> </strong>sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary </strong>of unsolicited phone calls/emails<strong> </strong>(<strong>cold calling</strong>), that is, calls/emails where you have not taken any initiative prior to the call/email.<strong> </strong>These are often the first sign of fraud<strong>.</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to pay money into accounts in countries that have nothing to do with </strong>the company that is approaching you or with your own place of residence.</li>
 <li><strong>Never invest if you do not fully understand what is being offered</strong>.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious </strong>if the payout of returns is conditional on making an<strong> additional payment </strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt&nbsp;</strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<h2><strong>I have been the victim of fraud: what should I do?</strong></h2>

<p>If you think you have been the victim of fraud, make sure you&nbsp;<strong>do not make any more payments</strong>&nbsp;to your interlocutor.&nbsp;<strong>Note</strong>:&nbsp;this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used in order to try to obtain one last payment.</p>

<p><strong>Contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://www.police.be/en">your local police</a>&nbsp;to make a complaint and<strong>&nbsp;report the scam to the FSMA&nbsp;</strong>via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a><strong>.</strong></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-08-26T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">271605</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Continuing professional training in 2022 for accredited statutory auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/continuing-professional-training-2022-accredited-statutory-auditors</link>
  <description>
<p>The continuing professional training programme for 2022 will be spread over two sessions, of about an hour and a half to two hours each (not including the Q&amp;A session) and will take place within the FSMA on:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Thursday, 27 October 2022</strong> from 2 – 4 pm: training session for undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment and regulated real estate companies;</li>
 <li><strong>Thursday, 1 December 2022</strong> from 2 – 4 pm: training session for institutions for occupational retirement provision.</li>
</ul>

<p>Register for our continuing professional training by returning the form attached to the Communication referred to below by&nbsp;<a href="mailto:studies@fsma.be">email</a>&nbsp;at the latest by&nbsp;<strong>7 October 2022</strong>. Registration is free of charge.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>For additional information, see the Communication (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-08/fsma_2022_24_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-08/fsma_2022_24_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-08-25T08:38:31+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">278886</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Beware of offers of investment in wine</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-offers-investment-wine</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA once again warns the public against fraudulent investment offers in wine (see our warning of </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-offers-investment-wine-champagne-and-spirits"><strong>24 June 2021</strong></a><strong>).&nbsp; </strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;The principle remains the same: after having clicked on an advertisement on social media, victims are contacted by phone by a salesperson, who offers them investments in wine and invites them to consult an online <strong>trading platform for fine wines</strong>.</p>

<p>These companies offer the opportunity to <strong>acquire bottles</strong>, undertake to <strong>stock them in a cellar</strong> for you, and promise to <strong>find some major buyers</strong> so that you can earn a <strong>handsome profit</strong>. Would-be investors have nothing to do, the companies 'will take care of everything'! The concept, however, is <strong>too good to be true</strong>. In the end, despite the promises, the investors never recover their money! &nbsp;</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>The suspect companies active in recent weeks:</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>In recent weeks, the FSMA was informed that the companies behind the following websites have been approaching Belgians with these types of fraudulent offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>http://metropole-conseil.com/</li>
 <li>https://gst-investissements.com/fr/admin/login</li>
</ul>

<p>The FSMA warns that these companies<strong> do not hold an authorization </strong>and are thus<strong> not permitted to offer investment services </strong>in Belgium. Moreover, it is very likely that these are cases of investment fraud, which means that in the end, the amounts invested are never reimbursed.</p>

<p><strong>Be careful</strong>,<strong> </strong>don’t trust the 'professional' appearance of the website to which you are referred; the swindlers do everything they can, of course, to appear as legitimate as possible.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>How to avoid the trap?</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>In order to avoid such cases of fraud, the FSMA <strong>urges you to exercise utmost prudence </strong>and <strong>advises you to remain alert</strong> <strong>to any indication of investment fraud</strong>. It offers a few recommendations to this end:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns. </strong>If a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>who is contacting you (company identity, home country, etc.). If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. <strong>Find out as well when the company website was set up</strong>: if the company’s website is relatively new, this could be an additional sign of investment fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary if you are asked to deposit money to bank accounts in countries without any connection </strong>to the country where the company contacting you is said to be registered or with your own country of residence. Be wary as well if you are asked to deposit money into accounts whose <strong>beneficiary is someone other </strong>than the company itself.</li>
</ul>

<p>In any case, if your contact person comes across as <strong>particularly insistent</strong>, this is an additional indication of fraud.</p>

<p><strong>***</strong></p>

<p><strong>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. </strong></p>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt </strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-08-23T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>ESMA launches Call for Evidence on pre-hedging</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/esma-launches-call-evidence-pre-hedging</link>
  <description>
<p>ESMA has published last Friday a Call for Evidence on pre-hedging. The aim is to promote discussion among stakeholders and gather further evidence on the practice of pre-hedging that could help ESMA to develop appropriate guidance. Stakeholders – investment firms, credit institutions, proprietary traders, market makers, asset management companies and any other market participants including trade associations and industry bodies, institutional and retail investors, consultants, and academics – are invited to submit their responses <strong>by 30 September 2022</strong>.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more on our website under <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/lopende-consultaties">Ongoing consultations</a>.</p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>IOSCO discusses sustainability reporting standards</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-discusses-sustainability-reporting-standards</link>
  <description>
<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, attended the recent meeting of the IOSCO Board, the international organization of securities commissions, of which he is Vice Chair.</p>

<p>The Board discussed the proposed standards for corporate reporting on sustainability made by the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB). IOSCO is delighted at the positive responses to those proposals.</p>

<p>As chair of the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation, Jean-Paul Servais emphasized the crucial role that the ISSB will play in streamlining sustainability reporting, thereby contributing to ensuring that the market and investors are well&nbsp;informed.</p>

<p>The IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board, which consists of public authorities, monitors the &nbsp;work of the IFRS Foundation, of which the ISSB is a part.</p>

<p>The press release and the remarks by Jean-Paul Servais are available <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS653.pdf">here</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-29T10:45:18+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">245082</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Scammers pass themselves off as banks: beware of fraud!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/scammers-pass-themselves-banks-beware-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Fraudsters continue to usurp the identity of major banks in order to catch consumers off guard. The FSMA has already issued a warning against this phenomenon twice in&nbsp;2021, but has noticed that this type of fraud is still taking victims today. </strong></p>

<p>The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone or by email without having taken any prior initiative themselves or after having entered their contact details on an online form.&nbsp;Such forms are frequently offered to consumers on social media, via advertisements or sponsored publications.</p>

<p>The fraudsters then offer consumers&nbsp;<strong>savings plans</strong>&nbsp;with the promise of returns in excess of market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end, the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money.</p>

<p>The FSMA recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several banks to deceive consumers.&nbsp;<strong>The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:</strong>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>NatWest</strong>, using email addresses ending with ‘@nw-secure.info’;</li>
 <li><strong>ING-Diba</strong>, using email addresses ending with ‘@ingdiba-france.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>TSB Bank, </strong>using email addresses ending with ‘@tsbonline-contact.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>Ulster Bank</strong>, using email addresses ending with ‘@ulster-private.com’, and a website ‘https://monespace-secu.com/portefeuille.php’;</li>
 <li><strong>Banca March</strong>.</li>
</ul>

<p>Fraudsters might also usurp the names of other financial institutions.</p>

<p>For more information on how these fraudulent schemes work, you are invited to consult the FSMA’s warnings of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67423">29 January 2021</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/usurpation-identity-certain-banks-fraudsters-fsma-reiterates-its-warning">8 April 2021</a>.</p>

<p>The fraudsters may also use this technique to offer other banking services, and in particular <strong>offers of</strong> <strong>credit</strong>. In the latter case, the scam is based on the payment of <strong>fees</strong> that are supposedly necessary to obtain credit. The FSMA refers to its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-watch-out-scams-0">warnings</a> against “fake credit” fraud.</p>

<p><strong>How to avoid this trap?</strong></p>

<p><strong>The FSMA also encourages you to see the recommendations it made in its&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67423"><strong>previous warning</strong></a><strong> on the subject.</strong></p>

<p>In particular, the FSMA urges you to look very carefully at the email addresses or contact details of the companies who are contacting you.</p>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>, please feel free to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify the FSMA should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></p>

<p>If you think you have been the victim of fraud,&nbsp;make sure you&nbsp;<strong>do not pay any additional sums to your contact person</strong>.&nbsp;Please note, this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p>

<p>Also, <strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a>&nbsp;immediately to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA&nbsp;to the scam</strong>&nbsp;via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p>

<p>The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly</strong>&nbsp;and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-27T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">237943</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Communication on the Nyrstar dossier</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/communication-nyrstar-dossier</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In order to provide the market with the latest information, the FSMA would like to outline the state of affairs in the investigation of Nyrstar NV.</strong></p>

<p>The Management Committee of the FSMA decided, in September 2019, to task the investigations officer with conducting an administrative investigation of Nyrstar NV regarding its compliance with the obligation to provide information to the market. The investigation focused, in the first instance, on information provided by Nyrstar as regards the scope and modalities of its commercial relationship with Trafigura.</p>

<p>On 29 May 2020, the FSMA announced that the aforesaid investigation was being extended to two additional elements. First, the information published on the expected profit contribution by the Australian smelter in Port Pirie and on the total cost of the project, and second, the company’s solvency and liquidity position at the end of 2018. This extension enabled the FSMA’s investigations officer to take the desired investigation measures on these points as well, in order to assess whether the market had access at all times to the information necessary to form an accurate view of the company’s financial position.</p>

<p>The FSMA’s investigations officer conducted an investigation that involved sending more than 500 questions or requests for documents to various individuals and parties, including, by way of international cooperation, to persons and parties based abroad (Switzerland, France, United Kingdom, etc.).</p>

<p>&nbsp;That investigation made it possible to compile a dossier of more than 12,000 pages of documents and to draft a provisional report of more than 400 pages covering the three elements of the investigation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;In accordance with the procedure provided for in Articles 70 and following of the Law of 2 August 2002 on the supervision of the financial sector and on financial services, the next step in the procedure is to send this provisional report to Nyrstar to enable it to provide its comments.</p>

<p>&nbsp;After examining the comments provided, the investigations officer will finalize the report and submit it to the Management Committee of the FSMA. In accordance with Article 71 of the aforementioned Law of 2 August 2002, the Management Committee may then decide:</p>

<ul>
 <li>to draw up a notice of charges and send them to the Sanctions Committee</li>
 <li>to close the case</li>
 <li>to accept an agreed settlement.</li>
</ul>

<p>In the first case, if any of the charges in the notice includes actions that may also constitute a criminal offence, the FSMA will inform the Public Prosecutor.</p>

<p>The FSMA will continue to keep the market informed of developments in this case, within the limits of its obligation of professional secrecy.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-25T13:33:53+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">241503</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Speech at the Sustainable Finance Conference</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/speech-sustainable-finance-conference</link>
  <description>
<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, recently participated in the Sustainable Finance Conference: The Future of Sustainable Finance organized by the Hellenic Capital Market Commission. As chair of the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation and co-chair of the Monitoring Group on Audit Standard-Setting, he emphasized the role and the importance of high-quality and reliable sustainability reporting for combating greenwashing. The further development of international standards for sustainability reporting and supervision is a key component of this effort.</p>

<p>The text of Jean-Paul Servais’ speech is available <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/2022-06-29_future_sustainable_finance.pdf">here</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-22T17:09:57+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">237944</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Extension of the definition of PCP in the area of credit starting on 1 August 2022</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/extension-definition-pcp-area-credit-starting-1-august-2022</link>
  <description>
<p>The definition of ‘public-facing staff’ – known as a PCP – is being extended for credit intermediation. This is the consequence of a legislative amendment that enters into force on 1 August 2022.</p>

<p>The main impact of this legislative amendment is at the level of professional knowledge. Persons who are considered equivalent to a PCP and those who carry out such functions with a credit provider or credit intermediary as at 1 August 2022 have a period of 12 months to meet the requirements in terms of professional knowledge.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the Newsletter...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/2022-07_newsflash_pcp_nl.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/2022-07_newsflash_pcp_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-20T13:41:08+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">235540</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee of the international organization IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-re-elected-chair-european-regional-committee-international-organization-iosco-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), has been re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee of IOSCO, the international organization of financial market supervisors.</strong></p>

<p>The European members of IOSCO re-elected Jean-Paul Servais to another two-year term as chair of the European Regional Committee, the European country group within IOSCO. He has held this position since October 2014.</p>

<p><span lang="GSW-FR">IOSCO was founded in 1983 and comprises 130 supervisory authorities from 115 jurisdictions, representing 95% of the worldwide financial sector. The objective of the organization is to promote cooperation among market supervisors and to develop international standards and best practices.</span></p>

<p>IOSCO has four regional committees. The European Regional Committee brings together the 51 European members of IOSCO. The Committee discusses IOSCO initiatives that relate to the strengthening of worldwide standards for financial markets, with particular attention to matters that are of relevance to Europe.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais: “I am delighted to be re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee, which I already preside over for many years. The fact that I can continue to hold this position after all those years is a sign of appreciation for the work carried out by the FSMA both nationally and internationally.&nbsp;This important position allows the FSMA to play an active role in the international debates about financial regulation that is constantly evolving and has an impact on Belgian financial regulation”.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The chairman of the FSMA is also vice chair of the IOSCO Board and chair of IOSCO’s audit committee. On behalf of IOSCO he also chairs the IFRS Monitoring Board, chairs the SPACs network and co-chairs the Monitoring Group with regard to auditing.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-13T09:40:49+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">233002</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Publication of sectoral reports on compliance with MiFID</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-sectoral-reports-compliance-mifid</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has today published three sectoral reports on compliance with the MiFID conduct of business rules. Compliance with those rules is important in order to ensure that the right products are offered to the right people. The sectoral reports are based on inspections carried out by the FSMA. The results show that there has been improvement in terms compliance with the MiFID rules of conduct. These rules are now better incorporated into business practice and have proven their added value. There are a few points for which improvement is still needed. All those points are discussed in detail in the three sectoral reports published by the FSMA.</p>

<p>The reports address the following topics:</p>

<ul>
 <li>the suitability assessment (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/rapportsectoriel-evaluationcaractere-approprie.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/sectorrapport-passendheidsbeoordeling.pdf">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;;&nbsp;</li>
 <li>the appropriateness assessment (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/rapportsectoriel-evaluationcaractere-approprie.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/sectorrapport-geschiktheidsbeoordeling.pdf">Dutch</a> only);</li>
 <li>product governance (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/rapportsectoriel-gouvernance-produits.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/sectorrapport-productgovernance.pdf">Dutch</a> only).</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-13T08:01:18+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">232966</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: New status of ‘subagent in training’</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-new-status-subagent-training</link>
  <description>
<p>Since 1 January 2022, you can carry out (re)insurance intermediation as a ‘subagent in training’. This new status offers the solution for starting up the activity of (re)insurance distribution under the legal status of a self-employed person.<br>
<br>
A ‘subagent in training’ is a (re)insurance subagent who meets all the conditions for registration, including as regards the required theoretical knowledge, but who does not have 6 six months of practical experience. He or she can obtain the requisite practical experience under the heightened supervision of a (re)insurance broker or agent.</p>

<p>In this newsletter:</p>

<ol>
 <li>Context and registration conditions</li>
 <li>What is a ‘subagent in training’?</li>
 <li>Reminder: the heightened responsibility of the broker or agent who works with a subagent</li>
</ol>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the newsletter...available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/2022-07-07_newsletter_statut_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-07/2022-07-07_newsletter_statuut_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-07T10:08:07+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">176982</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Consultation on the Communication on the classification of crypto-assets as securities, investment instruments or financial instruments</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/consultation-communication-classification-crypto-assets-securities-investment-instruments-or</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Crypto-assets are currently the subject of much interest. It is thus not surprising that the FSMA regularly receives questions about the classification of such assets.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has therefore drawn up a Communication on the classification of crypto-assets as securities, investment instruments or financial instruments.</p>

<p>With this Communication, the FSMA wishes to provide clarity, while awaiting a harmonized European approach<sup><a href="#1">[1]</a></sup>, about when crypto-assets may be considered to be securities, investment instruments or financial instruments, and whether they may fall within the scope of the prospectus legislation and/or the MiFID conduct of business rules.</p>

<p>The Communication and the stepwise plan attached are intended to help issuers, offerors and service providers carry out the exercise of classifying crypto-assets within the applicable legal framework that was not drawn up specifically for these types of instruments.</p>

<p>The FSMA focuses to this end on the basic questions and the situations which it has encountered most frequently to date. This means that it does not address all potential classifications and that the stepwise plan is likely to evolve over time.</p>

<p>The stepwise plan is not intended, in any case, to replace a thorough analysis of all specific characteristics and presentation of the product in the light of the applicable rules. Moreover, it is best not to rely solely on the name of a product when deciding how to classify it. The label does not always match the content.</p>

<p>The FSMA is holding an <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/ongoing-consultations">open consultation</a> on the Communication. It will run from 05/07/2022 to 31/07/2022. The consultation is addressed to all players in the financial sector and to investors’ representatives. Responses can be submitted to the email address <a href="mailto:consult1@fsma.be">consult1@fsma.be</a>.</p>

<div>&nbsp;
<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="1">[1]</a></sup> Proposal by the European Commission of 24 September 2020 for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on Markets in Crypto-assets, and amending Directive (EU) 2019/1937.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-07-06T11:04:45+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">232838</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter for the AML compliance officers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-aml-compliance-officers</link>
  <description>
<p>AML compliance officers (ALMCO) play a key role in combatting money laundering and terrorist financing (AML/CFT). Given the importance of their tasks, the FSMA wishes to increase opportunities for exchanging information with AMLCOs, in particular by publishing newsletters and organising events specifically for them.</p>

<p>In line with this aim, the FSMA has published a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-09/2022-06-28_newsletter_amlco_en.pdf">newsletter</a> for AMLCOs, to inform them of recent developments regarding AML/CFT and of upcoming events. These include, in particular, the first-ever 'AMLCO Days' that will take place on 3 October 2022 and the updating of Communication FSMA_2020_12 of 6 October 2020 on the annual activity report of the AMLCO, with a view to specifying the deadline for submitting the said report to the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-06-28T14:11:52+02:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>Annual report 2021</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/annual-report-2021</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has today published its annual report for 2021. On this occasion, the FSMA held a webinar presenting its supervision of compliance with the rules intended to protect investors and introducing an innovative tool based on data analysis.</strong></p>

<p>The core mission of the FSMA is to contribute to an honest and fair treatment of financial consumers and to transparency in the financial markets. The MiFID conduct of business rules for consumer protection are an important instrument for achieving this objective in the area of investments. The FSMA supervises compliance by the financial sector with those rules of conduct.</p>

<p>In the past decade, we have seen a positive trend in compliance with the MiFID rules of conduct. They have come to be better integrated into the sector and have proven their added value. There remain, however, a few points requiring improvement. Many of those points concern the way in which products are developed, including the associated fees and potential return.</p>

<p>More information on this matter is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-06/2022-06-23_jvra_presentation_eng.pdf">webinar presentation</a>.</p>

<p>On the occasion of the publication of the 2021 annual report, the FSMA also introduced an innovative tool that is based on data analysis. This tool enables the FSMA to detect so-called ‘Closet Indexing’. Closet Indexing refers to the practice whereby a fund that is said to be actively managed and charges investors fees for that service is in reality under passive management. This practice is disadvantageous to investors. Click here for the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/combating-closet-indexing-new-approach-developed-fsma">press release on Closet Indexing</a>.</p>

<p>If you wish to know more about the main points of the Annual Report, we invite you to view and listen to the video message (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/723286860">French</a> - <a href="https://vimeo.com/723286708">Dutch</a> only) by the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais.</p>

<p>The full text of the 2021 annual report is available via the FSMA’s website (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/rapports-annuels">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/jaarverslagen">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-06-23T14:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">221568</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Combating Closet Indexing – A new approach developed by the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/combating-closet-indexing-new-approach-developed-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Closet Indexing refers to the practice of promoting an investment fund as actively managed, whereas in fact the fund closely tracks a benchmark index. The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has developed an innovative methodology to detect possible Closet Indexers on the Belgian public investment fund market.</strong></p>

<h2><strong>Closet Indexing: a practice that is disadvantageous to investors</strong></h2>

<p>This practice is disadvantageous to investors, since, on the one hand, they do not receive the active management described in the fund’s investment policy, while on the other hand, they pay higher fees than those charged for passive management. Therefore they are receiving passive management for the price of active management.</p>

<h2><strong>An innovative approach developed by the FSMA</strong></h2>

<p>Previous analyses conducted at European level by ESMA with a view to detecting potential Closet Indexers focused only on share funds (37% of the market). The importance of mixed funds (42% of the market), which invest in both shares and bonds and, to a lesser extent, in bond funds (6% of the market), on the Belgian public investment fund market prompted the FSMA to expand the scope of analysis.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore developed, with its Data Analytics Expertise Centre, an innovative methodology to detect potential Closet Indexers. This methodology can be applied to all funds, whatever their investment policy (shares, bonds or mixed).</p>

<p>In order to do so, the methodology compares the performance of funds with the performance of combinations of indices. Working with combinations of indices makes it possible to expand the scope, since many funds, and especially mixed funds, use multiple indices (e.g. an index for the share component of the portfolio and another index for the bond component). This methodology requires highly effective analytical tools, since there is a very large number of potential combinations of indices (depending on the indices used and the weighting among them).</p>

<h2><strong>No Closet Indexer was detected… </strong></h2>

<p>This methodology was applied to the Belgian public investment fund market. The quantitative analysis revealed a number of potential Closet Indexers. The subsequent qualitative analyses showed that these were not in fact Closet Indexers. At the end of the analysis, no Closet Indexer had been identified, which is good news for investors.</p>

<h2><strong>…but 4&nbsp;funds were insufficiently transparent</strong></h2>

<p>In the case of 4&nbsp;funds, the FSMA carried out an in-depth analysis, based on internal documents that had been made available to it. This analysis made it possible to determine that the 4 funds in question are managed with reference to an index, but that this is not stated in the information provided to clients.</p>

<p>These are not cases of Closet Indexing, however, since the intention is not for the funds to closely track that index. But the fact that the funds use an index, for example, when the objective is to outperform that index, should be communicated to investors. The 4&nbsp;funds will update their documentation to reinforce transparency vis-à-vis investors.</p>

<h2><strong>Vigilance remains advisable</strong></h2>

<p>The methodology that has been developed is an additional tool available to the FSMA to ensure that this practice is not adopted in our country. Analyses of this type will therefore be conducted on a regular basis.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-06-23T09:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">221569</guid>
    </item>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/certain-aspects-appropriateness-and-execution-only-requirements</link>
  <description>
<p>The purpose of the ESMA guidelines is to clarify the application of certain aspects of the MiFID II appropriateness and execution-only requirements in order to ensure the common, uniform and consistent application of Article 27ter, §§ 3 and 5, of the Law of 2 August 2002 on the supervision of the financial sector and on financial services and of Articles 55 to 57 of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565.</p>

  <description>
<p>On 16 June 2022, the Chairman of the FSMA took part in the Hellas 2022 International conference of the Hellenic Investors Association (HIA) and Better Finance, the European Federation of Investors and Financial Services Users. In his keynote speech, he addressed, among other things, the development of the Capital Markets Union within the European Union and the enhancement of investor confidence and protection. <item>
  <title>Update of the Communication on the annual activity report of the AMLCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-communication-annual-activity-report-amlco</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has updated its Communication FSMA_2020_12 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_nl.pdf">Dtuch</a> only) of 6 October 2020, which sets out the information that must be included in the annual activity report of the AMLCO. A copy of that report, written for the senior management and the legal governing body, must always be submitted to the FSMA.</p>

<p>The Communication has been updated to specify that the FSMA expects AMLCOs to send it <strong>a copy of the said report at the latest by 15 May</strong> following the reporting year. This does not apply to insurance intermediaries, which are required to keep the said report available to the FSMA.</p>

<p>Analysing these reports is one of the supervisory tools used by the FSMA. It is an important source of information for the FSMA as it performs its supervisory actions with regard to AML/CFT.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-06-15T13:41:21+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">215900</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies new fraudulent online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-1</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market. </strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use <strong>mobile applications </strong>to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li><strong>simply</strong> <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Agartha Asset Management</strong><strong> </strong>(www.agarthaassetmanagement.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Antarimarkets</strong> (www.antarimarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Apex500</strong><strong> </strong>(www.apex-500.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Brokeragea</strong> (www.brokeragea.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Calliber</strong> (www.calliber.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Capital Professional Reserve</strong><strong> </strong>(www.cp-r.net) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Concept Blue</strong> (www.concept-blue.com) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Cryptosaving</strong> (www.cryptosavings.io)</li>
 <li><strong>CTmatador</strong><strong> </strong>(www.ctmatador.com and www.platform.ctmatador-pro.com)</li>
 <li><strong>DCMGROUP</strong><strong> </strong>(www.dcmgroup.io)</li>
 <li><strong>EJMarkets</strong><strong> </strong>(www.ejmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Europa Trade Capital</strong> (www.europatradecapital.com, https://eurotrcap.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Euro Trade</strong> (www.eurotrade.co)</li>
 <li><strong>FinsRoyal</strong> (www.finsroyal.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Foxane</strong> (www.foxane.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Fxpoint</strong><strong> </strong>(www.fxpoint.co)</li>
 <li><strong>Glenrocks</strong><strong> </strong>(www.glenrocks.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Globalxtrades</strong><strong> </strong>(www.globalxtrades.com, https://globalx-trade.com/ and https://gxtrade.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>High Capital</strong> (www.high-capitals.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Introtrade</strong> (www.introtrade.pro)</li>
 <li><strong>Infinity4x</strong><strong> </strong>(www.infinity4x.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Kardon Capital</strong> (www.kardoncapital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>LPLeurope</strong><strong> </strong>(www.lpleurope.com)</li>
 <li><strong>LPL Invest</strong> (www.lplinvest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Oriontero</strong><strong> </strong>(www.oriontero.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Slimhandel</strong> (www.slimhandel.com and www.slimhandel.nl)</li>
 <li><strong>Soltechx</strong> (www.soltechx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Standpoint Finance</strong> (www.standpointfinance.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ti-GI</strong><strong> </strong>(www.ti-gi.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Top Capital 24</strong> (www.topcapital24.com) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Towards Source</strong> (www.towardssource.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Traderhouse </strong>(www.traderhouse.com, www.traderhouse2.com and www.traderhouse3.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Trade Horizon</strong><strong> </strong>(www.tradehorizon.com and www.tradehorizon2.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Trends Turbo</strong> (www.trends-turbo.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ualgo </strong>(www.ualgo.com)</li>
 <li><strong>World Markets</strong> (www.worldmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Word Wide Brokers </strong>(www.worldwidebrokers.co and www.ww-brokers.com)</li>
 <li><strong>x-tradebrokers</strong><strong> </strong>(www.x-tradebrokers.com and http://xtr-brokers.com/, xtb-futures.de)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:</p>

<p><strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

<p><span><span><span>On 31 May 2022, the Chairman of the FSMA took part in the 2022 Convention of the <a href="http://www.fese.eu">Federation of European Securities Exchanges</a> (FESE).   <title>Electronic submission to the FSMA of information on undertakings for collective investment</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/electronic-submission-fsma-information-undertakings-collective-investment</link>
  <description>
<p>This document sets out the procedure to be followed when:</p>

<ul>
 <li>submitting periodic statistical information and questionnaires via the FiMiS platform;</li>
 <li>submitting periodic documents via the eCorporate platform;</li>
 <li>submitting, by email or on a USB stick, the definitive documents requested in a letter of decision by the Management Committee of the FSMA or requested in a communication from the FSMA relating to a file that comes under Article 34 of the Royal Decree of 12 November 2012 on undertakings for collective investment that fulfil the conditions of Directive 2009/65/EC or under Article 26 of the Royal Decree of 25 February 2017 on certain alternative investment funds and their management companies and containing various provisions.</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">

</description>

<item>
  <title>Have you received an attractive credit proposal? Watch out for scams</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-watch-out-scams-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credit to consumers.</strong></p>

<p>In recent months, the FSMA has detected&nbsp;<strong>40 fraudulent lenders</strong>&nbsp;who offer false credit to Belgian consumers via the Internet. Consumers get in touch with these lenders in a variety of ways: they are&nbsp;<strong>approached unsolicited</strong>&nbsp;via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.), or they find advertisements on the&nbsp;<strong>internet</strong>.</p>

<p>However, in reality, these are&nbsp;<strong>false offers of credit</strong>&nbsp;made in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be authorized lenders or credit intermediaries and they do not shy away from using the names and logos of legitimate financial service providers. These are cases of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies">cloned firms</a>.</p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers credit at very&nbsp;<strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, a lender claims to extend substantial loans at a low interest rate. The lender may also claim not to check whether the consumer is a poor payer and has taken out loans in the past that he/she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain <strong>payments</strong> supposedly to cover <strong>costs</strong> relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly&nbsp;<strong>impossible to recover the amounts paid</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</strong></p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Air Credit Pro </strong>(https://air-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BCCE Bank </strong>(https://www.bcce-bank.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Bedrijf Financial </strong>(https://bedrijf-financial.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BKR Geld Bezorging </strong>(http://www.bkrgeldbezorging.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Chronys Services </strong>(www.chronys-services.fr)</li>
 <li><strong>CJ-Finances </strong>(https://www.cj-finances.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Credipea </strong>(https://credipea.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Duty Financial Corp </strong>(https://dutyfinancialcorp.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Empayc Finance (<em>cloned firm</em>)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>EranFinance </strong>(https://royal-eranfinance.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Europe-Finance </strong>(https://europe-finance.net/)</li>
 <li><strong>Fast Financial Bank </strong>(https://www.fastfinancialbnk.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financ-Ed (<em>cloned firm</em>) </strong>(https://www.financedkrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">Financien Krediet </span></strong><span lang="NL-BE">(https://financien-krediet.nl/)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Geld Sofort </strong>(https://www.geld-sofort.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Global Kreditering </strong>(https://globalkreditering.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>GlobalService-krediet </strong>(https://globalservice-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Groupe Asux </strong>(https://www.groupe-asux.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">Hoek Financien </span></strong><span lang="NL-BE">(www.hoekfinancien.com)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Idealus Krediet Bank </strong>(https://idealus-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>IFCR Services </strong>(https://ifcrservices.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Katel Finance </strong>(https://katel-finance.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Krediet Prestito </strong>(https://krediet-prestito.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Kredinel </strong>(https://www.kredinel.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Legal Finance Global </strong>(www.legalfinancegloball.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Lening Classic </strong>(www.lening-classic.com)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">Lening zonder voorwaarde </span></strong><span lang="NL-BE">(www.leningzondervoorwaarde.com)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Multi Diensten </strong>(https://www.multi-diensten.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Mzava Finance </strong>(http://mzava-financial.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Nieuwlening </strong>(https://nieuwlening.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Nofico Bank </strong>(http://www.noficogroup.org/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">Persoonlijk krediet </span></strong><span lang="NL-BE">(https://leningen-be.com/)</span></li>
 <li><strong>RachWin </strong>(www.rachwin.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Rexwin Financial </strong>(http://rexwin-financial.com/)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">SGL Investeerder </span></strong><span lang="NL-BE">(www.sgl-investeerder.com)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Sofina Invest Groupe </strong>(https://sofina-invest-groupe.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>SolisFunding </strong>(www.solisfunding.com)</li>
 <li><strong>UnaKredo </strong>(www.unakredo.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Unitec Global Finance LTD </strong>(https://ugf-ltd.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Zenicorn Corporate </strong>(http://zenicorncorporate.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA offers the following&nbsp;<strong>general recommendations</strong>&nbsp;for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be wary if (out of the blue) you receive an&nbsp;<strong>unsolicited credit offer</strong>&nbsp;via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on unusually favourable terms</strong>&nbsp;(a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you first pay a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan.</strong>&nbsp;The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Find out whether the lender has the requisite authorization.</strong>&nbsp;Via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines.</strong> You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.&nbsp;As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-05-24T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">190667</guid>
    </item>
