  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-3</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular FSMA_2022_15 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-05/fsma_2022_15_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-05/fsma_2022_15_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</p>

<item>
  <title>Cryptocurrencies: new rules enter into force</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/cryptocurrencies-new-rules-enter-force</link>
  <description>
<p>As from 1 May 2022, any legal person established in Belgium that wants to provide exchange services between virtual currencies and legal currencies, or custody wallet services, within Belgium will have to register with the FSMA in advance.</p>

<p>Providers already operating on 1 May 2022 must notify the FSMA of the exercise of their activity before 1 July 2022 and apply for registration before 1 September 2022.</p>

<p>Interested? Please consult our FAQs (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/virtual-asset-service-provider-vasp">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/virtual-asset-service-provider-vasp">Dutch</a> only) on our website, which will inform you of the steps to take to register.</p>
</description>

    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">190016</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Rules on sustainable finance - Insurance companies </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/rules-sustainable-finance-insurance-companies</link>
  <description>
<p>New European rules on sustainable finance have been in the making since 2019. They are gradually coming into force. The FSMA wishes to draw the attention of insurance companies to the sustainability rules that are or will be applicable to them. It has drawn up a document (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-04/fsma_2022_14_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-04/fsma_2022_14_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) outlining these rules in brief. It is the responsibility of the companies to conduct their own in-depth analysis of the rules in order to ascertain their precise impact on their activities.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Watch out for companies that offer trading software (Expert Advisors)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-companies-offer-trading-software-expert-advisors-1</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA warns the public against EA World FX, a company that is offering so-called ‘Expert Advisors’ or ‘EAs’ used to trade in forex-derivatives in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>An Expert Advisor is a type of software that tells you when to make certain trades or even carries them out for you automatically, based on preprogrammed parameters.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that companies are distributing such Expert Advisors, including to Belgian consumers. This comes with risks.</p>

<p>First, these companies do not have an authorization to offer financial services and products in Belgium.</p>

<p>Moreover, the FSMA has found that such trading software often occurs via a pyramid structure. In general, these are referred to as ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing) schemes, in which consumers are incentivized to bring in new members. In exchange, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the software package.</p>

<p>Such MLM networks appear to be active on social media via countless (private) groups. It appears that these schemes mainly target young people. The message is that everyone can afford a luxurious lifestyle provided they bring in enough new members and make the appropriate investment in the software being promoted.</p>

<p>The FSMA also wishes to emphasize that distribution of certain financial instruments that are available via the software (such as CFDs, forex and crypto-derivatives) is prohibited in Belgium.</p>

<p>Lastly, <strong>offers of CFDs and forex derivatives via the internet are very risky and open to fraud</strong>: anyone who invests in CFDs or forex derivatives runs the risk of losing the entire sum invested. <strong>The chance of loss is far greater than the chance of profit</strong>: surveys by other European supervisors among investors shows that at least 75% to 89% of the investments in derivative products, such as forex derivatives, are loss-makers! These products are appropriate only for those who really wish to speculate, are ready to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and are familiar with derivative financial products. <strong>There have also been many cases of fraud with these instruments</strong>. In a number of cases, it turned out that no actual transactions were ever made by the offeror.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>Based on the information available to the FSMA, the following website is offering these types of trading software in Belgium, in contravention of Belgian legislation:</p>

<ul>
 <li>EA World FX (https://eaworldfx.com/front/index.html)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>Have you received an offer of an investment and would like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud">Beware of fraud’</a>.</p>

<p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-04-12T08:50:00+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>New legislation governing crowdfunding service providers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-legislation-governing-crowdfunding-service-providers</link>
  <description>
<p>The Law of 23 February 2022 Implementing certain aspects of Regulation (EU) 2020/1503 on crowdfunding service providers subjects the crowdfunding service providers governed by the Regulation to the supervision of the FSMA. The Law of 18 December 2015 on the recognition and delineation of crowdfunding has therefore been completely replaced by this new legislation.</p>

<p>Any applicant crowdfunding service provider that falls within the scope of the Regulation can, as from now, submit an application for authorization.</p>

<p>The FSMA’s website has thus been updated and includes:</p>

<ul>
 <li>New FAQs on the conditions for authorization and on the conduct of business rules;</li>
 <li>The forms provided by the FSMA to facilitate the preparation of an application for authorization.</li>
</ul>

<div>
<p>Please see our <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/crowdfunding">Crowdfunding page</a>.</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-04-04T14:47:46+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">183959</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Victim of an investment scam? Beware of recovery room fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/victim-investment-scam-beware-recovery-room-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Victims of investment fraud run the risk of being swindled a second time via fake crypto trading platforms. The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against these platforms.</strong></p><p>Every <strong>victim of investment fraud</strong> runs the risk of being contacted once again by fraudsters, who falsely offer to<strong> recover the lost funds</strong>. This form of fraud is called recovery room fraud.</p><p>The FSMA has noticed that <strong>fake platforms for trading in cryptocurrencies</strong> are engaging in recovery room fraud.</p><p>In most cases, victims receive unsolicited phone calls or emails. The fraudsters are often very aggressive in their approach. They always ask for a <strong>fee </strong>for their services. They claim these are to cover certain administrative or legal expenses or to pay taxes. But these are purely<strong> fictitious costs</strong>.</p><p>Victims of investment fraud are told they must <strong>pay this fee in advance</strong>. As soon as the fraudsters receive the fee, they disappear into thin air. It is thus almost impossible to recover the fee. <strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises not to take up such offers.</strong></p><p>These fraudsters <strong>misuse the identity details</strong> of existing companies who are authorized to offer certain financial services. In this way, they try to appear more trustworthy. Fraudsters and their companies also falsely claim to work with the police or with financial supervisors.</p><p><strong>The FSMA advises great vigilance if you are contacted, unsolicited</strong>, by the following entities:</p><ul><li><strong>'Blockchain'</strong> (cloned firm)</li></ul><p>'Blockchain' is active under the following names, among others: <em>Blockchain Agent Ltd; the international blockchain department; Blockchain Inc; Blockchain (GB) LIMITED; Blockchain Ltd Headquarters; Blockchain Finance Team.</em></p><p>According to information available to the FSMA, “Blockchain” has been contacting victims of, among others, CFD Advanced, Winngroup(s) and Finance Reserves (FRCM), all three of which are on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">list</a> of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium.</p><p>The FCA, the British financial supervisory authority, has published a <a href="https://www.fca.org.uk/news/warnings/iqbcoin-clone-fca-authorised-firm">warning</a> against the practices of 'Blockchain'.</p><ul><li><strong>IQBcoin</strong> (http://iqbcoin.com/; http://iqbcoin.net/; cloned firm)</li></ul><p>According to information available to the FSMA, IQBcoin has been contacting victims of, among others, My Safe Market and Investteck, which are on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium?title=&amp;field_ct_website_uri=&amp;field_ct_warning_types_target_id_1=10447&amp;order=field_ct_date_time&amp;sort=desc">list</a> of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium.</p><p>IQBcoin describes itself as a platform for investments in cryptocurrencies. It promises investors risk-free high returns.</p><p>The FCA thus also <a href="https://www.fca.org.uk/news/warnings/iqbcoin-clone-fca-authorised-firm">warned</a> against the activities of IQBcoin.</p><p>The above-mentioned entities do not have the requisite permission to offer financial products or services in Belgium.</p><blockquote><p><strong>A consumer reports:</strong></p><p><em>'3 years ago, I fell victim to fraudsters. A few weeks ago, I was contacted by someone who said that he could recover my 2 stolen Bitcoins. I would have to pay a one-time ‘fee’ of EUR 4100 for this. They were going to transfer the money to my bank account, but I’m still waiting.'</em></p></blockquote><p>***</p><p>Victims of investment fraud are in this way often victimized a second time by the same fraudsters: the first time as they commit the investment fraud, and the second time as they commit recovery room fraud. It is also possible that those who committed the investment fraud sold the identity details of their victims on to other fraudsters. <strong>Everyone who has ever been the victim of investment fraud can be targeted a second time by fraudsters.</strong></p><p>How can you recognize and avoid recovery room fraud?</p><ul><li>If you have been the victim of investment fraud, we advise you always to <strong>file a complaint</strong> with the local police.</li><li>If you receive an <strong>unsolicited phone call</strong> with an offer to recover the money you lost, ask the person how he or she found out that you had lost money. Reports of fraud will be shared only with the judicial authorities, and not with private companies.</li><li>If you are asked to <strong>pay a fee in advance</strong>, you should refuse to accept their offer and end all contact.</li><li><strong>Financial supervisors</strong> such as the FSMA are not competent to recover lost money, and therefore they will never contact victims of investment fraud for such purposes.</li></ul><p>***</p><p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a proposed transaction complies with the financial legislation? Please use the search function available (in Dutch and French only) on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. For more recommendations on how to avoid investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">'How to recognize and avoid fraud?'</a> page on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-03-30T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">185191</guid>
    </item>

  <title>75,000 pupils take part in the seventh edition of Money Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/75000-pupils-take-part-seventh-edition-money-week</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Next Monday marks the beginning of the seventh edition of Money Week. This is an annual thematic week organized by Wikifin, the FSMA’s financial education programme. The aim of the week is to discuss money matters in as accessible a manner as possible, and to devote particular attention to the importance of financial education. In the course of the week, more than 75,000 elementary and secondary school pupils will be taking part in a variety of activities. An overview.</strong></p>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/sustainability-guide-new-reporting-obligations-listed-companies</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is publishing a communication (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/fsma_2022_09_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/fsma_2022_09_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) that explains the new European rules governing sustainability reporting by listed companies. The new reporting is essential to meet the growing demand by investors for reliable and high-quality information on sustainability. The new reporting obligations are gradually entering into force and will apply in full starting with the 2022 financial year.</strong></p>

<p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/183084">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/183084">Dutch</a>&nbsp;site.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Fewer questions and complaints about the date when supplementary pension is paid out</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fewer-questions-and-complaints-about-date-when-supplementary-pension-paid-out</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Consumers who have questions or complaints about their supplementary pension can contact the FSMA. In 2021, the FSMA received 261 messages from consumers about this matter, representing a 28 per cent decrease compared to 2020. Most messages in 2021 once again had to do with the payment of the supplementary pension upon retirement. Contrary to past years, pension consumers had fewer questions or complaints about the date when the supplementary pension will be paid out.</strong></p>

<p>This press release is not available in English. Please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/183915">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/183915">Dutch</a> site.</p>
</description>

  <title>Cryptocurrencies: new rules for certain service providers </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/cryptocurrencies-new-rules-certain-service-providers</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>As from 1 May 2022, the activities of certain virtual currency service providers in Belgium will be regulated. These service providers will have to meet a series of conditions, including ones relating to their professional integrity and compliance with the anti-money laundering legislation.</strong></p>

<item>
  <title>FSMA launches international relations service</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-international-relations-service</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is launching a specialized team in charge of international relations. This team will play a leading role in the FSMA's participation in international activities. </strong></p>

<p>The new organizational structure responds to the active role the FSMA is playing on an international level and the increasing interaction of the FSMA with international bodies. The new service will also pay particular attention to projects on sustainable finance.</p>

<p>Mr. Antoine Van Cauwenberge, Head of International Relations &amp; ESG Policy, leads this new team. He also supports the FSMA Chairman in his multiple international functions. The FSMA Chairman is Vice-Chair of IOSCO (International Organization of Securities Commissions) and Chair of the European Regional Committee, the Finance and Audit Committee and the SPAC Network of IOSCO. The FSMA Chairman holds mandates at the international oversight bodies on the development of international financial and ESG reporting standards (IFRS Monitoring Board Chair) and audit standards (Monitoring Group co-chair). He is also member of the ESMA Board.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-02-22T08:50:41+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">183778</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: the FSMA warns the public against unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-unauthorized-activities-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>The companies are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/183207"><strong>Allied Indices International</strong></a> (www.alliedindicesinternational.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/183208"><strong>Alpes Trading</strong></a> (www.alpes-trading.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/183209"><strong>Shard Asset Management</strong></a><strong> </strong>(www.sassetmanagement.net and www.shardassetmanagement.net)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/183210"><strong>Universal Asset Management</strong></a> (www.universalassetmgmt.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above<strong> </strong>and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p>Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be '<strong>boiler rooms</strong>'.</p>

<p><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p>

<p>Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p>As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p>

<p>The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term 'boiler room'), insisting that they keep making further payments. <strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p>

<p>In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.</li>
</ul>

<p>On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website.</p>

<p><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p>If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-02-17T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">183206</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Circular on the duty of cooperation of accredited auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/circular-duty-cooperation-accredited-auditors-0</link>
  <description>
<p class="intro"><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The duty of cooperation of accredited auditors of public open-ended undertakings for collective investment</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>This circular FSMA_2022_08 (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/fsma_2022_08_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/fsma_2022_08_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)&nbsp;describes the modalities of the accredited auditors' duty of cooperation in the following areas:</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">activities and reporting of half-yearly and annual financial statements and reports;</span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">assessment of the internal control measures and of the reporting about them;</span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">reporting to the FSMA, including the reporting layout and the special report;</span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-GB">exchange of information between the accredited auditors and the FSMA, including the signalling function.</span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Belgian investment funds set a new record of 212 billion at the end of 2021</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/belgian-investment-funds-set-new-record-212-billion-end-2021</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has published the second edition of its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/2021_dashboard_q4.pdf">quarterly dashboard of Belgian public open-ended investment funds</a>, generally referred to as investment funds. The overview presented in this dashboard covers the fourth and last quarter of the year 2021. It shows that the Belgian fund sector has continued to grow, reaching total net assets under management of more than EUR&nbsp;212&nbsp;billion euros. </strong></p>

<p>Other elements included in the overview:</p>

<ul>
 <li>During the last quarter of 2021, the net assets of funds saw a growth of 12.6&nbsp;billion&nbsp;euros (+&nbsp;6 per cent); over the entire year 2021, the growth was 24 per cent.</li>
 <li>The interest of investors in funds that refer to sustainability is evident, since such funds saw a net inflow of around 5.3&nbsp;billion euros in the fourth quarter.</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-02/2021_dashboard_q4.pdf">The quarterly dashboard of Belgian public open-ended investment funds</a> is available on the FSMA website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-02-16T08:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">183303</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: 53 per cent increase in reports</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-53-cent-increase-reports</link>
  <description>
<p><strong><strong>In 2021, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received 1,918 consumer questions and complaints on the subject of fraud and unlawful offers of financial products and services. </strong>This is an increase of 23 per cent over 2020. Reports concerning fraudulent online trading platforms in particular have seen a major increase (+53 per cent). This increase is explained in part by awareness campaigns launched by the FSMA in 2020 and 2021. By way of information, a little more than half of the reports received in the second half of 2021 (56 per cent, that is, 466 out of 831) are complaints by victims. </strong></p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p><strong>Unlawful offers of financial products and services in 2021</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>Number of reports received in 2021</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>Change as compared to 2020</strong></p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Fraudulent online trading platforms</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>724</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>+53 %</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Fake credit offers</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>245</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>+12 %</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Fraud linked specifically to cryptocurrencies</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>109</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>-11 %</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Boiler rooms</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>62</strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>-50 %</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

<p>Of the 1,918 consumer reports received in 2021, about 40 per cent were about fraudulent online trading platforms that offer trading in binary options, CFDs, Forex products and cryptocurrencies. These types of fraud are continuing to increase. Last year, the FSMA received 53 per cent more reports relating to this phenomenon as compared to 2020.</p>

<p><strong>These platforms thus continue to attract consumers via false advertisements on social media. Such advertisements use the images of Dutch-speaking or French-speaking celebrities without their knowledge. </strong></p>

<p>In 2021, these platforms diversified and modernized their techniques. They are disseminating more and more promotional videos on social media such as Twitter and YouTube. They also use <strong>mobile applications </strong>that offer virtual currencies or training programmes. After having clicked on the message published on social media or having downloaded one of these applications and entered their contact details in the form, victims generally receive a call from the fraudsters, who make a very specific investment offer (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p>Based on the notifications received between May 2019 and December 2021, victims of such fraudulent platforms already appear to have lost at least <strong>50.5&nbsp;million euros</strong> (of which <strong>25.5&nbsp;million</strong> were in 2021). This number is purely indicative, since not all victims contact the FSMA or they do not always tell us the amount they have lost.</p>

<h3><strong>Actions against fraud</strong></h3>

<p>The FSMA conducted several targeted campaigns in 2021 to raise consumers’ awareness of the risk of fraud.</p>

<ol>
 <li><strong>Launch of a video campaign to raise awareness of online fraud</strong></li>
</ol>

<p>In order to extend its efforts to raise even more people’s awareness of <strong>investment and credit fraud</strong>, the FSMA put out 10 animated videos and video testimonials. The purpose of these films is twofold: to make the public aware of the existence of this type of fraud, and to inform them about the most common investment and credit fraud mechanisms and the steps that victims of such fraud can take. The videos are available on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud">the FSMA website</a>.</p>

<ol>
 <li><strong>Launch of a digital campaign on Facebook, Instagram and Google</strong></li>
</ol>

<p>During&nbsp;<a href="https://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">World Investor Week 2021</a>&nbsp;(a thematic week organized by IOSCO in October 2021, the FSMA launched a new digital campaign against investment and credit fraud on Facebook, Instagram and Google. The Facebook and Instagram posts and Google Display ads in the October 2021 campaign were viewed nearly 22 million times. The visuals proved very effective. Among those who saw the campaign, 182,089 clicked one of the posts and were transferred to the FSMA site.</p>

<ol>
 <li><strong>Publication of warnings against 156 companies working unlawfully in Belgium</strong></li>
</ol>

<p>Of the 156 warnings published by the FSMA in 2021, 75 – that is, 48 per cent – were specifically against fraudulent trading platforms. Parallel to these, 3 thematic warnings were published to raise public awareness of the topic of theft of banks’ identity and the theft of the name and logo of the FSMA itself.</p>

<ol>
 <li><strong>Reports to the judicial authorities and blocking access to fraudulent website</strong></li>
</ol>

<p>A growing number of consumers are contacting the FSMA preventively as soon as they have the least suspicion. Thanks to these efforts, the FSMA can intervene and inform the judicial authorities more quickly.&nbsp;The Belgian judicial authorities were thus able, at the FSMA’s request, to block access from Belgium to 128 websites with fraudulent offers.</p>

<h3><strong>Recommendations if you have any suspicions that an offer being made to you is fraudulent.</strong></h3>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Contact&nbsp;the FSMA&nbsp;directly </strong>via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud"><strong>FSMA website</strong></a>&nbsp;and find out how to recognize and avoid fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Lastly, take the</strong> <strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud">test</a></strong> on the FSMA website to find out if the offer you have received may be fraudulent.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-02-15T00:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">183085</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies new fraudulent online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market. </strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use <strong>mobile applications </strong>to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money. They also make promises of repayment in exchange for one last money transfer. This is a technique to collect even more money from their victims.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li><strong>simply</strong> <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>24xFOREX </strong>(www.24xforex.com)</li>
 <li><strong>4x-Trade</strong> (www.4x-trade.net and www.4x-trade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Advantium Limited</strong> (www.advantiumlimited.com)&nbsp;<strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>AlfaPrime-Markets</strong> (www.alfaprime-markets.com and https://www.alfaprime-markets.net/)</li>
 <li><strong>AssetShot</strong> (www.assetshot.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Bitreserve</strong> (www.bitreserve.cc) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>BrownFinance </strong>(www.b-finances.com, www.a-bfinances.com, www.abfinances.com en www.brownsfinances.com)</li>
 <li><strong>BTC-Markets</strong> (www.btc-markets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Capital Of Focus</strong> (www.capitaloffocus.com)</li>
 <li><strong>CoinsBanking </strong>(www.coinsbanking.com)</li>
 <li><strong>CRPmarkets</strong> (www.crpmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>FinoTrend </strong>(www.finotrend.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Fortexo</strong> (www.fortexo.co)</li>
 <li><strong>FundsProMax</strong> (www.fundspromax.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Holding Partners</strong> (www.holding-partners.com)</li>
 <li><strong>IGC Markets</strong> (www.igcmarkets.com) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Impressive Area</strong> (www.impressivearea.com)</li>
 <li><strong>InGoInvest </strong>(www.ingoinvest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Invesdo </strong>(www.invesdo.io) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Kiplar </strong>(www.fr.kiplar.com and www.kiplar.org)</li>
 <li><strong>Kirther Investment</strong> (www.kirtherinvestments.com and wwww.kirtherinvestment.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ladson Capital</strong> (www.ladson-capital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Liquidspro</strong> (www.liquidspro.com)</li>
 <li><strong><span lang="NL-BE">Lite Gap</span></strong><span lang="NL-BE"> (www.litegap.com)</span></li>
 <li><strong>Livetradingfx</strong> (www.livetradingfx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Luxury Capitals</strong> (www.luxury-capitals.com and www.luxurycapitals.com)</li>
 <li><strong>MarketsEU </strong>(www.marketseu.com and www.marketseufx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Marketsi </strong>(www.marketsi.co.uk) <strong>(cloned firm)</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Ozon F Corporation</strong> (www.ozonfcorporation.bond)</li>
 <li><strong>Pegasus Invest</strong> (www.pegasus-invest.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Sagatrade</strong> (www.sagatrade.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Selfkings </strong>(www.sellfkings.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Status Markets </strong>(www.statusmarkets.com and www.status-mark.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Sterlingspecialist</strong> (www.sterlingspecialist.com)</li>
 <li><strong>SwissMarket(s)fx </strong>(www.swissmarketfx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>The Investment Center</strong> (www.investmentcenter.co.uk and www.investmentcenter.com)</li>
 <li><strong>TradingFX Global</strong> (www.tradingfxglobal.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Vnsmart </strong>(www.vnsmart.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:</p>

<p><strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Chairmanship of the EURIBOR college</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairmanship-euribor-college</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Public statement</strong></p>

<p>On 27 January 2022, the FSMA formally handed over its chairmanship of the supervisory EURIBOR college to ESMA, being the new competent authority of the administrator of EURIBOR.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Over the last few years, the FSMA took its role in protecting financial consumers seriously. The FSMA took up the role as observer in a task force consisting of EMMI and EURIBOR panel banks to provide guidance on how a BMR-compliant benchmark could look like. This task force resulted in the development of a BMR-compliant hybrid methodology anchored to the largest extent possible in transactions.</p>

<p>In addition, the FSMA granted on 2 July 2019, following a positive advice of the EURIBOR supervisory college, the European Money Markets Institute (EMMI) the authorisation as a benchmark administrator. This decision was made after the FSMA closely followed up the transition from a quote-based to a hybrid methodology and analyzed the authorisation file with great scrutiny.</p>

<p>As a consequence, users can continue to use EUBIBOR as it is deemed a robust and representative benchmark. The FSMA is proud to hand over to ESMA the supervision of a benchmark that is now more robust and representative, and with less potential for manipulation, compared to several years ago.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-01-31T13:42:37+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">181865</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Rules on sustainable finance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/rules-sustainable-finance</link>
  <description>
<p>New European rules on sustainable finance have been in the making since 2019. They are gradually coming into force. The FSMA wishes to draw the attention of credit institutions, management companies and investment firms to the sustainability rules that are or will be applicable to them. It has drawn up a document (available in French and Dutch only) outlining these rules in brief. It is the responsibility of the companies to conduct their own in-depth analysis of the rules in order to ascertain their precise impact on their activities.</p>

<p>Read more in our communication on rules on sustainable finance ...(available in French - Dutch only)</p>

<br>

<item>
  <title>Have you received an attractive credit proposal? Watch out for scams</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-received-attractive-credit-proposal-watch-out-scams</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credit to consumers.</strong></p>

<p>In recent months, the FSMA has identified <strong>36 fraudulent lenders</strong> who offer false credit to Belgian consumers via the Internet. Consumers get in touch with these lenders in a variety of ways: they are <strong>approached unsolicited</strong> via email or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, etc.), or they find advertisements on the <strong>internet</strong>.</p>

<p>However, in reality, these are <strong>false offers of credit</strong> made in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be authorized lenders or credit intermediaries and they do not shy away from using the names of authorized entities. These are cases of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/cloned-firms-theft-identity-authorized-companies"><strong>cloned firms</strong></a><strong>.</strong></p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers credit at very <strong>attractive conditions</strong>. For example, a lender claims to extend substantial loans at a low interest rate. The lender may also claim not to check whether the consumer is a poor payer and has taken out loans in the past that he/she was unable to repay.</p>

<p>If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain <strong>payments</strong> supposedly to cover<strong> costs</strong> relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly <strong>impossible to recover the amounts paid</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit</strong>.</p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Allright Company </strong>(https://allright-company.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BDPM </strong>(https://bdpm-group-bank.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Best Lening </strong>(https://best-lening.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BPI krediet </strong>(https://bpikrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Carrefourdupret </strong>(https://www.carrefourdupret.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>CEFIPRO </strong>(https://www.cefipro-kredietfinanciering.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Credit Conso Cash </strong>(https://credit-conso-cash.com/nl)</li>
 <li><strong>Eight88 Griffins </strong>(https://888griffins.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Euno-Krediet </strong>(https://euno-kredit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Fiata-Geld </strong>(https://www.fiata-geld.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financial Credit Union </strong>(https://financial-credit-union.be/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financiele hulp </strong>(https://financielehulp.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financiële oplossing </strong>(http://financiele-oplossing.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financiering services </strong>(https://financieringservices.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Finev Financial </strong>(https://finev-financial.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>G-lenen </strong>(https://g-lenen.nl/)</li>
 <li><strong>Geld Finanz </strong>(https://www.geld-finanz.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Global Services Agency &amp; Financiën </strong>(https://global-financien.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Halderen Lening </strong>(www.halderen-lening.com)</li>
 <li><strong>HosmyaInvest </strong>(https://hosmyainvest.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Illimity Service Krediet </strong>(https://illimity-servicekrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Joy Service </strong>(https://joy-service.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Kovack Finance </strong>(https://kovack-finance.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Magda Ruppe </strong>(www.magdaruppe.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Maxi-Financiën </strong>(https://maxi-financien.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Mijn snelle tegoed </strong>(https://mijn-snelle-tegoed.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Oplosing Finance </strong>(https://oplosing-finance.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Privat-Kreditering </strong>(https://privatkreditering.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snel Krediet </strong>(https://snel-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snel Krediet Financien </strong>(https://snelkrediet-financien.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snel Kredieten </strong>(https://snel-kredieten.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snelle Geld Lening </strong>(http://snelservicekrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Spainco Commercialbank </strong>(https://spaincocommercialbank.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Ultima Diensten </strong>(https://ultima-diensten.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Vandaag Geldlening </strong>(https://vandaag-geldlening.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Vitalfinanzen </strong>(https://www.vital-finanzen.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The FSMA offers the following <strong>general recommendations</strong> for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Be wary if (out of the blue) you receive an <strong>unsolicited credit offer</strong> via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on unusually favourable terms</strong> (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you first pay a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan.</strong> The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Find out whether the lender has the requisite authorization.</strong> Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a> on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a><strong>.</strong> As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-01-20T09:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">181272</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Handbook for IORPs on the implementation of the IORP II Directive</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/handbook-iorps-implementation-iorp-ii-directive</link>
  <description>
<p>The IORP II Directive requires supervisory authorities to base their supervision on a forward-looking, risk-based approach and to communicate transparently on this subject by publishing the text of laws, regulations and administrative provisions as well as their general supervisory guidelines. EIOPA itself has published a series of opinions on the subject.</p>

<p>In this context, the FSMA has published on its website a handbook on the implementation of the IORP II Directive and EIOPA's opinions on governance and risk management.</p>

<p>In this handbook, the FSMA sets out its <strong>expectations</strong> regarding the implementation of the governance rules. In addition, the FSMA presents a number of <strong>examples of good practice</strong>.</p>

<p>The text is partly based on the draft circular on governance, for which the FSMA organized an open consultation in 2019. In redrafting the text, the FSMA took into account what it considered to be relevant comments and suggestions from that consultation exercise.</p>

<p>The handbook pays particular attention to <strong>risk management</strong>. It lists the risks that an institution for occupational retirement provision (IORP) may face. In addition, the handbook gives examples of tools and methods that an IORP can use to assess and manage the identified risks and report on these. Finally, the ORA (own risk assessment) exercise that IORPs must perform at least every three years is discussed in detail.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the Handbook FSMA_2022_01 ...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/fsma_2022_01_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/fsma_2022_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-01-19T09:12:15+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">181321</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Reporting on continuing education becomes easier</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-reporting-continuing-education-becomes-easier</link>
  <description>
<p>In the past, intermediaries and credit providers were required to enter each individual continuing education credit in the CABRIO online application. This coding requirement applied to everyone subject to the obligation to engage in continuing education.</p>

<p>As previously announced, the FSMA has simplified this practice considerably. From now on, continuing education credits no longer have to be coded individually. This means less administrative work for intermediaries and credit providers.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/2022-01-14_newsletter_obligation_recyclage_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/2022-01-14_newsletter_bijscholingsversplichting_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-01-14T09:37:14+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">176979</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Newsletter: harmonisation of the conditions for registration and maintaining registration in the various financial intermediation registers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-harmonisation-conditions-registration-and-maintaining-registration-various</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA aims at maximum harmonisation of the conditions for the registration and the pursuit of financial intermediation activities, particularly insurance distribution, credit intermediation (in consumer and mortgage credit) and intermediation in banking and investment services.</p>

<p>Thus, the FSMA’s objective is to simplify and clarify the administrative and regulatory obligations for financial intermediaries.</p>

<p>To this end, the Royal Decree of 12 December 2021 introduced a number of changes to the status of intermediaries in banking and investment services and of credit intermediaries.</p>

<p>These changes are in line with the changes introduced for insurance intermediaries, transposing the IDD Directive. They mainly concern:</p>

<ul>
 <li>the introduction of a 'trainee CFE' status for all intermediaries;</li>
 <li>the introduction of the status of 'trainee insurance sub-agent';</li>
 <li>the granting of certain derogations with regard to professional expertise;</li>
 <li>an update of the requirements regarding continuing education;</li>
</ul>

<p>Further harmonisation may be carried out at a later stage.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our Newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/2022-01-07_newsletter_kbharmonisatie_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2022-01/2022-01-07_newsletter_kbharmonisatie_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2022-01-11T11:24:51+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">180719</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Continuing professional training in 2021 for accredited statutory auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/continuing-professional-training-2021-accredited-statutory-auditors</link>
  <description>
<p>The continuing professional training programme for 2021 will be offered ‘remotely’ in the form of webinars and will be spread over two sessions, of about an hour and a half each (not including the Q&amp;A session):</p>

<ul>
 <li>Thursday, 9 December 2021 from 1 – 3 pm: training session for undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment, and regulated real estate companies;</li>
 <li>Thursday, 16 December 2021 from 2 – 4 pm: training session for institutions for occupational retirement provision.</li>
</ul>

<p>Register for this continuing professional training by returning the attached form by <a href="mailto:policy@fsma.be?subject=Continuing%20professional%20training%20in%202021%20for%20accredited%20statutory%20auditors"><strong>email</strong></a>&nbsp;<strong>at the latest by</strong> <strong>3 December&nbsp;2021</strong>. Registration is free of charge.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>For additional information, see the Communication (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-11/fsma_2021_18_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-11/fsma_2021_18_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</p>
</div>

<item>
  <title>Colloquium on new challenges in financial regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/colloquium-new-challenges-financial-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On Friday, 19 November 2021, the Chairman of the FSMA and Vice-Chairman of IOSCO, Mr Jean-Paul Servais, spoke at a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-11/20211119_colloque_nouveaux_enjeux_regulation_financiere.pdf">colloquium</a> held at the Sorbonne University in Paris.</strong></p>

<p>The event was organized by the LabEx ReFi, a multidisciplinary research laboratory dedicated to the study and evaluation of regulatory policies. The objective of the laboratory is to improve understanding of the functioning and regulation of financial systems.</p>

<p>The first part of the colloquium focused on digital assets. In the second part, a round table was held. On that occasion, various speakers addressed some of the major challenges in the field of financial regulation. The Chairman of the FSMA shared his vision of several important topics for the years to come, such as digital developments and progress in the field of sustainability, as well as methods for evaluating an appropriate supervisory framework for various players within the financial sector.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-11-19T17:30:41+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">178663</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies new fraudulent online trading platforms</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-new-fraudulent-online-trading-platforms</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a (well-known) person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use <strong>mobile applications </strong>to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li><strong>simply</strong> <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Binarycent</strong> (www.binarycent.com)</li>
 <li><strong>BTC-chain</strong> (www.btc-chain.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Clever Trade</strong> (www.clever-trade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Crypto Trading Association</strong> (www.cta-capitals.com and www.cta-capital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>FiniVieX</strong> (www.finiviex.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finomarkets</strong> (www.finomarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Genesis11</strong> (www.genesis11.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Global Trading26</strong> (www.globaltrading26.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Gs4trade</strong> (www.gs4trade.com and www.gs-4trade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>KapitalEU</strong> (www.kapitaleu.com)</li>
 <li><strong>LPLFinances</strong> (www.lplfinances.com and www.lplfinances.eu)</li>
 <li><strong>NitroCapitals</strong> (www.nitrocapitals.com)</li>
 <li><strong>OrbitGTM </strong>(www.orbitgt-m.com and www.orbitgtm-pro.net, https://orbitgtm-lite.com/ en https://trade.orbitgtm-lite.com/login)</li>
 <li><strong>Sunton Capital</strong> (www.suntonfx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Uptrade</strong> (www.uptrademarket.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Ventera Group</strong> (www.venteragroup.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Winbitx</strong> (www.winbitx.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:</p>

<p><strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website. Also watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-11-15T09:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">177951</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA Chairman welcomes the new International Sustainability Standards Board</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-chairman-welcomes-new-international-sustainability-standards-board</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The establishment of the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) was announced on the occasion of the climate change conference in Glasgow. The ISSB will develop international standards to be applied by issuers in climate- or other sustainability-related reporting. In his capacity as chair of the <span>IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board</span>, Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA, will take part in supervising the ISSB and welcomes its establishment.</strong></p>

<p>The Monitoring Board ensures the proper functioning of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) operates under the umbrella of that not-for-profit organization. The IASB sets the IFRS standards. The latter are international accounting rules governing the preparation of annual reports and financial statements. On the occasion of the climate conference in Glasgow, the IFRS Foundation announced the formation of a new organization under its auspices: the ISSB. The mission of the new Board is to develop standards for sustainability-related reporting.</p>

<p>Sustainability, in its various aspects, is of growing importance when it comes to company valuation. Therefore, the financial markets are increasingly calling for more uniform reporting about its impact. This includes the financial impact of climate change on a company. The standards that the ISSB will develop are intended to serve as the basis for such reporting.</p>

<p>For purposes of developing these standards, the ISSB will work with the IASB to ensure compatibility with existing accounting standards. Like the IASB, the ISSB will develop standards independently and in accordance with robust procedures, and will also be accountable to the IFRS Foundation Board of Trustees. The latter is, in turn, overseen by the Monitoring Board, made up of representatives of various leading market regulators and public authorities.</p>

<p>The chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, is also chair of the Monitoring Board. In that capacity and as vice chair of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), he welcomes the formation of the ISSB:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>“<em>Corporate reporting, supported by high-quality internationally accepted standards continues to be essential for efficient, fair and transparent financial markets. That is why I welcome the establishment of the ISSB and the cooperation of existing organizations on sustainability reporting within the ISSB, thereby responding to the demand for a single, worldwide basis for reporting on sustainability-related matters. The Monitoring Board stands ready to extend its mandate to the ISSB with a view to ensuring that its sustainability-related standards are guaranteed to be of the same high quality as the IFRS accounting standards.”</em></p>
</blockquote>

<p>For more information:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="https://www.iosco.org/about/monitoring_board/pdf/Press-20211103-1.pdf">Monitoring Board press release</a></li>
 <li><a href="https://www.ifrs.org/news-and-events/news/2021/11/ifrs-foundation-announces-issb-consolidation-with-cdsb-vrf-publication-of-prototypes/">IFRS Foundation press release</a></li>
 <li><a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS625.pdf">International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) press release</a></li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-11-03T12:18:08+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">177832</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Sector report – Inspections of the independence of the actuarial function at IORPs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/sector-report-inspections-independence-actuarial-function-iorps</link>
  <description>
<p>An IORP must enable the key function holders and any of their staff to fulfil their tasks in an objective, honest and independent manner.</p>

<p>In order to examine whether this legal obligation is complied with in practice, the FSMA has conducted an inspection campaign. The inspections were directed at examining the independence of the actuarial function, although this issue may also arise in other key functions.</p>

<p>The FSMA has included the findings of this inspection campaign in an overall <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-10/2021-10-12_sectorverslag_nl.pdf">sector report</a>. The FSMA also provides more information in that report about what qualifies as a conflict of interest in the context of exercising the actuarial function and of other activities by the person/persons who fulfil the actuarial function. Moreover, the FSMA sets out a number of good practices and points for improvement.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-28T10:00:25+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">177363</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Watch out for investment fraud through dating apps</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-investment-fraud-through-dating-apps</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against investment fraud starting on dating apps and websites.</strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>In recent months, the FSMA has received an increasing number of notifications regarding fraudulent online trading platforms using dating apps and websites (Tinder, Facebook Dating, etc.) to contact Belgian consumers.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Fraudsters contact consumers through <strong>fake profiles</strong> picturing wealthy people looking for a partner. Soon thereafter, the fraudsters behind these profiles ask to get in touch on another app, such as WhatsApp. The discussion quickly turns to the subject of money. The fraudsters flaunt their supposed wealth and share their secret to getting rich quickly and without risk: <strong>online trading platforms</strong>. They encourage their victims to use one particular platform. However, these platforms <strong>do not have an authorization</strong> to offer investment products in Belgium.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><strong>Most consumers are suspicious at first. </strong>The fraudsters therefore engage in conversation during several weeks in order to gain their trust and to develop a fictitious relationship. The fraudsters do not hesitate to take advantage of the feelings that the victim is feeling towards the fake profile.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>To try to prove that their system is risk-free, the scammers often put the victims in touch with a so-called financial expert, who advises them on their investment strategy.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Most victims start by investing small amounts. These small investments are always profitable. Moreover, if a victim who begins to suspect something attempts to withdraw a small amount of money in order to verify whether the platform is trustworthy, the withdrawal is carried out without impediment.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Through <strong>snowball effect</strong>, the victims are gradually urged to pay more and more money, only to lose their savings, and sometimes even go into debt. Consumers who invest in these firms never recover their investment. Therefore, such activities constitute a case of<strong> investment fraud</strong>.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><strong>A consumer tells us:</strong></span></span></span></span></p>

<h5><span><span><span><span>‘<em>I met C. on a dating website. After a few days chatting, C. mentioned an app that she was using for trading. Following the advice of her financial expert uncle, she said she had managed to build herself a small fortune. C. offered to send me her uncle’s tips. At first, I was not interested, and a bit suspicious. However, she kept on praising the platform. Their website looked very professional and I even found reviews by other users, unanimously positive. I first tried it in demo mode (making fictitious investments), and as everything turned out to be highly lucrative, I started by investing EUR 1&nbsp;200. My profits increased and I put more and more money in. Since then, it has turned out to be impossible to withdraw my money, even after paying all their alleged fees and taxes. In total, I have lost more than EUR 45 000.</em>’</span></span></span></span></h5>

<p><span><span><span>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following:</span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Forex 7xt+0 </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>(https://web.ftasjh.com/)</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Garafi</span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>&nbsp;(</span>https://garafi.com/)</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>Insun Forex</span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>&nbsp;(http://tradeinsun.com/)</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>MWNG Company Limited</span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>&nbsp;( https://mwngglobal.com/mwng_en/index.htm)</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>XT.com</span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span>&nbsp;(https://www.xt.com/) </span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span><span>***</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-US"><span>In order to avoid fraud</span></span></strong><span lang="EN-US"><span>, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:&nbsp;<strong><span>Always check the identity</span></strong>&nbsp;(company name, home country, registered office, etc.)&nbsp;<strong><span>of the company</span></strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-US"><span>Always verify if the company in question has the requisite authorization</span></span></strong><span lang="EN-US"><span>. To this end, an easy&nbsp;</span></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span lang="EN-US"><span>search</span></span></a>&nbsp;<span lang="EN-US"><span>on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do.<strong><span>&nbsp;Important!</span></strong>&nbsp;Always beware of ‘<strong><span>cloned firms</span></strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;</span></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><span lang="EN-US"><span>consumer contact form</span></span></a><span lang="EN-US"><span>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span>***</span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, please consult the ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud</a>’ page on the FSMA website.</span></span></span></span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-27T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">176983</guid>
    </item>
