<item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies 27 new websites of fraudulent lenders</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-27-new-websites-fraudulent-lenders</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><strong><span lang="EN-US"><span>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credits to consumers.</span></span></strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The FSMA continues its investigation into fraudulent credit websites and manages to track down <strong>27&nbsp;websites of fraudulent lenders</strong>.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The scam remains the same. Consumers get thus in touch with these providers in a variety of ways: they are approached unsolicited via mail or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, …), or they find advertisements on the internet. On social networks, profiles are also sometimes hacked to promote fake credits.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>However, in reality, these are&nbsp;<strong>false credits offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers</strong>. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions and they do not shy away from using the names of authorized entities. These are cases of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22959">cloned firms</a>.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>These fraudsters offer consumers credits&nbsp;<strong>at very attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain&nbsp;<strong>payments</strong>&nbsp;supposedly to cover costs relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly&nbsp;<strong>impossible to recover the amounts paid</strong>.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</span></span></span></p>

<ol>
 <li><strong>Atlantix - Krediet</strong> (https://www.atlantixkrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Atlantix krediet</strong> (https://www.atlantix-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Bank Krediet online</strong> (https://bankkredietonline.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Credo Credit</strong> (https://www.credo-credit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Emie-Kredit-Finance</strong> (https://emie-kredit-finance.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Fia Serv</strong> (https://fia-services.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Finances Pour Tous</strong> (https://finances-pourtous.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Financiele Vereniging</strong> ( https://financiele-vereniging.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Gerdo Leningen</strong> (https://gerdo-leningen.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Global Kredit</strong> (https://global-kredit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Henver Finance</strong> (https://henverfinance.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Ideale Financiele</strong> (https://ideale-financiele.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>International Service Credit</strong> (https://international-service-credit.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Krediet diensten</strong> (https://kredietdiensten.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Krediet Investeringsbank</strong> (https://krediet-investeringsbank.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Krediet Service</strong> (https://krediet-service.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Legal Finance Global</strong> (https://legalfinanceglobal.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Leningdienst</strong> (https://leningdienst.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Lening Euro Beleggingsfond</strong> (https://lening-euro-beleggingsfond.site123.me/)</li>
 <li><strong>Lening Persoonlijke</strong> (https://leningpersoonlijke.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Mutuo Financin</strong> (https://mf-groep.be/)</li>
 <li><strong>Molio-Krediet</strong> (https://molio-krediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Mutuel Krediet</strong> (https://mutuelkrediet.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Service Financial Euro</strong> (https://service-financial-euro.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snelle Geldlening</strong> (https://snellegeldlening.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snelle-Lening Group.com</strong> (https://snelle-leninggroup.com/)</li>
 <li><span><span><span><strong>Union Credit</strong> (https://union-credit-service.com/)</span></span></span></li>
</ol>

<p><span><span><span>The FSMA offers the following general recommendations for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><span><span>Before anything else, find out whether the lender has the requisite&nbsp;<strong>authorization</strong>. Via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration.&nbsp;<strong>Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit</strong>.</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span>Be&nbsp;<strong>wary if you receive an unsolicited</strong>&nbsp;credit offer via the internet or via social media.</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span>Beware of&nbsp;<strong>any offers of credit on unusually</strong>&nbsp;favourable terms (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you&nbsp;<strong>first pay a sum of money</strong>&nbsp;intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan. The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</span></span></span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span>Consider doing&nbsp;<strong>a search</strong>&nbsp;for the person using the customary search engines. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</span></span></span></p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>End of the World Investor Week 2021</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week-2021</link>
  <description>
<p>The fifth edition of World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held from 4 to 10 October 2021. The aim of this week was to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</p>

<p>This year’s World Investor Week focused in particular on online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to. Other topics, such as sustainable finance, Initial Coin Offerings and digital assets, were also featured. This thematic week offered one more opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p>

<p>As vice-chair of IOSCO and member of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again supported this initiative. The FSMA is currently conducting an important campaign via social media to raise awareness of investment fraud perpetrated online. It posts fraud awareness videos as well as testimonials from victims of scams such as credit fraud or fraudulent online trading platforms. With this campaign, the FSMA intends to be present on the favorite hunting ground of fraudsters, that mostly carry out their illegal activities on social media, and to thereby help consumers avoid the traps set by scammers.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-11T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">176432</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Feedback statement on the information provided by a pension institution through the pension information sheet</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/feedback-statement-information-provided-pension-institution-through-pension-information-sheet</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has carried out a study to assess the quality of the pension information sheets linked to a VAPZ/PLCI agreement (voluntary supplementary pension for self-employed persons). In addition to checking that the pension institutions were complying with all relevant legal provisions, the FSMA also sought to identify a number of good and bad practices in order to share them with the sector.</p>

<p>The study focused on the pension information sheets relating to the stage of pension rights on 1 January 2018. A sample of 188 pension information sheets was examined. However, many of the pension information sheets in the sample turned out to be based on identical standard models used by the pension institutions. Therefore, it was decided to include only one example of the identical models in the results of the survey. Thus, the final report on the study contains conclusions based on <strong>51 'unique' model pension information sheets</strong>. These sheets were spread over <strong>18 insurance companies</strong> and <strong>3 IORPs</strong>.</p>

<p>The <strong>report </strong>(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-10/fsma_2021_17-01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)<strong>&nbsp;</strong>outlines the main findings, as well as all the obligations and recommendations set out by the FSMA in connection with its study. The findings, obligations and recommendations are placed in a broader context. This report is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our Communication FSMA_2021_17 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-10/fsma_2021_17_fr_0.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-10/fsma_2021_17_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)...</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-05T10:12:41+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">176734</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>60% increase in reports of fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/60-increase-reports-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the first half of 2021, <strong>the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received 1,087 questions and reports by consumers concerning fraud and unlawful offers of financial products and services. This represents an increase of 60% as compared to the first half of 2020. The FSMA wishes to further raise public awareness of the risk of investment and credit fraud. To this end, a new digital campaign has just been launched. The campaign is being conducted entirely online, as was the case with the campaigns launched in 2020. The aim is to post on Facebook, Instagram and Google a series of awareness-raising videos created by the FSMA for various target groups. </strong></strong></p>

<p>Out of <strong>1,087</strong> reports or questions the FSMA received from consumers in the first half of 2021, around <strong>40%</strong> were about fraudulent online trading platform, <strong>30%</strong> about various types of fraud (fraudulent offers of portfolio management, fraudulent alternative investments or pyramid schemes) and <strong>10%</strong> about credit fraud.</p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p><strong><strong>Unlawful offers of financial products and services </strong><strong>in the first half of 2021</strong></strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong><strong>Number of reports received in the first half of 2021</strong></strong></p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p><strong>Changes compared to the first half of 2020</strong></p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Fraudulent online trading platforms</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>404</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>+116%</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Credit fraud</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>105</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>-10%</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Fraudulent offers of portfolio management, alternative investments or pyramid schemes</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>317</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>+80%</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Cryptocurrencies</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>88</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>+54%</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p>Boiler room&nbsp;</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>34</p>
   </td>
   <td>
   <p>-30%</p>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

<p>The number of fraudulent online platforms that offer trading in binary options, CFDs or forex as well as cryptocurrencies continues to grow. One of the characteristics of such platforms is that they attract consumers via fake advertisements on social media. The advertisements use the photos (unbeknownst to them) of <span lang="GSW-FR">Flemish and French-speaking celebrities.</span></p>

<div>
<div>
<div>
<p>For the past few months, we have seen such fraudulent platforms use mobile applications&nbsp;as well to lure victims.&nbsp;These apps often make offers relating to virtual currencies or training. Shortly after clicking on an advertisement placed on social media or downloading one of these apps and entering their contact details on a form, the victims usually receive a phone call from the fraudsters, who make a specific investment offer (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.). For more information: see <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-6">the warning of 5 May 2021</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>The swindlers also promote these fraudulent platforms via dating sites and applications such as Tinder.</p>

<p><span>The FSMA estimates that victims of fraudulent online trading platforms lost <strong>at least 42 million euros</strong> between May 2019 and June 2021.<span>&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>The increase in the number of reports or questions about cryptocurrencies can be explained by the significant number of questions about the reliability of service providers offering virtual currencies and more generally about the topic of virtual currencies.</p>

<p>The number of reports of fraud linked specifically to virtual currencies has thus remained constant as compared to the first half of 2020. In fact, the FSMA received <strong>53</strong> reports from consumers on this topic in the first half of 2021 as compared to <strong>48</strong> in the first half of 2020.</p>

<p>The number of warnings published by the FSMA is increasing. During the first half of 2021, the FSMA published warnings about <strong>89</strong> companies engaged in unlawful activity in Belgium. This is a <strong>46%</strong> increase over the number of warnings published in the first half of 2020.</p>

<h2><strong><strong>Launch of a new digital campaign on Facebook, Instagram and Google</strong></strong></h2>

<p>The significant increase in the number of reports by consumers coincides with the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-video-campaign-raise-publics-awareness-online-fraud">awareness-raising campaigns</a> launched&nbsp; by the FSMA in 2020 and in the first half of 2021, such as the various digital campaigns, the updating of the FSMA website, the launch of the “Have I been the victim of fraud?” test, the posting of animated videos and of testimonials, etc.</p>

<p>The various campaigns conducted by the FSMA have helped raise consumer awareness of the risk of fraud. More and more victims know they should automatically alert the FSMA if they realise they have been defrauded of their money. Consumers are also increasingly contacting the FSMA before investing, whenever they have any suspicions that the offer they have received may be fraudulent.</p>

<p>During <a href="https://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">World Investor Week 2021</a>&nbsp;(a thematic week organized by IOSCO), the FSMA will be launching a new digital campaign on Facebook, Instagram and Google against investment and credit fraud. &nbsp;</p>

<p>The aim of this campaign is to continue raise public awareness by disseminating <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-campaign-against-online-investment-fraud">videos created by the FSMA</a> among 3 target groups: pensioners (60+), young investors (26-39) and more experienced investors (40-59).</p>

<h2>3 recommendations if you have any suspicions that the offer you have received may be fraudulent</h2>

<ul>
 <li><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether the financial services being offered to you are lawful, <strong>contact the FSMA</strong> directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</li>
 <li>Consult <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">the FSMA’s website</a> and find out how to recognize and avoid fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Lastly, take the&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/have-i-been-victim-fraud"><strong>test</strong></a>&nbsp;on the FSMA’s website to find out if the offer you have received may be fraudulent.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-04T08:16:06+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Launch of World Investor Week 2021</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/launch-world-investor-week-2021</link>
  <description>
<p>The fifth World Investor Week will take place from Monday 4 to Sunday 10 October 2021. It is organized by IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions. The aim of World Investor Week is to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas will be at the centre of attention.</p>

<p>This year’s World Investor Week focuses in particular on online investments and the different types of scams they are liable to. Other topics, such as sustainable finance, Initial Coin Offerings and digital assets, are also featured. This thematic week also offers one more opportunity to draw investors' attention to the basic principles of investing without taking undue risks.</p>

<p>As vice-chair of IOSCO and member of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again lends its support to this initiative. The FSMA will launch on Monday 4 October an important campaign via social media to raise awareness of investment fraud perpetrated online. It will post fraud awareness videos as well as testimonials from victims &nbsp;of scams such as credit fraud or fraudulent online trading platforms. With this campaign, the FSMA intends to be present on the favorite hunting ground of fraudsters, that mostly carry out their illegal activities on social media, and to thereby help consumers avoid the traps set by scammers.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-10-01T11:57:09+02:00</pubDate>

  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved on 22 June 2021 in accordance with Article 34, §1, of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU. <item>
  <title>The FSMA identifies 11 new websites of fraudulent lenders</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-identifies-11-new-websites-fraudulent-lenders</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credits to consumers.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA recently received a large number of notifications from consumers about fraudulent credit offers circulating on the internet. Since its last warning, the FSMA has received complaints about <strong>11 new fraudulent websites</strong>.</p>

<p>The scam remains the same. Consumers get thus in touch with these providers in a variety of ways: they are approached unsolicited via mail or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, …), or they find advertisements on the internet. On social networks, profiles are also sometimes hacked to promote fake credits.</p>

<p>However, in reality, these are <strong>false credits offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers</strong>. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions and they do not shy away from using the names of authorized entities. These are cases of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22959">cloned firms</a>.</p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers credits<strong> at very attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain <strong>payments </strong>supposedly to cover costs relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly<strong> impossible to recover the amounts paid</strong>.</p>

<p>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>BSBC Bank</strong> (https://bbk-inter.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Diamond Groupe</strong> (http://www.diamondgroupe.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Finance Fox / Finmove</strong> (https://nl.finance-fox.net/, https://www.nl.finmove.net/)</li>
 <li><strong>JP Krediet Express</strong> (https://jpkredietexpress.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Kredit Finance Bank </strong>(https://www.kfb-inter.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Mael Groups</strong> (https://maelgroups.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Sereniteit Service</strong> (https://sereniteit-service.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Snel Kapitaal </strong>(https://snelkapitaal.com/)&nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>Sobrimogeld</strong> (https://sobrimogeld.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>UFUK Group</strong> (http://ufuk-krediet.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>The FSMA offers the following general recommendations for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Before anything else, find out whether the lender has the requisite <strong>authorization</strong>. Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a> on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. <strong>Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit</strong>.</li>
 <li>Be<strong> wary if you receive an unsolicited</strong> credit offer via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li>Beware of <strong>any offers of credit on unusually</strong> favourable terms (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you <strong>first pay a sum of money</strong> intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan. The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li>Consider doing <strong>a search</strong> for the person using the customary search engines. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-08-27T10:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Watch out for companies that offer trading software (Expert Advisors)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-companies-offer-trading-software-expert-advisors-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is warning against Finiko, a company that offers so-called ‘Expert Advisors’ or ‘EAs’ used to trade in CFDs, forex and crypto-derivatives.</strong></p>

<p>An Expert Advisor is a type of software that tells you when to make certain trades or even carries them out for you automatically, based on preprogrammed parameters.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that ever more companies are distributing such Expert Advisors, including to Belgian consumers. This comes with risks.</p>

<p>First, these companies do not have an authorization to offer financial services and products in Belgium.</p>

<p>Moreover, the FSMA has found that such trading software often occurs via a pyramid structure. In general, these are referred to as ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing) schemes, in which consumers are incentivized to bring in new members. In exchange, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the software package.</p>

<p>Such MLM networks appear to be active on social media via countless (private) groups. It appears that these schemes mainly target young people. The message is that everyone can afford a luxurious lifestyle provided they bring in enough new members and make the appropriate investment in the software being promoted.</p>

<p>The FSMA also wishes to emphasize that distribution of certain financial instruments that are available via the software (such as CFDs, forex and crypto-derivatives) is prohibited in Belgium.</p>

<p><strong>Lastly, offers of CFDs and forex derivatives via the internet are very risky and open to fraud</strong>: anyone who invests in CFDs or forex derivatives runs the risk of losing the entire sum invested. <strong>The chance of loss is far greater than the chance of profit</strong>: surveys by other European supervisors among investors shows that at least 75% to 89% of the investments in derivative products, such as forex derivatives, are loss-makers! These products are appropriate only for those who really wish to speculate, are ready to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and are familiar with derivative financial products.<strong> There have also been many cases of fraud with these instruments</strong>. In a number of cases, it turned out that no actual transactions were ever made by the offeror.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>Based on the information available to the FSMA, the following website is offering these types of trading software in Belgium, in contravention of Belgian legislation:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Finiko (www.thefiniko.com)&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p>Have you received an offer of an investment and would like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud">Beware of fraud</a>’.</p>

<p>We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> via the search function on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-08-24T00:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>FAQ on the impact of the coronavirus crisis on supplementary pensions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/faq-impact-coronavirus-crisis-supplementary-pensions-1</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>In the light of the coronavirus crisis, the government has drawn up a number of special measures concerning supplementary pensions. These measures have been extended until 30 September 2021. You can find all the relevant information on this matter in the following FAQ section (available in&nbsp;</span></span></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/106061"><span lang="EN-US"><span>Dutch</span></span></a><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>&nbsp;and in&nbsp;</span></span></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/106061"><span lang="EN-US"><span>French</span></span></a><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>&nbsp;only).</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>The Chairman of the FSMA chairs network on SPACs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-chairs-network-spacs</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, has been appointed by IOSCO, the world organization of financial market regulators, to chair the network within IOSCO on SPACs.</strong></p>

<p>A SPAC or Special Purpose Acquisition Company is a listed vehicle without assets that seeks to merge with an unlisted company - allowing the latter to go public.</p>

<p>The network provides a platform for IOSCO members to monitor and discuss this phenomenon that has raised significant amounts of money over the past year.</p>

<p>During the first virtual meeting of the network held on July 26, 46 members of IOSCO exchanged their experiences on SPACs and discussed the relevant points of attention related to investor protection and market integrity.</p>

<p>The FSMA recently published its opinion on SPACs after a public consultation. ESMA has also published a communication on SPACs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Read also the <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS614.pdf"><span>press release</span></a> published by IOSCO.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-27T08:43:44+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172688</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Opinion on the suitability and appropriateness assessment regarding the services to be provided in case of usufruct</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/opinion-suitability-and-appropriateness-assessment-regarding-services-be-provided-case</link>
  <description>
<p>Regulated companies provide investment services to a range of clients. In some cases, ownership is split between usufruct and bare ownership. Often both the usufructuary and the bare owner are clients.</p>

<p>For the application of the rules of conduct, this poses a number of challenges. Who benefits from the investment service: the usufructuary or the bare owner? From whom should the company collect information for the suitability or appropriateness assessment? To whom does the information relate? The rules of conduct and the ESMA guidelines do not contain any specific guidance on this subject.</p>

<p>Read the FSMA opinion here (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/172249">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/172249">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-09T12:40:21+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172259</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: the FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-7</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent online trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market. To help understand how this type of fraud works, the FSMA has produced an animated film as well as a video with the testimony of a victim (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a> only) of this kind of fraud. The films are being disseminated as part of the FSMA’s <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-video-campaign-raise-publics-awareness-online-fraud">new campaign raising awareness of online fraud</a>.</strong></p>

<p>These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use <strong>mobile applications</strong> to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p><strong>These platforms act very aggressively</strong>. Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p>Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p>These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms propose a so-called "affiliate programme" to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/pyramid-schemes">pyramid scheme</a> or at any rate of a Ponzi scheme.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitengecko</strong> (www.bitengecko.com)</li>
 <li><strong>CryptoMatex</strong> (www.cryptomatex.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Deltamarket</strong> (www.deltamarket.net and www.delta-mark.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Eiro-group</strong> (www.eiro-group.com)&nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>EuroStandarte</strong> (www.eurostandarte.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finetero </strong>(www.finetero.com)</li>
 <li><strong>FXCT Investments</strong> (www.fxctinvestments.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Goldenrodfx </strong>(www.goldenrodfx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Kapitalfx </strong>(www.kapitalfx.de and www.kapitalfx.ch)</li>
 <li><strong>Profxmarket</strong> (www.profxmarket.eu) (<strong>cloned firm</strong>)</li>
 <li><strong>Riva financial systems</strong> (www.rivafinancialsystems.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Tradergy </strong>(www.tradergy.io)</li>
 <li><strong>TradeVtech</strong> (www.tradevtech.com)&nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>United asset finance limited</strong> (www.united-asset-finance.com) (<strong>cloned firm</strong>)</li>
</ul>

<p>***<br>
<strong>In order to avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors: <strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p><strong>Always verify if the company in question has the requisite authorization</strong>. To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do.<strong> Important!</strong> Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms</strong>’: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p>More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/how-recognize-and-avoid-fraud">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>

<p>Watch the new awareness campaign videos (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-08T00:42:46+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172117</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>La Franco-suédoise d’investissement (www.franco-suedoise-investissement.fr)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/la-franco-suedoise-dinvestissement-wwwfranco-suedoise-investissementfr</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the website named www.franco-suedoise-investissement.fr, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p>

<p>The Franco-suedoise-investissement.fr website is not authorized to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p>Moreover, the offers made via that website show <strong>numerous indications of fraud </strong>and seem to be similar to the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/fraudulent-offer-portfolio-management-and-alternative-investments-precious-metals-wines-etc">fraudulent offers of wealth management</a>.</p>

<p>The company uses the website site www.franco-suedoise-investissement.fr (currently inactive).</p>

<p><strong>On 2 June 2021, the French supervisor (<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/en/warnings/warnings-and-blacklists?key=la%20franco-su%C3%A9doise&amp;page=0">AMF</a>) had already warned the public about offers on that website.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA thus <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer</strong> of financial services made by that website and <strong>against transferring money</strong> to any account number it might mention.</p>

<h3 class="green"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary. </strong></h3>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt </strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form">consumer contact form</a>.</p>

<p>As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-01T12:52:52+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172083</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Call for candidates for the audit Public Interest Oversight Board </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/call-candidates-audit-public-interest-oversight-board</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span>The Monitoring Group selects new members of the Public Interest Oversight Board that oversees the quality of international auditing standards. </span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The Monitoring Group brings together a number of international institutions and financial regulators that represent the public interest in areas related to international auditing standards setting and audit quality.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>The FSMA Chairman, Jean-Paul Servais, in his capacity as co-chair of the Monitoring Group, encourages stakeholders to assist in the identification of high-quality candidates to apply.</span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li><span><span><a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS609.pdf">MG Press release</a> announcing the establishment of the MG NC and the publication of the open call for applications</span></span></li>
 <li><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><a href="https://www.iosco.org/about/monitoring_group/pdf/Call-for-Applications-Board-Member-of-the-Public-Interest-Oversight-Board-PIOB.pdf">Call for Applications for PIOB Board Member</a></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-01T11:42:54+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172093</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent offers of wealth management</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-offers-wealth-management</link>
  <description>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA)&nbsp;warns the public against the activities of two new companies that make fraudulent offers of wealth management. To help understand how this type of fraud works, the FSMA has produced an animated film as well as a video with the testimony of a victim (available in </strong></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>French</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB"><strong> or&nbsp;</strong></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Dutch</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB"><strong> only)&nbsp;of this kind of fraud. The films are being disseminated as part of the FSMA’s </strong></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-video-campaign-raise-publics-awareness-online-fraud"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>new campaign raising awareness of online fraud</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>.</strong></span></p><p>As part of such fraudulent offers of wealth management, the fraudsters contact you by phone, without having requested it or after you entered your contact details on an online form. A ‘specialist’ offers to manage your assets, promising interest rates that are much higher than market rates, and usually offering a capital guarantee. However, these offers are <strong>too good to be true</strong>. Be vigilant, since if you put your trust in these fraudsters, you will never get your money back!</p><p><span>In recent weeks, the FSMA has received alerts about two such companies:</span></p><ul><li><strong>ML-Capital (www.ml-capital.fr)</strong></li><li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/172083"><strong>La Franco-Suédoise d’investissement (www.franco-suedoise-investissement.fr</strong>)</a></li></ul><h3 class="green"><strong>How does the fraud scheme begin?</strong></h3><p><span lang="EN-GB">You may be approached <strong>after having expressed an interest in an advertisement </strong>dangling the promise of high interest rates published on social media or other websites. In the following days, you will receive a call from a telephone salesperson, who will offer to manage your assets. For more information, please see our warnings of</span> <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/be-wary-investment-offers-made-through-social-media"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>30 September 2019</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB">&nbsp;and of </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/be-cautious-social-media-scammers-use-all-sorts-tricks-circulate-their-fraudulent-offers"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>3 December 2020</strong></span></a><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB">You may also be contacted <strong>by phone without you having taken any initiative at all.</strong> This ‘cold calling’&nbsp;technique is widely used in investment fraud. You will then be invited to consult the website of their ‘company’ and open a personal account. Sometimes you are also offered a contract. Contacts will continue by email, phone, text message or via WhatsApp.</span></p><p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Be careful</strong>, don’t rely on the ‘professional’ appearance of the website to which you are referred; naturally, the fraudsters do everything to make their site seem as serious as possible.</span></p><h3 class="green"><strong>What are you being offered?</strong></h3><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Testimonies by consumers indicate that they are often offered <strong>wealth management contracts</strong>. In short, you entrust your money to your interlocutor, who will manage it for you, promising high returns that may even come with a guaranteed rate.</span></p><h3 class="green"><strong>How to avoid the trap?</strong></h3><p><span>The FSMA&nbsp;<strong>invites you to heed the following recommendations in order to avoid fraudulent schemes:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span><strong>Take the </strong></span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/beware-fraud"><span><strong>test</strong></span></a><span><strong>&nbsp;</strong>on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</span></li><li><span><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns. </strong>Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</span></li><li><span><strong>Don’t accept uncritically the information provided by these companies.</strong> It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</span></li><li><span><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization </strong></span><span lang="EN">by searching the lists published on the FSMA website </span><span>– </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span>Check your provider</span></a><span>. <strong>Be wary as well of ‘cloned firms’</strong>. The latter are companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</span></li><li><span><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website and on the sites of foreign supervisory authorities and of </span><a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal"><span>IOSCO</span></a><span>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the names of the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.</span></li></ul><p><span>On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><span>search function</span></a><span> provided. In addition, all the ‘companies’ about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium"><span>List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</span></a><span>, also published on the FSMA website.</span></p><p><span><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that no warning has been published about a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</span></p><ul><li><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls </strong>(<strong>cold calling</strong>), that is, calls where you have not taken any initiative prior to the call. These are often the first sign of fraud.</span></li><li><span><strong>Be wary of requests to pay money into accounts in countries that have nothing to do </strong>with the company that is approaching you or with your own place of residence.</span></li><li><span><strong>Never invest if you do not fully understand what is being offered.</strong></span></li><li><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Be all the more suspicious </strong>if the payout of returns is conditional on <strong>making an additional payment </strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</span></li></ul><p><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>If you have the least doubt </strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><span lang="EN-GB">consumer contact form</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">. As well, feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</span></p><h3 class="green"><span><strong>I’ve been the victim of fraud: what should I do?</strong></span></h3><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">If you think you have been the victim of fraud, make sure you <strong>do not make any more payments</strong>&nbsp;to your interlocutor.&nbsp;<strong>Note:</strong> this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used in order to try to obtain one last payment.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB"><strong>Contact</strong></span><span> </span><a href="https://www.police.be/en"><span lang="EN-GB">your local police</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">&nbsp;to make a complaint and <strong>report the scam to the FSMA</strong>&nbsp;via the </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/consumer-contact-form"><span lang="EN-GB">consumer contact form</span></a><span lang="EN-GB">.</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly</strong>&nbsp;and <strong>with&nbsp;ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;of your complaint (the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</span></p><p class="rtejustify"><span lang="EN-GB">Watch the new awareness campaign videos about fraudulent offers of wealth management (available in </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit"><span lang="EN-GB">French</span></a><span lang="EN-GB"> or </span><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude"><span lang="EN-GB">Dutch</span></a><span lang="EN-GB"> only).</span></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-07-01T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">172087</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Compliance with the obligation of continuing professional education and long-term medical leave</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-compliance-obligation-continuing-professional-education-and-long-term-medical-leave</link>
  <description>
<p>Since 1 January 2020, <strong>insurance and reinsurance intermediaries</strong>, their senior managers responsible for day-to-day management, their heads of distribution as well as insurance companies’ heads of distribution and public-facing staff (PCPs) must attend <strong>15 hours</strong> of continuing professional education annually.</p>

<p>The FSMA recently received various questions from the sector regarding the application of these rules to staff who are on long-term medical leave. <strong>The FSMA considers the continuing professional education obligation to be suspended if a person is 100% unfit for work over a period of at least 120 calendar days within one continuing education period.</strong></p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more about this in our newsletter... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/2021-06-30_newsletter_absence_fr_0.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/2021-06-30_newsletter_afwezigheid_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Fraudulent credit offers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-credit-offers-8</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credits to consumers. The FSMA also publishes two new videos (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a> only) to raise public awareness of this type of fraud.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has received several reports from consumers about fraudulent credit offers made via the internet. Consumers get thus in touch with these providers in a variety of ways: they are approached unsolicited via mail or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, …), or they find advertisements on the internet.</p>

<p>Fraudulent credit offers relate to <strong>false credits offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers</strong>. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions and they do not shy away from using the names or logos of authorized entities. These are cases of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22959">cloned firms</a>.</p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers credits <strong>at very attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain <strong>payments </strong>supposedly to cover costs relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly <strong>impossible to recover the amounts paid</strong>.</p>

<p>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>24Quest </strong>(https://twentyfourquest.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>BKR-Investbank</strong> (https://bkr-investbank.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Credit Horizon</strong> (https://credit-horizon.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Direct Golden Bank</strong> (https://www.direct-golden.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Successful Kredit</strong> (https://successful-krediet.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p>***<br>
 <br>
The FSMA offers the following general recommendations for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary if you receive an unsolicited </strong>credit offer via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li>Beware of<strong> any offers of credit on unusually</strong> favourable terms (a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you <strong>first </strong>pay a <strong>sum of money</strong> intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan. The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li>Find out whether the lender has the requisite <strong>authorization</strong>. Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a> on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li>Consider doing <strong>a search</strong> for the person using the customary search engines. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary.</strong> In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p>Watch the new videos about fraudulent credit offers&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/films-de-sensibilisation-et-de-prevention-concernant-les-fraudes-linvestissement-et-au-credit">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/sensibiliserings-en-preventiefilms-over-beleggings-en-kredietfraude">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)!</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-29T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

  <title>IOSCO report on Sustainability-related Issuer Disclosures</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-report-sustainability-related-issuer-disclosures</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>IOSCO elaborates on its vision and expectations for the IFRS Foundation’s work towards a global baseline of investor-focussed sustainability standards. </span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>The aim is to improve the global consistency, comparability and reliability of sustainability reporting and to support investors’ evolving informational needs.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span><span lang="EN-US"><span><span>The chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, is closely involved in these discussions as IOSCO Vice Chair and as Chair of the IFRS Monitoring Board.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p><a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS608.pdf">Read more ...</a></p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Beware of offers of investment in wine, champagne and spirits</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/beware-offers-investment-wine-champagne-and-spirits</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA once again warns the public against fraudulent investment offers in wine, champagne and spirits (see our warnings from <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/offers-investment-wine-beware-fraud-fsma-renews-its-warning">4 July 2019</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/offers-investment-whisky-beware-fraud">11 February 2020</a>).</strong></p>

<p>The principle remains the same: victims are contacted by phone by a salesperson, who offers them investments in wine, champagne or <strong>spirits&nbsp;</strong>and invites them to consult an<strong> online trading platform for fine bottles</strong>.</p>

<p>These companies offer the opportunity to <strong>acquire bottles</strong>, undertake to <strong>stock them in a cellar </strong>for you, and promise to <strong>find some major buyers </strong>so that you can earn a <strong>handsome profit.</strong> Would-be investors have nothing to do, the companies 'will take care of everything'! The concept, however, is <strong>too good to be true</strong>. In the end, despite the promises, the investors never recover their money!</p>

<h3 class="blue">The suspect companies active in recent weeks</h3>

<p>In recent weeks, the FSMA was informed that the companies behind the following websites have been approaching Belgians with these types of offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li>www-cap-de-France.com&nbsp;</li>
 <li>www.st-conseils.com&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>The FSMA warns that these companies<strong> do not hold an authorization</strong> and are thus <strong>not permitted to offer investment services</strong> in Belgium. Moreover, it is very likely that these are cases of investment fraud, which means that in the end, the amounts invested are never reimbursed.</p>

<p><strong>Please note</strong>, don’t trust the 'professional' appearance of the website to which they referred you; the swindlers do everything they can, of course, to appear as legitimate as possible.</p>

<h3 class="blue">How to avoid the trap?</h3>

<p>In order to avoid such cases of fraud, the FSMA <strong>urges you to exercise utmost prudence </strong>and <strong>advises you to remain alert to any indication of investment fraud</strong>. It offers a few recommendations to this end:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns</strong>. If a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company who is contacting you </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.). If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. <strong>Find out as well when the company website was set up</strong>: if the company’s website is relatively new, this could be an additional sign of investment fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary if you are asked to deposit money to bank accounts in countries without any connection </strong>to the country where the company contacting you is said to be registered or with your own country of residence. Be wary as well if you are asked to deposit money into accounts <strong>whose beneficiary is someone other than the company itself.</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>In any case, if your contact person comes across as<strong> particularly insistent</strong>, this is an additional indication of fraud.</p>

<p><strong><strong>***</strong></strong></p>

<p><strong><strong><strong>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary.</strong></strong></strong></p>

<p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-24T10:10:10+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">171668</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>More than 800,000 Belgians invest on the stock market</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/more-800000-belgians-invest-stock-market</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>During the past three years, 830,000 Belgians traded on the stock market. That number is now on the rise: in the first three months of 2021, the number of unique investors had more than doubled relative to the first quarter of 2019. The number of new investors at the beginning of 2021 was 50% higher than at the beginning of 2019. These are among the findings of a new study conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) on the behaviour of Belgian retail investors. This study was presented today during a webinar that the FSMA organized on the occasion of the publication of its tenth annual report.</strong></p>

<p>In May 2020, the FSMA published an initial study on investor behaviour. That study showed that during the first lockdown, the number of Belgians who traded in BEL20 shares had increased fivefold compared to the period before the crisis. Moreover, young and infrequent investors were much more active during the lockdown period.</p>

<p>At a webinar held today with almost 800 participants, the FSMA unveiled the results of a more extensive follow-up study. The latter is based on an analysis of the data in reports received by the FSMA between January 2018 and March 2021 on stock market transactions by retail investors. The key points from this study are set out below.</p>

<h3 class="blue">More than half a million Belgians trade in shares</h3>

<p>Belgians carried out 29,825,716 transactions in the period under study. Across all financial instruments (shares, bonds, options, etc.), there were 830,000 unique Belgian retail investors in total, measured by the number of securities accounts. Around 550,000 of them traded in shares. On average, Belgians traded in nine different instruments.</p>

<h3 class="blue">Number of unique investors in BEL20 has doubled</h3>

<p>Between the beginning of 2018 and the end of March 2021, 330,000 unique investors invested in BEL20 shares. Around 80 per cent of them also traded in other financial instruments. The number of unique investors who carried out at least one transaction in a BEL20 share rose enormously during the first lockdown.</p>

<p>Even after that period, we saw a further increase in those figures: in the first quarter of 2021, the number of unique investors more than doubled as compared to the first quarter of 2019. At the beginning of 2021, still other new investors began to trade on the market. In comparison with the beginning of 2019, the number of new investors had increased by more than 50 per cent.</p>

<h3 class="blue">Volume traded in BEL20 rose during the coronavirus crisis</h3>

<p>Since the coronavirus crisis, the volume of BEL20 shares traded has risen sharply. Over the entire 2018-2021 period, the volume amounted to an average of 625 billion euros per month. From mid February 2020 to the end of March 2021, that amount stood at an average of 933 billion euros per month.</p>

<p>The rise in the volume traded was not limited to the first lockdown. At the start of the second lockdown, in early November 2020, the volume rose again, but less dramatically than during the first lockdown. Unlike in that first period, this time more shares were sold than bought.</p>

<h3 class="blue">ETFs also gained in popularity among retail investors</h3>

<p>The study also measured investments in Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs), which are listed funds that track the performance of one particular index. In total, around 360,000 unique Belgian investors traded in ETFs. In all, they carried out 1.8 billion transactions. A substantial part of the transactions in ETFs took place via discretionary management, but since 2020, retail investors have also been discovering ETFs.</p>

<h3 class="blue">GameStop, Blackberry and AMC</h3>

<p>The study also examined the behaviour of Belgians in the face of the hype, mainly in the United States, around shares such as GameStop, Blackberry and AMC. The number of Belgians who invested in those shares was very limited. Between 1 December 2020 and 12 February 2021, a total of 4237 Belgians traded in GameStop, 1580 in Blackberry and 4058 in AMC. It was mainly men under the age of 35 who were trading in those shares.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais, the Chairman of the FSMA, observed: ‘This study shows not only an increased interest in the stock market on the part of Belgians. But it also illustrates the modern techniques of data analysis that enable the FSMA to make optimal use of the information available to it. In addition to this study, we are working on other applications that make it possible to use the data available to us even faster and more efficiently, convinced as we are that this is an essential tool for the supervisor of the future.’</p>
</blockquote>

<p>A presentation of the results of the study is available on the FSMA website (Available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/20210621_etude_investisseursdetail.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/20210621_studie_retailbelegger.pdf">Dutch</a> only).</p>

<p>The FSMA is also publishing today its annual report on 2020, which is likewise available on the FSMA website (Available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/7232">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/7232">Dutch</a> only).</p>

<p></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-21T11:34:03+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">171643</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA expects the sector to improve the quality of the key information documents provided to retail investors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-expects-sector-improve-quality-key-information-documents-provided-retail-investors</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has examined the key information documents made available to Belgian retail clients who buy insurance-based investment products or structured products. The aim was to determine whether these documents are of sufficiently high quality to enable clients to understand clearly the features of these products. As a result of its observations, the FSMA expects the sector to improve in particular the clarity and legibility of the information that these documents must provide.</strong></p>

<p>Internal investment funds, separate management, barrier conditional coupon or <em>quanto </em>participation. These terms do not mean much to a large majority of the population, yet they appear frequently in the key information documents (KIDs) provided to Belgian retail clients, the FSMA has determined.</p>

<p>A KID is a document that must be drawn up by the manufacturer of the product in accordance with European legislation. It contains key information about a financial product. The objective of such a document is to help investors take an informed investment decision and to facilitate comparison among products. The KID is a useful document for this purpose.</p>

<p>The FSMA carried out a qualitative examination of a representative sample of KIDs for insurance-based investment products and structured products.</p>

<p>After contacting the supervised manufacturers individually, the FSMA now wishes to share with the financial sector the most important and most frequent observations and remarks raised as a result of this examination.</p>

<p>Its examination indicated that KIDs do not always achieve a sufficiently high quality and do not always provide sufficiently clear information about the features and risks of the financial product in question. The language used in these documents is often too technical and difficult to understand. Moreover, the font size used is often very small, making it difficult to read. However, clients should be able to understand the KID without having to use a magnifying glass and a financial dictionary.</p>

<p>Respect for the objectives of the legislation in this regard therefore remains a challenge for the sector. The FSMA expects a sustained effort on the part of manufacturers, who are required to give their clients clear and comprehensible documents. It asks them therefore to be more attentive to the quality of their KIDs and to improve their clarity and comprehensibility, in order to enable retail investors to take an informed investment decision. To this end, it is publishing a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/fsma_2021_13_en.pdf">Feedback Statement</a> that contains the main conclusions of its examination.</p>

<p>The FSMA will continue in future to review attentively the KIDs notified to it. In the process, it will devote particular importance to how the sector responds to the points requiring attention set out in the Feedback Statement. If the FSMA finds that there are still infringements of the PRIIP Regulation, it will take appropriate measures. The FSMA will focus its enforcement action on infringements that are directly at odds with the objectives pursued by the European legislation, namely to enable investors to compare products and make an informed decision. The FSMA is of the opinion that an illegible or incomprehensible KID, in particular as regards the functioning of the product and the risks associated with it, is clearly in contradiction with these objectives.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-17T09:00:37+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">171004</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Belgian investment funds evolve toward sustainability</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/belgian-investment-funds-evolve-toward-sustainability</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span><span><strong>A little more than half of all Belgian public funds consist of sustainable assets or invest sustainably. These are the findings of a study conducted by the FSMA on the occasion of the introduction of the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR).</strong></span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The European Regulation on sustainability-related disclosures in the financial services sector, better known as the SFDR, entered into force on 10&nbsp;March 2021. The Regulation seeks to ensure that managers of investment funds do not greenwash their products, presenting them as more sustainable than they really are.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>This is why the SFDR imposes transparency obligations on managers of undertakings for collective investment (UCIs) as regards the sustainability of their investments. In particular, they must disclose how they have integrated environmental, social and governance (ESG) objectives into their investment policy. They must include this information in the prospectuses for their funds and compartments.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Based on that information, the SFDR distinguishes among three main categories of funds. Article&nbsp;9 covers funds that have sustainable investment as their objective. The category of funds with sustainable characteristics is covered in Article&nbsp;8. Funds without sustainable characteristics or sustainable objectives have to comply only with Article 6 of the SFDR.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>The FSMA examined how managers apply the new Regulation. As at 21&nbsp;May 2021, the FSMA held data from 706&nbsp;funds and their compartments. They represent more than 95&nbsp;per cent of all Belgian public UCIs.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Their breakdown into SFDR categories based on the number of funds is as follows: </span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li>Article&nbsp;6: 68&nbsp;per cent;</li>
 <li>Article&nbsp;8: 25&nbsp;per cent;</li>
 <li><span><span><span>Article&nbsp;9: 3&nbsp;per cent.</span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span>Their breakdown into SFDR categories based on the assets invested is as follows:</span></span></span></p>

<ul>
 <li>Article&nbsp;6: 46&nbsp;per cent;</li>
 <li>Article&nbsp;8: 50&nbsp;per cent;</li>
 <li><span><span><span>Article&nbsp;9: 4&nbsp;per cent.</span></span></span></li>
</ul>

<p><span><span><span>The total assets invested by the funds and compartments in the study amount to 187&nbsp;billion euro. A little over half of that, or 100&nbsp;billion euro, belongs to the Article&nbsp;8 and Article 9 categories and have ESG characteristics or are sustainably invested.</span></span></span></p>

<p><span><span><span>Between the end of February 2020 and the end of May 2021, the funds and compartments covered by Articles 8 and 9 saw considerable growth. Net subscriptions in the category of Article&nbsp;8 rose by 15&nbsp;billion euro (+22&nbsp;per cent). Net subscriptions in the category of Article&nbsp;9 rose by 3&nbsp;billion euro (+85.5&nbsp;per cent). The funds and compartments covered by Article&nbsp;6 saw net redemptions totalling 6&nbsp;billion euro (-7&nbsp;per cent).</span></span></span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span><span><span>“The new European legislation offers investors the possibility of devoting more attention, when taking investment decisions, to the sustainability of their investments,” observed the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais. “The FSMA’s research indicates that the sector has rapidly adapted to the new Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation and that investors are more interested in investments with sustainability characteristics.”</span></span></span></p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-16T07:41:47+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">170986</guid>
    </item>
