<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches a video campaign to raise the public’s awareness of online fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-video-campaign-raise-publics-awareness-online-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Today the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is launching a series of awareness and prevention videos (available in </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/170883"><strong>French</strong></a><strong> - </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/170883"><strong>Dutch</strong></a><strong> only) on investment and credit fraud. This campaign is all the more pertinent as it is being released in these times of coronavirus crisis, characterized by lockdown and widespread teleworking, increasingly exposing consumers to scams by fraudsters.</strong></p><p>At the slightest doubt as to whether or not an offer of financial products or services is fraudulent, more and more consumers are contacting the FSMA before investing their money. In 2020, the FSMA received 1,555 fraud reports, which is 50% more than in 2018. In order to continue its efforts to raise awareness of such fraudulent practices among an even wider public, the FSMA has now developed testimonial videos and animated films. This initiative is a continuation of its 2020 digital campaign "An offer too good to be true? Start by saying no".</p><h2 class="blue">The first 3 animated films are already available on the FSMA website!</h2><p>Be sure to check them out if you are asking yourself the following questions:</p><ul><li>How can I recognize and avoid investment and credit fraud?</li><li>What are the main mechanisms of this type of fraud?</li><li>How can I recognise <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22959">cloned firms</a>?</li><li>What should I do if I become the victim of such fraud?</li><li>How can I recognize and avoid cryptocurrency fraud?</li></ul><p><strong>In the coming months, more videos will be released.</strong> These will include testimonies by consumers who became victims of today’s most frequent types of fraud, as well as animated films on four forms of fraud: credit fraud, fraudulent online trading platforms, fraudulent offers of portfolio management and boiler room fraud.</p><div class="box box-tip"><p><strong>Remember our 3 tips if you are concerned that an offer may be an attempt at fraud:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to <strong>contact the FSMA directly</strong> via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</li><li><strong>Visit the </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599"><strong>FSMA website</strong></a> and learn how to recognize and avoid scams.</li><li>Finally, <strong>take the </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/fraud-quiz/quiz-en.html"><strong>test</strong></a> on the FSMA website to find out if the offer you received is a scam.</li></ul></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-11T14:13:59+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">170917</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Non-financial reporting: progress, but with room for improvement</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/non-financial-reporting-progress-room-improvement</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Belgian listed companies have improved their reporting of non-financial information than two years ago. There are still some points requiring attention, however, and room for improvement. That is clear from an wide-ranging <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/study48_en.pdf">study</a> conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), which makes recommendations for further progress.</strong></p>

<p>Non-financial information covers a range of different topics, such as environmental, climate, social and employee matters, human rights and the fight against corruption. Unlike financial reporting, reporting on these topics is a relatively new requirement. Companies have therefore been going through a learning process as regards the way such reporting is done.</p>

<p>In its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/studies/study47_en.pdf">study</a> published in March 2019, the FSMA took stock for the first time of the state of affairs in the area of non-financial reporting by large listed companies in Belgium. Since the previous study, sustainability reporting has developed significantly. It is partly for this reason that two years later, the FSMA once again conducted a study of non-financial reporting by listed companies.</p>

<p>The follow-up study first examines which areas have seen progress, and then at which areas still have room for improvement. The study is intended to give the companies in question a set of guidelines for drawing up a high-quality NFI statement, identifying good practices and making recommendations to that end.</p>

<h2 class="blue">Reporting is better in significant areas</h2>

<p>The study shows that in two years’ time, the companies have made a good deal of progress. Non-financial reporting has significantly improved in important areas, such as environmental and staff policies. The non-financial information is of higher quality and focuses more specifically on the points that are essential for the company in question. Companies are also setting out more quantitative targets than in the past when it comes to non-financial topics. A large majority of the companies has drawn up an internal code of conduct or a code of ethics.</p>

<h2 class="blue">There is still room for improvement</h2>

<p>However, there is still room for improvement. For example, reporting does not cover all (aspects of) non-financial topics equally thoroughly. Human rights and anti-corruption considerations are often presented with less detail, as is the description of the principal risks. The NFI statements often lack sufficient balance: there is a tendency to foreground the favourable elements, while devoting little attention to the less positive elements.</p>

<h2 class="blue">Preventing differences in reporting quality</h2>

<p>In addition, it is important that all listed companies provide information of sufficiently high quality. We should prevent a gap arising between the ‘good students’, who keep improving, and the weaker ones that lag behind. The study shows that the BEL 20 companies generally provide more complete and specific non-financial information than other companies.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>“With this study, the FSMA seeks to help all the companies concerned to improve the quality of their non-financial reporting,” according to Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA.<br>
&nbsp;</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-06-10T10:23:08+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">170830</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Authorization procedure for statutory auditors – call for applications  </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/authorization-procedure-statutory-auditors-call-applications</link>
  <description>
<p><span><span>The FSMA is setting up a procedure for the authorization of statutory auditors who intend to carry out an audit mandate at undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment, regulated real estate companies and institutions for occupational retirement provision.</span></span></p>

<p><span><span>Applications must be submitted in writing, by <strong>1 September 2021</strong> at the latest, to the FSMA, secretariat for the Policy, Legal Service and International Relations Department, Congresstraat/rue du Congrès 12-14, 1000 Brussels. Thereafter, applications (including all documents for the file) must also be sent to the FSMA by email to the following address: <a href="mailto:policy@fsma.be">policy@fsma.be</a>.</span></span></p>

<div class="box box-tip">
<p><span><span>Read the Communication FSMA 201_12 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/fsma_2021_12_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-06/fsma_2021_12_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</span></span></p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Certain aspects of the MiFID II compliance function requirements</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/certain-aspects-mifid-ii-compliance-function-requirements</link>
  <description>

<item>
  <title>Renewal of the term of office of the FSMA Chairman, FSMA Deputy Chairman and members of the Management Committee</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/renewal-term-office-fsma-chairman-fsma-deputy-chairman-and-members-management-committee</link>
  <description>
<p>Renewal of the term of office of the FSMA Chairman, FSMA Deputy Chairman and Members of the Management Committee</p>

<p>The mandate of the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, has been renewed. The new term of office is for a period of six years, until March 2027.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais has led the FSMA since its creation in 2011. Before that, he was Chairman of the FSMA's predecessor. This re-appointment is linked with his existing and new international functions: he is Vice-Chair of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) and Chair of the European Regional Committee of IOSCO. He is also Chair of the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation, which oversees accounting standard-setting, and Co-Chair of the Monitoring Group responsible for monitoring international audit standard-setting. In his capacity as FSMA Chairman, he is member of the Board of Supervisors of ESMA and member of the ESRB.</p>

<p>The mandates of the Deputy Chairman and of the two Members of the Management Committee were also renewed for six years.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-05/2021-03-25_kb_ar.pdf#open">Royal Decrees</a> on these renewals have been published in the Belgian Official Journal.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-05-10T08:01:09+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">117436</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA has launched a consultation about SPACs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-has-launched-consultation-about-spacs</link>
  <description>
<p>A SPAC, or Special Purpose Acquisition Company, is a new company established for the specific purpose of raising capital, applying for a stock exchange listing and within a short period thereafter, financing a merger or acquisition.</p>

<p>The FSMA is proposing to introduce minimum standards for SPACs. These minimum standards concern the structure of SPACs, information disclosure and the arrangements whereby investors may withdraw from the SPAC. The FSMA also takes a position on the extent to which SPACs are suited, and should thus be accessible, to retail investors.</p>

<p>Market participants are invited to submit reactions and suggestions regarding the FSMA’s proposal. The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-05/20210505_consultation_spac_en.pdf">consultation</a> will run between 10 and 31 May 2021.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="mailto:Consult1@fsma.be?subject=Consultation%20on%20SPACs">Participate in the consultation ...</a></p>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Update by the NBB and the FSMA on Asset management and Non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-nbb-and-fsma-asset-management-and-non-bank-financial-intermediation-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) are today publishing an <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-05/2021_update_assetmanagement.pdf">updated study</a> on <em>Asset management and Non-bank financial intermediation</em> (NBFI) in Belgium. This update is part of the regular monitoring of these activities, which constitutes a €138&nbsp;billion market in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>In 2017, the FSMA and the NBB published an initial, extensive report on <em>Asset management and shadow banking</em> in Belgium. The third update of this report, with recent figures and an analysis of national and international developments, is now available.</p>

<p>The initial report and its updates address the trend toward a more market-based financial system.</p>

<p>This type of financing offers an alternative to borrowing from banks and helps to support the real economy. It fits in well with the argument, put forward in Europe, that the economy should become less dependent on banks for financing. But non-bank financial intermediation can – like any other financial activity – also give rise to systemic risks that could threaten the stability of the financial system.</p>

<p>Financing via the markets can take many forms. In the report, the supervisory authorities analyse asset management activities and non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium. The most important aim of the report is to keep a finger on the pulse of the sector. The supervisors pay particular attention to the risks associated with these activities and their interconnectedness with other sectors.</p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB have calculated the scale of non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium based on the definition provided by the Financial Stability Board, the organization which, on behalf of the G20, oversees reforms of the financial sector at a worldwide level. At the end of September 2020, the total financial assets in this category amounted to 138&nbsp;billion euros. These assets consist mainly of money market funds and non-equity investment funds. The vast majority of these funds are under the supervision of the Belgian authorities.</p>

<p>As things stand currently, no substantial systemic risks have been identified in relation to asset management and non-bank financial intermediation.</p>

<p>The developments in both areas of activity and the links with other sectors of the economy do, however, require careful monitoring, including for potential reputational risks to financial service groups. The latter includes the so-called ‘step-in risk’, namely, the risk that these groups may de facto feel obliged to compensate clients for the risks associated, for example, with the investment funds sold by these groups, even where they are not contractually bound to do so.</p>

<p>During the COVID-19 crisis, the FSMA instituted closer supervision of the asset management sector and collected additional data on Belgian public open-ended investment funds. These additional analyses showed that Belgian public open-ended investment funds have for the most part held up well during the period of the COVID-19 crisis and market stress. Moreover, the massive adoption of <em>Liquidity Management Tools</em> by Belgian public open-ended investment funds has been a response to a specific recommendation in the initial report.</p>

<p>Lastly, the NBB and the FSMA continue to take an active part in international work aimed at providing a clearer picture of European and international developments in the NBFI sector and, where necessary, strengthening the regulatory framework.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>According to Minister of Finance Vincent Van Peteghem: “The non-banking financial sector makes an essential contribution to financing the economy. Investment funds and asset managers, in particular, that succeed in attracting individual assets for investment, play a crucial role. The monitoring conducted by the FSMA and the NBB not only makes it possible to gain a better overview of this part of the financial sector, but also ensures that the risks - both to financial stability and from the perspective of consumer protection - are clearly understood. Nevertheless, recent events on the international capital market have shown that careful vigilance continues to be necessary.”</p>
</blockquote>

<blockquote>
<p>As noted by Governor Pierre Wunsch of the NBB: “The vulnerabilities that appeared in March 2020 in certain subsegments of the worldwide NBFI sector had a limited impact on the Belgian market. In line with the previous analyses, the NBB-FSMA report confirms once again that the Belgian market for asset management and non-banking financial intermediation can be considered fundamentally healthy. The crucial role of this sector in financial intermediation was thus never under threat. Given the rapid developments in this sector, supervisors do need to remain vigilant. Regular updates of the analysis just published will be part of that ongoing monitoring.”</p>
</blockquote>

<blockquote>
<p>In the view of Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA: “The COVID-19 crisis has once again demonstrated the importance for the FSMA and the NBB of having reliable information and data on the entities under our supervision and the need for investment funds to be sufficiently prepared to deal with crises. This report illustrates some of the progress and efforts made to improve our common ability to monitor the evolution of the sector."</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-05-06T08:12:20+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">117439</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Keynote speech by the Chairman of the FSMA at a high-level conference on sustainability reporting organized by the European Commission</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/keynote-speech-chairman-fsma-high-level-conference-sustainability-reporting-organized-european</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On Wednesday, 6 May 2021, Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA and Vice Chair of IOSCO, gave a speech at a major conference of more than 2000 participants, organized by the European Commission and titled “<em>High-level conference on a Commission proposal for a Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive – the way forward”</em>.</strong></p>

<p>A considerable number of leading figures of the economic and financial world, including Madame Christine Lagarde, President of the European Central Bank, Valdis Dombrovskis, Vice president of the European Commission, European Commissionner Mairead McGuinness and several Ministers from EU countries attended the event. This international conference focussed amongst other things on the European Commission’s proposal for a Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD). The text is intended, notably, to improve the disclosure by a great numer of European companies of sustainability information.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Several participants spoke at the conference, and discussion panels were held. Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, gave a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/media/files/2021-05/20210605_euconference_keynote.pdf">keynote speech</a> in which he highlighted the role of the financial sector in the transition to a more sustainable economy. In this regard, he noted the importance, both for investors and for society as a whole, of having access to reliable and clear information about sustainability. As Vice Chair of IOSCO, the international organization of securities commissions, and as Chair of the Monitoring Board – the body responsible for advancing the public interest in areas related to the international standards governing company reporting – he emphasized the crucial importance of close cooperation among the various national, European and international authorities, stressing the significant role of the IFRS Foundation, supported by IOSCO and the FSB, in collaborating on setting international standards for sustainability reporting.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-05-06T08:07:34+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">117438</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: the FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-6</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also use <strong>mobile applications </strong>to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA notes that several fraudulent trading platforms propose a so-called 'affiliate programme' to consumers. These programmes exhibit signs of a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957"><strong>pyramid scheme</strong></a> or at any rate of a Ponzi scheme.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of the following new fake-ads and websites that refer to subsequent projects and training courses:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Champion </strong></li>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Superstar</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin System</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Acceptrade</strong> (www.acceptrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Antarigroup </strong>(www.antarigroup.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Capitalfx </strong>(www.capitalfx.co)</li>
 <li><strong>CFD Advanced</strong> (www.cfdadvanced.com, www.cfdadvanced.london, www.cfdadvances.com and www.cfdadv.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Cinda Securities </strong>(www.cinda-securities.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Commerce wealth </strong>(www.commercewealth.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finrexo </strong>(www.finexro.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Finvesting</strong> (www.finvestings.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Galore Pro </strong>(www.galore.pro)</li>
 <li><strong>Horizon Invest </strong>(www.horizoninvest.cc and www.horizoninvest.io)</li>
 <li><strong>ICTrades </strong>(www.ictrades.co)</li>
 <li><strong>Ironefx </strong>(www.ironefx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>My Coin Elite </strong>(www.mycoinelite.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Northstate </strong>(www.northstate.io)</li>
 <li><strong>OmegaPro </strong>(www.omegaprofx.com, www.omegaproworld.site, www.omegaprotrading.com and www.omegapro.world)</li>
 <li><strong>Primecap </strong>(www.primecap.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Quantums Trade </strong>(www.quantums-trade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Topdigitalcoin </strong>(www.topdigitalcoin.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Triton Capital Markets </strong>(www.tritoncapitalmarkets.com, www.tritonmarkets.com and www.tcapitaltrading.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Westmark </strong>(www.westmark.com)</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>
</description>

  <description>

<item>
  <title>Re-election of the chairman of the FSMA as chair of the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/re-election-chairman-fsma-chair-monitoring-board-ifrs-foundation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Jean-Paul Servais, has been re-elected as chair of the IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board for a mandate of two years.</strong></p>

<p>The Monitoring Board ensures the proper functioning of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (the IFRS Foundation). The IFRS Foundation is the non-for-profit organization that is responsible for supervising the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB). The IASB sets the IFRS standards. These are international accounting rules governing the preparation of annual reports and financial statements. The Trustees of the IFRS Foundation determine its strategy and governance and exercise oversight over the work performed by the IASB. The Trustees are accountable to the Monitoring Board.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board consists of representatives of various prominent market regulators and authorities. The financial market supervisors of the United States, Brazil, Japan and South Korea, the European Commission, the Chinese Ministry of Finance and IOSCO currently sit on the Monitoring Board.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board regularly consults with the Trustees and the chairman of the IASB to review the quality and effectiveness of the IFRS Foundation’s governance structure and hence to supervise the development of high-quality IFRS standards in the interest of the general good. 87% of jurisdictions worldwide and more than 6,000 companies within the European Union use IFRS standards.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board has re-elected Jean-Paul Servais as chair for another two-year term until April 2023. The FSMA chairman became a member of the Monitoring Board as a representative of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), of which he has been vice-chair since 2016.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais: “We are delighted by this decision that recognizes the work achieved in the past four years and attests to the trust placed in us by the various members of the Monitoring Board. We will continue to strive, with the same commitment and determination, for high-quality accounting standards that contribute to the transparency of the financial markets. The Monitoring Board will also make its voice heard regarding the development of the governance for setting global sustainability reporting standards by the IFRS Foundation. I<em> also encourage the IFRS Foundation to continue its engagement with key jurisdictions and stakeholders with the view to ensure a globally consistent and comparable sustainability reporting baseline.</em>”</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-30T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Emw capital (www.emwcapital.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/emw-capital-wwwemwcapitalcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of EMW Capital, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">EMW Capital is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/166836">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 28 April 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by EMW Capital and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">EMW Capital uses the website <strong>www.emwcapital.com</strong> and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Sydney CBD, AustraliaSquare, 264 GeorgeStreet, Sydney NSW2000, Australia and Stockerstrasse 23, 8002Zürich, Switzerland<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contact@emwcapital.com, contact.au@emwcapital.com, r.major@emwcapital.com and contact.ch@emwcapital.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+61 2 8073 4122 and +41 43 508 88 19</p>

<p class="rtejustify">EMW Capital has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of Switzerland (<a href="https://www.finma.ch/en/finma-public/warning-list/emw-capital/">FINMA</a>).</p>

<p class="rtejustify">It also uses bank accounts that claim to be opened in the name of Preston Willcox Limited, Radis Group ADV, MG Valda ltd, Blossom Enterprises ltd and Fluxsmooth Trading Company Ltd.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-28T17:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68534</guid>
    </item>

More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/166836">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 28 April 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by Daltium and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Daltium uses the website <strong>www.daltium.com</strong> and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; HNA Tower, No. 8 Linhe Middle Road, Tianhe District, Guangzhou 510610, China;<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;China World Trade Center, 1 Jianguomen Outer St, Guomao, Chaoyang, Beijing, China, 100004;<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Hankyu Grand Building, 8-47 Kakuda-cho, Kita-ku, Osaka, 530-0017, Japan;<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Curepipe, Mauritius.<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; g.wambeke@daltium.com, accounts@daltium.com and info@daltium.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+862028016127 and +862028306918</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>

<item>
  <title>Bruckhaus quist (www.bruckhaus-quist.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/bruckhaus-quist-wwwbruckhaus-quistcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of Bruckhaus Quist, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Bruckhaus Quist is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/166836">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 28 April 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by Bruckhaus Quist and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Bruckhaus Quist uses the website <strong>www.bruckhaus-quist.com</strong> and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;World Wide House, 19 Des Voeux Road Central, Hong Kong S.A.R.<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; contact@bruckhaus-quist.com and clientservices@bruckhaus-quist.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+852 5801 0932<br>
<strong>Fax</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+852 3014 7692</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Bruckhaus Quist has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of Hong Kong (<a href="https://www.sfc.hk/en/alert-list/2640">SFC</a>).</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: the FSMA warns the public against unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-unauthorized-activities</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The companies are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/68532"><strong>Bruckhaus Quist</strong></a> (www.bruckhaus-quist.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/68533"><strong>Daltium</strong></a> (www.daltium.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/68534"><strong>EMW Capital</strong></a> (www.emwcapital.com)</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be '<strong>boiler rooms</strong>'.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term 'boiler room'), insisting that they keep making further payments. <strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>

    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Watch out for companies that offer trading software (expert advisors)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-companies-offer-trading-software-expert-advisors</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA warns the public against various companies in Belgium that are offering so-called ‘Expert Advisors’ or ‘EAs’ used to trade in CFDs, forex and crypto-derivatives.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">An Expert Advisor is a type of software that tells you when to make certain trades or even carries them out for you automatically, based on preprogrammed parameters.</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA notes that ever more companies are distributing such Expert Advisors, including to Belgian consumers. This comes with risks.</p><p class="rtejustify">First, these companies do not have an authorization to offer financial services and products in Belgium.</p><p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the FSMA has found that such trading software often occurs via a pyramid structure. In general, these are referred to as ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing) schemes, in which consumers are incentivized to bring in new members. In exchange, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the software package.</p><p class="rtejustify">Such MLM networks appear to be active on social media via countless (private) groups. It appears that these schemes mainly target young people. The message is that everyone can afford a luxurious lifestyle provided they bring in enough new members and make the appropriate investment in the software being promoted.</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA also wishes to emphasize that distribution of certain financial instruments that are available via the software (such as CFDs, forex and crypto-derivatives) is prohibited in Belgium.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>Lastly, offers of CFDs and forex derivatives via the internet are very risky and open to fraud</strong>: anyone who invests in CFDs or forex derivatives runs the risk of losing the entire sum invested. <strong>The chance of loss is far greater than the chance of profit</strong>: surveys by other European supervisors among investors shows that at least 75% to 89% of the investments in derivative products, such as forex derivatives, are loss-makers! These products are appropriate only for those who really wish to speculate, are ready to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and are familiar with derivative financial products. <strong>There have also been many cases of fraud with these instruments</strong>. In a number of cases, it turned out that no actual transactions were ever made by the offeror.</p><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">Based on the information available to the FSMA, the following websites are offering these types of trading software in Belgium, in contravention of Belgian legislation:</p><ul><li><strong>Cashfx Group</strong> (www.cashfxgroup.com)</li><li><strong>MirrorTrading International</strong></li><li><strong>World Markets </strong>(www.worldmarkets.com)</li></ul><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">Have you received an offer of an investment and would like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">Beware of fraud</a>’.</p><p class="rtejustify">We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-26T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">312904</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Watch out for companies that offer forex training</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/watch-out-companies-offer-forex-training</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA warns the public against various companies that are selling training in Belgium intended to teach people to trade in complex financial instruments such as forex derivatives.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Anyone who signs up for such training, is given access to instructional videos, webinars and live chat sessions with all sorts of information about how the forex market works. They explain what forex derivatives are, how exactly you can trade in them, what type of orders you can place and what software you can download for the purpose. The message is that forex trading offers opportunities on condition that you have thoroughly studied and have a full understanding of how it works.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">This comes with risks. First, the FSMA wishes to remind you that distribution of derivative instruments traded on an electronic trading system and involve leverage (including certain forex instruments) is prohibited in Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Secondly, such training materials are often distributed done via a pyramid structure. In general, these are referred to as ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing) schemes, in which consumers are incentivized to bring in new members. In exchange, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the training.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Such MLM networks appear to be active on social media via countless (private) groups. It appears that these schemes mainly target young people. The message is that everyone can afford a luxurious lifestyle provided they bring in enough new members and make the appropriate investment in the training on offer.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Offers of instruments on forex via internet are very risky and open to fraud</strong>: anyone who invests in instruments on forex runs the risk of losing the entire sum invested. <strong>The chance of loss is far greater than the chance of profit</strong>: surveys by other European supervisors among investors shows that at least 75% to 89% of the investments in derivative products, such as forex derivatives, are loss-makers! These products are appropriate only for those who really wish to speculate, are ready to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and are familiar with derivative financial products. <strong>There have also been many cases of fraud with these instruments</strong>. In a number of cases, it turned out that no actual transactions were ever made by the offeror.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of the following websites that offer this type of training to Belgian consumers.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Edu4traders </strong>(www.edu4traders.com)</li>
 <li><strong>SmartCapitale.fr </strong>(www.smartcapitale.fr)</li>
 <li><strong>Tradehouse Europe</strong> (www.tradehouseeurope.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Have you received an offer of an investment and would like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">Beware of fraud</a>’.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">We also urge investors always to check that the company in question has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-21T10:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68461</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Educational brochures on the rules governing the distribution of insurance products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/educational-brochures-rules-governing-distribution-insurance-products</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) publishes two new educational brochures to inform the sector and the consumers. These brochures explain the rules of the European IDD Directive, which governs the distribution of insurance products. They provide customers with a better understanding of the mechanisms introduced by the IDD Directive to safeguard their interests when buying insurance products or insurance-based investment products.</strong></p>

<p>In 2020, the FSMA published a first <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/63656">educational brochure</a> summarizing the rules of MiFID I and MiFID II<sup><a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1">[1]</a></sup>. The brochure aimed at raising consumers’ awareness of their rights and of the obligations binding on the firms that provide investment services to them. Today, the FSMA publishes two new information brochures focusing on the distribution of insurance products.</p>

<p>The European Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD) contains a set of rules aimed at providing customers with a better protection within the framework of the distribution of insurance products. Today, the FSMA published two brochures regarding that Directive. The first one, entitled '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/68471">The IDD Directive: better protection for consumer interests. Focus on insurance products</a>', summarizes the rules applicable to insurance products in the classical meaning of the term.</p>

<p>Furthermore, the IDD contains additional requirements that solely apply to insurance-based investment products (or IBIPs). These products are discussed in a separate brochure, entitled '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/68470">The IDD Directive: better protection for consumer interests. Focus on insurance-based investment products</a>'.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Each brochure explains the various obligations binding on the distributors of the products concerned, both before concluding an insurance contract and during its term. These brochures respond to the needs of both the insurance sector and consumers, confirms Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA: '<em>As a supervisory authority, the FSMA is more than just a watchdog. Supervision and curbing infringements are obviously part of its main tasks, but it also wants to give guidance to the actors active in the sector. It does so by providing them with clear information that enables them to better understand and assimilate their various obligations. At the same time, the FSMA wishes to provide consumers with accessible information so that they are aware of their rights regarding insurance. These two new brochures fully meet the requirements of both target groups.'</em></p>
</blockquote>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;MiFID is the abbreviation of the European <em>Markets in Financial Instruments Directive</em>. MiFID I and MiFID II are European legal texts that entered into force in 2007 and 2018 respectively. They regulate the services regarding financial instruments provided by regulated companies.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-20T12:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68123</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA submits dossier on the CEO of Keyware Technologies to the judicial authorities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-submits-dossier-ceo-keyware-technologies-judicial-authorities</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is submitting to the judicial authorities a dossier relating to transactions between Keyware Technologies and companies related to its CEO, Big Friend NV, represented by Stéphane Vandervelde.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has learned of the findings of the forensic audit, conducted at the request of the board of directors of Keyware Technologies, of the transactions between Keyware Technologies and companies related to its CEO, Big Friend BV, represented by Stéphane Vandervelde<a href="#ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a>.</p>

<p>Based in part on its own findings following from supervisory actions it launched in 2020 regarding Keyware’s financial reporting, the FSMA has decided to submit a dossier relating to the aforementioned transactions to the judicial authorities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>

</div>
</div>

<div>
<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Usurpation of the identity of certain banks by fraudsters: the FSMA reiterates its warning</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/usurpation-identity-certain-banks-fraudsters-fsma-reiterates-its-warning</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During recent weeks, the FSMA has continued to receive notifications from consumers who have been approached by companies usurping the names of certain banks to present them with savings plans offering extremely high yields. The FSMA reiterates its warning against this practice, because behind these tantalizing offers are fraudsters whose sole aim is to steal your savings.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone or by e-mail without having taken any prior initiative themselves or after having entered their contact details on an online form. Such forms can often be found on websites that invite consumers to ‘<strong>check their eligibility</strong>’ for what they claim is a very profitable investment opportunity. The sites pass themselves off as information websites such as 'La Revue Economique' or 'Le Guide Financier'.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The fraudsters then offer consumers <strong>savings plans</strong> with the promise of returns in excess of market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several banks to deceive consumers.&nbsp;<strong>The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:&nbsp;</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Royal Bank of Scotland</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with ‘@personalrbs.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>Banco Santander Totta</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with ‘@stdrdepartment.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>Neo26, </strong>using the e-mail address ‘access.neo26@gmail.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>First</strong><strong>-Direct / HSBC</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with ‘@firstd-private.com’;</li>
 <li><strong>BPI-Portugal</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with ‘@bpi-portugal.com’ and a website ‘www.app-bpi-portugal.com’.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Fraudsters might also usurp the names of other financial institutions.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Swindlers redirect consumers wishing to take up the offer to an&nbsp;<strong>online platform</strong>&nbsp;where they can monitor the progress of their investment. The FSMA has received reports about such a platform that usurps the name and the logo of the London Stock Exchange:&nbsp;<strong>www.lse-client.com / www.lse-asset.com.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more information on how these fraudulent schemes work, consumers are invited to consult the FSMA’s warning of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67423">29 January 2021</a>.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>How to avoid this trap?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA also encourages you to see the recommendations it made in its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67423">previous warning</a>.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">In particular, the FSMA urges you to look very carefully at the e-mail addresses or contact details of the companies who are contacting you.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>, please feel free to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify the FSMA should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify">If you think you are the victim of fraud,&nbsp;make sure you <strong>do not pay any additional sums to your contact</strong>.<strong>&nbsp;Please note</strong>, this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Also, immediately&nbsp;<strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a> to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA</strong><strong>&nbsp;to the scam</strong> via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly</strong>&nbsp;and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-08T17:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68174</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Frequently asked questions about advertising for investment instruments</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/frequently-asked-questions-about-advertising-investment-instruments</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published FAQs (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2021/fsma_2021_09_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2021/fsma_2021_09_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) about advertisements for investment instruments when they are offered to the public, admitted to trading and distributed to retail clients. The FSMA held open consultations for these FAQs at the end of 2020.</p>

<p>Advertisements for investment instruments in conjunction with these operations must meet European requirements<a href="#ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a>. Thus, the information in the advertisements may not be inaccurate or misleading. The advertisements may not give an imbalanced image of the information in the prospectus.</p>

<p>The FSMA’s Frequently Asked Questions set out good practices that contribute to compliance with these requirements. The aim is to help make the FSMA’s actions predictable and to contribute to a level playing field.</p>

<div>
<hr>
<div>
<p><a name="#ftn1">[1]</a> Article 22 of Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2017 on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading on a regulated market, and repealing Directive 2003/71/EC; Article 22 of the Law of 11 July 2018 on public offers of investment instruments and the admission of investment instruments to trading on a regulated market; Article 9, § 3 of the Royal Decree of 25 April 2014 on certain information obligations for the distribution of financial products to retail clients.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-04-01T15:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68163</guid>
    </item>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-disclosure-requirements-under-prospectus-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published Communication FSMA_2021_08 on the Guidelines of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) on the disclosure requirements under the Prospectus Regulation and on their implementation by the FSMA (communication available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2021/fsma_2021_08_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2021/fsma_2021_08_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only, <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/library/esma31-62-1426_final_report_on_guidelines_on_prospectus_disclosure_requirements.pdf">ESMA Guidelines</a> available in English).</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Savings offers that are too good to be true? Beware!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/savings-offers-are-too-good-be-true-beware</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>In recent months, many consumers have reported to the FSMA that they were approached by companies with a variety of offers, promising rates of return far higher than market rates and often claiming the returns are guaranteed. Beware, because often behind these tempting offers are scammers who are not authorized to make such offers, the sole aim of which is to steal your savings.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The principle is always the same: you are contacted by phone by a salesperson,<strong> without any prior initiative on your part</strong> or after leaving your details on an online contact form.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The swindlers then promise you will earn very high, or even guaranteed returns</strong>, thanks to <strong>savings accounts </strong>with various underlying investments <strong>(rental of parking spaces or closed garages, purchase of rooms in retirement homes in Portugal or France)</strong>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA was informed that the companies behind the following websites have been approaching Belgians with these types of offers:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Alpha Connect Capital France</strong> – www.accfrance.com</li>
 <li><strong>Dutch Options &amp; Futures institute BV </strong>– https://www.dofin-bv.com</li>
 <li><strong>Global Multi Trade</strong> – www.globalmtcorp.com</li>
 <li><strong>ITM IMMO LOG</strong></li>
 <li><strong>International Financial Advisers</strong> – www.robingregory-ifa.com and https://occxpng.1e-gtwsjdnqj7msc-1-3dbtwdnfgq.com</li>
 <li><strong>Omicron SCPI </strong>– www.omicron-scpi.com</li>
 <li><strong>Oranje Vest BV</strong> – www.oranje-bv.com</li>
 <li><strong>PMB Invest</strong> – www.PMB-invest.com</li>
 <li><strong>Themis Patrimoine</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Warning: these companies</strong>&nbsp;<strong>do not hold an authorization and are thus not permitted to offer investment services&nbsp;</strong><strong>in Belgium.&nbsp;Moreover, it is very likely that these are cases of investment fraud, which means that in the end, the amounts invested are never reimbursed.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to appear more convincing to consumers, these companies have&nbsp;<strong>usurped the identity</strong>&nbsp;of authorized investment firms; namely Alpha Connect Capital GmbH, Dutch Options and Futures Institute BV, International Financial Advisers SARL, Omicron Investment Management GmbH, Oranjeveste BV and PMB Capital LTD.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>How to avoid the trap?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA&nbsp;encourages you to follow the recommendations below in order to prevent being defrauded:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Take the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">test</a></strong>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of&nbsp;promises of completely disproportionate returns.</strong>&nbsp;Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Do</strong>&nbsp;<strong>not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check</strong>&nbsp;<strong>whether the company holds an authorization</strong>&nbsp;by searching the lists published on the FSMA website –&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>Check your provider</strong></a>.<strong>&nbsp;Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong>&nbsp;published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal"><strong>IOSCO</strong></a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money. &nbsp;<br>
 <br>
 On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;provided. In addition, all the 'companies' about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium"><strong>List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</strong></a>' published on the FSMA website.<br>
 <br>
 <strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.<br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary&nbsp;</strong>of unsolicited phone calls/emails&nbsp;<strong>(cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to&nbsp;pay money into bank accounts in countries that have nothing to do with the company</strong>&nbsp;that is approaching you, or your own place of residence.</li>
 <li><strong>Never invest in a product if you do not fully understand what is being offered.</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong>&nbsp;if the payout of returns is conditional on an<strong>&nbsp;additional payment&nbsp;</strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud<strong>.</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>What to do if you are victim of fraud?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify">If you think you are the victim of fraud, make sure&nbsp;you&nbsp;<strong>do not pay any additional sums&nbsp;</strong>to your contact.&nbsp;<strong>Note</strong>: this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to try to obtain one last payment.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Also,&nbsp;<strong>contact</strong>&nbsp;the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.police.be/en"><strong>local police</strong></a>&nbsp;immediately to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA</strong>&nbsp;to the scam&nbsp;via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly&nbsp;</strong>and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-26T12:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68059</guid>
    </item>
