<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against recovery room fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-recovery-room-fraud-2</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The</strong><strong> FSMA is again warning the Belgian public against recovery room fraud. </strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Recovery room fraud is a practice whereby fraudsters offer to help <strong>victims of investment fraud</strong> to obtain compensation for their losses or to <strong>recover their lost assets</strong>. This may, for example, take the form of offering to buy the victims’ worthless shares or to initiate legal proceedings on their behalf.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Generally, the fraudsters contact their victims by phone or by e-mail. The FSMA has noted, however, that victims sometimes come into contact with the so-called ‘recovery rooms’ while conducting internet searches or via social media. When introducing themselves, fraudsters and their companies pass themselves off as law firms or accountants, and sometimes as police services or financial supervisors. The fraudsters do not hesitate to misuse the identity information of existing companies or official institutions in order to appear trustworthy. In addition, they sometimes claim that victims should not inform anyone of this offer in order not to hinder their investigation.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The fraudsters always charge a <strong>fee</strong> for their services. Victims of investment fraud must <strong>pay the fee in advance</strong>. This is a clear indication that it is a recovery room. The payment is demanded, for example, allegedly to cover certain administrative or legal costs or to pay taxes. These are purely <strong>fictitious costs</strong>, however. Once the fraudsters have received the fees, they disappear without a trace and it is almost impossible to recover the amounts paid.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Private-Union (cloned firm) (</strong><strong>www.private-union.com</strong><strong>)</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Private-Union, in turn, offers financial services and products without complying with Belgian financial legislation (no authorization / failure to publish a prospectus, etc.).</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Victims of investment fraud are often targeted twice by the same fraudsters: first the latter perpetrate investment fraud, and thereafter, recovery room fraud. The persons behind the investment fraud may also sell their victims’ contact information on to other fraudsters. <strong>Anyone who has ever been a victim of investment fraud needs to be aware that fraudsters may target their victims again or sell their personal data on to others.</strong></p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>How can you recognize and avoid recovery room fraud?</strong></h3>

<ul>
 <li>If you have been a victim of investment fraud, we advise you always to <strong>file a complaint</strong> with the local police.</li>
 <li>Be extremely careful if you find an advertisement on <strong>social media or the internet</strong> which offers to recover funds you have lost.</li>
 <li>If you receive <strong>unsolicited phone calls </strong>with an offer to recover funds you have lost, be sure to ask how that person found out that you have lost money. Reports of fraud are shared only with the judicial authorities and not with private companies.</li>
 <li>If you are asked to <strong>pay a set fee in advance</strong>, don’t respond but terminate all contact.</li>
 <li><strong>Financial supervisors </strong>such as the FSMA are not authorized to recover lost money and would therefore not take the initiative to contact victims of investment fraud.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-21T12:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">312903</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Ministers to offer virtual classes to secondary school students during Money Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/ministers-offer-virtual-classes-secondary-school-students-during-money-week</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>For its sixth edition, Money Week will resolutely take a digital turn. Today, Queen Mathilde has held a video chat with schoolchildren who were playing a budget game in class.&nbsp; During Money Week, the Prime Minister and several federal government Ministers will teach an online class on a financial topic. Students will have a chance to put their questions directly to the Ministers.</strong></p>

<p>Money Week is an initiative of Wikifin, the financial education programme of the FSMA (Financial Services and Markets Authority). The aim of the themed week is, as always, to focus on money matters: shining light on the importance of financial education. Numerous activities are offered in the schools all week long.</p>

<h3 class="green"><strong>Students can attend online classes taught by government Ministers</strong></h3>

<p>During this 6<sup>th</sup> edition of Money Week, students in years 2 and 3 of secondary school will have the opportunity to attend one or more classes taught by Ministers via videoconference, depending on their teacher’s choice. On the day of the class chosen, students will be able to put questions to the minister, who will reply in person.</p>

<p>The following classes will be offered between 22 and 26&nbsp;March 2021:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Alexander De Croo</strong>, Prime Minister, 'From barter to bitcoin: the evolution of means of payment in an increasingly digital economy'.</li>
 <li><strong>Pierre-Yves Dermagne</strong>, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for the Economy and Labour:&nbsp;'The labour market and the jobs of the future'.</li>
 <li><strong>Vincent Van Peteghem</strong>, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, in charge of the Fight against Tax Fraud:&nbsp;'Why do individuals pay tax? What obligations do Belgians have in this area?'.</li>
 <li><strong>David Clarinval</strong>, Minister of Small Businesses, the Self-Employed, SMEs and Agriculture and Institutional Reform:&nbsp;'What is the difference between the self-employed status for individuals and for companies?'.</li>
 <li><strong>Karine Lalieux</strong>, Minister of Pensions and Social Integration:&nbsp;'The workings of the social security system'.</li>
 <li><strong>Eva De Bleeker</strong>, State Secretary for the Budget and Consumer Protection:&nbsp;'The State budget and advice for managing your own budget'.</li>
 <li><strong>Jean-Paul Servais</strong>, Chairman of the FSMA: 'Sources of financing for businesses: from bank loans to crowdfunding'.</li>
</ul>

<p>The detailed schedule is available on <a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a>. The Ministers’ classes will then be made available to all teachers to use in class. They will be accessible on the Wikifin School platform, in the ‘teachers’ space on Wikifin.be. This initiative meets the growing demand for digital materials, and will be added to all the educational programmes offered to teachers who wish to incorporate financial and responsible consumer education into their classes.</p>

<h3 class="green"><strong>Students in year 1 of secondary school play the Wikifin Quiz</strong></h3>

<p>On Wednesday, 24 March, students in year 1 of secondary school will compete in the 3<sup>rd</sup> edition of the interactive quiz on money organized at the initiative of Wikifin and Febelfin.</p>

<p>The aim is to help students learn more about money questions and hone their financial skills. This event is much appreciated by both students and teachers, who can prepare their classes drawing on the educational materials available on Wikifin School.</p>

<h3 class="green"><strong>Primary school pupils can play the Just’in Budget educational game</strong></h3>

<p>This game familiarizes pupils in years 5 and 6 of primary school with how to manage a budget. The pupils are required to meet financial obligations while making consumer choices.</p>

<p>Each year, more than 70,000&nbsp;pupils play this game in class during Money Week. Today, Queen Mathilde held a video chat with two classes that were playing the game Just’In Budget. The classes involved were year 5 at the Mariaschool in Tervuren and year 6 of the Ecole libre de Soignies- Carrières.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Prime Minister Alexander De Croo: 'Money Week teaches young people to handle money matters and make financial decisions reasonably. I hope that many young people will become interested in taking a deeper look at the benefits of a strong economy and what they themselves can do to contribute to it. In the coming years, we will after all be needing all their talents to guide our country out of the current crisis.'</p>
</blockquote>

<blockquote>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA: 'With Money Week, we involve more than 70,000 pupils each year in the financial education activities offered by Wikifin, the financial education programme of the FSMA. For the 2021 edition, we have slightly modified our approach and are offering new activities by videoconference with top line guests, including government Ministers, who will teach classes virtually. A fine opportunity that enables students to put their questions directly to the political representatives, all of whom are experts in their field.'</p>
</blockquote>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-18T21:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67971</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>MiFID work programme for product governance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/mifid-work-programme-product-governance</link>
  <description>
<p>Regulated companies that produce or sell financial instruments must meet the MiFID II requirements as regards product governance. These rules differ depending on the role played by the companies in this area.</p>

<p>The FSMA wishes to help companies comply with these new product governance requirements by offering them a work programme (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/programmedetravail/programmedetravail_mifidii_productgovernance_fr.xlsx">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/werkprogramma/werkprogramma_mifidii_productgovernance_nl.xlsx">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only). The work programme gives an overview of the legislation and regulations applicable to product governance. It is intended as a practical guideline and resource for compliance with the MiFID rules of conduct. The work programme also applies to brokers in banking and investment services when carrying out their intermediation.</p>

<div class="box box-info box-small">
<p>Read more in the communication (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2021/fsma_2021_07_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2021/fsma_2021_07_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;...</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-17T18:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68005</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>What are atypical transactions, as defined in the anti-money laundering legislation?</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/what-are-atypical-transactions-defined-anti-money-laundering-legislation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is launching a series of animated films (available in French and Dutch only) about the rules intended to combat money-laundering and terrorist financing. The films are intended to help insurance intermediaries to apply these rules correctly.</strong></p>

<p>Via these new films, the FSMA seeks to raise the awareness of insurance intermediaries active in the field of life insurance of the risks they may encounter regarding money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>

<p>This film (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/510586366" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="https://vimeo.com/510582461" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only) focuses on atypical transactions and their analysis. It evokes the importance of the obligation to notify the Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CTIF-CFI), which is the cornerstone of an effective system to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-16T11:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67986</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Keynote: sustainable finance and sustainability disclosures by public companies</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/keynote-sustainable-finance-and-sustainability-disclosures-public-companies</link>
  <description>
<p>Mr Jean-Paul Servais, the Chairman of the FSMA, delivered the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20210312_afore_asifma_keynote.pdf" target="_blank">closing keynote</a> at the yearly EU-Asia Financial Services Dialogue organised by Asifma and Afore, in which more than 450 persons participated digitally. His remarks focused on the recent developments in the international landscape for sustainable finance and sustainability disclosures by public companies.</p>

<p>Mr Servais is directly involved in these discussions in his capacity of Vice Chair of the International Organization of Securities Commissions, whose members regulate over 95% of the world’s capital markets. In that capacity he takes part in the international governance of accounting standard-setting as chair of the IFRS Monitoring Board, which oversees the IFRS Foundation, and as co-chair of the Monitoring Group overseeing that audit-related standard setting is done in the public interest.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-15T13:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67970</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Publication of orders - Octopus Invest CV</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-orders-octopus-invest-cv</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA is authorized, pursuant to Article 29, §1, n) of the Law of 11 July 2018 on public offers of investment instruments and the admission to trading of investment instruments on a regulated market (hereafter the ‘Prospectus Law’), to disclose to the public any decision it has made in accordance with Article 29, §1, d) to l) of that Law, unless such disclosure would seriously jeopardize the financial markets or cause disproportionate damage to the parties involved.</p>

<p>The FSMA is invoking the above-mentioned possibility to make public its decision of 8 March 2021 in respect of Octopus-Invest co-op, with registered office at Chaussée de Tirlemont, 90 box 23, 5030 Gembloux and registered under Crossroads Bank of Enterprises number 0700.205.287:</p>

<ul>
 <li>ordering Octopus-Invest co-op to take the following measures, at the latest by 2 April 2021 (in accordance with Article 29, §1, d) in conjunction with Article 29, §1, b) of the Prospectus Law):
 <ul>
  <li>to provide the services of the FSMA with the full information requested in the course of the earlier correspondence with the FSMA,</li>
  <li>to adjust all advertising that Octopus-Invest co-op disseminates in line with the applicable rules and to confirm these adjustments to the services of the FSMA (providing the services with proof that the adjustments have been made)</li>
 </ul>
 </li>
 <li>ordering the offering to the public of cooperative shares in Octopus-Invest co-op to be suspended until the aforementioned measures have been taken (in accordance with Article 29, §1, e) of the Prospectus Law);</li>
 <li>informing Octopus-Invest co-op that this order means, among other things, that the company must immediately take offline the website <a href="http://www.octopus-invest.eu">www.octopus-invest.eu</a> and the advertisements disseminated via Facebook.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-12T23:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67905</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Publication of orders - JEX</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-orders-jex</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA is authorized, pursuant to Article 29, § 1, n) of the Law of 11 July 2018 on the public offer of investment instruments and the admission of investment instruments to trading on a regulated market (hereafter the ‘Prospectus Law’), to disclose to the public any decision it has made in accordance with Article 29, §1, d) to l) of that Law, unless such disclosure would seriously jeopardize the financial markets or cause disproportionate damage to the parties involved.</p>

<p>The FSMA is invoking the above-mentioned possibility to make the public its decision of 2 March 2021 in respect of JEX Technology Group BV, with registered office at Rivium Boulevard 156, 2909LK Capelle aan den Ijssel, the Netherlands and registered under Chamber of Commerce number 761711183:</p>

<ul>
 <li>ordering it to provide the services of the FSMA, at the latest by 16 March 2021, with the full information requested in the course of earlier correspondence (in accordance with Article 29, §1, d) in conjunction with Article 29, §1, b) of the Prospectus Law);</li>
 <li>ordering it to suspend immediately the offering to the public within Belgium of the shares and bonds of Jex Technology Group until all the information requested has been submitted to the services of the FSMA and the informtion notes required under Belgian law have been filed (in accordance with Article 29, §1, d) in conjunction with Article 29, §1, e) of the Prospectus Law);</li>
 <li>disclosing that this order means, among other things, that the Group must immediately block access for Belgian visitors to the website <a href="https://www.jex.nl/publiek/investeerders">https://www.jex.nl/publiek/investeerders</a> and stop the distribution of advertising (both by JEX itself and by anyone acting on behalf of JEX) to Belgian investors.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-12T11:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67906</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: the FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-5</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. Trading platforms also <strong>use mobile applications</strong> to lure victims. These fake ads or mobile applications often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad or downloading the mobile app and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Recently, these platforms have even hacked into user profiles on social media in order to further spread the aforementioned fake ads.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of the following new fake-ads and websites that refer to subsequent projects and training courses:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Loophole </strong>(www.bitcoin-loophole.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Idées Placement</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Yuan Pay App / Yuan Pay Group</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>4TFX</strong> (www.4tfx.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Binvesting </strong>(www.binvesting.com)</li>
 <li><strong>BitStarMarkets </strong>(www.bitstarmarkets.com)</li>
 <li><strong>BTC Brokerz</strong> (www.btcbrokerz.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Capitalfx </strong>(www.capitalfx.co)</li>
 <li><strong>Finexics</strong> (www.finexics.com and www.finexics.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Global Alliance </strong>(www.glballiance.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Mynetcoin </strong>(www.mynetcoin.net)</li>
 <li><strong>Quantbitex </strong>(www.quantbitex.com)</li>
 <li><strong>STR Capital </strong>(www.str-capital.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Tradezmarket </strong>(www.tradezmarket.com)</li>
 <li><strong>UnixBroker </strong>(www.unixbroker.com)</li>
 <li><strong>XTRgate </strong>(www.xtrgate.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:&nbsp;<strong>always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-10T14:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67812</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent use of the name and logo of the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-use-name-and-logo-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the fraudulent use of the name and logo of the FSMA with the intention of misleading consumers.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA was recently informed that consumers are being contacted by email or phone by individuals who claim to be members of the FSMA’s staff and to be able to help people who were previously victims of fraud recover the losses incurred. Those persons also report having received contractual documents featuring the logo and the name of the FSMA.&nbsp; These are cases of '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22955">recovery room</a>' fraud.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">To this end, fraudsters have used email addresses ending with '<strong>@fsmabelgium.com'</strong>. Emails received from such email addresses are <strong>not</strong> from the FSMA and should be considered fraudulent.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Whatever the scenario, these are cases of identity theft, whereby swindlers try to extort money and/or information from their victims. Information the FSMA has received has thus been forwarded to judicial authorities.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA recommends that consumers exercise extreme caution if they receive unsolicited contacts and warns against responding to any request for payment for financial services and/or products supposedly offered by the FSMA. <strong>The FSMA is not a financial institution</strong> and does not offer financial services or products to consumers. Moreover, supervisory authorities such as the FSMA are <strong>not competent to recover lost funds</strong>, and therefore will never contact investment fraud victims for this purpose. Lastly, the FSMA points out that it never asks consumers to share personal financial data or to pay for certain services. If you have the least doubt, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">the consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-09T17:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67813</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Sustainability-related disclosures in the financial services sector</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/sustainability-related-disclosures-financial-services-sector</link>
  <description>
<p>Communication FSMA_2021_06 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2021/fsma_2021_06_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a>&nbsp;-&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2021/fsma_2021_06_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;informs companies of the entry into force of European Regulation (EU) 2019/2088 on sustainability-related disclosures in the financial services sector (also known as the ‘Disclosure Regulation’ or ‘SFDR’). It clarifies the rules that apply both to companies and to products, as well as the expectations of the FSMA in this regard. These rules enter into force on 10 March 2021.</p>

<p>The FSMA has been designated the competent authority to supervise compliance with the provisions of the Regulation. Its task is to ensure that the information published by companies on sustainability are accurate, clear, not misleading, adequate and transparent, so as to avoid any risk of ‘greenwashing’.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-09T15:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67879</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Financial sanctions and the obligations under the anti-money laundering legislation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/financial-sanctions-and-obligations-under-anti-money-laundering-legislation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is launching a series of animated films (available in French and Dutch only) about the rules intended to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The films are intended to help insurance intermediaries to apply the anti-money laundering rules correctly.</strong></p>

<p>Via a new series of animated films, the FSMA seeks to raise the awareness of insurance intermediaries active in the field of life insurance of the risks they are may encounter regarding money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>

<p>This film&nbsp;(available in&nbsp;<a href="https://vimeo.com/510589397" target="_blank">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://vimeo.com/510588704" target="_blank">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)&nbsp;explains the concept of ‘financial sanctions’ and sets out the obligations that arise from the detection of a person or entity to whom such sanctions apply.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-05T21:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67819</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Antares (www.antares.trade)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/antares-wwwantarestrade</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the irregular activities of </strong><strong>Antares, which is active via www.antares.trade.</strong><strong> This company offers investment services in Belgium without respecting the Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Antares is not authorized as an investment firm in Belgium. Antares is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">However, this does not stop this company from selling so-called '<strong>investment packages</strong>' over the internet, promising <strong>unrealistic returns</strong>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the system this company offers clearly resembles that of a <strong>pyramid scheme</strong> or, at the very least, a Ponzi fraud. You can find more information about these types of fraud on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">the website of the FSMA</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus strongly advises <strong>against responding to any offer of financial services made by </strong><strong>Antares</strong> and against transferring funds to any bank account number this company might mention. <strong>The FSMA also warns you that when you invest funds through unauthorized firms, it is often very difficult to recover these amounts.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search engine</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-04T11:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67794</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>What additional measures of vigilance does an intermediary need to take in respect of ‘politically exposed persons’ </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/what-additional-measures-vigilance-does-intermediary-need-take-respect-politically-exposed</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is launching a series of animated films (available in French and Dutch only) about the rules intended to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The films are intended to help insurance intermediaries to apply the anti-money laundering rules correctly.</strong></p>

<p>Via a new series of animated films, the FSMA seeks to raise the awareness of insurance intermediaries active in the field of life insurance of the risks they may encounter regarding money laundering and terrorist financing.</p>

<p>This film&nbsp;(available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/510591229" target="_blank">French</a> and <a href="https://vimeo.com/510589732" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only) goes into the concept of ‘politically exposed persons’ in greater detail and explains what additional measures of vigilance an intermediary must take in respect of such persons.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-03-02T10:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67747</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Okuras Global Capital (www.okuras-global.capital)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/okuras-global-capital-wwwokuras-globalcapital</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of Okuras Global Capital, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">Okuras Global Capital is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p><p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67432">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 2 February 2021.</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by Okuras Global Capital and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p><p class="rtejustify">Okuras Global Capital uses the following contact details:</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>Website:&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>www.okuras-global.capital<br><strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 38F Shinjuku i-Land Tower, 6 Chome-5-1 Nishishinjuku, Tokyo, Japan<br><strong>Email</strong>:&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; contact@okuras-global.capital<br><strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; +81 3 4590 0730</p><p class="rtejustify">Okuras Global Capital appears to have links to Akita Michinoku Company, a company about which the FSMA has also issued a warning.</p><p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-02-02T14:30:00+01:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">67439</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Hepburn Investment (www.hepburninvestment.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/hepburn-investment-wwwhepburninvestmentcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of </strong><strong>Hepburn Investment</strong><strong>, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Hepburn Investment is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67432">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 2 February 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by &nbsp;Hepburn Investment and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Hepburn Investment uses the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Website:&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>www.hepburninvestment.com<br>
<strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; First Floor, 22 Garden Road, Central, Hong Kong<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;14 Gancheng Street, Nantun District, Taichung City, Taiwan<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;411 Dongyuhang Rd, Hongkou Qu, Shanghai, China<br>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;4-chōme-29-7, Hirai Edogawa City, Tokyo, Japan<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; clients@hepburninvestment.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+852 5808 0268</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-02-02T14:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67437</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Greenbridge International (https://www.greenbridgeinternational.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/greenbridge-international-httpswwwgreenbridgeinternationalcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of </strong><strong>GreenBridge International</strong><strong>, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">GreenBridge International is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67432">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 2 February 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by GreenBridge International and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">GreenBridge International uses the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Website: &nbsp;&nbsp; </strong>https://www.greenbridgeinternational.com<br>
<strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2 Wall Street, Suite 501, New York, NY 10005, USA<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;admin@greenbridgeinternational.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+1 (646) 547 11815058654062</p>

<p class="rtejustify">GreenBridge International has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of the <a href="https://www.sec.gov/enforce/public-alerts/unregistered-soliciting-entities/greenbridge-international">USA</a>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>

<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: The FSMA warns the public against unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-unauthorized-activities-1</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p>The companies are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67433">Belgius Capital (www.belgius.com)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67434">Brock Holdings (https://brockholdings.com/)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67435">Cortez Capital (http://cortezcap-hk.com/)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67436">Greenbridge International (https://www.greenbridgeinternational.com)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67437">Hepburn Investment (www.hepburninvestment.com)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67438">Kasimayari Group (www.kasimayari.com)</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67439">Okuras Global Capital (www.okuras-global.capital)</a></li>
</ul>

<p>The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p>Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be '<strong>boiler rooms</strong>'.</p>

<p><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p>

<p>Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p>As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p>

<p>The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term 'boiler room'), insisting that they keep making further payments. <strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p>

<p>In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.<br>
 <br>
 On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website.<br>
 <br>
 <strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.<br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p>If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-02-02T13:15:00+01:00</pubDate>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>Has a bank approached you with a tempting savings plan offer? Be wary, fraudsters may have usurped its name!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/has-bank-approached-you-tempting-savings-plan-offer-be-wary-fraudsters-may-have-usurped</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA has recently received numerous complaints from consumers who have been approached by companies usurping the names of certain banks to present them with savings plans offering extremely high yields. Behind these tantalizing offers, however, are fraudsters whose sole aim is to steal your savings. </strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone or by e-mail without having taken any prior initiative themselves or after having entered their contact details on an online form. They are offered savings plans, with the promise of returns in excess of market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money!</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA has recently observed that fraudsters usurped the names of several banks to deceive consumers. <strong>The FSMA has received reports about scammers using the following names:&nbsp; </strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Lloyds Bank</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with '@lbcmarkets.info', '@lbpsecure.com' and '@lseclient.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Revolut-Trade</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with '@revolut-trade.com';</li>
 <li><strong>Barclays Bank</strong>, using e-mail addresses ending with '@bb-client.info'.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Fraudsters might also usurp the names of other financial institutions.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Swindlers redirect consumers wishing to take up the offer to an <strong>online platform</strong> where they can monitor the progress of their investment. The FSMA notably received reports about such a website, which usurps the name and the logo of the London Stock Exchange: <strong>www.lse-client.com / www.lse-asset.com</strong><strong>.</strong></p>

<h2 class="blue"><strong>How does the fraud start?</strong></h2>

<p class="rtejustify">There are different ways in which scammers may approach you.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">You may be approached&nbsp;<strong>after having expressed interest in an advertisement</strong>&nbsp;on social media or on other websites boasting high interest rates. These ads will often offer to check if you are '<strong>eligible to invest</strong>'. In the next few days, you will receive a phone call from a telephone salesperson offering you investments. For more information, you can consult our warnings of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/62512">30 September 2019</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/66649">3 December 2020</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">You may also be contacted&nbsp;<strong>by phone (or by e-mail) without having taken any prior initiative yourself</strong>. This technique, known as 'cold calling', is widely used in investment fraud.</p>

<h2 class="blue"><strong>What do they offer?</strong></h2>

<p class="rtejustify">Once the first contact has been made, the fraudsters will usually send you a proposal by e-mail, followed by frequent phone calls.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">This highly professional-looking e-mail will summarize a high-yield investment proposal, detailed in a multi-page contract often titled 'Savings Agreement' or 'Active Savings Account'.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">As an example, these e-mails are frequently drafted as follows:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><img alt src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/images/example_mail_creditfraude.jpg"></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The script is always the same: they lure you in with yields that are considerably better than those offered by <strong>conventional savings accounts</strong>.</p>

<h2 class="blue"><strong>How to avoid falling into the trap?</strong></h2>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA&nbsp;encourages you to follow the recommendations below in order to prevent being defrauded:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Take the&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599"><strong>test</strong></a>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of&nbsp;promises of completely disproportionate returns.</strong>&nbsp;Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Do</strong>&nbsp;<strong>not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check</strong>&nbsp;<strong>whether the company holds an authorization</strong>&nbsp;by searching the lists published on the FSMA website –&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>Check your provider</strong></a>.&nbsp;<strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong>&nbsp;published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal"><strong>IOSCO</strong></a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money. &nbsp;<br>
 <br>
 On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;provided. In addition, all the 'companies' about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium"><strong>List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</strong></a>' published on the FSMA website.<br>
 <br>
 <strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.<br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary&nbsp;of unsolicited phone calls/emails&nbsp;(cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to&nbsp;pay money into bank accounts in countries that have nothing to do with the company</strong>&nbsp;that is approaching you, or your own place of residence.</li>
 <li><strong>Never invest in a product if you do not fully understand what is being offered.</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong>&nbsp;if the payout of returns is conditional on an<strong>&nbsp;additional payment&nbsp;</strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud<strong>.</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt&nbsp;</strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<h2 class="blue"><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></h2>

<p class="rtejustify">If you think you are the victim of fraud, <strong>make sure you do not pay any additional sums to your contact.</strong> Be especially wary if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Also, immediately&nbsp;<strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a>&nbsp;to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA</strong>&nbsp;to the scam via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly&nbsp;</strong>and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-29T21:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67423</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The Chairman of the FSMA appointed Co-Chair of the Monitoring Group, the body responsible for advancing the public interest in relation to international audit standard setting</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-appointed-co-chair-monitoring-group-body-responsible-advancing-public-interest</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Mr Jean-Paul Servais, has been appointed by IOSCO as Co-Chair of the Monitoring Group.</strong></p>

<p>As the Vice-Chair of the Board of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, also chairs the Monitoring Board of the IFRS Foundation.</p>

<p>He was appointed Co-Chair of the Monitoring Group, alongside Mr Sagar Teotia, Chief Accountant of the US Securities and Exchange Commission.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Group is a body that consists of a group of international institutions and financial regulatory bodies committed to advancing the public interest in areas related to international audit standard setting and audit quality. Its members include the World Bank, the European Commission, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board (FSB).</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais: “I feel privileged to take on the role of Monitoring Group Co-Chair together with Sagar at this critical juncture in the implementation of important reforms in international audit standard setting. I look forward to working closely with my Monitoring Group colleagues towards our shared goals of an independent and efficient audit standard-setting process that serves the public interest. This appointment attests to the confidence shown in the FSMA, which also hosts the Belgian Audit Oversight College.”</p>

<p>We invite you to consult the <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS591.pdf" target="_blank">press release</a> published by the Monitoring Group, which provides further details about the Group’s mission.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-28T11:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67404</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Communication on the suitability statement for retail clients</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/communication-suitability-statement-retail-clients</link>
  <description>
<p>Regulated companies (hereafter, ‘companies’) that provide investment advice must first give their retail clients a suitability statement, in which they set out what their advice consists of and explain why it is suited to the client. The suitability statement is mandatory, even where the advice does not lead to a transaction. The FSMA has noted that companies vary greatly in the way they fulfil this obligation.</p>

<p>The FSMA intends this Communication FSMA_2021_04 (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2021/fsma_2021_04_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2021/fsma_2021_04_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>) to further clarify this obligation and provide recommendations regarding what companies must, at a minimum, include in the suitability statement. The FSMA will use this Communication as a guideline in conducting its supervision.</p>

<p>The Communication can also serve as a guide for the preparation of the report on the annual review of the investment advice that companies provide to retail clients along with a periodic suitability assessment or when conducting &nbsp;portfolio management.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-26T17:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67406</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Opinion of the Commission on Supplementary Pensions regarding the FSMA’s research into the funding of defined benefit pension plans</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/opinion-commission-supplementary-pensions-regarding-fsmas-research-funding-defined-benefit</link>
  <description>
<p>The Commission has conducted an analysis of the FSMA’s research into the funding of defined benefit pension plans as well as of its feedback statement. The Commission agrees with the recommendations of the FSMA, and in particular with the recommendation to use sufficiently prudent methods of financing. In addition, it emphasises the importance of transparency about the funding of pension commitments. A strengthening of the legal framework is not (yet) appropriate, in the Commission’s opinion. Instead, it considers it better to wait and see the impact of the obligations and recommendations now set out by the FSMA.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the advice ... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/advorg/2021/advice_40_ap_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/advorg/2021/advice_40_ap_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-25T22:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67339</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>eCorporate: adaptations to enable filings in European Single Electronic Format</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/ecorporate-adaptations-enable-filings-european-single-electronic-format</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has adapted its eCorporate portal to enable filing of annual financial reports prepared in the European Single Electronic Format (ESEF). More information can be found in the communication <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/2021/fsma_2021_03_en.pdf">FSMA_2021_03</a>.</p><p>The circular <em>eCorporate </em><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/nl/2013/fsma_2013_16_nl.pdf">FSMA_2013_16</a><em>: transmission of documents</em> has also been updated to reflect those modifications. Changes are indicated by a line in the margin.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Global Bank Investment (www.gbk-investment.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/global-bank-investment-wwwgbk-investmentcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the fraudulent activities of</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Global Bank Investment, a company that is offering credit illegally to consumers.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">Global Bank Investment is not authorized as a lender or registered as a credit intermediary in Belgium.&nbsp;<strong>Therefore, Global Bank Investment may not offer credit in Belgium.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">According to the information available to the FSMA, it seems that the credit being offered by Global Bank Investment is&nbsp;<strong>entirely fraudulent</strong>. The company operates as follows: if a consumer tries to take up the offer, he or she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover various&nbsp;<strong>costs&nbsp;</strong>relating to the credit (for example, so-called dossier fees or an insurance premium). Once these costs have been paid, the consumer does not receive the credit, and it is almost impossible to recover the sums that were paid. More information about this type of consumer credit fraud is available in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67291"><strong>general warning</strong></a>&nbsp;published by the FSMA on 18 January 2021.</p><p class="rtejustify">Global Bank Investment usurps the logos of authorized credit institutions.</p><p class="rtejustify">This company also seems to have links with ‘Krediet Service’, for which the FSMA has also issued a warning.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore very strongly advises against responding to any offers of credit made by&nbsp;Global Bank Investment and against making any payment to the company.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">Global Bank Investment uses the website<strong>&nbsp;www.gbk-investment.com</strong>, and the email addresses bank@gbk-investment.com and contact@services-krediet.com</p><p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-18T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67296</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Hontabal invest (www.hontabalinvest.com) (cloned firm)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/hontabal-invest-wwwhontabalinvestcom-cloned-firm</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the fraudulent activities of</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Hontabal Invest, a company that is offering credit illegally to consumers&nbsp;and is using the name of an existing company, SAS Hontabal Invest, to appear credible. This is a case of identity theft.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Hontabal Invest is not authorized as a lender or registered as a credit intermediary in Belgium.&nbsp;<strong>Therefore, Hontabal Invest may not offer credit in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">According to the information available to the FSMA, it seems that the credit being offered by Hontabal Invest is&nbsp;<strong>entirely fraudulent</strong>. The company operates as follows: if a consumer tries to take up the offer, he or she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover various&nbsp;<strong>costs&nbsp;</strong>relating to the credit (for example, so-called dossier fees or an insurance premium). Once these costs have been paid, the consumer does not receive the credit, and it is almost impossible to recover the sums that were paid. More information about this type of consumer credit fraud is available in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67291"><strong>general warning</strong></a>&nbsp;published by the FSMA on 18 January 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore very strongly advises against responding to any offers of credit made by&nbsp;Hontabal Invest and against making any payment to the company.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Hontabal Invest uses the website<strong>&nbsp;www.hontabalinvest.com</strong>, and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Email:&nbsp;</strong>contact@hontabalinvest.com<br>
<strong>Tel.:&nbsp;</strong>+33 7 57 936 567</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-18T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67297</guid>
    </item>

<p class="rtejustify">According to the information available to the FSMA, it seems that the credit being offered by Atlantix Services is&nbsp;<strong>entirely fraudulent</strong>. The company operates as follows: if a consumer tries to take up the offer, he or she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover various&nbsp;<strong>costs&nbsp;</strong>relating to the credit (for example, so-called dossier fees or an insurance premium). Once these costs have been paid, the consumer does not receive the credit, and it is almost impossible to recover the sums that were paid. More information about this type of consumer credit fraud is available in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67291"><strong>general warning</strong></a>&nbsp;published by the FSMA on 18 January 2021.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore very strongly advises against responding to any offers of credit made by&nbsp;Atlantix Services and against making any payment to the company.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Atlantix Services uses the website<strong>&nbsp;www.atlantix-services.com</strong>, and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Address:&nbsp;</strong>Quellinstraat 49, 2018 Antwerp, Belgium<br>
<strong>Email:&nbsp;</strong>contact@atlantix-services.com<br>
<strong>Tel.:&nbsp;</strong>+32 460 24 52 32</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-18T10:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67292</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent credit offers </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-credit-offers</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of unauthorized lenders who offer false credits to consumers.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA has received several reports from consumers about&nbsp;<strong>fraudulent credit offers</strong>&nbsp;made via the internet. Consumers get thus in touch with these providers in a variety of ways: they are&nbsp;<strong>approached unsolicited&nbsp;</strong>via mail or social media (Facebook, WhatsApp, …), or they find advertisements on the&nbsp;<strong>internet</strong>. Sometimes, profiles on social media are also hacked to promote fake credits.</p>

<p>Fraudulent credit offers relate to&nbsp;<strong>false credits</strong>&nbsp;offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions and they do not shy away from using the names of authorized entities. These are cases of&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22959"><strong>cloned firms</strong></a>.</p>

<p>These fraudsters offer consumers&nbsp;credits at very<strong>&nbsp;attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover&nbsp;<strong>costs</strong>&nbsp;relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p>Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly impossible to recover the amounts paid.</p>

<p><strong>The FSMA thus advises absolutely against responding to such offers of credit.</strong></p>

<p>Companies operating unlawfully and against which the FSMA warns the public are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67292"><strong>Atlantix Services</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67293"><strong>Blessing Service</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67294"><strong>Finev Finance</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67295"><strong>FNL Groep</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67296"><strong>Global Bank Investment</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67297"><strong>Hontabal Invest</strong></a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67298"><strong>Private Finance Group</strong></a></li>
</ul>

<p><strong>***</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA offers the following&nbsp;<strong>general recommendations&nbsp;</strong>for recognizing these fraudulent offers of credit:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary if you receive a</strong><strong>n&nbsp;unsolicited credit offer&nbsp;</strong>via the internet or via social media.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware of any offers of credit on unusually favourable terms&nbsp;</strong>(a loan that is very large in relation to the consumer's financial situation, at an extremely low interest rate, with a particularly long repayment period, etc.) that would not usually be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you first pay a sum of money intended to cover certain costs before issuing the loan</strong>. The justifications given for such a payment can vary: they may be called an insurance premium with a view to insuring the lender against default on the loan, dossier fees, authentication costs, administrative costs, etc. These costs are purely fictitious. Once the money has been paid, the 'lender' disappears and the victim never recovers the money transferred.</li>
 <li><strong>Find out whether the lender has the requisite authorization</strong>. Via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search engine</strong></a>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Consider doing a search for the person using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find testimonials by people who have already been approached by him or her. But be alert, as sometimes these are falsely positive testimonials posted by the lenders themselves in order to gain the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, don't hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2021-01-18T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67291</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Brookfield Investment fund PLC (https://brookfieldinvestmentfundsplc.net) - Cloned firm</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/brookfield-investment-fund-plc-httpsbrookfieldinvestmentfundsplcnet-cloned-firm</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the website named https://brookfieldinvestmentfundsplc.net, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ is&nbsp;not authorized&nbsp;to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the offer made via that website shows&nbsp;<strong>numerous indications of fraud</strong>&nbsp;and seems to be similar to the fraudulent wealth management or savings plan offers denounced by the FSMA in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59991"><strong>warning</strong></a>&nbsp;it published on 1 March 2019.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Brookfield Investment fund PLC usurps the name of the company called Brookfield Investment Funds (UCITS), an investment company established in Ireland.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, this ‘company’ has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of the United Kindgom (<a href="https://www.fca.org.uk/news/warnings/brookfield-investment-funds-plc-clone-fca-authorised-schedule-5-firm">FCA</a>) on 24 April 2020.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Brookfield Investment fund PLC uses the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Website</strong>: &nbsp;https://brookfieldinvestmentfundsplc.net/<br>
<strong>Email</strong>: info@brookfieldinvestmentfundsplc.net<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>: +353 1 691 7462<br>
<strong>Addresses</strong>: London and Dublin</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus&nbsp;<strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong>&nbsp;made by that website and&nbsp;<strong>against transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-30T17:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67010</guid>
    </item>
<item>

  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the website named www.asse-groupe.com, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ is&nbsp;not authorized&nbsp;to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p><p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the offer made via that website shows&nbsp;<strong>numerous indications of fraud</strong>&nbsp;and seems to be similar to the fraudulent wealth management or savings plan offers denounced by the FSMA in the&nbsp;<strong>warning</strong>&nbsp;it published on 1 March 2019.</p><p class="rtejustify">Asse-groupe uses the website www.asse-groupe.com (now inactive) and the following contact details:</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>Email </strong>: contact@asse-groupe.com<br><strong>Tel</strong>. : +33971076836</p><p class="rtejustify">Asse-groupe (www.asse-groupe.com) has also been the subject of a warning by the French supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/fr/espace-epargnants/proteger-son-epargne/listes-noires-et-mises-en-garde?page=0&amp;key=asse">AMF</a>) on 9 November 2020.</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus&nbsp;<strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong>&nbsp;made by that website and&nbsp;<strong>against transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
