<item>
  <title>Fraudulent wealth management offers: Stay vigilant!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-wealth-management-offers-stay-vigilant</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>In the past few weeks, the FSMA has received new complaints from consumers who have been approached by companies offering wealth management. The FSMA warns consumers against these tempting offers, because often behind them are fraudsters who are not authorized to make such offers, the sole aim of which is to steal your savings.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The principle always remains the same: victims are contacted by telephone without having asked for it or after having entered their contact details on an online form. They are offered wealth management services, with the promise of returns in excess of the market returns and most often with a capital guarantee. But in the end the result remains the same: the victims find themselves unable to recover their money (or at least all of it)!</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Over the past few weeks, the FSMA has been informed of fraudulent activities conducted by:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67009">Asse-Groupe</a> (www.asse-groupe.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67010">Brookfield Investment fund PLC</a> (</strong><strong>https://brookfieldinvestmentfundsplc.net/)</strong></li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67080">Create Capital Invest</a> (www.createcapitalinvest.com) </strong></li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67081">Patrimoine Connect</a> (</strong><strong>https://4gste3-12qxt9901mnd.com)</strong></li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/67082">Vuelex</a> (</strong><strong>https://www.vuelex.com/fr/)</strong></li>
</ul>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>How does the fraud start?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify">There are different ways in which scammers may approach you.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">You may be approached&nbsp;<strong>after having expressed interest in an advertisement</strong>&nbsp;on social media or on other websites boasting high interest rates. In the next few days, you will receive a phone call from a telephone salesperson offering you investments. For more information, you can consult our warnings of <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/62512">30 September 2019</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/66649">3 December 2020</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">You may also be contacted&nbsp;<strong>by phone without having taken any prior initiative yourself</strong>. This technique, known as 'cold calling', is widely used in investment fraud. You will then be invited to check the 'company’s' website and to open a personal account. Sometimes you will also be offered a contract. Contact will subsequently be by e-mail and telephone.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Beware</strong>, and do not trust the 'professional' look of the website to which you are referred; fraudsters clearly do everything they can to appear as legitimate as possible.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>What do they offer?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify">You may be offered a variety of investments. However, consumers have over the last few months frequently reported being offered&nbsp;<strong>wealth management contracts</strong>. In essence, you give them your money and they manage it for you, with the promise of high – or even guaranteed – returns.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In other cases, consumers are asked to open an&nbsp;<strong>account (savings or otherwise)</strong>, the key again being high – or even guaranteed – returns.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>How to avoid falling into the trap?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA&nbsp;encourages you to follow the recommendations below in order to prevent being defrauded:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Take the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">test</a></strong>&nbsp;on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</li>
 <li>Be wary of<strong>&nbsp;promises of completely disproportionate returns.</strong>&nbsp;Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li>
 <li><strong>Do</strong>&nbsp;<strong>not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check</strong>&nbsp;<strong>whether the company holds an authorization</strong>&nbsp;by searching the lists published on the FSMA website –&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>Check your provider</strong></a>.&nbsp;Be wary as well of<strong> 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong>&nbsp;published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal"><strong>IOSCO</strong></a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money. &nbsp;<br>
 <br>
 On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en"><strong>search function</strong></a>&nbsp;provided. In addition, all the 'companies' about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium"><strong>List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</strong></a>' published on the FSMA website.<br>
 <br>
 <strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.<br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary&nbsp;</strong>of unsolicited phone calls/emails&nbsp;<strong>(cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to&nbsp;pay money into bank accounts in countries that have nothing to do with the company</strong>&nbsp;that is approaching you, or your own place of residence.</li>
 <li><strong>Never invest in a product if you do not fully understand what is being offered.</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong>&nbsp;if the payout of returns is conditional on an<strong>&nbsp;additional payment&nbsp;</strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud<strong>.</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt&nbsp;</strong>about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>What to do if you have been the victim of fraud?</strong></h3>

<p class="rtejustify">If you think you are the victim of fraud, <strong>make sure you do not pay any additional sums to your contact.</strong> Be especially wary if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Also, immediately&nbsp;<strong>contact&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://www.police.be/en"><strong>the&nbsp;local police</strong></a>&nbsp;to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA</strong>&nbsp;to the scam via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly&nbsp;</strong>and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-30T17:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67008</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Vuelex (www.vuelex.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/vuelex-wwwvuelexcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the website named www.vuelex.com, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ is&nbsp;not authorized&nbsp;to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the offer made via that website shows&nbsp;<strong>numerous indications of fraud</strong>&nbsp;and seems to be similar to the fraudulent wealth management or savings plan offers denounced by the FSMA in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59991"><strong>warning</strong></a>&nbsp;it published on 1 March 2019.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Vuelex uses the website www.vuelex.com and pretends to have offices in China and Japan.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ has also been the subject of a warning by the French supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/fr/espace-epargnants/proteger-son-epargne/listes-noires-et-mises-en-garde?page=0&amp;key=vuelex">AMF</a>) on 29 October 2020.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus&nbsp;<strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong>&nbsp;made by that website and&nbsp;<strong>against transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-30T10:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67082</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Patrimoine Connect (https://4gste3-12qxt9901mnd.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/patrimoine-connect-https4gste3-12qxt9901mndcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the company named Patrimoine Connect, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ is&nbsp;not authorized&nbsp;to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the offer made via that website shows&nbsp;<strong>numerous indications of fraud</strong>&nbsp;and seems to be similar to the fraudulent wealth management or savings plan offers denounced by the FSMA in the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59991"><strong>warning</strong></a>&nbsp;it published on 1 March 2019.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The consumers approached by Patrimoine Connect were sent a link to the website https://4gste3-12qxt9901mnd.com.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Patrimoine Connect uses the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Email</strong>: t.stegemans@patrimoine-connect.com<br>
<strong>Tel</strong>.: 0973037618</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus&nbsp;<strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong>&nbsp;made by that website and&nbsp;<strong>against transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-30T10:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67081</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Create Capital Invest (www.createcapitalinvest.com)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/create-capital-invest-wwwcreatecapitalinvestcom</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of the website named www.createcapitalinvest.com, which offers investment services without complying with Belgian financial legislation.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ is&nbsp;not authorized&nbsp;to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p><p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the offer made via that website shows&nbsp;<strong>numerous indications of fraud</strong>&nbsp;and seems to be similar to the fraudulent wealth management or savings plan offers denounced by the FSMA in the&nbsp;<strong>warning</strong>&nbsp;it published on 1 March 2019.</p><p class="rtejustify">Create Capital Invest uses the website www.createcapitalinvest.com.</p><p class="rtejustify">This ‘company’ has also been the subject of a warning by the French supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/fr/espace-epargnants/proteger-son-epargne/listes-noires-et-mises-en-garde?page=0&amp;key=createcapitalinvest">AMF</a>) on 17 July 2020.</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA thus&nbsp;<strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong>&nbsp;made by that website and&nbsp;<strong>against transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, prudence is necessary.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don't hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-30T10:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67080</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: The FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-4</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning new fraudulent online trading platforms that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">The approach remains the same. These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. These methods or projects often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p><p class="rtejustify">Recently, these platforms have even hacked into user profiles on social media in order to further spread the aforementioned fake ads.</p><p class="rtejustify">Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p><ul><li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li><li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li></ul><p class="rtejustify">These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of the following new fake-ads and websites that refer to subsequent projects and training courses:</p><ul><li><strong>Bitcoin Buyer</strong></li><li><strong>Bitcoin Prime </strong>(www.bitcoinprime.net, https://bitcoinprime.software/, https://bitcoin-prime.net/)</li><li><strong>Immediate Edge </strong>(www.immediate-edge.co)</li></ul><p class="rtejustify">Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA therefore strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p><ul><li><strong>BitCapitals</strong> (www.bit-capitals.com)</li><li><strong>Brokerunity </strong>(www.brokerunity.com)</li><li><strong>Bubblext</strong> (www.bubblext.com)</li><li><strong>Cryptenix </strong>(www.cryptenix.com)</li><li><strong>FDI Funds</strong> (www.fdifunds.com)</li><li><strong>Financial Reserve Capital Management/Finance&nbsp;Reserves (FRCM)</strong>&nbsp;(www.financereserve.com, http://freserves.com/, https://financereserves.com/ and https://financeresm.com)</li><li><strong>GCG International </strong>(www.gcginternational.net)</li><li><strong>GFX Royal </strong>(www.gfxroyal.com)</li><li><strong>Global CTB </strong>(www.globalctb.com)</li><li><strong>Migotrade </strong>(www.migotrade.com&nbsp;and https://www.migotrade.net/)</li><li><strong>Safe IG </strong>(www.safeig.com)</li></ul><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">In order to avoid fraud, the FSMA addresses the following recommendations to investors:&nbsp;<strong>always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p><p class="rtejustify">Always verify if <strong>the company in question</strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p><p class="rtejustify">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><p class="rtejustify">Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify">For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-23T10:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66880</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Brexit: Information for Belgian policyholders</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/brexit-information-belgian-policyholders</link>
  <description>
<p>On 31 December 2020, the United Kingdom (UK plus Gibraltar) will withdraw from the European Union. Brexit has important consequences for the insurance companies and intermediaries that are active in Belgium on the basis of an authorization in the UK.</p>

<p>As from 1 January:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Insurance companies based in the UK may not launch new activities or extend existing contracts. They may continue, however, to ensure the regular performance of their existing insurance contracts, in the course of which they must guarantee compliance with the contractual obligations.</li>
 <li>Insurance intermediaries from the UK may no longer carry out distribution activities in respect of insurance.</li>
</ul>

<p>This of course applies only to companies or intermediaries that do not have an authorization to continue to carry out their activities in Belgium after Brexit.</p>

<p>The FSMA asks insurance companies and intermediaries from the UK to take measures before 31 December 2020 in order to limit the effects of Brexit on the contracts in their portfolio and to inform their Belgian policyholders as soon as possible of the consequences of Brexit for their existing contracts.</p>

<p>Are you a client of a British insurance company? In that case, we advise you to check before 31 December that you have adequate and complete information about the consequences of Brexit. If necessary, you can contact your insurance company or intermediary.</p>

<p>For more information, please see also the Brexit <a href="https://www.eiopa.europa.eu/sites/default/files/publications/consumer_guide_brexit_final.pdf" target="_blank">Consumer Guide</a> published by EIOPA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-22T18:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">67012</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Newsletter: AML – Annual activity report and animated films</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-aml-annual-activity-report-and-animated-films</link>
  <description>
<h3 class="blue"><strong>AML – ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT</strong></h3>

<p>In its Communication FSMA_2020_12 (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>) of 6 October 2020, the FSMA provides AMLCOs of entities subject to the Law of 18 September 2017 ('AML Law') with a <strong>guide (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12-01_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12-01_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>)&nbsp;to help them prepare their annual activity report</strong>. The guide offers a clear and comprehensive structure to establish this report.</p>

<p>The report must contain a number of specific items of information about the actions taken by the obliged entity during the past year to combat money laundering and terrorist financing (ML/TF).</p>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>ANIMATED FILMS: VIDEOS TO PROMOTE BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF AML LEGISLATION</strong></h3>

<p>The AML legislation is not new, and yet it continues to elicit discussion in the press. It must be implemented correctly in order to ensure that the combat against money laundering and terrorist financing is effective.</p>

<p>To help insurance intermediaries who are subject to this legislation, that is, insurance intermediaries who offer life insurance contracts and are bound by any exclusive tie, to go through this process, the FSMA decided to produce a number of animated films.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the newsletter&nbsp;...&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2020-12-18_newsletter4_aml_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2020-12-18_newsletter4_aml_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-18T14:45:00+01:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">66630</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Extension of the transition period for the old accredited exams per class of insurance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-extension-transition-period-old-accredited-exams-class-insurance</link>
  <description>
<p>In the light of the current public health crisis, a considerable number of exam sessions in the insurance sector were suspended.</p>

<p>It has therefore been decided that candidates who registered for the old accredited exams per class of insurance before 31 December 2020 will have three extra months to pass those exams.</p>

<p>This communication FSMA_2020_18 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_18_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_18_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) applies to persons who registered before 31 December 2020 for one or more accredited exams per class of insurance. If they pass the exam(s) in question between 1 January and 31 March 2021 inclusive, these results are acceptable as proof that they have the requisite professional knowledge.</p>

<p>The new, module-based exam system will, however, enter into force on 1 January 2021.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-15T17:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66797</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Brexit – Update – European passport for certain intermediaries and the impact of Brexit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-brexit-update-european-passport-certain-intermediaries-and-impact-brexit</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA regularly informs intermediaries and financial service providers via newsletters about topics of interest to them, such as changes to legislation and supervision. As we approach the end of 2020, the FSMA once again wishes to review certain developments in supervisory practice. In the coming days, you will receive brief newsletters about various topics, such as the impact of Brexit, the end of the transition period for ancillary insurance intermediaries, and the anti-money laundering legislation. To keep up to date with the developments, we advise everyone to consult these newsletters.</p>

<p>The current newsletter provides an update on the European passport for certain intermediaries and the impact of Brexit.</p>

<p>On <strong>31 December 2020, the transition period for Brexit comes to an end</strong>. After the departure &nbsp;of the United Kingdom (UK) from the European Union on 31 January 2020, a transition period allowed for all parties concerned to continue their activities under the European passport, giving them time to prepare for the period following 31 December 2020.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter&nbsp;... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2020-12-10_newsletter3_brexit_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2020-12-10_newsletter3_brexit_nl_.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-11T14:45:00+01:00</pubDate>

  <title>Newsletter: Ancillary insurance intermediaries – Reminder – Transitional period ends on 28/12/2020</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-ancillary-insurance-intermediaries-reminder-transitional-period-ends-28122020</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA regularly informs intermediaries and financial service providers via newsletters about topics of interest to them, such as changes to legislation and supervision. As we approach the end of 2020, the FSMA once again wishes to review certain developments in supervisory practice. In the coming days, you will receive brief newsletters about various topics, such as the impact of Brexit, the end of the transition period for ancillary insurance intermediaries, and the anti-money laundering legislation. To keep up to date with the developments, we advise everyone to consult these newsletters.</p>

<p>This newsletter reminds ancillary insurance intermediaries that the transitional period ends on 28 December 2020.</p>

<p>Were you active as an ancillary insurance intermediary on 28 December 2018 and wish to continue carrying out insurance distribution activities? Unless you are entitled to an exemption, <strong>you have until 28 December 2020</strong> to submit an application for registration with the FSMA.</p>

<item>
  <title>Be cautious on social media: Scammers use all sorts of tricks to circulate their fraudulent offers!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/be-cautious-social-media-scammers-use-all-sorts-tricks-circulate-their-fraudulent-offers</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Social media abound with false investment offers of </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55960"><strong>cryptocurrencies</strong></a><strong>, </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/61135"><strong>binary options and forex/CFD products</strong></a><strong>, 'investment wine'&nbsp;and the like, with fake offers of wealth management and </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/61981"><strong>fraudulent credit offers</strong></a><strong>. Swindlers 2.0 are constantly devising new strategies to make even more victims.</strong></p><p>Deceivers regularly use social media to disseminate their fraudulent investment offers. These are spread through sponsored ads on Facebook and Instagram, simple posts on Facebook, fake press articles or via chats between the scammer and the victim. For more information, please consult our <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/62512">warning</a> of 30 September 2019.</p><p>The FSMA has identified two new techniques used by swindlers to propagate their fraudulent offers on social media:</p><ul><li><h3 class="blue"><strong>Hacking of Facebook&nbsp;accounts: has one of your contacts come up with an offer that sounds too good to be true?&nbsp;</strong></h3></li></ul><p>You aren’t normally suspicious of your Facebook friends. Crooks are well aware of that! Be watchful because the identity of your contacts can be misused to trap you.</p><p>Fraudsters hack Facebook accounts and use these to promote investment or credit offers. They will for example publish on the account of one of your friends a post boasting of an investment offer providing an exceptional return. If you click on that post, the scammers will usually very quickly call you to present their fraudulent offer. Be all the more wary if you see that several persons are tagged on that post.</p><p>Fraudulent online trading platforms currently make a wide use of this technique. For more information on this type of fraud, please consult the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22954">website of the FSMA</a> as well as our <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/66498">warning</a> of 19&nbsp;November 2020.</p><ul><li><h3 class="blue"><strong>Fraudulent investment offers via dating sites and applications&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></h3></li></ul><p>Dating sites and apps such as Tinder are venues conducive to emotional scam attempts.</p><p>These sites and apps have lately also been used to prospect for potential preys to investment fraud. Victims are mostly men. While looking for a date, they get in touch with women of allegedly Asian descent.</p><p>This fraud generally unfolds in 4 steps:</p><h4 class="green">1st step&nbsp;: Seducing you</h4><p>On a dating app such as Tinder, you discover pictures of a charming woman. Most of the time, she has dropped a “Super Like” on your profile. Super Likes are a paid feature of Tinder that allows you to express a special interest in someone.</p><p>Beware! Swindlers could well be hiding behind the features of the woman you see on the pictures. They have created a fake character with fake photos in order to manipulate you.</p><h4 class="green">2nd step: Arousing your curiosity</h4><p>Once contact is made, exchanges will systematically be conducted in English. Your chat partner will often offer to continue chatting on WhatsApp.</p><p>One conversation follows another.&nbsp;Where does she live? What does she do in her spare time? What is her occupation?</p><p>She then explains that she doesn’t have to worry about money and her financial future.</p><p>Then you ask her the question she was awaiting since your initial contact: how does she manage to make so much money so easily?&nbsp;</p><h4 class="green">3rd step: Promising riches</h4><p>She then tells you her secret: she makes money by investing! She tells you that you can also do the same. She sends you a link to a website through which you can invest either in cryptocurrencies (new ICO), or on online trading platforms proposing to invest in forex products for example. The link directs you to a fraudulent online trading platform typically produced in English and Chinese.</p><p>In some cases, your chat partner will tell you that she can put you in touch with one of her acquaintances who is a renowned trader or a financial adviser who will help you get rich.&nbsp;</p><p>She has won your trust and you are convinced that you have found a way to invest your money profitably and without risk. You then make a payment.</p><h4 class="green">4th step: Making off with your money</h4><p>Once you have paid, you will have no hope of getting your money back. As soon as you begin wondering about the veracity of that offer, your chat partner will disappear and will not answer your messages anymore.</p><ul><li><h3 class="blue"><strong>Avoid being a victim of investment fraud on social media</strong></h3></li></ul><p>The FSMA<strong>&nbsp;encourages you to follow the recommendations below in order to prevent being defrauded:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Take the </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599"><strong>test</strong></a> on the website of the FSMA to determine whether the offer you have received is fraudulent.</li><li>Be wary of<strong> promises of completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li><li><strong>Do</strong>&nbsp;<strong>not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li><li><strong>Check</strong>&nbsp;<strong>whether the company holds an authorization</strong>&nbsp;by searching the lists published on the FSMA website –&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.<strong>&nbsp;Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li><li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money. &nbsp;<br><br>On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the 'companies' about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website.<br><br><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.<br>&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Be wary </strong>of unsolicited phone calls/emails <strong>(cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li><li>Be wary of requests to<strong> pay money into bank accounts in countries that have nothing to do with the company</strong> that is approaching you, or your own place of residence.</li><li><strong>Never invest in a product if you do not fully understand what is being offered.</strong></li><li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an<strong> additional payment </strong>and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud<strong>.</strong></li></ul><p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><ul><li><h3 class="blue"><strong>What to do if you are a victim of fraud?</strong></h3></li></ul><p>If you think you are the victim of fraud, make sure&nbsp;you <strong>do not pay any additional sums&nbsp;</strong>to your contact. <strong>Note</strong>: this is also and especially true if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to try to obtain one last payment.</p><p>Also, <strong>contact</strong>&nbsp;the <a href="https://www.police.be/en">local police</a> immediately to make a complaint and&nbsp;<strong>alert the FSMA</strong>&nbsp;to the scam&nbsp;via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p><p>The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint&nbsp;<strong>quickly&nbsp;</strong>and with&nbsp;<strong>ample documentation</strong>&nbsp;(the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-03T11:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66649</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Newsletter: continuing education - Transfer of credits</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-continuing-education-transfer-credits</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA regularly informs intermediaries and financial service providers via newsletters about topics of interest to them, such as changes to legislation and supervision. As we approach the end of 2020, the FSMA once again wishes to review certain developments in supervisory practice. In the coming days, you will receive brief newsletters about various topics, such as the impact of Brexit, the end of the transition period for ancillary insurance intermediaries, and the anti-money laundering legislation. To keep up to date with the developments, we advise everyone to consult these newsletters.<br>
<br>
The current newsletter reviews the rules governing the transfer of continuing education credits.<br>
<br>
Now that the end of the year is approaching, the FSMA regularly receives questions from insurance intermediaries about whether they can transfer surplus continuing education credits to the following year, as was the case in the past.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in our newsletter...(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2020-12-02_newsletter1_recyclage_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2020-12-02_newsletter1_bijscholing_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-12-02T14:45:00+01:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: The FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-3</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The approach remains the same. These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. These methods or projects often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Recently, these platforms have even hacked into user profiles on social media in order to further spread the aforementioned fake ads.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of the following new fake-ads and websites that refer to subsequent projects and training courses:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Era </strong>(www.bitcoinera.com and www.bitcoinera.app)</li>
 <li><strong>Ethereum Code</strong></li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>365capitalmarkets</strong> (www.365capitalmarkets.com and https://365capitalmarkets2.com/)</li>
 <li><strong>Bright Finance</strong> (www.brightfinance.co)</li>
 <li><strong>Markets Pilot</strong> (www.marketspilot.com)</li>
 <li><strong>MottoFX</strong> (www.mottofx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>MyCoinBanking</strong> (www.mycoinbanking1.com and www.mycoin-banking.com)</li>
 <li><strong>OnlineMarketShare</strong> (www.onlinemarket-share.com)</li>
 <li><strong>OTPFX </strong>(www.otpfx.com and www.otpfxtrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Profits Trade </strong>(www.profitstrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Solid Invest </strong>(www.solidinvest.co)</li>
 <li><strong>Synergy Capitals </strong>(www.synergycapitals.co.uk)</li>
 <li><strong>TradersChain </strong>(www.traderschain.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Uptos </strong>(www.uptos.com)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-11-19T11:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66498</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Reminder of the product governance rules that apply when offering structured products in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/reminder-product-governance-rules-apply-when-offering-structured-products-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p>Credit institutions and insurance distributors are required to act honestly, fairly and professionally in the best interests of their customers when offering structured products in Belgium. That applies in particular to the product governance requirements. The FSMA draws attention in its Communication FSMA_2020_14 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_14_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_14_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;to this obligation.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-11-13T14:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66473</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Opinion on supplementary pensions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/opinion-supplementary-pensions</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>FSMA publishes a new opinion: the increase in a fringe benefit that is not itself a supplementary pension is, in the event of the death of one of the parents, not necessarily a supplementary pension.</strong></p>

<p>The increase in a fringe benefit that is not itself a supplementary pension (e.g. child supplement, study grant, etc.), made in the event of the death of one of the parents, is not necessarily to be regarded as a supplementary pension within the meaning of the Law on Supplementary Pensions, provided the following conditions are met:</p>

<p>(i) The increase in the event of death should be regarded as of secondary importance in relation to that fringe benefit. In other words:</p>

<ol>
 <li>the fringe benefit is granted independently of anyone’s death;</li>
 <li>the increase in the fringe benefit in the event of death is not very substantial in comparison with the amount of the fringe benefit that was paid before the death.</li>
</ol>

<p>(ii) The increase must be intended to supplement an existing fringe benefit that serves the same purpose (for example, contributing to the tuition costs of school-aged children) and not to provide a survivor’s pension. This intention must also be clearly formulated in the contract.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Please see the full text of the opinion here (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/66469">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/66469">Dutch</a> only).</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-11-12T12:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66468</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Continuing professional training in 2020 for accredited statutory auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/continuing-professional-training-2020-accredited-statutory-auditors</link>
  <description>
<p>The continuing professional training programme for 2020 will be offered ‘remotely’ in the form of webinars and will be spread over two sessions, of about an hour and a half each (not including the Q&amp;A session):</p>

<ul>
 <li>Friday, 27 November 2020 from 2 – 4 pm: training session for institutions for occupational retirement provision;</li>
 <li>Friday, 4 December 2020 from 2 – 4 pm: training session for undertakings for collective investment, management companies of undertakings for collective investment, and regulated real estate companies.</li>
</ul>

<p>Register for this continuing professional training by returning the attached form by <a href="mailto:policy@fsma.be?subject=Continuing%20professional%20training%202020"><strong>email</strong></a>&nbsp;<strong>at the latest by</strong> <strong>20&nbsp;November&nbsp;2020</strong>. Registration is free of charge.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>For additional information, see the Communication (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_15_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_15_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</p>
</div>

<item>
  <title>Approval of the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/approval-modified-market-rules-regulated-markets-organized-euronext-nvsa-5</link>
  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved&nbsp;on 27 October 2020 in accordance with Article 34, §1, of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU. These market rules enter into force as of 30 November 2020.</p>

<p>The market rules are available on <a href="https://www.euronext.com/en/regulation/regulated-markets" target="_blank">Euronext's website</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Money-laundering risk situations: how to apply the necessary vigilance measures?</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-money-laundering-risk-situations-how-apply-necessary-vigilance-measures</link>
  <description>
<ul>
 <li>
 <h4 class="blue"><em>States with no or low taxation?</em></h4>
 </li>
 <li>
 <h4 class="blue"><em>High-risk countries?</em></h4>
 </li>
 <li>
 <h4 class="blue"><em>Countries or persons subject to financial embargoes and asset-freezing measures?</em></h4>
 </li>
</ul>

<h3 class="blue"><strong>Where can you find the relevant lists and what are your obligations in this regard?</strong></h3>

<p>The anti-money laundering legislation refers to these concepts, but which are the countries or persons concerned? Where can you find the updated lists? What should you do if a transaction or a client has a link with one of these countries, or if a country or person subject to financial embargoes and asset-freezing measures appears to be involved in a transaction?</p>

(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2020-10-26_newsletter_amllijsten_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2020-10-26_newsletter_amllistes_fr.pdf">French</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>End of the World Investor Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week-0</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The fourth edition of World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held from 5 to 11 October 2020. The aim of the week was to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives taken by the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</strong></p>

<p>As was the case in 2019, World Investor Week 2020 focused on raising awareness of the risks and challenges posed by the increasing digitalization of the financial markets. Other topics, such as digital learning, online education and the basic principles of investment, were also featured.</p>

<p>As vice-chair of IOSCO and member of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again supported this initiative. The FSMA is currently conducting an important campaign to raise awareness of investment fraud perpetrated online via social media. After a first wave of the campaign that targeted pensioners, the FSMA is now placing the emphasis on the younger generations. In addition to publishing warnings on the topic, the FSMA has also completely redesigned the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">section of its website devoted to a discussion of fraud</a>. The section now offers consumers the possibility of checking, via a quick and simple test, whether an investment offer is fraudulent.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-10-12T18:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66016</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Guide to the preparation of the AMLCO’s annual activity report</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guide-preparation-amlcos-annual-activity-report</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has observed that the annual activity reports of AMLCOs have often been limited to a general, relatively unstructured description of the policies, procedures and organization of internal controls. With a view to increasing the quality and clarity of such reports, the FSMA is offering AMLCOs a guide&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_12_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;to the preparation of the annual activity report.</p>

<item>
  <title>Satisfaction survey about supplementary pensions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/satisfaction-survey-about-supplementary-pensions</link>
  <description>
<p>Are you, as an employee, a member of a supplementary pension plan? If so, you can now take part in a satisfaction survey conducted by the FSMA, the Belgian supervisor of supplementary pensions.</p>

<p>We would like to know whether you are satisfied with the information you receive about your supplementary pension:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Is the information about your supplementary pension clear?</li>
 <li>Do you know how much you are charged for your supplementary pension?</li>
 <li>Do&nbsp; you have an overview of how much you will receive when you retire?</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-info">
<p>LET US KNOW VIA THE WEBSITE <a href="http://www.mypension.be">www.mypension.be</a> (available in <a href="http://WWW.MYPENSION.BE/fr" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://WWW.MYPENSION.BE/nl" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only).</p>

<p>In the ‘Ma pension complémentaire/Mijn aanvullend pensioen’ section, an automatic pop-up will appear with a link to the questionnaire.</p>
</div>

<h3 class="green">Would you like to know more about supplementary pensions in general? Visit <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14879">our website</a>!&nbsp;</h3>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-10-07T15:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">66034</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Animated film for insurance intermediaries – Know the warning signs of money laundering</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/animated-film-insurance-intermediaries-know-warning-signs-money-laundering</link>
  <description>
<p>In recent years, the FSMA has reinforced its supervision in the struggle against money laundering and the financing of terrorism.</p>

<p>In the course of its supervision, the FSMA has noticed that some non-tied insurance intermediaries active in life insurance did not meet their obligations in this regard because of a lack of knowledge about or a misunderstanding of the legislation.</p>

<p>In addition to its many publications about this subject, the FSMA wishes to support insurance intermediaries in an innovative way via animated films that convey the main messages of the legislation.</p>

<p>The first animated film is ready and is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>

<p>This first film is intended to alert insurance intermediaries to the fact that they could fall victim to a money laundering or terrorist financing network. The film does so by drawing their attention to certain situations in which they should request additional information and, if necessary, file a report with the Belgian Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CTIF/CFI).</p>

<p>In the coming months, additional animated films will be posted. They will address topics in the money laundering legislation in which the FSMA has noticed that not all intermediaries are sufficiently well versed.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>View the animated film... (available in <a href="https://vimeo.com/462551182" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="https://vimeo.com/462553251" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-09-30T11:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">65977</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Companies that sell trading and training software</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-sell-trading-and-training-software</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA has noted that various companies in Belgium are selling, via a pyramid structure, trading and training software intended for trading principally in forex, CFDs and cryptocurrencies.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The sale of such trading and training software mostly takes place via a pyramid structure. The term generally used for this technique is ‘MLM’ (multi-level marketing), in which consumers are given incentives to bring in new members. In exchange for doing so, they receive compensation in the form of a commission or discount on the price of the software package or subscription price.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA has observed that such MLM networks are very active on social media via numerous (private) groups whose only purpose is to promote a particular MLM and to recruit new members. It is worth noting that these schemes mainly target a young audience, who are very active on social media, where all sorts of photos circulate showing young people seemingly swimming in riches. The message is that everyone can afford this kind of lifestyle if they bring in enough new members and make the right investment in the software being promoted.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA draws attention to the fact that the investments accessible via the software are often not subject to financial supervision (alternative investments such as precious metals or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14814">virtual money</a>) or their <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55509">distribution in Belgium is prohibited</a> (certain derivative instruments such as forex, <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14796">CFDs</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14795">binary options</a>).</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Moreover, offers of CFDs and forex via the internet are very risky and vulnerable to fraud</strong>: anyone who invests in CFDs or forex runs the risk of losing all the money invested. <strong>The possibility of loss is much higher than the possibility of gain</strong>: surveys by other European supervisors conducted among investors show that as much as 75% to 89% of investments in derivative products, such as forex products, are loss-making! These products are suited only to someone who really wishes to speculate, is prepared to lose the entire amount invested or even more, and is familiar with derivative financial products. <strong>A great many cases of fraud have also been found to use these instruments</strong>. In some cases, we have seen that no actual transactions were carried out by the offeror.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Have you received an offer of an investment and would you like to find out whether it could be fraudulent? If so, take the test under the heading ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">Beware of fraud’</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">We urge investors always to find out whether the company making the offer has the requisite authorization. A simple search via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the website of the FSMA is all you need. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-09-21T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">65858</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Fraudulent online trading platforms: The FSMA updates its list of suspicious sites</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fraudulent-online-trading-platforms-fsma-updates-its-list-suspicious-sites-2</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>During the last weeks, the FSMA continued to receive complaints from consumers concerning </strong><strong>new fraudulent online trading platforms </strong><strong>that are operating in the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The approach remains the same. These trading platforms try to arouse consumers’ curiosity by placing <strong>scam ads on social media</strong>. In these fake ads, a well-known person often explains how to get rich quick. These methods or projects often form part of the offer of a virtual currency or training course. After clicking on the ad and having given their contact details, the victims are usually swiftly called by fraudsters presenting a concrete investment proposal (in shares, alternative investment products, virtual currencies, etc.).</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>These platforms act very aggressively.</strong> Scammers even try to persuade the victims to allow them to take control of their computer remotely in order to make certain money transfers. The fraudsters also try to convince the victims to invest increasingly higher amounts of money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Victims who agree to do so complain in particular about:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>finding themselves unable to recover their money</strong>, or</li>
 <li>simply <strong>not hearing any more from the platform</strong> with which they have invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">These are most likely cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA is aware of fake-ads and websites that refer to subsequent projects and training courses:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Bank</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Code</strong></li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/64418">Bitcoin-Evolution / Bitcoin-Revolution</a></strong></li>
 <li><strong>Bitcoin Trader</strong></li>
 <li><strong>La Formule Française</strong></li>
 <li><strong>La Grande Capitale </strong>(www.lagrandecapitale.fr)</li>
 <li><strong>Trading Academy 360 </strong>(www.tradingacademy360.com)</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, various new trading platforms have appeared on the internet in recent weeks.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offers of financial services</strong> made by the following new trading platforms:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>BigFX</strong> (www.bigfx.com)</li>
 <li><strong>CMarketsGroup</strong> (www.cmarketsgroup.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Innerbrokers</strong> (www.innerbrokers.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Interactive Trade</strong> (www.interactivetrade.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Invcenter</strong> (www.invcenter.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Primecapitec</strong> (www.primecapitec.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Qteck</strong> (www.qteck.io)</li>
 <li><strong>Remaxima </strong>(www.remaxima.com)</li>
 <li><strong>Solidcapital </strong>(www.solidacapital.io)</li>
 <li><strong>WinnGroup(s)</strong> (www.winngroups.com, www.winngroupltd.com, www.winngc.com&nbsp;and www.winngroupltd.net)</li>
</ul>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to <strong>avoid fraud</strong>, the FSMA addresses the following <strong>recommendations</strong> to investors:&nbsp;<strong>Always check the identity</strong> (company name, home country, registered office, etc.) <strong>of the company</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Always verify <strong>if the company in question</strong></strong> <strong>has the requisite authorization. </strong>To this end, an easy <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search</a> on the financial supervisory authority’s website will do. Important! Always beware of ‘<strong>cloned firms’</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they have no connection with them. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect this type of fraud and prevent it.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">More than ever, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, and before making any (more) payments, do not hesitate to contact the FSMA using the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, please feel free to notify it of any contact with a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Should fraudsters moreover manage to take control of your computer, the FSMA recommends that you contact your bank and, if necessary, that you change your passwords.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more recommendations aimed at avoiding investment fraud, the FSMA invites investors to consult the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/33896">How to recognize and avoid fraud?</a>' page on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-09-17T15:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">65781</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>ILA International</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/ila-international</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of </strong><strong>ILA International</strong><strong>, a company that offers investment services.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">ILA International is <strong>not an authorized investment firm</strong> in Belgium. It is therefore not allowed to provide investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to the information available to the FSMA, the activities proposed could be of a fraudulent nature, i.e. <strong>boiler room fraud</strong>. More information on this form of fraud is available in the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65746">general warning</a> published by the FSMA on 10 September 2020.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly</strong> <strong>advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by ILA International and <strong>against transferring </strong>money to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">ILA International uses the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Website</strong>: http://ilainternational.com/<br>
<strong>Address</strong>: LKF Tower, Level 22n 55 D’Aguilar St, Central, Hong Kong, China S.A.R.<br>
<strong>E-mail</strong>: info@lainternational.com<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>: +852 3018 3062<br>
<strong>Tel.</strong>: +852 3015 0776</p>

<p class="rtejustify">ILA International has also been the subject of a warning by the supervisory authority of <a href="https://www.sfc.hk/web/EN/alert-list/i.html#2568">Hong Kong</a>&nbsp;and of <a href="https://www.cmvm.pt/en/SDI/FinancialIntermediaries/Pages/20200717mc1.aspx?v=">Portugal</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/Node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Boiler rooms: The FSMA warns the public against unauthorized activities</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/boiler-rooms-fsma-warns-public-against-unauthorized-activities-2</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against several companies engaging in unauthorized activities on the Belgian market.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The companies are the following:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65747"><strong>Akiyama Acquisitions</strong></a> (http://www.akiyamaacq.com/)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65748"><strong>Ashton Group Ltd</strong></a> (https://www.ashtongroupltd.com/)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65750"><strong>Carlyle Capital Management</strong></a> (https://www.carlylecapitalmanagement.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65751"><strong>Crest View International</strong></a> (https://www.crestviewcapital.com/)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65752"><strong>Dunn &amp; Burchill</strong></a> (http://www.dunnandburchill.net)</li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/65753">ILA International</a> </strong>(http://ilainternational.com/)</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">The above companies are <strong>not authorized</strong> to provide investment services in Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, according to information in the possession of the FSMA, these companies may be '<strong>boiler rooms</strong>'.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products. In recent times, the services being offered have grown ever more diverse. Products and services currently being offered also include: management accounts, term deposit accounts, investment advice, investments in crowdfunding, etc.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The fraudsters often put the consumer under severe pressure (hence the term 'boiler room'), insisting that they keep making further payments. <strong>In the end, the consumer will never get the invested money back.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">If you have the least doubt about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-09-10T14:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">65746</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-1</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_11_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_11_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)&nbsp;informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s (hereinafter 'FSMA') permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-09-10T10:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
