<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee of the international organization IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-re-elected-chair-european-regional-committee-international-organization-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), has been re-elected chair of the European Regional Committee of IOSCO, the international organization of financial market supervisors.</strong></p>

<p>The European members of IOSCO re-elected Jean-Paul Servais to another two-year term as chair of the European Regional Committee, the European country group within IOSCO. He has held this position since October 2014.</p>

<p>IOSCO was founded in 1983 and comprises 129 supervisory authorities from 115 jurisdictions. The objective of the organization is to promote cooperation among market supervisors and to develop international standards and best practices. An important instrument in this regard is the IOSCO multilateral memorandum of agreement (MMoU).</p>

<p>The memorandum enables supervisory authorities to exchange information quickly among each other. The information may be used, among other things, in an investigation into market abuse practices, which increasingly have an international dimension and can in this way be tackled more efficiently. The memorandum has been signed by 123 supervisors, including the FSMA.</p>

<p>The European Regional Committee brings together the 50 European members of IOSCO. The Committee discusses IOSCO initiatives that relate to the strengthening of worldwide standards for financial markets, with particular attention to matters that are of relevance to Europe.</p>

<p>‘This re-election attests to the recognition and esteem for the work done by the FSMA at both national and international levels. Moreover, the chairmanship of the European Regional Committee enables the FSMA to exert significant influence on the international standards that the IOSCO develops at the request of the G20 and of the Financial Stability Board, and that increasingly affect Belgian financial regulation’, says Jean-Paul Servais.</p>

<p>The chairman of the FSMA is also vice chair of the IOSCO Board and chair of IOSCO’s audit committee. On behalf of IOSCO he also chairs the IFRS Monitoring Board.</p>

<p>More information about IOSCO’s activities can be found in the <a href="https://www.iosco.org/library/pubdocs/pdf/IOSCOPD648.pdf" target="_blank">IOSCO work program for 2020</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-03-02T14:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">64035</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>IOSCO Stakeholder meeting in Madrid</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-stakeholder-meeting-madrid</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>IOSCO, the international organization of financial market supervisors, held a stakeholder meeting in Madrid on Friday 28 February. </strong></p>

<p>Various regulatory issues relating to asset management and the challenges posed by technology were discussed. The meeting was also an opportunity for stakeholders to discuss IOSCO's priorities for 2020.</p>

<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, who is also Vice Chair of IOSCO, participated in one of the panels. Among other things, he raised the issue of the means and efforts dedicated to contributing to high-quality financial reporting.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-28T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">64034</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Participation in the symposium of the CFA Institute</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/participation-symposium-cfa-institute</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, participated in the first symposium of the CFA Institute on financial regulation, held in Madrid.</strong></p>

<p>The CFA Institute has more than 160,000 members and is a global organization that aims to promote high standards of ethics, education and professionalism in the financial sector. The symposium in Madrid focused on how the culture in the sector has changed since the financial crisis and the role that regulation can play in modifying behaviour in the sector.</p>

<p>During his <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20200225_cfa_corporateconduct.pdf" target="_blank">remarks</a>, Jean-Paul Servais discussed the various means regulators can use to contribute to better protection of retail investors. Among other things, he described the moratorium launched by the FSMA on the distribution of particularly complex structured products. The moratorium has contributed to simplifying such products on the Belgian retail market.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-26T13:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">64027</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The IFRS Monitoring Board defines its key objectives for 2020-2021 at a meeting held in Brussels</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/ifrs-monitoring-board-defines-its-key-objectives-2020-2021-meeting-held-brussels</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board, chaired by Mr Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, approved its work plan for the next two years during a meeting held in Brussels on 20 February 2020.</strong></p>

<p>The Monitoring Board was created in 2009 with the aim of overseeing the IFRS Foundation, whose Trustees in turn exercise oversight over the IASB (International Accounting Standards Board). The IASB, as the international accounting standards-setting body, draws up the international accounting standards that must be applied, for example, by more than 7000 listed companies in Europe.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, has chaired the Monitoring Board since 1 March 2017. The Chairman of the FSMA became a member of the Monitoring Board as a representative of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), of which he has been vice-chairman since 2016.</p>

<p>During a meeting held in Brussels at the premises of the FSMA on 20 February 2020, the Monitoring Board defined its principal areas of activity for the next two years. The Monitoring Board also held a joint meeting with all the Trustees and their chair, Erkki Liikanen, and with the chairman of the IASB, Hans Hoogervorst. The Monitoring Board consults regularly with the Trustees and the IASB chairman, with a view to reviewing the quality and effectiveness of the governance framework of the IFRS Foundation and hence to supervising the process by which the IFRSs are developed.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais: “<em>The 2020-2021 action plan seeks to extend the remarkable work done in the past two years to promote high-quality financial information. </em>Such information is nothing short of the cornerstone of investor confidence and of the transparency of the financial markets."</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board published a <a href="https://www.iosco.org/about/monitoring_board/pdf/Press-20200221-1.pdf" target="_blank">press release</a> on this subject. It contains a link to the 2020-2021 work plan that has been approved by the Monitoring Board.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board is made up of representatives of various prominent market regulators. At the moment, the Board consists of representatives of the European Commission and of the securities regulators of the United States (SEC), Brazil, Japan and South Korea, the Chinese Ministry of Finance and IOSCO. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision takes part in the Monitoring Board meetings as an observer, as does the Financial Sector Conduct Authority of South Africa, representing the IOSCO Africa and Middle East Committee, and the <em>Comisión Nacional de Valores</em> of Argentina, representing the IOSCO Inter-American Regional Committee.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-21T13:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63986</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Remarks by the Chairman of the FSMA to the General Meeting of the IRAIF/IREFI</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/remarks-chairman-fsma-general-meeting-iraifirefi</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, spoke at the General Meeting of the Institut des Réviseurs Agréés pour les Institutions Financières/Instituut van de Revisoren Erkend voor de Financiële Instellingen (IRAIF/IREFI) on 3 February 2020.</strong></p>

<p>During his remarks, the chairman emphasized the importance of the role of auditors in the smooth operation of the markets and for financial stability. He also reviewed the recent legal and regulatory changes intended to strengthen and better support their legal mandates.</p>

<p>He then described the new modes of collaboration by accredited auditors with the prudential supervision conducted by the FSMA. These new modes have also been set out in a circular&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_01_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only). The circular clarifies the information that the FSMA expects from entities under supervision on the one hand, and from accredited auditors on the other, in particular as regards the new layout for annual reporting. The chairman also stressed the importance of the signal function, which should cover a much wider range of topics than the imminent dissolution of a company, and should include all information that is relevant from a prudential standpoint. Accredited auditors, as partners in prudential supervision, are expected to approach their preventive mission not only from a short-term perspective – as it the case for the certification of the annual accounts – but also from a medium and long-term perspective in order to fulfil the objectives of prudential supervision.</p>

<p>Lastly, the chairman commented on certain developments that pose challenges to the profession as a whole. He evoked technological changes and the increasing use of artificial intelligence and data analytics, as well as the changes in the regulatory and normative framework. In this regard, he also referred to developments at international level, which he is monitoring closely as vice-chairman of IOSCO and chair of the IFRS Foundation Monitoring Board. The Monitoring Board was created in 2009 with the aim of overseeing the IFRS Foundation, whose Trustees in turn exercise oversight over the IASB. The Monitoring Board consults regularly with the Trustees and the IASB chairman, with a view to reviewing the quality and effectiveness of the governance framework of the IFRS Foundation and thus to supervising the process by which the IFRSs are developed. The next meeting of the Monitoring Board will be held in February 2020 in Brussels, at the premises of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-17T13:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63864</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Offers of investment in Whisky: beware of fraud!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/offers-investment-whisky-beware-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA warned the public against fraudulent offers of investment in wine (see our warnings from 22 May 2019 and 4 July 2019). Since then, consumers have reported to us that they were approached with fraudulent offers of investment in whisky.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify">The principle remains the same: victims are contacted by phone by a salesperson, who offers them investments in whisky and invites them to consult an&nbsp;<strong>online trading platform for fine whiskies</strong>.</p><p class="rtejustify">These companies offer the opportunity to&nbsp;<strong>acquire bottles of whisky</strong>, undertake to&nbsp;<strong>stock them in a cellar</strong>&nbsp;for you, and promise to&nbsp;<strong>find some major buyers</strong>&nbsp;so that you can earn a&nbsp;<strong>handsome profit</strong>. Would-be investors have nothing to do, the companies 'will take care of everything'! The concept, however, is<strong>&nbsp;too good to be true</strong>. In the end, despite the promises, the investors&nbsp;<strong>never recover</strong>&nbsp;their money!</p><h3 class="blue">The suspect companies active in recent weeks</h3><p class="rtejustify">In recent weeks, the FSMA was informed that the companies behind the following websites have been approaching Belgians with these types of offers:</p><ul><li>www.epargne-whisky.com</li><li>www.whisky-prestige.com</li></ul><p class="rtejustify">The FSMA warns that these companies&nbsp;<strong>do not hold an authorization and are thus not permitted to offer investment services&nbsp;</strong>in Belgium<strong>.&nbsp;</strong>Moreover, it is very likely that these are cases of investment fraud, which means that in the end, the amounts invested are never reimbursed.</p><p class="rtejustify">Please see also&nbsp;the <a href="https://www.amf-france.org/en/warnings"><strong>blacklist</strong></a>&nbsp;of sites that offer investments in various goods (cryptoassets, diamonds, wine, etc.) published by the AMF, the French supervisory authority.</p><h3 class="blue">How to avoid the trap?</h3><p class="rtejustify">In order to avoid such cases of fraud, the FSMA&nbsp;<strong>urges you to exercise utmost prudence</strong>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<strong>advises you to remain alert to any indication of investment fraud</strong>. It offers a few recommendations to this end:</p><ul><li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns</strong>. If a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li><li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company</strong>&nbsp;who is contacting you (company identity, home country, etc.). If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.&nbsp;<strong>Find out</strong>&nbsp;as well&nbsp;<strong>when the company website was set up</strong>: if the company’s website is relatively new, this could be an additional sign of investment fraud.</li><li><strong>Be wary</strong>&nbsp;if you are asked to&nbsp;<strong>deposit money to bank accounts in countries without any connection&nbsp;</strong>to the country where the company contacting you is said to be registered or with your own country of residence. Be wary as well if you are asked to deposit money into accounts whose&nbsp;<strong>beneficiary is someone other than the company itself</strong>.</li></ul><p class="rtejustify">In any case, if your contact person comes across as&nbsp;<strong>particularly insistent</strong>, this is an additional indication of fraud.</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>Please note</strong>, don’t trust the 'professional'&nbsp;appearance of the website to which they referred you; the swindlers do everything they can, of course, to appear as legitimate as possible.</p><p>***</p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>For more information about this type of fraud, the FSMA invites potential investors to consult its&nbsp;warning&nbsp;of&nbsp;22 May 2019 regarding fraudulent offers of investment in wine.</strong></p><p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong>&nbsp;about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468"><strong>consumer contact form</strong></a>. As well, feel free to notify us of any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-11T12:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63860</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Senate hearing on cryptocurrencies</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/senate-hearing-cryptocurrencies</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, provided information on cryptocurrencies during a Senate hearing. The hearing took place before the Committee on Cross-cutting Issues following the tabling of a proposal for a resolution aimed at establishing a legal framework for the sale, purchase and use of virtual currencies and all related financial products.</strong></p>

<p>In his presentation, the Chairman gave explanations on the characteristics of cryptocurrencies, on the European and international initiatives in this area, on the regulatory context and on the combating of investment fraud. Representatives of the National Bank of Belgium and of the Belgian Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CTIF-CFI) also took part in the hearing.</p>

<p>More information can be found in the motion for a resolution (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20200131_voorstelvanresolutie_senatcrypto.pdf">French/Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)&nbsp;and the Chairman's presentation (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20200131_senatcrypto.pdf">French/Dutch</a> only).</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-02-10T09:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63831</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Communication by the Federal Prosecutor’s Office and the FSMA on investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/communication-federal-prosecutors-office-and-fsma-investment-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On Wednesday 29 January 2020, the Federal Prosecutor's Office and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) held a joint press briefing at the FSMA premises to provide information on different types of investment fraud currently being committed.</strong></p>

<p>On this occasion, Mrs Wenke Roggen, federal magistrate and spokeswoman for the Federal Prosecutor's Office, commented on judicial investigations conducted jointly by the Belgian and French authorities, which led to the arrest of several people in connection with an extensive dossier of cryptocurrency investment fraud.</p>

<p>Mr Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, gave more detailed explanations on the broader issue of investment fraud, detailing in particular the methods used by fraudsters to try to steal investors' money. In his presentation (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20200129_parquet_fraudesinvestissement.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20200129_parket_beleggingsfraude.pdf">Dutch</a> only), he pointed to the important collaboration between financial sector supervisors and judicial authorities and highlighted the preventive and enforcement role of the FSMA. In 2019, as many as 138 warnings were issued by the FSMA, which reported these cases to the Prosecutor's Office. 173 websites were blocked by the Prosecutor's Office at the request of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-01-31T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63807</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Audit of the financing of defined benefit pension plans via group insurance policies</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/audit-financing-defined-benefit-pension-plans-group-insurance-policies</link>
  <description>
<p>Communication – Feedback Statement FSMA_2020_02 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_02_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_02_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) on the financing of defined benefit pension plans via group insurance policies</p>

<p>One of the fundamental principles of the legislation on supplementary pensions is that pension plan sponsors are required to outsource the management of such plans to a pension institution. The building up of reserves in a separate ('external') body is designed to safeguard accrued supplementary pension savings in the event that the sponsor goes bankrupt.</p>

<p>In this context, the FSMA has performed an audit on the financing of defined benefit pension plans via group insurance policies.</p>

<p>As detailed in its audit report, the FSMA’s main aim was to ascertain the extent to which the financing methods used offer adequate protection for members’ pension rights.</p>

<ul>
 <li>FSMA_2020_02-01 / Financing of defined benefit pension plans via group insurance policies – Main audit results (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_02-01_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_02-01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</li>
 <li>FSMA_2020_02-02 / Financing of defined benefit pension plans via group insurance policies – Audit report&nbsp;(available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_02-02_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</li>
</ul>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-01-14T17:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63657</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>New brochure on investor protection rules (MiFID II)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-brochure-investor-protection-rules-mifid-ii</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA, the Financial Services and Markets Authority, publishes a new educational brochure presenting a summary of the rules arising from MiFID I and MiFID II. The brochure should help raise consumers’ awareness of their rights and of the obligations binding on the firms which provide investment services to them.</strong></p>

<p>MiFID is the abbreviation for the European ‘Markets in Financial Instruments Directive’. This is a European legislative text that came into force in 2007 and regulates services relating to financial instruments rendered by regulated companies<sup><a href="#ftn1">[1]</a></sup> (investment services). One of the principal objectives of the Directive is the harmonization of investor protection across Europe. MiFID II, which came into force in 2018, reinforces MiFID I.</p>

<p>The FSMA is responsible for supervising compliance with the conduct of business rules by the regulated companies. In the course of exercising its supervision, the FSMA carries out inspections aimed at verifying whether the regulated companies abide by the rules in force when providing investment services to their clients. Where shortcomings are identified, the FSMA may issue orders, adopt specific measures, formulate recommendations or raise points for consideration.</p>

<p>Alongside its supervision of sector participants, the FSMA intends to ensure that consumers be well informed of their rights. They should be able to rely on correct finan­cial services and to buy financial products in line with their wishes and needs. That is why the new brochure published by the FSMA provides information on the different protection mechanisms established by MiFID I and MiFID II.</p>

<p>The brochure gives an overview of the different obligations imposed on firms both before, during and after the investment by the client.</p>

<p>Depending on the type of service requested by the client (order to buy or sell a financial product, investment advice or portfolio management), different degrees of protection will apply. The firm will, in some cases, provide an execution‑only service, while in others it will have to conduct a preliminary appropriateness or suitability test.</p>

<p>The brochure further details the information that should be provided to the client before, during and after a transaction and addresses the requirements that firms must meet with regard to the prevention of conflicts of interest, inducements and the handling of complaints.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/63656">brochure</a> is available on the website of the FSMA, in English, French and Dutch.</p>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="ftn1">[1]</a></sup>&nbsp;'Regulated companies'&nbsp;refers inter alia to credit institutions, portfolio management and investment advice companies and stockbroking firms.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2020-01-13T12:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63617</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Circular on the duty of cooperation of accredited auditors</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/circular-duty-cooperation-accredited-auditors</link>
  <description>
<p class="intro">Circular on the duty of cooperation of accredited auditors of management companies of undertakings for collective investment or alternative investment funds and regulated real estate investment companies</p>

<p>This circular FSMA_2020_01 (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2020/fsma_2020_01_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2020/fsma_2020_01_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)&nbsp;describes the modalities of the accredited auditors' duty of cooperation in the following areas:</p>

<ul>
 <li>&nbsp;&nbsp; activities and reporting of half-yearly and annual financial statements and reports;</li>
 <li>&nbsp;&nbsp; assessment of the internal control measures and of the reporting about them;</li>
 <li>&nbsp;&nbsp; reporting to the FSMA, including the reporting layout and the special report;</li>
 <li>&nbsp;&nbsp; exchange of information between the accredited auditors and the FSMA, including the signalling function.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA authorises EMMI as administrator of the EONIA benchmark</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-authorises-emmi-administrator-eonia-benchmark</link>
  <description>
<p>On 16 September 2019 the European Money Markets Institute (<a href="https://www.emmi-benchmarks.eu/" target="_blank">EMMI</a>) applied for authorisation as administrator of the <strong>Eonia&nbsp;</strong>benchmark. On 10 December 2019, following the positive advice of the college of Supervisors, the FSMA granted the requested authorisation to EMMI, by application of the European Benchmark Regulation (BMR).</p>

<p>On 2 July 2019 the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/61711">FSMA already authorised EMMI as administrator of the EURIBOR benchmark</a>. The authorisation was at the time restricted to the EURIBOR benchmark and did not include the Eonia&nbsp;benchmark. This limitation has now been removed by the decision of the FSMA of 10 December 2019.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-12-13T16:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63343</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against fraudulent credit offers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-fraudulent-credit-offers-0</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA warns consumers against spam messages containing fraudulent credit offers.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>What is spam?</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Spam is the collective name for unwanted messages and advertisements. Cybercriminals use this technique to obtain personal information from consumers (<em>phishing</em>) or to swindle them.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Fighting spam is extremely difficult as spam messages are often sent from untraceable or short-lived email addresses.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>What are fraudulent credit offers?</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Fraudulent credit offers relate to <strong>false credits</strong> offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">These fraudsters offer consumers <strong>credits at very attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover <strong>costs</strong> relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly impossible to recover the amounts paid.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Examples</strong></p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <div>
   <blockquote>
   <p class="rtejustify">Hello,</p>

   <p class="rtejustify">In need of a loan with a 2% interest rate? Please contact us if you are interested.</p>

   <p class="rtejustify">Credit amount:</p>

   <p class="rtejustify">Duration:</p>

   <p class="rtejustify">Aim:</p>
   </blockquote>
   </div>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <div>
   <blockquote>
   <p class="rtejustify">I offer financial assistance ranging from 5,000 euro to 2,500,000 euro at a 2% interest rate. We are established in Germany and provide assistance in various areas.</p>

   <p class="rtejustify">PS: contact me by emailing your request to name@gmail.com</p>
   </blockquote>
   </div>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>How does the FSMA act against spam?</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>The FSMA handles consumer questions and notifications about credits, whether or not fraudulent.</li>
 <li>After investigation, the FSMA may publish a warning against fraudulent credit providers. In those warnings the FSMA explains how fraudsters operate and gives tips on how to recognize false credits.</li>
 <li>De FSMA forwards dossiers regarding fraudulent credits offers to the judicial authorities, to enable them to take appropriate measures, e.g. blocking access to fraudulent websites.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>What can you do?</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>Inform your customers about the existence of false credits, and urge them to always verify the identity of the credit provider and whether he has the requisite authorization. Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search engine</a> on the website of the FSMA, your customers can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer credits.</li>
 <li>Customers who have already fallen victim to fraudulent credit offers, can be best referred to the local police or the judicial authorities to file a complaint.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-12-06T12:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63315</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Colloquium on cybercrime and investment fraud</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/colloquium-cybercrime-and-investment-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, spoke at a&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191204_roundtable_acpr.pdf" target="_blank">colloquium</a> in Paris organized by the French financial supervisors the ACPR and the AMF and attended by approximately 500 people.&nbsp;The topic of the colloquium was the protection of consumers against cybercrime and investment fraud. These phenomena have grown more frequent in the past few years and the methods used keep changing. During his remarks, the Chairman described the various actions taken by the FSMA against these crimes and spoke of the challenges the latter represent: raising the awareness of and informing consumers, making the financial sector more aware of the issue and collaborating with partners, in particular the courts, with the emphasis on blocking access to websites and blocking funds. The Chairman also stressed that an effective fight against fraud indisputably requires mobilization and consultation by all of these players. This is the approach that the FSMA is taking and will continue to take.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-12-05T09:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63237</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Roundtable of the EC on the review of the EU benchmark regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/roundtable-ec-review-eu-benchmark-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais, was invited by the European Commission to speak at a panel discussion organized as part of a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191126_roundtable_benchmark_agenda.pdf" target="_blank">roundtable</a> on the review of the Benchmark Regulation (BMR). The subject of the discussion was the IBOR review and the extent to which the framework created for the BMR gives supervisory authorities sufficient means to take action in the event of cessation of a benchmark.</p>

<p>During the panel discussion, the Chairman emphasised that the FSMA has been able to take the necessary measures on the basis of the current BMR to <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-authorises-emmi-administrator-euribor-benchmark">authorize EMMI as the administrator of EURIBOR</a> as well as to accompany the panel banks’ transition to the new, hybrid methodology. As a result, EURIBOR can now be used in both existing and new contracts.</p>

<p>The Chairman clarified that although the roadmap has been successfully implemented, this does not mean that no adjustments are needed to the regulatory framework. He pointed out specifically the need to strengthen the framework available to supervisors to ensure that there is a stable panel of banks, to have access to market data and to be able to have the methodology adapted if the benchmark is no longer representative. Lastly, he pointed out that although EURIBOR can continue to be used over the medium term, it is very important that the work being carried out by the private sector on possible fallback rates be continued.</p>

<p><a href="https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/better-regulation/initiatives/finance-2019-benchmark-review/public-consultation_en">Click here</a> for more information about the consultation on the review of the Benchmark Regulation, available on the website of the European Commission.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-11-27T12:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63184</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Speech on financial education</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/speech-financial-education</link>
  <description>
<p>The Chairman of the FSMA, Mr Jean-Paul Servais, gave a speech at the Investment Management Forum organized by EFAMA (European Fund and Asset Management Association). During his remarks, the Chairman stressed the importance of financial education. He also outlined the initiatives that the FSMA has already taken via its financial education programme, Wikifin, and in which the FSMA is a pioneer at European level. The Wikifin programme consists of three pillars: initiatives for the general public, collaboration with schools, and the new Wikifin Lab. The Chairman set out in greater detail the approach that will be used at the Wikifin Lab, which will be an interactive experience centre for financial education.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191121_efama_investmentmanagementforum.pdf" target="_blank">Click here</a> to read the presentation.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-11-25T13:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63164</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Approval of the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/approval-modified-market-rules-regulated-markets-organized-euronext-nvsa-4</link>
  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) hereby announces that the modified market rules of the regulated markets organized by Euronext NV/SA (namely Euronext Brussels and the Euronext Brussels Derivative Instruments Market) were approved on 19 November 2019 in accordance with Article 34, § 1 of the Law of 21 November 2017 on the market infrastructures for financial instruments and transposing Directive 2014/65/EU.</p>

<p>These market rules enter into force as of 25 November 2019and are available on Euronext's website: <a href="https://www.euronext.com/en/regulation/euronext-regulated-markets">https://www.euronext.com/en/regulation/euronext-regulated-markets</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Seminar of the FSMA on market abuse legislation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/seminar-fsma-market-abuse-legislation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA is offering seminars for issuers concerning the legislation in the area of market abuse. The first of these was held on 21 November 2019 on the premises of the FSMA. Around one hundred representatives of listed companies attended. The Chairman of the FSMA emphasized at the beginning of the seminar the importance of a sound knowledge and application of the rules by the sector.</strong></p>

<p>After the opening remarks, experts from within the FSMA gave presentations, with examples drawn from practice, about the various aspects of the legislation. The subjects addressed included reporting directors’ transactions and the rules governing communication and the postponement of market-sensitive information. The FSMA staff also explained the suspension policy and the investigations and decisions taken in the context of administrative sanction proceedings.</p>

<p>During the presentations, emphasis was placed on giving clear guidelines to enable listed companies to meet their obligations in full. Using a pro-active approach, companies can prevent incidents in the area of communication and reduce the risk of market abuse.</p>

<p>The session ended with conclusions offered by Ms Annemie Rombouts, the Deputy Chairman of the FSMA.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191121_marktmisbruik.pdf" target="_blank">Click here</a> to see the presentations given at the seminar.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-11-22T11:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63155</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Compliance Day 2019</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/compliance-day-2019</link>
  <description>
<p>Compliance Day was held this week. The day was organized by the Compliance.be Forum. Compliance Day is an annual conference that focuses on current topics of importance to compliance officers in Belgium.</p>

<p>In the course of the day, several representatives of the FSMA gave presentations to the more than 150 compliance officers in attendance. They received feedback about the transversal inspections carried out by the FSMA on the topic of conflicts of interest and inducements in the distribution of class 23 insurance products and about the application of the European Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD).</p>

<p>Representatives of the FSMA also provided an overview of developments in the supervision at European level and of the role of the European financial supervisory authorities ESMA, EBA and EIOPA.</p>

<p>Click here (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191118_compliancedayidd.pdf" target="_blank">Feedback inspectie belangenconflicten en inducements &amp; Stand van zaken implementatie IDD</a> -&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Presentation/20191118_complianceday_esma.pdf" target="_blank">ESMA, EIOPA and EBA: EU rule makers &amp; indirect supervisors</a>)&nbsp; to see the Compliance Day presentations.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-11-20T11:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63123</guid>
    </item>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-risk-factors-under-prospectus-regulation-implementation-fsma</link>
  <description>
<p>The guidelines (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2019/fsma_2019_29_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2019/fsma_2019_29_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only) contained in this document are addressed to the FSMA, which is competent in respect of the Prospectus Regulation. However, the guidelines state that persons responsible for the prospectus should consider these guidelines when preparing a prospectus for submission to the competent authority, in order to expedite the approval process for prospectuses, registration documents, universal registration documents, securities notes and any supplements thereto.</p>

<item>
  <title>Irico SA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/irico-sa</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of Irico&nbsp;SA, a company that offers investment instruments to the public in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Irico SA, a company apparently registered in Belize, is offering notes, futures and CFD’s to Belgian investors. However, it is doing so without having published a prospectus approved by the FSMA. The company in question is therefore not allowed to offer its investment instruments in Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the FSMA has indications that the offer of Irico SA investment instruments is a <strong>scam</strong>. Consumers who have invested in Irico SA experience great difficulty afterwards in recovering invested amounts.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA <strong>therefore advises</strong>&nbsp;<strong>against responding to</strong>&nbsp;<strong>any public offers of investment instruments&nbsp;</strong>issued by Irico SA or persons connected with that company and against&nbsp;<strong>transferring money</strong>&nbsp;to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Irico SA uses the website www.iricosa.com.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a proposed transaction complies with the financial legislation? If so, please use the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search engine</a>&nbsp;on the FSMA website. Feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-11-12T10:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">63017</guid>
    </item>

  <description><p>The continuing professional training 2019 of the accredited statutory auditors will take place in the offices of the 'Instituut van de Bedrijfsrevisoren' (IBR) / 'Institut des Réviseurs d’Entreprises' (IRE) on 6 (for the institutions for occupational retirement provision) and on 18 (for the undertakings for collective investment, the management companies of the undertakings for collective investment and the regulated real estate investment companies) December 2019.</p>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns against fraudulent credit offers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-against-fraudulent-credit-offers</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The FSMA warns consumers against spam messages containing fraudulent credit offers.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>What is spam?</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Spam is the collective name for unwanted messages and advertisements. Cybercriminals use this technique to obtain personal information from consumers (<em>phishing</em>) or to swindle them.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Fighting spam is extremely difficult as spam messages are often sent from untraceable or short-lived email addresses.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>What are fraudulent credit offers?</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Fraudulent credit offers relate to <strong>false credits</strong> offered in order to wheedle money out of consumers. The providers are fraudsters pretending to be lenders or collaborators of credit institutions.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">These fraudsters offer consumers credits<strong> at very attractive conditions</strong>. If a consumer wishes to take up the offer, he/she is asked to make certain payments supposedly to cover <strong>costs</strong> relating to the credit (e.g. an insurance premium to protect the lender against the risk of the loan not being repaid, dossier fees, administrative costs, etc.). Those costs are, however, fictitious.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Once those so-called costs are paid, the lender disappears without a trace, making it nearly impossible to recover the amounts paid.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Examples</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><em>Hello,<br>
In need of a loan with a 2&nbsp;% interest rate? Please contact us if you are interested.</em></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><em>Credit amount:<br>
Duration:<br>
Aim:</em></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><em>I offer financial assistance ranging from 5,000&nbsp;euro to 2,500,000&nbsp;euro at a 2&nbsp;% interest rate. We are established in Germany and provide assistance in various areas.<br>
PS: contact me by emailing your request to name@gmail.com</em></p>

<p class="rtejustify">&nbsp;<strong>How to recognize fraudulent credit offers and what to do about them?</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Verify the email addresses used</strong>. Such providers often use email addresses that end with @hotmail.com, @gmail.com and @outlook.com. Authorized lenders and registered intermediaries in principle use a professional email address.</li>
 <li>Spelling mistakes, unclear logos and vague email addresses that have nothing to do with the lender are important indications of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Beware</strong> <strong>of any offers of credit on unusually favourable terms</strong>. A very large loan at an extremely low interest rate or with a particularly long repayment period could be an indication of fraud. This is certainly the case where such loans would not be granted by authorized lenders.</li>
 <li>Be all the more suspicious if the lender asks that you <strong>first pay&nbsp;a sum of money</strong> to cover certain costs before issuing the loan<strong>.</strong></li>
 <li>Always check the lender’s <strong>identity</strong> and find out whether he has the requisite <strong>authorization</strong>. Via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search engine</a> on the website of the FSMA, you can easily determine whether the person has the requisite authorization or registration. Persons without an authorization or registration may not offer you a credit.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of</strong> <strong>'cloned firms</strong>'<strong>.</strong> These companies pass themselves off as authorized undertakings even though they in fact have no connection with the latter.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary</strong> if you receive an <strong>unsolicited credit offer</strong>. Receiving such an unsolicited email is often the first step of a fraudulent practice.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">In case you suspect you are receiving spam messages, <strong>you are advised to delete them immediately! </strong>Do not react to unsolicited credit offers.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>How to avoid ending up on a list used by cybercriminals?</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Tips provided on <a href="http://www.safeonweb.be/" target="_blank">www.safeonweb.be</a>:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Keep your email address private. </strong>Make sure that your email address is not posted publicly on the internet. Those who send spam and phishing emails automatically scour the web for email addresses. Always think twice before entering your email address somewhere.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not respond to unwanted messages and do not click ‘unsubscribe’ in spam mails. </strong>This way, spammers and phishers know that the email address actually exists and is still being used. You will receive even more spam. Moreover, the links in those emails are often false links.</li>
 <li><strong>Think twice before entering your email address for newsletters and marketing campaigns.&nbsp;</strong></li>
 <li><strong>Don't forward chain letters.&nbsp;</strong>Forwarding a chain letter causes your e-mail address and that of your contacts to be spread, so you will receive more spam.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-10-11T14:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">62710</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Kuvera Global</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/kuvera-global</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of Kuvera Global LLC (Kuvera), which irregularly offers investment services in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Kuvera, via the website www.kuveraglobal.com, offers Belgian consumers tools and trainings that are supposed to help them trade in forex products, virtual currencies and equity. Via these tools the users allegedly also get access to investment advice. Kuvera mainly targets young people.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In addition, the firm offers its members advantages and compensation that increase the more new members they recruit.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Kuvera is&nbsp;<strong>not</strong>, however, <strong>authorized</strong> to offer financial services and products in Belgium. Moreover, the system proposed by Kuvera exhibits features characteristic of a <strong>pyramid scheme</strong>. More information about this form of fraud is available on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22957">website of the FSMA</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Kuvera has also been the subject of warnings by the French supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/Actualites/Communiques-de-presse/AMF/annee-2019?docId=workspace%3A%2F%2FSpacesStore%2Fbaf7797f-28dc-471c-aeea-a0c19a204455">AMF</a>) and by the Spanish supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.cnmv.es/Portal/ResultadoBusqueda.aspx?tipo=1&amp;nombre=KUVERA%20LLC">CNMV</a>).</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For all these reasons, <strong>the FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by Kuvera.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a proposed transaction complies with the financial legislation? If so, please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-10-09T12:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">62686</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA draws attention to managing cyber security risks</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-draws-attention-managing-cyber-security-risks</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) publishes <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/62614">a communication about managing cyber security risks</a>. The communication follows on from the cyber security campaign held in Belgium this month.</strong></p>

<p>Cyber threats are a major operational risk that firms active in the financial sector face. They deserve every firm’s full attention, since their clients, data regarding them as well as their reputation are their most valuable asset.</p>

<p>The FSMA wants to raise awareness and provide guidance on the foundations of managing cyber risks. With the baseline information and cybersecurity principles listed in this document, the FSMA wants to assist all firms in the implementation of organizational and technical cyber measures concerning cyber security.</p>

<p>The FSMA drafted the communication in cooperation with the Centre for Cyber Security Belgium. Presently, the Centre and the Cyber Security Coalition jointly organize a cyber security awareness campaign, as part of the European Cyber Security Month in October 2019.</p>

<p>Focal point of that campaign is phishing. Its ultimate objective is to convince internet users to think twice before clicking on a link in an email. Do not click on just any link, is the underlying message. Whenever receiving a suspicious message, you can best forward it to <a href="mailto:suspicious@safeonweb.be">suspicious@safeonweb.be</a>. By doing so, the Centre for Cyber Security Belgium wants to reduce the number of phishing victims.</p>

<p>The FSMA fully supports this campaign.</p>

<p>More information is available on <a href="https://www.ccb.belgium.be/en">https://www.ccb.belgium.be/en</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-10-02T16:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">62616</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Be wary of investment offers made through social media</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/be-wary-investment-offers-made-through-social-media</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>New communication channels enable “fraudsters 2.0” to make even more victims. Social networks such as Twitter, Facebook, Instagram or LinkedIn appear to be ideal channels for spreading false investment offers, for instance offers in </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55960"><strong>crypto currencies</strong></a><strong>, in binary options and forex trading/CFDs, in “investment wines”, offers of portfolio management agreements and credit offers. The FSMA warns consumers against these offers, because often behind these tempting offers are scammers who are not authorized to make such offers, the sole aim of which is to steal your savings.</strong></p><ul><li><strong>How do false investment/credit offers circulate on social networks?</strong></li></ul><p>The following techniques appear to be most popular among fraudsters when making fraudulent offers via social networks:</p><ul><li><strong>Sponsored links on Facebook and Instagram</strong></li></ul><p>Investment fraud victims often indicate being contacted by phone after having clicked on a sponsored link or post on Facebook or Instagram.</p><p>At present, it appears that especially fraudulent investment offers in crypto currencies, in binary options and forex trade/CFDs and in “investment wines”, as well as fraudulent offers of portfolio management contracts are promoted via such links or posts (cf. the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings">relevant warnings</a> on the FSMA website).</p><p>Contrary to ordinary posts, which do not necessarily spring to the eye in the news feed, sponsored posts pop up based on age, gender or areas of interest, and in view of the pages consulted by the person concerned or the target audience.</p><p>Advertisements promoting “very profitable” investments appear in the relevant advertising spaces or in the news feed of the user concerned. The user is often invited to provide his contact details, so that he can be contacted again at a later stage.</p><p>Those advertisements are often illustrated with an image or video, and accompanied by fake comments and automatically generated likes. The message disseminated looks intriguing but remains extremely vague.</p><p>The pages containing those sponsored advertisements seem to be specifically conceived for such advertising campaigns. They appear under a variety of names, referring to the financial world in one way or another. Nevertheless, they hardly ever mention a telephone number, website, address or company name.</p><ul><li><strong>Simple sponsored ads on Facebook</strong></li></ul><p>Certain fraudulent offers, mostly of credits, are simply distributed by fraudsters through advertisements on Facebook groups specialized in, for example, buying and selling of real estate or second hand goods. The swindlers choose groups with mostly Belgian consumers.</p><ul><li><strong>Fake press articles referring to public figures</strong></li></ul><p>Fake press articles with alleged statements or interviews of public figures or celebrities praising financial investments, especially in cryptocurrencies, also circulate on the internet via fake news websites and via Facebook through sponsored advertisements.</p><p>The purpose of this practice is to gain your confidence by using images of well-known personalities in the media, sports or business world. Thus these fraudsters try get you to invest in their offers of lucrative investments that are too good to be true.</p><ul><li><strong>Fraudsters chat with their victims on social media</strong></li></ul><p>Fraudsters 2.0 also use social media to contact their victims personally, either by sending them a friend request, or by chatting with them using the chat boxes of Facebook, Instagram and even LinkedIn.</p><p>When such an unscrupulous operator initiates a conversation with a new victim, he will not try from the outset to tempt him to invest, quite the contrary. He first tries to bring about a <a href="https://context.reverso.net/vertaling/engels-nederlands/relationship+of+trust">relationship of trust</a> as is the case with friendship scams (only available in <a href="https://tropbeaupouretrevrai.be/fraude/les-fraudes-lamitie">French</a> and <a href="https://temooiomwaartezijn.be/fraude/vriendschapsfraude">Dutch</a>). Only after having been chatting for a few hours, weeks or even several month will the fraudster casually let it slip that he has a golden investment tip.</p><p>Some swindlers also open fake accounts by using the identity and the picture of persons who are quite active on social media. To our knowledge, this practice is mostly observed on Instagram.</p><ul><li><strong>Avoid being a victim of investment fraud on social media</strong></li></ul><p>Further to the <a href="https://www.worldinvestorweek.org/?p=resources&amp;id=key-messages">World Investor Week 2019</a> (thematic week organized by IOSCO), that focuses on the risks attaching to certain online investments, the FSMA invites you <strong>to follow the recommendations below in order not to become a victim of fraud:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) disproportionate returns.</strong> Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is!</li><li><strong>Do</strong> <strong>not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given (company identity, home country, etc.). If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li><li><strong>Check</strong> <strong>whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">Check your provider</a><strong>. Be wary as well of 'cloned firms'</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li><li><strong>Consult</strong> <strong>the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.<br><br>On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> provided. In addition, all companies about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the '<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium</a>' published on the FSMA website<br><br><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</li><li><strong>Be</strong> <strong>wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li><li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident.</li><li><strong>Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</strong></li><li><strong>Be</strong> <strong>all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li></ul><p><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p><ul><li><strong>What to do if you are a victim of fraud?</strong></li></ul><p>If you think you are the victim of fraud, make sure <strong>you do not pay any additional sums</strong> to your contact. Be especially wary if you are promised a refund in exchange for a final payment, as this is a technique frequently used by fraudsters in order to obtain additional funds.</p><p>Also, immediately <strong>contact </strong>the <a href="https://www.police.be/en">local police</a> to make a complaint and <strong>alert the FSMA to the scam</strong> via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p><p>The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint <strong>quickly </strong>and with <strong>ample documentation</strong> (the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p><p>Equally, do not hesitate to alert the FSMA to any suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning on its part.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-09-30T18:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">62512</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>World Investor Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week-0</link>
  <description>
<p>World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held between 30 September and 6 October 2019. The aim was to promote the education and protection of investors. The various initiatives of the supervisory authorities in these two critical areas were at the centre of attention.</p>

<p>World Investor Week 2019 focused more specifically on raising awareness about the risks and challenges attaching to the increasing digitalization of the financial markets. As vice-chair of IOSCO and member of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) once again supported this initiative. As such, the FSMA published inter alia a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/62512">warning</a> against fraudulent credit offers via social networks. The FSMA also participated in an event organized by the European Fund and Asset Management Association (EFAMA) in Brussels, focusing on the young generation's attitude towards investments.</p>

<p>Comprehensive information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-09-30T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">62599</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: New features and modifications in the CABRIO online app: anti-money laundering laws and regulations and continuing professional training obligation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-new-features-and-modifications-cabrio-online-app-anti-money-laundering-laws-and</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>This Newsletter presents information on the main new features and modifications brought in the CABRIO online application.</strong></p>

<p>The new features were introduced as a follow-up to <strong>anti-money laundering laws and regulations</strong>, which require you to provide certain information to the FSMA. <strong>These laws and regulations have led to several changes that require an action on your part as an intermediary or as a lender.</strong></p>

<p>The changes concern the entering of continuing <strong>professional training courses</strong> into the online application. These entries will henceforth be centralized, for all statuses, in the 'Recyclage' section. It is from now on furthermore possible to enter courses taken at accredited providers of training in credit intermediation. It will also be easier to sort, filter and search for the courses entered. The FSMA hopes that these changes will further improve the user-friendliness of the application.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Read more in the Newsletter... (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2019-07_newsletter_cabrio_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2019-07_nieuwsbrief_cabrio_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-07-11T19:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61573</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Combat against money laundering and terrorist financing – Define your organizational framework</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-combat-against-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing-define-your-organizational</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The application of a risk-based approach in the combat against money laundering and terrorist financing is a process composed of four successive steps. This Newsletter aims at defining the organizational framework.</strong></p>

<p>This Newsletter repeats the principal obligations regarding organization and internal control that are imposed by the regulation governing the combat against money laundering and terrorist financing. Those obligations are discussed in more detail in circular FSMA_2019_12 (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2019/fsma_2019_12_fr.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2019/fsma_2019_12_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">

(available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2019-07_newsletter_cadreorganisatonel_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2019-07_newsletter_organisatorischkader_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-07-04T19:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61684</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA authorises EMMI as administrator of the EURIBOR benchmark</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-authorises-emmi-administrator-euribor-benchmark</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 10 April 2019 the European Money Markets Institute (<a href="https://www.emmi-benchmarks.eu" target="_blank">EMMI</a>) applied for authorisation as administrator of the EURIBOR benchmark. On 2 July 2019, following the positive advice of the EURIBOR College of Supervisors, the FSMA granted the requested authorisation to EMMI, by application of the European Benchmark Regulation (BMR).</strong></p>

<p>The authorisation granted is restricted to the EURIBOR benchmark and does not include the EONIA benchmark. EMMI already informed the FSMA of its intention to apply for authorisation as administrator of the EONIA benchmark in September 2019.</p>

<p>The fact that EMMI has obtained authorisation as administrator of the EURIBOR benchmark, confirms that the requirements contained in the BMR are met. Consequently, the benchmark may also be used after 1 January 2020. As such, an important step is made towards the durability of the benchmark.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-07-03T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61711</guid>
    </item>

  <description>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD): new professional knowledge requirements in the insurance sector</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-insurance-distribution-directive-idd-new-professional-knowledge-requirements</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Law of 6 December 2018 transposing the IDD entered into force on 28 December 2018. This European Directive introduces new rules for insurance distribution. This year, the FSMA publishes a series of Newsletters to inform you about the major changes regarding insurance intermediaries. This Newsletter contains information about the new professional knowledge requirements applicable to persons exercising certain functions in insurance intermediaries or insurance undertakings.</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li>Exams: exam modules instead of exams per insurance branch</li>
 <li>'Trainee PCP'-status : in the insurance sector as well</li>
 <li>Follow-up training: minimum 15 hours per year</li>
 <li>Practical experience: minimum 6 months</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Find out more in the Newsletter... (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2019-06_newsletter_directiveidd_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2019-06_newsletter_directiveidd_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-06-26T16:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61574</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Presentation of the 2018 annual report</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/presentation-2018-annual-report</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has today published its 2018 annual report. At its presentation of the report, the FSMA commented, amongst other things,&nbsp;on the inspections it conducted in the insurance sector, the preparations for a possible Brexit, its involvement in certain aspects of the fight against&nbsp;money laundering, the promotion of sustainable investment, and work on the creation of the&nbsp;new FSMA financial education centre.</strong></p>

<p>The core mission of the FSMA is to contribute to an honest and fair treatment of financial consumers and to transparency in the financial markets. The FSMA’s areas of competence are: supervision of financial products, supervision of compliance with the conduct of business rules, market surveillance, supervision of financial service providers and intermediaries, supervision of supplementary pensions and contributing to the financial education of the public.</p>

<p>In 2018, the FSMA took measures and initiatives to prepare for the departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union. A hard Brexit may impact financial players offering their services from the United Kingdom within the EU and vice versa. Consumers who are clients of a British financial service provider may also feel the impact. Guaranteeing continuity of contracts after Brexit has been the FSMA’s chief concern.</p>

<p>This past year was marked in particular by efforts to combat money laundering. New rules were transposed into Belgian legislation and explained to the financial players under the supervision of the FSMA. These rules require them to inventory, assess and understand the risks to which they are exposed and then to take the necessary measures.&nbsp;The FSMA has already conducted 105 on-site inspections in this area.</p>

<p>Sustainability is also at the top of the international and European agenda. The range of sustainable financial products on offer has recently grown substantially. The FSMA considers it important that the sustainability of a product should not be used purely as a marketing argument. While awaiting the new European legislation governing the taxonomy of sustainable economic activities, the FSMA will conduct&nbsp;a public consultation at national level on the marketing of sustainable financial products.</p>

<p>During its presentation of the annual report, the FSMA also provided more information about the creation of the Wikifin Lab. The FSMA’s financial education centre will be an experiential learning centre where young people can receive financial education in a fun, interactive and pedagogical manner. The Wikifin Lab will open its doors in the next school year.</p>

<p>The FSMA also conducted inspections last year into the way in which insurers apply the rules on conflicts of interest and on distribution fees for the sale of class 23 insurance products to consumers. More information on these inspections is available in a separate press release (in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/61436">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/61436">Dutch</a>).</p>

<p>The annual report (in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/61522">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/61522">Dutch</a>) is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-06-21T20:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61491</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Warning by the FSMA regarding the General Meeting of Nyrstar</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/warning-fsma-regarding-general-meeting-nyrstar</link>
  <description>
<p>Within the framework of its supervision of the information disseminated by listed companies<sup><a href="#1">1</a></sup>,&nbsp;the FSMA is publishing the following warning regarding Nyrstar, a company whose shares are admitted to trading on Euronext Brussels.</p>

<p>The FSMA deems that the shareholders do not have sufficient information to be able to approve the annual financial statements for the financial year ended on 31 December 2018 at the general meeting of 25 June 2019. The FSMA bases this determination on the fact that the auditor issued a report of non-compliance concerning the said annual financial statements.</p>

<p>The FSMA has therefore asked the Board of Directors of Nyrstar that during the meeting, it postpone the decision on approving the financial statements by five weeks, as provided for in Article 555 of the Companies Code.</p>

<p>The FSMA has also recommended to Nyrstar that:</p>

<ul>
 <li>during the General Meeting of 25 June 2019, and even though this is not on the agenda,
 <ul>
  <li>it provide full transparency about the circumstances that led to the signing of the lock-up agreement and the recapitalisation terms announced on 15 April 2019;</li>
  <li>it answer questions that the shareholders will put to them;</li>
 </ul>
 </li>
 <li>it make available on its website as soon as possible all the information that is provided to the shareholders during the aforementioned general meeting, including the questions posed and the answers given to the shareholders’ questions.</li>
</ul>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<p><a name="1"></a><sup>1</sup> This warning is published in application of Article 43, § 1, second subparagraph of the Royal Decree of 14 November 2007 on the obligations of issuers of financial instruments admitted to trading on a regulated market.</p>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO Annual Meeting in Sydney </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-annual-meeting-sydney</link>
  <description>
<p class="intro">The 44th annual meeting of IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions, was held in Sydney, Australia, on 13, 14 and 15 May.</p>

<p>The members of IOSCO discussed the next steps needed in order to accomplish its 2019 workplan.</p>

<p>The workplan includes topics such as the sale of crypto-assets to consumers, the digitalization of the financial sector and the protection of consumers, data protection, sustainable finance, asset management and the use of new financial technologies.</p>

<p><a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS531.pdf">More information is available in IOSCO’s media release on the subject.</a></p>
</description>
