<item>
  <title>Euribor panel: withdrawal of National Bank of Greece</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/euribor-panel-withdrawal-national-bank-greece</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>National Bank of Greece (NBG) has informed EMMI of its intention to withdraw from the Euribor panel. The FSMA&nbsp;does not object to this decision.</strong></p>

<p>In accordance with the European Benchmark Regulation<sup><a href="#_ftn1">[1]</a></sup> (BMR), the FSMA is the supervisory authority of the European Money Markets Institute (EMMI), the Brussels-based entity that administers the Euribor benchmark. Euribor was added to the list of critical benchmarks by the European Commission in August 2016<sup><a href="#_ftn2">[2]</a></sup> and, as a critical benchmark, is supervised by a College of supervisors, including national competent authorities and ESMA, which is chaired by the FSMA (<em>the Euribor College</em>).</p>

<p>Since the end of 2013, EMMI has been working on reforming Euribor in order to underpin it to the greatest extent possible with transaction data and thus make it BMR compliant. When, in May 2017, efforts to implement a fully transaction-based methodology proved unfeasible, EMMI developed a hybrid methodology with the support of a dedicated Task Force in which the FSMA participated as an observer. In October 2018, EMMI published <a href="https://www.emmi-benchmarks.eu/assets/files/D0373B-2018%20Second%20Consultation%20Hybrid%20Euribor_full.pdf" target="_blank">a consultation paper presenting a summary of its findings</a>. The FSMA commended EMMI on the work done to develop and test the hybrid methodology, qualifying the results of the testing as a significant step towards a BMR compliant benchmark.</p>

<p>EMMI applied for authorization in April 2019. An important element towards the implementation of the hybrid methodology is the assurance that panel banks are capable to be operationally ready operationally ready to contribute under the new hybrid methodology.</p>

<p>National Bank of Greece (NBG) officially informed EMMI on 30 April 2019 of its intention to withdraw from the Euribor panel by 28 May 2019<sup><a href="#_ftn3">[3]</a></sup>. This notification was in line with previous communication from NBG stating its inability to consistently meet the minimum requirements of the new methodology.</p>

<p>EMMI formally notified the FSMA of the intended withdrawal of NBG on 30 April 2019. The FSMA received EMMI’s assessment of the implications of NBG’s withdrawal on the capability of the benchmark to measure the underlying market or economic reality on the same day<sup><a href="#_ftn4">[4]</a></sup>. EMMI concluded that the withdrawal would not substantially impact the benchmark’s representativeness and robustness.</p>

<p>On 23 May 2019, the FSMA presented the Euribor College with its own assessment of the impact of NBG leaving the panel, based on NBG’s level of actual and potential participation in the market that Euribor intends to measure. The FSMA came to the conclusion that, the leave of NBG would not put the representativity of the hybrid methodology at risk, and that NBG should therefore not be required to continue to contribute data to Euribor. After thorough deliberation, the Euribor College decided to support the FSMA’s conclusions and to advise the FSMA not to require NBG to stay on the Euribor panel.</p>

<p>On 28 May 2019, the FSMA informed EMMI, NBG and its supervisory authority the Hellenic Capital Market Commission of its decision not to make use of its powers under article 23(6) of the BMR to require NBG to continue to contribute input data regarding Euribor.</p>

<p>The FSMA’s decision with regard to NBG is without prejudice to any future decisions to use or refrain from using its powers to require panel banks to continue to contribute input data regarding Euribor. It is motivated by an individual assessment taking into account NBG’s specific level of actual and potential participation in the market that Euribor intends to measure.</p>

<p>The withdrawal of NBG from the Euribor Panel does not impact the transition to the hybrid methodology being implemented by EMMI. The FSMA, together with the Euribor College remain committed to work closely with EMMI, and all other stakeholders, to ensure a smooth transition to the hybrid methodology, which will improve the robustness, integrity and accuracy of&nbsp;Euribor.</p>

<div>
<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn1">[1]</a></sup> &nbsp;Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 of 8 June 2016.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn2">[2]</a></sup> &nbsp;Full list of critical benchmarks in the EU available here:&nbsp;<a href="https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32018R1557" target="_blank">https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32018R1557</a>.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn3">[3]</a></sup> &nbsp;In accordance with article 23(3) of the BMR.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn4">[4]</a> </sup>&nbsp;In accordance with article 23(4) of the BMR.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-05-28T20:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

<item>
  <title>First SkyWay Invest Group Limited ('SkyWay Capital')</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/first-skyway-invest-group-limited-skyway-capital</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of First SkyWay Invest Group Limited ('SkyWay Capital'), a company that offers investment instruments to the public in Belgium.</strong></p><p>Despite its previous <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/51812">warning</a>, the FSMA continues to receive questions from consumers about Skyway&nbsp;Capital, indicating that this company is still active in Belgium.</p><p>SkyWay Capital, is offering its shares to Belgian investors. However, it is doing so without having published a prospectus approved by the FSMA. The company in question is therefore not allowed to offer its shares in Belgium.</p><p>Moreover, the scheme proposed by SkyWay Capital exhibits the characteristics of a <strong>pyramid scheme</strong>. More information about this form of fraud is available on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14674">website of the FSMA</a>.</p><p>Various foreign supervisory authorities have likewise published warnings about Skyway Capital:</p><ul><li>The Lithuanian supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.lb.lt/en/news/bank-of-lithuania-warns-skyway-activities-in-lithuania-illegal">Bank of Lithuania</a>);</li><li>The German supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.bafin.de/SharedDocs/Veroeffentlichungen/DE/Verbrauchermitteilung/weitere/2018/vm_181108_first_skyway_invest_group.html">BaFin</a>);</li><li>The New Zealand supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.fma.govt.nz/library/warnings-and-alerts/skyway-capitalskyway-group/">FMA</a>);</li><li>The Greek supervisory authority (<a href="http://www.hcmc.gr/aweb/files/warnings/files/SkyWay_warning_09%2011%202018.pdf">HCMC</a>);</li><li>The Slovakian supervisory authority (<a href="http://www.nbs.sk/en/financial-market-supervision-practical-info/warnings/warning-list-of-non-authorized-business-activities-of-entities/nbs-warning-about-the-activity-of-first-skyway-invest-group-limited">NBS</a>);</li><li>The Italian supervisory authority (<a href="http://www.consob.it/web/consob-and-its-activities/warnings?viewId=ultime_com_tutela">Consob</a>).</li></ul><p>The FSMA <strong>therefore advises</strong> <strong>against responding to</strong> <strong>any public offers of investment instruments </strong>issued by Skyway Capital or persons connected with that company and against <strong>transferring money</strong> to any account number it might mention.</p><p>Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a proposed transaction complies with the financial legislation? If so, please use the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/">search engine</a> on the FSMA website. Feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-05-17T12:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">61035</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: new category of insurance intermediary: the mandated underwriter</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-new-category-insurance-intermediary-mandated-underwriter</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The law of 3 April 2019 introduces, effective 10 April 2019, a new category of insurance intermediary: the mandated underwriter (gevolmachtigde onderschrijver / souscripteur mandaté). </strong></p>

<p>This newsletter describes the new category known as ‘mandated underwriter’ (‘Gevolmachtigde onderschrijver’ in Dutch / ‘Souscripteur mandaté’ in French) and answers the following questions:</p>

<ul>
 <li>What is a mandated underwriter?</li>
 <li>Why create a new category of insurance intermediary?</li>
 <li>What requirements must mandated underwriters fulfil?</li>
 <li>What do you have to do if you carry out such activities?</li>
</ul>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/newsletter/2019-04_newsletter_underwriters_en.pdf">Read more in our Newsletter ...</a></p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-04-12T15:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">60608</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Newsletter: The IDD Directive introduces the new category of ancillary insurance intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-idd-directive-introduces-new-category-ancillary-insurance-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<p>The European Insurance Distribution Directive, known as the IDD, has been transposed into Belgian law.</p>

<p>The FSMA recently published a Newsletter covering the most important changes to the conditions for exercising the profession of insurance intermediary.</p>

<p>In addition to the existing categories of broker, agent and subagent, the law transposing the IDD introduces a new category of insurance intermediaries: the ancillary insurance intermediary.</p>

    </item>
<item>
  <title>Re-election of the chairman of the FSMA as chair of the Monitoring Board of the IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards) Foundation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/re-election-chairman-fsma-chair-monitoring-board-ifrs-international-financial-reporting</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Jean-Paul Servais, has been re-elected as chair of the IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards) Foundation Monitoring Board for a new mandate of two years.</strong></p>

<p>The Monitoring Board was created in 2009 with the aim of overseeing the IFRS Foundation, whose Trustees in turn exercise oversight over the IASB (International Accounting Standards Board). The IASB, as an independent, private-sector international body, sets international standards for reporting in annual reports and financial statements (IFRSs).</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board is made up of representatives of various prominent market regulators. At the moment, the Monitoring Board consists of representatives of securities regulators from the United States, Brazil, Japan and South Korea and representatives of the European Commission, the Chinese Ministry of Finance, and IOSCO. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Financial Sector Conduct Authority of South Africa, in representation of the IOSCO Africa and Middle-East Regional Committee, and the Comisión Nacional de Valores of Argentina in representation of the IOSCO Inter-American Regional Committee are observers. The Monitoring Board consults regularly with the Trustees and the chairman of the IASB with a view to reviewing the quality and nature of the governance framework of the IFRS Foundation and hence to supervising the development of high-quality IFRS standards that are currently used in 87% of jurisdictions worldwide and by more than 6000 listed companies within the European Union.</p>

<p>The Monitoring Board re-elected Jean-Paul Servais as chair for another two-year term, starting on 1 March 2019. The FSMA Chairman became a member of the Monitoring Board as a representative of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), of which he has been vice-chairman since 2016.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais: 'The FSMA is delighted by the decision to renew my mandate for a second term. It attests to the trust placed in us by the various members of the Monitoring Board and recognizes the work achieved in the past two years. We will continue to strive, with the same commitment and determination, for high quality accounting standards.'</p>

<p>IOSCO has also published a <a href="https://www.iosco.org/about/monitoring_board/pdf/Press-20190311-1.pdf" target="_blank">press release</a> to announce this re-election.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-03-12T13:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">60082</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: The Directive on Insurance Distribution: what changes does it bring about regarding the conditions for exercising the profession of insurance intermediary?</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-directive-insurance-distribution-what-changes-does-it-bring-about-regarding</link>
  <description>
<p>The Law of 6 December 2018 implementing into Belgian law the European Directive on Insurance Distribution (more commonly referred to as the 'IDD') entered into force on 28 December 2018.</p>

<p>The purpose of this Newsletter is to inform you of the main changes to the 'status' of insurance intermediaries.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Find out more in the Newsletter (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2019-02_newsletter_idd_fr.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2019-02_nieuwsbrief_idd_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) …</p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Provision of investment services and performance of investment activities in Belgium by companies governed by UK law after Brexit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/provision-investment-services-and-performance-investment-activities-belgium-companies-governed</link>
  <description>
<p>Communication <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/2019/fsma_2019_06_en.pdf" target="_blank">FSMA_2019_06</a> concerning the provision of investment services and performance of investment activities in Belgium by companies governed by the law of the United Kingdom after entry into force of Brexit.</p>

<p>The present communication is for the purpose of:</p>

<ul>
 <li>describing the system that applies in Belgium to investment firms governed by the law of the UK or Gibraltar after entry into force of Brexit;</li>
 <li>examining the issue of the impact of Brexit on the continuity of contracts in force, entered into in Belgium by investment firms governed by the law of the UK or Gibraltar. The present communication looks at this issue from the angle of administrative law, i.e. the impact of the loss of a European passport on the ability to continue the performance of such contracts for investment firms governed by the law of the UK that will no longer be authorized to carry on their activity in Belgium.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-02-21T16:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">59935</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Have you been offered a lucrative investment over the phone? Don’t be taken in!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/have-you-been-offered-lucrative-investment-over-phone-dont-be-taken-0</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of new ‘companies’ approaching Belgian consumers with offers of lucrative investments. These ‘companies’ do not hold any authorization.&nbsp;They are not authorized to provide investment services in Belgium. Moreover, these companies are most likely new ‘boiler rooms’.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Boiler room fraud</strong> is a type of fraud that generally involves contacting consumers unsolicited, often by telephone, offering to sell them shares or other financial products.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Although boiler rooms claim to be authorized service providers, with a professional website and forms to fill out, they are in reality fraudsters who offer fictitious or worthless products or services.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">As a rule, the consumer is enticed to make an initial, limited investment that very soon appears to be profitable. After that, the consumer is asked to make more and more additional investments. But when a consumer asks for his or her money back, this proves to be impossible without making additional payments and/or the new investments begin to lose money. <strong>In the end, the investor never recovers the amounts invested.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA warns the public against the following new ‘companies’:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59304">Ashcroft Cohen Strategic Capital - ACSC</a> </strong>(https://acscinc.com)</li>
 <li><strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59305">Asia Associates</a> </strong>(www.asiaassociates.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59306"><strong>Cobalt Capital Inc.</strong></a> (https://cobaltcapitalinc.com/)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59308"><strong>Index Financial Group</strong></a> (http://indexfinancialgroup.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59309"><strong>KLM Holdings</strong></a>&nbsp; (www.klmholdings.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59307"><strong>Resona Dai-Ichi Group</strong></a> (https://rdgfinancial.com)</li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/59310"><strong>Warrington Shaw</strong></a> (http://www.warringtonshaw.com)</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore <strong>strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services </strong>made by the companies listed above and<strong> against transferring money </strong>to any account number they might mention.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">In order to prevent consumers from falling victim to this type of investment fraud, the FSMA makes the following <strong>recommendations:</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of the company </strong>(company identity, home country, etc.) <strong>offering you financial services</strong>. If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. If the company is located outside the European Union, you will also have to be aware of the difficulty of legal recourse in the event of a potential dispute.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization</strong> by searching the lists published on the FSMA website – <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">Check your provider</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Consult the warnings</strong> published on the FSMA website as well as on the website of foreign supervisory authorities and of <a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal" target="_blank">IOSCO</a>. Check if the company offering you a financial service has been named in a warning. Search not only for the name of the company(ies) in question but also for the companies to which you are being asked to transfer money.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify">On the FSMA website, this search can be conducted via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en">search function</a> provided. In addition, all the boiler rooms about which the FSMA has already published a warning are included on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">'List of companies operating unlawfully in Belgium'</a> published on the FSMA website.</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Please note</strong>: the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning against a given company does not mean that that company is authorized to offer financial services. While the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that a company operating unlawfully on the Belgian market may not yet have come to its attention. Moreover, unauthorized companies regularly change their name.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Be wary of unsolicited phone calls/emails (cold calling)</strong>, that is, where no prior request has been made by the investor. Such calls are often indications of an attempt at fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of requests to transfer money to a country without any connection</strong> to the company or to the State of which the investor is resident. Please note that in the case of boiler room fraud, requests to transfer money are made most often toward accounts opened with banks based in Asia.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns.</strong> Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by such companies</strong>. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case. Be sure always to verify the information you are given.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary as well of "cloned firms"</strong>: companies that pass themselves off as different, lawful companies even though they in fact have no connection with the latter. A close look at the email addresses or contact details for the companies in question may prove useful in order to detect potential fraud of this sort.</li>
 <li><strong>Ask your intermediary for clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Never invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered.</li>
 <li><strong>Be all the more suspicious</strong> if the payout of returns is conditional on an <strong>additional payment</strong> and/or the payment of a tax. These additional demands are often the sign of fraud.</li>
 <li><strong>Company directors and managers</strong> should be extremely vigilant. Many boiler rooms target that group in particular.</li>
</ul>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>More than ever, caution is needed.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>If you have the least doubt</strong> about whether financial services being offered to you are lawful, please don’t hesitate to contact the FSMA directly using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876">consumer contact form</a>. As well, feel free to notify it should you come across a suspicious company that has not yet been the subject of a warning by the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-01-08T15:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68070</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Euribor Panel: withdrawal of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/euribor-panel-withdrawal-banca-monte-dei-paschi-di-siena</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena (BMPS) has informed EMMI of its intention to withdraw from the Euribor panel. The FSMA&nbsp;does not object to this decision.</strong><strong> </strong></p>

<p>In accordance with the European Benchmark Regulation<sup><a href="#_ftn1">[1]</a></sup> (BMR), the FSMA is the supervisory authority of the European Money Markets Institute (EMMI), the Brussels-based entity that administers the Euribor benchmark. Euribor was added to the list of critical benchmarks by the European Commission in August 2016<sup><a href="#_ftn2">[2]</a></sup> and, as a critical benchmark, is supervised by a College of supervisors, including national competent authorities and ESMA, which is chaired by the FSMA (<em>the Euribor College</em>).</p>

<p>Since the end of 2013, EMMI has been working on reforming Euribor in order to underpin it to the greatest extent possible with transaction data and thus make it BMR compliant. When, in May 2017, efforts to implement a fully transaction-based methodology proved unfeasible, EMMI developed a hybrid methodology with the support of a dedicated Task Force in which the FSMA participated as an observer. In October 2018, EMMI published <a href="https://www.emmi-benchmarks.eu/assets/files/D0373B-2018%20Second%20Consultation%20Hybrid%20Euribor_full.pdf">a consultation paper presenting a summary of its findings</a>. The FSMA commended EMMI on the work done to develop and test the hybrid methodology, qualifying the results of the testing as a significant step towards a BMR compliant benchmark.</p>

<p>EMMI has expressed its intention to apply for authorization by Q2, 2019, well ahead of the BMR transition deadline of 31 December 2019. An important element towards the implementation of the hybrid methodology is the assurance that panel banks are operationally ready and willing to contribute under the new hybrid methodology. In this context, EMMI sent a letter to panel banks on 21 November 2018, asking them to confirm, by 4 January 2019, their intention to remain a contributor to the Euribor and to devote the necessary resources to be ready for the operational launch of the hybrid methodology for Euribor by Q2 2019, with the effective phase-in date for each bank to be determined by EMMI.</p>

<p>Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena (BMPS) informed EMMI on 30 November 2018 of its intention to withdraw from the Euribor panel<sup><a href="#_ftn3">[3]</a></sup>. This notification was in line with previous communication from BMPS that its priorities lay with its own reorganisation rather than with preparing to be operationally ready for the new Euribor methodology. For the same reason, BMPS had not participated in the testing phase (from May until the end of July 2018) for the hybrid Euribor methodology.</p>

<p>The FSMA, having been informed by EMMI on 7 December 2018 of the intended withdrawal of BMPS, used its power under article 23 (5) of the BMR to require BMPS to continue contributing input data to Euribor until 4 January, pending the outcome of the procedure of mandatory contributions under article 23 of the BMR. The FSMA received EMMI’s assessment of the implications of BMPS’s withdrawal on the capability of the benchmark to measure the underlying market or economic reality on 12 December 2018<sup><a href="#_ftn4">[4]</a></sup>. EMMI concluded that the impact of this withdrawal on the representativeness and the robustness of the benchmark would be limited.</p>

<p>On 21 December 2018, the FSMA presented the Euribor College with its own assessment of the impact of BMPS leaving the panel, based on BMPS’s level of actual and potential participation in the market that Euribor intends to measure. The FSMA came to the conclusion that, without BMPS, the panel would still represent a considerable market share, which could allow EMMI to transition to a representative benchmark, and that BMPS should therefore not be required to continue to contribute data to Euribor. After thorough deliberation, the Euribor College decided to support the FSMA’s conclusions and to advise the FSMA not to require BMPS to stay on the Euribor panel.</p>

<p>On 4 January 2019, the FSMA informed EMMI, BMPS and its supervisory authorities Consob and Banca d’Italia of its decision not to make use of its powers under article 23 (6) of the BMR to require BMPS to continue to contribute input data regarding Euribor.</p>

<p>The FSMA’s decision with regard to BMPS is without prejudice to any future decisions to use or refrain from using its powers to require panel banks to continue to contribute input data regarding Euribor. It is motivated by an individual assessment taking into account BMPS’s specific level of actual and potential participation in the market that Euribor intends to measure.</p>

<p>The withdrawal of BMPS from the Euribor Panel does not impact the implementation plan for the hybrid methodology envisaged by EMMI. The FSMA, together with the Euribor College remain committed to work closely with EMMI, and all other stakeholders, to ensure a smooth transition to the hybrid methodology, which will improve the robustness, integrity and accuracy of&nbsp;Euribor.</p>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn1">[1]</a></sup> Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 of 8 June 2016.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn2">[2]</a></sup> Full list of critical benchmarks in the EU available here:&nbsp;<a href="https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32018R1557">https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32018R1557</a>.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn3">[3]</a></sup> In accordance with article 23(3) of the BMR.</p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn4">[4]</a></sup> In accordance with article 23 (4) of the BMR.</p>
</div>
</div>
</description>

<item>
  <title>IORPs: Communication of the annual accounts, statistics and related documents for the 2018 financial year</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iorps-communication-annual-accounts-statistics-and-related-documents-2018-financial-year</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2019/fsma_2019_01_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2019/fsma_2019_01_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) determines the concrete procedures to be followed by institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) when submitting reports for the 2018&nbsp;financial year.</p>

<p>IORPs must submit their complete FiMIS report at the latest three weeks before the general meeting at which the annual accounts are to be approved. If the general meeting makes any changes to the draft annual accounts, these changes can be entered in the reports until 30 June 2019. IORPs are asked to confirm the date of the general meeting at the latest by 28 February 2019&nbsp;in an email sent to the address <a href="mailto:pensions@fsma.be">pensions@fsma.be</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2019-01-04T10:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">59313</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Working group on euro risk-free rates: Call for feedback</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/working-group-euro-risk-free-rates-call-feedback</link>
  <description>
<p>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/50646">working group on euro risk-free rates</a>, chaired by a private sector representative and with the Secretariat provided by the European Central Bank, is calling on market participants and all other interested parties to comment on its technical analysis of the paths available for transitioning from the euro overnight index average (EONIA) to the euro short-term rate (ESTER), as well as on its recommendation of the preferred transition option. Comments on <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/pdf/cons/euro_risk-free_rates/ecb.eoniatransitionreport201812.en.pdf"><strong>the proposed transition path from EONIA to ESTER</strong></a> can be sent to <a href="mailto:EuroRFR@ecb.europa.eu"><strong>EuroRFR@ecb.europa.eu</strong></a> by 17:00 Frankfurt time on 1 February 2019 using the <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/pdf/cons/euro_risk-free_rates/ecb.eoniatransitionreport_responseform201812.en.xlsx"><strong>response form</strong></a>.</p>

<p>The working group is also seeking market feedback on its assessment of alternative ESTER-based term structure methodologies that can serve as a fallback for EURIBOR-linked contracts, as well as on their specific use cases. Comments on the <strong><a href="mailto:public%20consultation">public consultation</a></strong> can be sent your comments to <a href="mailto:EuroRFR@ecb.europa.eu"><strong>EuroRFR@ecb.europa.eu</strong></a> by 17:00 Frankfurt time on 1 February 2019 using the <strong><a href="mailto:response%20form">response form</a></strong>.</p>

<p>The working group on euro risk-free rates is an industry-led group established in 2018 by the European Central Bank, the Financial Services and Markets Authority, the European Securities and Markets Authority and the European Commission. Its main tasks are to identify and recommend alternative risk-free rates and transition paths. On 13 September 2018 the working group recommended ESTER as the new euro risk-free rate. ESTER reflects the wholesale euro unsecured overnight borrowing costs of euro area banks and will be produced by the ECB as of October 2019 at the latest. The next steps for the working group are to finalise its recommendation on the transition from EONIA to ESTER and to develop and recommend a term structure methodology as a fallback to EURIBOR.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-12-21T12:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">59193</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Crowdfunding growing steadily in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/crowdfunding-growing-steadily-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Investments in projects via crowdfunding have seen steady growth in Belgium, and it is expected that this trend will continue apace. This is the conclusion of a study conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p>

<p>The study examines crowdfunding that involves investing in a project by means of a capital contribution or a loan. These two types of crowdfunding are regulated in Belgium by the FSMA. The study focuses on the period between January 2012 and December 2017 and covers the five most important crowdfunding platforms active on the Belgian market. These are <em>Lita.co</em>, <em>Ecco Nova</em>, <em>Look&amp;Fin</em>, <em>Spreds</em> and <em>Bolero Crowdfunding</em>.&nbsp;</p>

<h2><strong>232 campaigns successfully financed</strong></h2>

<p>The five platforms launched a total of 273&nbsp;campaigns. Of those, 232 were successfully financed. 41 campaigns did not reach the defined target amount. The 232 successful campaigns raised a total of 40,025,000&nbsp;euros. The platforms follow a very strict selection of projects that are eligible for financing. Of the nearly 17,389&nbsp;projects proposed to the five platforms, only 273 survived the selection process.</p>

<h2><strong>Crowdfunding in constant growth</strong></h2>

<p>Both the number of projects and the total sums collected have seen a steady increase. While in 2012 only three projects were financed, by 2017 the number had risen to 92&nbsp;projects. The total amount collected in 2017 was roughly 20 million euros. The sharp increase in 2017 is probably linked to the relaxation of the prospectus rules. The tax exemption via the tax shelter introduced that year may also have played a part.</p>

<h2><strong>Investors are prudent</strong></h2>

<p>Investors in projects via crowdfunding are generally prudent. On average, each campaign was financed by 100&nbsp;different investors. The average amount per investor and per campaign was 2,871&nbsp;euros. More than half the investors invested 500&nbsp;euros or less per campaign, while less than 3&nbsp;per cent of investors contributed more than 5000&nbsp;euros.</p>

<h2><strong>Varying rate of return</strong></h2>

<p>The debt financing campaigns yielded investors an average of 7.42 per cent. In the case of equity campaigns, there have so far been two collective exits from the capital. One of those yielded a significant return (100&nbsp;per cent after deducting costs), while investors in the second case lost money (-4 per cent). Seven companies financed via equity campaigns went bankrupt.</p>

<h2><strong>Further growth expected</strong></h2>

<p>Investments via crowdfunding are expected to continue to grow, partly as a result of the exemption from the prospectus obligation for projects of under 5 million euros. The tax relief introduced in 2017 via the tax shelter, which provides, among other things, for a tax deduction of up to 45&nbsp;per cent for investments in micro-enterprises may also be a contributing factor. Nevertheless, crowdfunding remains a marginal source of financing in comparison with, for example, the 131 billion euros in bank loans extended to businesses in 2017.</p>

<p>The research report has been published in English and is available on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/crowdfunding/2018-12-19_crowdfundingstudy.pdf">the website of the FSMA</a>. The executive summary is also available in French and in Dutch.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-12-20T12:45:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">59165</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Mandatory public takeover bid by Congra Software Sàrl on Global Graphics plc</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/mandatory-public-takeover-bid-congra-software-sarl-global-graphics-plc</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>NOTIFICATION ANNOUNCED BY THE FSMA IN ACCORDANCE WITH ARTICLE 7 OF THE ROYAL DECREE OF 27 APRIL 2007 ON PUBLIC TAKEOVER BIDS</strong></p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (“Authoriteit voor Financiële Diensten en Markten”/”Authorité des Services et Marchés Financiers”) (FSMA) announces, in accordance with article 7 (1) of the Royal Decree of 27 April 2007 on public takeover bids, the notification which it received pursuant to article 5 of the aforementioned Decree on 28 November 2018 with respect to the launch by Congra Software Sàrl, a private limited liability company (“besloten vennootschap/”société à responsabilité limitée”) incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg, with its registered office at 19-21 Route d'Arlon L-8009 Strassen, Luxembourg and registered under number B162896 (<strong>the Bidder</strong>), of a mandatory public takeover bid in cash for the shares issued by Global Graphics plc, a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, with its registered office at 2030 Cambourne Business Park, Cambourne, Cambridge, CB23 6DW, the U.K. and registered under number 10872426, whose shares are admitted to trading on the regulated market Euronext Brussels.</p>

<p>As announced by the Bidder on 13 November 2018, by entering into share purchase agreements with Johan Volckaerts and Clema Capital Sàrl relating to 1,973,068 shares in Global Graphics plc (representing 17.04 % of the voting rights), the Bidder – who is affiliated and acting in concert with Powergraph BVBA, who holds 1,640,000 shares in Global Graphics plc (representing 14.17 % of the voting rights) – has incurred an obligation under the UK City Code on Takeovers and Mergers to launch a public takeover bid. To date, the Bidder and Powergraph BVBA together hold 3,745,096 shares in Global Graphics plc (representing 32.35 % of the voting rights).</p>

<p>The mandatory public takeover bid will be made at a price in cash of EUR 4.25 per share, i.e. the same price that was paid in the context of the aforementioned share purchase agreements. The mandatory public takeover bid relates to all the shares in Global Graphics plc not already owned by the Bidder or persons acting in concert with the Bidder. The UK City Code on Takeovers and Mergers does not require the mandatory public takeover bid to extend to shares held in treasury by Global Graphics plc. Accordingly, the mandatory public takeover bid will extend to such treasury shares only to the extent that they are transferred out of treasury to option holders to satisfy the exercise of outstanding, vested share options during the course of the mandatory public takeover bid. In case of exercise of all 104,776 outstanding vested share options, the bid relates to a total of 7,936,946 shares in Global Graphics plc. The mandatory public takeover bid is unconditional.</p>

<p>The Bidder intends to launch a squeeze-out process in accordance with English law (under Chapter 3 of Part 28 of the UK Companies Act 2006) if it has acquired, by virtue of acceptances of the bid, not less than 90 % in value of the shares to which the offer relates and not less than 90 % of the voting rights carried by those shares.</p>

<p>As explained in the joint press release by Congra Software sàrl and Global Graphics plc of 13 November 2018, the mandatory public takeover bid falls under the shared jurisdiction of the U.K. Panel on Takeovers and Mergers in the U.K. and the FSMA in Belgium, who are jointly regulating this mandatory takeover bid. The Bidder has submitted to the FSMA a draft takeover prospectus that will published after its approval.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Cryptocurrency fraud: don’t be taken in!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/cryptocurrency-fraud-dont-be-taken</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In spite of prior warnings by the FSMA, cryptocurrency fraud continues to trap ever more victims in Belgium. Therefore the FSMA is publishing a new warning today against these forms of fraud. It has also updated the <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium?field_type_of_fraude_tid_i18n=10595&amp;submit=Apply">list of cryptocurrency trading platforms</a> for which it has detected indications of fraud, adding 21 new suspect sites. This list now comprises a total of 99 websites.</strong></p>

<h3 class="blue">How do these types of fraud get started?</h3>

<p>Swindlers may reach you in a number of different ways.</p>

<ul>
 <li>You may be approached after having expressed interest in an advertisement published on social media or other websites that sings the praises of cryptocurrencies. If you click on such an advertisement, you will be asked to fill in a contact form with your email address and phone number. In the next few days, you will first receive a phone call from a telephone salesperson, who will offer you some explanations of cryptocurrencies and direct you to his or her 'company’s' website.</li>
 <li>These types of swindlers are also very active on social media such as Facebook, which they use to promote their 'investments'. So be careful about 'liking' a page!</li>
 <li>Lastly, you may also be contacted by phone without having taken any prior initiative yourself. This technique, known as 'cold calling', is widely used in the commission of investment fraud.</li>
</ul>

<h3 class="blue">What do the fraudsters offer you?</h3>

<p>Once the fraudsters have your contact details, they offer you an investment they claim is <strong>secure, easy </strong>and <strong>very lucrative</strong>. They try to inspire confidence by assuring you that you don’t need to be an expert in cryptocurrencies in order to invest in them. They claim to have specialists who will manage your investments for you.</p>

<p>The formulas vary: purchase of cryptocurrencies, savings accounts based on cryptocurrencies, management agreements, ICOs, etc.</p>

<p>Whatever the formula, the (false) promises are often the same:</p>

<ul>
 <li>a very high rate of return, often around 8% per month (sometimes even more!);</li>
 <li>the possibility of withdrawing your money very easily and at any time ('in a few clicks');</li>
 <li>the funds deposited are guaranteed (often at 100%!), which means that even if the market collapses, you will recover at least your initial investment, which makes this a very safe type of investment.</li>
</ul>

<p>All these promises are worthless, however: if an offer is fraudulent, the promises that accompany it are equally so.</p>

<h3 class="blue">When and how to determine that an offer is a fraud?</h3>

<p>Generally speaking, it is hard to tell that one has been the victim of investment fraud. Often for several months, the swindlers manage to maintain the illusion that this is an entirely legitimate and highly profitable investment, thereby encouraging their victims to invest even more.</p>

<p>They do not hesitate to employ various particularly effective techniques to this end. Their websites look very professional: they provide you with a <strong>personal space</strong> where <strong>you can track changes in the value of your investment</strong> via well designed tables and graphs.</p>

<p>At the beginning of their relationship with their 'clients', the fraudsters will typically <strong>make one or more payouts to you</strong>. They try in this way to show that they are trustworthy, sending you 'earnings' either upon your request or automatically. But don’t fall for their ruse: their aim is solely to persuade you to invest even larger amounts. When you try later to recover your money, suddenly there is no one at the other end of the line.</p>

<p>In some cases, the swindlers ask you to pay capital gains tax or exit fees before you can receive your earnings. But these are simply pretexts to get you to make one last payment: as soon as these 'fees' are paid, the fraudsters disappear with your money and cut off all contact.</p>

<h3 class="blue">How can you protect yourself from these types of fraud?</h3>

<p>In order to avoid such swindles, the FSMA <strong>invites </strong>you <strong>to exercise utmost prudence and advises</strong> you <strong>to remain alert to any indication of investment fraud</strong>. It therefore offers a few recommendations:</p>

<ul>
 <li>always <strong>verify the identity of the company</strong> (company name, home country, etc.). If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</li>
</ul>

<p>Be wary as well of companies that claim to hold authorizations from supervisory authorities and refer you to such authorizations. This is a very frequently used technique. However, these are often cases of <strong>identity theft</strong>. Feel free to ask the FSMA to confirm the information you have received.</p>

<p>The FSMA wishes to reiterate that there is no current supervision of online platforms active in the cryptocurrency sector, and refers in this regard to its warnings published on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8290">14 January 2014</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8076">16 April 2015</a>.</p>

<p>Also be wary if the company or its <strong>website is fairly new</strong>; this is often the case with fraudulent cryptocurrency trading platforms.</p>

<ul>
 <li>always<strong> ask</strong> your interlocutor for <strong>clear and comprehensible information</strong>, and take a <strong>critical attitude</strong> to the information they provide.</li>
</ul>

<p>Many cryptocurrency trading platforms promise guaranteed returns or protection of your entire capital. In the cryptocurrency sector, such promises are illusory! Moreover, if an offer is fraudulent, the guarantee given is equally so.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>be wary as well of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns</strong>. Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is.</li>
</ul>

<p>The FSMA also suggests you consult the <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium?field_type_of_fraude_tid_i18n=10595&amp;submit=Apply">list of cryptocurrency trading platforms</a> for which it has detected indications of fraud. <strong>Please note, however</strong>: this list is based solely on observations made by the FSMA on the basis of reports received from consumers. It therefore does not include all players that may be unlawfully active in this sector.</p>

<p><strong>In case of any doubt, feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876">consumer contact form</a> on its website.</strong></p>

<h3 class="blue">Have you been victim of this type of fraud, or do you think you might have been?</h3>

<p>If you are the victim of this type of fraud or think you might have been, file a complaint with the local police or the competent judicial authorities. The FSMA stresses the importance of filing a complaint <strong>quickly </strong>and with <strong>ample documentation</strong> (the company in question, bank accounts to which you transferred money, etc.).</p>

<p>For any questions you may have, feel free to contact the FSMA’s services using the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>. The FSMA also invites you to send it any useful information that can help it fulfil its mandate to protect the financial consumer.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>For more information on this type of fraud, the FSMA invites you to consult its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55960">warning</a> of 22 February 2018 as well, which includes a particularly evocative and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55962">detailed testimony</a> by a victim of such a platform.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-10-26T18:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58621</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Update by the NBB and the FSMA on asset management and shadow banking in Belgium</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/update-nbb-and-fsma-asset-management-and-shadow-banking-belgium</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The National Bank of Belgium (NBB) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) are today publishing an <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/shadowbanking/2018_update_assetmanagement_shadow_banking.pdf" target="_blank">updated study</a> of asset management and shadow banking in Belgium. This update is part of the regular monitoring of that sector, which constitutes a €147 billion market in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>In 2017, the FSMA and the NBB published an initial, extensive report on asset management and shadow banking in Belgium. The study was prepared for the Minister of Finance, Johan Van Overtveldt, in response to the recommendations of the High Level Expert Group on the Future of the Belgian Financial Sector. An update to that initial report, with recent figures and an analysis of national and international developments, is now available.</p>

<p>The initial report and the update address the trend toward a more market-based financial system, where financial intermediation also takes place outside the banking sector. In international fora, the term ‘shadow banking’ is in fact no longer used, but has been replaced by the preferred term ‘non-bank&nbsp;financial intermediation’.</p>

<p>This type of financing offers an alternative to borrowing from banks and helps to support the real economy. It fits in well with the argument, put forward in Europe, that the economy should become less dependent on banks for financing. But non-bank financial intermediation can – like any other financial activity – also give rise to systemic risks that could threaten the stability of the financial system.</p>

<p>Non-bank financial intermediation can take many forms. At the request of the High Level Expert Group, the supervisory authorities’ reports analyse asset management and non-bank financial intermediation. The expert group had recommended that the risks associated with these activities and their interconnectedness with other sectors be more closely monitored.</p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB have calculated the scale of non-bank financial intermediation in Belgium based on the definition given by the Financial Stability Board, the organisation which on behalf of the G20 oversees reforms of the financial sector at a worldwide level. The total financial assets in this category amounted to €&nbsp;147 billion at the end of last year. These assets consist mainly of money market funds and non-equity investment funds. The vast majority of these funds are under the supervision of the Belgian authorities.</p>

<p>As things stand currently, no substantial systemic risks have been identified in relation to asset management and non-bank financial intermediation. The developments in both areas of activity and the links with other sectors of the economy do, however, require careful monitoring, including for potential reputational risks to financial service groups.</p>

<p>The latter include the so-called ‘step-in’ risk, namely, the risk that these groups may de facto feel obliged to compensate clients for the risks associated, for example, with the investment funds sold by these groups, even where they are not contractually bound to do so.</p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB consider it very important to collect hitherto unavailable data on asset management and non-bank financial intermediation. It is for this reason that the FSMA has adjusted and expanded the statistical information which investment funds are required to submit. Soon a royal decree will be published that equips investment funds with tools that can be used in the event of liquidity problems.</p>

<p>As the Minister of Finance, Johan Van Overtveldt, observes with regard to the updated study: ‘The report illustrates the important progress observed in the development of capital markets in Belgium and Europe, which should better shield taxpayers’&nbsp;money from financial calamities, while at the same time providing more direct funding to the Belgian economy. It also helps to satisfy my&nbsp;concerns over the lack of transparency and supervision of these non-bank funding channels. Regarding the evolution in “shadow banking” we must&nbsp;remain vigilant. There is still a lot of work to be done.’</p>

<p>According to the Governor of the NBB, Jan Smets: ‘The risks associated with these activities are a priority for the NBB from the perspective of financial stability. In this regard, international developments also have to be closely monitored.’</p>

<p>In the view of Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA: ‘Non-bank financial intermediation is a useful supplementary source of funds for the real economy. But it is certainly important to continue gathering data with a view to effective monitoring, which is one of the FSMA’s tasks.’</p>

<item>
  <title>End of the World Investor Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/end-world-investor-week</link>
  <description>
<p>World Investor Week, an initiative of IOSCO (the International Organization of Securities Commissions), was held between 1 and 7 October 2018. The aim was to promote the education and protection of investors worldwide. The week featured various activities run by supervisory authorities and other stakeholders from 90 countries.</p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), which is currently vice-chair of IOSCO and member of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, lent its support once again this year to this initiative. &nbsp;It is important in the wake of World Investor Week to continue pursuing its objectives so that discussion of financial topics and attention to financial education remain key priorities.</p>

<p>Comprehensive information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org" target="_blank">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-10-08T11:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58498</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Updating of the takeover rules</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/updating-takeover-rules</link>
  <description>
<p>A <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/wg/kbar/2018-09-23_kb_ar.pdf" target="_blank">Royal Decree</a> was published in the Belgian Official Gazette on 5 October 2018 containing, among other things, amendments to the Takeover Decree (Royal Decree of 27 April 2007 on takeover bids) and the Squeeze-out Decree (Royal Decree of 27 April 2007 on squeeze-out bids), with a view to updating the said texts.</p>

<p>For the companies of which voting securities are admitted to trading on Euronext Growth or Euronext Access, the threshold for a mandatory bid has been increased from 30% to 50%.</p>

<p>For issuers of debt instruments that make a bid to buy back their (own) listed debt instruments, the obligation to publish a prospectus has been abolished and replaced by the obligation to publish a press release approved by the FSMA.</p>

<p>The definitions of the terms ‘credit institution’ and ‘stockbroking firm’ have been broadened, in part so that the guarantee of the availability of the resources necessary to carry out the offer may be issued by any credit institution or stockbroking firm established in a member state of the European Economic Area.</p>

<p>The rules governing the reporting to the FSMA, during the bid period, of certain securities transactions has also been relaxed. Thus, for example, persons who hold voting securities in the offeror no longer have to report their transactions.</p>

<p>The Squeeze-out Decree has been entirely updated and adjusted to take account of the case law since 2007 regarding squeeze-outs. The rules in the Takeover Decree that govern the takeover bids issued by an offeror that controls the target company have, moreover, been harmonised with the amendments made to the corresponding provisions of the Squeeze-out Decree.</p>

<p>The Law of 11 July 2018 had already amended Article 33 of the Takeover Law, which addresses advertising. 'Other documents and announcements that relate to a takeover bid' are no longer treated as equivalent to advertisements, as a result of which they do not have to be approved by the FSMA any more.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-10-05T11:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58497</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>World Investor Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week</link>
  <description>
<p>IOSCO, the International Organization of Securities Commissions, is today launching the second edition of World Investor Week. After the great success of last year’s event, the initiative will be repeated this year from 1 to 7 October 2018. The aim is to promote the education and protection of investors worldwide. The week will feature various activities organized by supervisory authorities and other stakeholders from more than 80 countries.</p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), which is currently vice-chair of the IOSCO committee on retail investors, will once again this year lend its support to this initiative. In particular, it is participating in the national anti-fraud campaign, the second stage of which, devoted to investment fraud, is currently under way. The corresponding Belgian thematic week, held in March 2018 under the banner of “Money Week”, pursues the same objective, namely to foster discussion of financial topics and devote particular attention to financial education.</p>

<p>Additional information on World Investor Week is available on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-10-01T16:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58362</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Burden of proof in insurance contracts</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/burden-proof-insurance-contracts</link>
  <description>
<p>Insurance contracts sometimes contain clauses that require policyholders/insureds/beneficiaries to prove that a given event has not occurred. Such persons thus have to prove that there is no reason (grounds for exclusion) why they should not be entitled to a payout by the insurer. An analysis of the legislation clearly indicates, however, that if the insurer refuses to pay compensation on the basis of a contractual ground for exclusion, it is up to the insurer to prove that such a ground for exclusion exists. Insurance contracts may not, therefore, contain clauses that place the burden of proof of the existence of a ground for exclusion on the policyholders/insureds/beneficiaries. More information is available in the FSMA’s opinion on this matter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/58357">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/58357">Dutch</a> only).&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-09-20T11:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58358</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Anti-fraud campaign: If it seems too good to be true, it probably is!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/anti-fraud-campaign-if-it-seems-too-good-be-true-it-probably</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Over the past few months, a major awareness campaign has been underway to combat online fraud. The campaign is centred on the slogan: 'If it seems too good to be true, it probably is'.</strong></p>

<p>The first stage of the campaign focused on fraud involving cryptocurrencies. The second stage, currently in progress, addresses investment fraud. Later in the year, a final stage will be devoted to ‘friendship scams’.</p>

<p>The FSMA is playing an active role in the campaign, in collaboration with the FPS Economy and the office of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Employment, Economy and Consumer Affairs, Kris Peeters.</p>

<p>There have been numerous reports of investment scams. Each year, hundreds of consumers and businesses have been victims of crooks who offer them alternative financial products that look ‘attractive’. The awareness campaign provides consumers with information that will enable them to recognize these sorts of fraudulent practices and invites potential investors always to verify who it is they are dealing with.</p>

<p>More information about the campaign is available in French (<a href="http://www.tropbeaupouretrevrai.be/" target="_blank">www.tropbeaupouretrevrai.be</a>) or Dutch (<a href="http://www.temooiomwaartezijn.be/" target="_blank">www.temooiomwaartezijn.be</a>) only.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-09-14T18:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58224</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>ESTER benchmark</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/ester-benchmark</link>
  <description>
<p>The working group set up by the European Central Bank to examine the interest rate benchmarks that will succeed EONIA has suggested ESTER (Euro Short-Term Rate) as the new euro risk-free rate.</p>

<p>For more information on this matter, please see <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2018/html/ecb.pr180913.en.html" target="_blank">the press release published by the ECB</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-09-14T18:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58223</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Disclosure of information to customers about the impact of the Brexit </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/disclosure-information-customers-about-impact-brexit</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) published on 28 June 2018 an ‘Opinion on disclosure of information to customers about the impact of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union’.</strong></p>

<p>This opinion is addressed to the national supervisory authorities. It deals with the duty imposed on insurance companies and intermediaries to inform customers about the possible consequences of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.</p>

<p>In its opinion, EIOPA first indicates that customers should be made aware in due time of the implications of the Brexit for contracts existing on the withdrawal date. Clients are to be provided with clear and non-misleading information on the contingency measures taken or planned and on their impact on their insurance contracts.</p>

<p>Potential customers should also be appropriately informed about the impact on their contractual rights and the provision of insurance services that may emerge from the Brexit.</p>

<p>The opinion provides further details on these information duties. It also specifies that EIOPA, in conjunction with national supervisory authorities, will monitor how customers are informed.</p>

<p>The original English version of the ‘<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/Brexit/2018-06-28_eiopa_opinionondisclosure.pdf" target="_blank">Opinion on disclosure of information to customers about the impact of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union</a>’.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-09-05T13:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58104</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Information session about the European Single Electronic Reporting Format (ESEF)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/information-session-about-european-single-electronic-reporting-format-esef</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), XBRL Belgium and the National Bank of Belgium (NBB) will organize an information session about the European Single Electronic Format (ESEF) on 10 October 2018.</strong></p>

<p>The European Single Electronic Format (ESEF) is the electronic reporting format in which issuers listed on EU regulated markets shall prepare their annual financial reports from 1 January 2020. IFRS consolidated financial statements contained in those reports shall be labelled with XBRL ‘tags’ which make the labelled disclosures structured and machine-readable.</p>

<p>During this event regulators, listed companies with (i)XBRL experience and experienced stakeholders will share their insights on the ESEF roadmap towards 2020 to help prepare for structured electronic reporting.</p>

<p>The target audience consists of all those involved in the preparation, audit and filing with the FSMA for publication through <a href="http://stori.fsma.be/Pages/Search.aspx?PageID=a2f7bbda-e4c5-42d6-98a8-6edf860ed7b1" target="_blank">STORI</a> (the Belgian official mechanism for storage of regulated information) of annual financial reports of listed companies as well as those who will make use of the structured electronic reporting in the ESEF inline XBRL format.</p>

<p><a href="https://www.xbrl.be/esef-event-2018/" target="_blank">Click here for further information</a> on the agenda of this event.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-09-04T11:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">58120</guid>
    </item>

  <title>Periodic questionnaire on the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/periodic-questionnaire-prevention-money-laundering-and-terrorist-financing</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular (available in French or Dutch&nbsp;only)&nbsp;informs obliged entities on the contents of the information, and the modalities for their transmission, intended to be used to assess the compliance and the efficiency of the system they have implemented for combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This information is collected by means of an annual questionnaire, which is an important tool in the exercise of the Financial Services and Markets Authority’s (hereinafter 'FSMA') permanent legal supervisory powers in combating ML/TF.</p>
</description>

  <title>Circular on the implementation of a risk-based approach to combating money laundering</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/circular-implementation-risk-based-approach-combating-money-laundering</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2018/fsma_2018_12_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2018/fsma_2018_12_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only) sets out the measures relating to the application of the provisions of the Law of 18&nbsp;September 2017 on the implementation, by obliged entities, of a risk-based approach to combating money laundering and terrorist financing. It also specifies the expectations of the FSMA regarding the implementation of these provisions and certain supervisory actions that the FSMA intends to take to ensure compliance with these provisions.</p>
</description>

<p>In a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/2018/fsma_2018_11_en.pdf" target="_blank">communication</a>, the FSMA sets out the procedure for the filing of information notes with the FSMA pursuant to the Law of 11 July 2018 on public offers of investment instruments and the admission to trading of investment instruments on regulated markets.   <title>Brokers in banking and investment services – New requirements under the transposition into Belgian law of the MiFID II Directive</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/brokers-banking-and-investment-services-new-requirements-under-transposition-belgian-law-mifid</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has drawn up a document (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2018/fsma_2018_10_fr.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2018/fsma_2018_10_nl.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>)&nbsp;for brokers in banking and investment services which clarifies a number of points regarding certain organizational and governance requirements laid down by MifID II and that under the Law of 21 November &nbsp;2017 are mandatory for this group of brokers. The provisions have been in force since 3 January 2018.</p>

<div class="box box-small box-info">
<p>More information is available in the Newsflash (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2018-07-19_newsflash_clarificationmifidii.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2018-07-19_newsflash_verduidelijkingenmifidii.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>

<item>
  <title>Presentation of the 2017 annual report</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/presentation-2017-annual-report</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has today published its 2017 annual report. On the occasion of the presentation of the annual report, the FSMA described the preventive and enforcement actions taken by the FSMA in 2017 and a number of topics that were addressed in the course of the year.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA’s core mission is to contribute to the honest and fair treatment of financial consumers and to the transparency of the financial markets. The FSMA’s areas of competence are:&nbsp; supervision of financial products, supervision of compliance with conduct of business rules, market surveillance, supervision of financial service providers and intermediaries, supervision of supplementary pensions and contributing to the financial education of the public.</p>

<p>In order to fulfil its mandate, the FSMA can take a wide range of actions. In all that it does, the FSMA seeks to act preventively whenever possible.</p>

<p>The ex ante approval of advertisements for financial products is one example of such preventive action. Verifying advertising materials beforehand helps prevent the use of misleading advertisements or those that do not fulfil the legal requirements. As a result, there are very few complaints about such types of advertising. In 2017, more than 3,200 advertisements received prior approval from the FSMA.</p>

<p>The ban on distributing particularly complex structured products likewise serves a preventive purpose. In 2017, 20 of the 50 such products with new features were rejected in Belgium as too complex. Another form of preventive action has been the introduction of new regulations such as the ban on distribution of binary options on the Belgian market. The number of complaints about such products has thus also fallen substantially. The warnings that the FSMA publishes against potentially illegal offers of financial products and services also fit within that preventive approach. Last year the FSMA published 116 warnings, as compared to 54 in 2016. This increase is due partly to the rise in notifications from consumers, who are finding it easier to contact the FSMA in this regard.</p>

<p>In cases where preventive action is not possible, the FSMA can take enforcement measures. One of the options available to it is the imposition of administrative sanctions. In 2017, the FSMA imposed 13 such sanctions for a total amount of EUR 2.15 million. Since mid 2012, a total of 50 administrative sanctions have been imposed, amounting to EUR 16.2 million. Another form of enforcement action is to withdraw the registration of intermediaries. In 2017, the FSMA withdrew 285 intermediaries from its register.</p>

<p>At the presentation of the annual report, attention was also paid to the sectoral inquiries that the FSMA conducted in the areas of insurance and pensions, and to the new Whistleblowers’ point of contact. Since the launch of the point of contact at the end of last September, the FSMA has received 51 reports from whistleblowers.</p>

<p>The annual report (in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/57282">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/57282">Dutch</a>) is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-06-08T12:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">57320</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Signature of a new MoU on coordinated supervision of Euronext</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/signature-new-mou-coordinated-supervision-euronext</link>
  <description>
<p>On 31 May 2018, the FSMA and the British (FCA), Dutch (AFM), French (AMF), Irish (Central Bank of Ireland) and Portuguese (CMVM) financial market authorities, together forming the Euronext College of Regulators, signed a new <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/MoU/EN/mou_2018-05-31_en.pdf" target="_blank">Memorandum of Understanding</a> (‘MoU’) on the coordinated regulation and supervision of Euronext. This MoU supersedes the MoU previously signed in March 2015 and marks the integration of the Central Bank of Ireland into the Euronext College of Regulators. This comes after Euronext NV completed the acquisition of the Irish Stock Exchange, now Euronext Dublin, on 26 March 2018.</p>

<p>The Euronext College of Regulators was set up in order to establish a common coherent and efficient regulatory framework between the different national competent authorities supervising Euronext. It came into existence, shortly after the Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris Stock Exchanges merged into Euronext in 2000 and has evolved over the years taking into account the evolution of Euronext.</p>

<p>The new MoU was signed in Brussels during the Chairmen’s Committee meeting, under the FSMA’s Chairmanship of the Euronext College of Regulators.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-06-01T13:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">57194</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA has a new data protection policy</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-has-new-data-protection-policy</link>
  <description>
<p>On 25 May 2018, new data protection legislation enters into force, intended to offer better protection of your personal data. The General Data Protection Regulation (‘GDPR’) lays down rules that companies and public authorities must comply with when they process your personal data; the GDPR offers you various rights that enable you to better protect your personal data.</p>

<p>The FSMA takes the protection of your personal data very seriously. For this reason, the FSMA has updated its data protection policy in order to provide you with appropriate information about how we handle your personal data. You can consult the new text <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/privacy-cookies" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>

<p>Should you have any questions about the protection of your personal data, feel free to contact us via <a href="mailto:dataprotection@fsma.be">dataprotection@fsma.be</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-05-24T17:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56969</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA re-elected vice-chairman of the international organization IOSCO as well as chairman of its European Regional Committee</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-re-elected-vice-chairman-international-organization-iosco-well-chairman-its</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), has been re-elected vice-chairman of IOSCO, the international organization of financial market supervisors, as well chairman of that body’s European Regional Committee.</strong></p>

<p>At the annual general meeting held in Budapest, IOSCO re-elected Jean-Paul Servais vice-chairman of the organization for another two-year term. The chairman of the FSMA, who since October 2014 has also been serving as chairman of IOSCSO’s European Regional Committee, was re-elected to head that committee for another two-year term starting in May 2018.</p>

<p>IOSCO was founded in 1983 and comprises 126 supervisory authorities. The objective of the organization is to promote cooperation among market supervisors and to develop international standards and best practices. An important instrument in this regard is the IOSCO multilateral memorandum of agreement (MMoU).</p>

<p>The memorandum enables supervisory authorities to exchange information quickly among each other. The information may be used, among other things, in an investigation into market abuse practices, which increasingly have an international dimension and can in this way be tackled more efficiently. 118 supervisors, including the FSMA, have signed the memorandum.</p>

<p>The European Regional Committee, for its part, brings together the 50 European members of IOSCO. The Committee discusses IOSCO initiatives that relate to the strengthening of worldwide standards for financial markets, with particular attention to matters that are of relevance to the European region.</p>

<p>‘This dual re-election attests to the recognition and esteem enjoyed by the work done by the FSMA at both national and international levels. The vice-chairmanship of IOSCO and the chairmanship of the European Regional Committee in turn enable the FSMA to exert significant influence on the international standards that the IOSCO develops at the request of the G20 and of the Financial Stability Board, and that increasingly affect Belgian financial regulation. These mandates also make it possible to engage at international level in combating the distribution of binary options’, says Jean-Paul Servais.</p>

<p>The chairman of the FSMA also chairs IOSCO’s audit committee. On behalf of IOSCO he also chairs the IFRS Monitoring Board.</p>

<p>IOSCO has also published a <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS497.pdf">media release</a> to this effect.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-05-14T12:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56555</guid>
    </item>
