<item>
  <title>Conversion of pension capital into a temporary and/or deferred benefit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/conversion-pension-capital-temporary-andor-deferred-benefit</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published two additional opinions&nbsp;(available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/opinions-de-la-fsma" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/fsma-standpunten" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only) regarding the possibility of converting a pension in the form of a capital sum into a benefit. In the FSMA’s opinion, a pension commitment or pension agreement that pays out the capital in the form of a lump sum may provide that the capital can be converted into a temporary and/or deferred benefit. Such benefits, moreover, do not fall within the scope of Article&nbsp;28, § 1 of the Law on Supplementary Pensions for employees (WAP/LPC) or of Article 50, § 1 of the Law on Supplementary Pensions for the self-employed (WAPZ/LPCI).</p>

<p>The provision of such additional conversion options does not in any way derogate from the right of the pension plan member to request the conversion of his or her pension capital into a lifelong benefit that begins immediately and that meets the minimum requirements of Article 19, § 1 of the Royal Decree implementing the Law on Supplementary Pensions for employees (KB WAP/RA LPC) or of Article 3, § 1 of the Royal Decree implementing the Law on Supplementary Pensions for the self-employed (KB WAPZ/RA LPCI).</p>

<p>The sponsoring undertaking (for employees) and the pension institution must, moreover, communicate clearly about all payment options when a benefit is due.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-05-02T15:30:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56812</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Newsletter: Combatting money laundering and the financing of terrorism - Evaluate your risks</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsletter-combatting-money-laundering-and-financing-terrorism-evaluate-your-risks</link>
  <description>
<p>The purpose of this newsletter is to remind you of the principal obligations imposed on you by the new anti-money laundering law as regards the assessment and management of the risks of money laundering and the financing of terrorism (ML/FT).</p>

<p>The FSMA has published on its website the joint Risk Factor Guidelines&nbsp;(<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2018/fsma_2018_03_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2018/fsma_2018_03_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only) drawn up by the European Supervisory Authorities (ESAs). These guidelines are intended to assist you in analysing the ML/FT risks to which you are exposed, as well as to help you take the appropriate preventive measures in respect of the risks identified.</p>

<p>The FSMA expects you to carry out, by 30 June, a general risk assessment within your company with a view to implementing effective mechanisms to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The FSMA will make available to intermediaries an informational handbook to help them carry out the risk assessment.<br>
&nbsp;</p>

<div class="box box-small box-tip">
<p>Find out more in the Newsletter (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2018-04_newsletter_antiblanchiment.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2018-04_nieuwsbrief_witwassen.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) …</p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-04-20T13:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56693</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Publication of an opinion on the decision upon exit to maintain death insurance cover in the amount of the acquired reserves</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-opinion-decision-upon-exit-maintain-death-insurance-cover-amount-acquired-reserves</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published an opinion (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/56602">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/56602">Dutch</a> only) on the consequences of opting, upon exit, to maintain death insurance cover corresponding to the amount of the acquired reserves. The FSMA considers that the consequences of this choice for the future evolution of those reserves should be subject to strict interpretation. According to the FSMA, the recalculation provided for by law is amied solely at neutralizing the effect of mortality risk.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Newsflash intermediaries: approval of providers of training in credit intermediation as from on 1 April 2018</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsflash-intermediaries-approval-providers-training-credit-intermediation-1-april-2018</link>
  <description>
<p>All natural persons who have the status of intermediary must have a certain level of professional knowledge and must engage regularly in continuing professional training. This also applies to persons who perform ‘regulated’&nbsp;key functions at an intermediary that is a legal entity. Although those who serve as ‘persons in client-facing positions (PCP)’ may receive ongoing training in a manner determined by their employer, all other persons who are subject to these requirements must obtain a certain number of continuing education credits by taking specific courses. As regards intermediation and intermediation in banking and investment services, these must be courses offered by accredited training providers.</p>

<div class="box box-tip">
<p>READ MORE IN THE&nbsp;NEWSFLASH (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2018-03_newsflash_intermediation.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2018-03_newsflash_bijscholing.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-03-28T13:45:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56426</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>ESMA introduces measures against binary options and CFDs</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/esma-introduces-measures-against-binary-options-and-cfds</link>
  <description>
<p>The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has decided to ban the offering of binary options and to introduce restrictions on the sale of CFDs (contracts for difference). ESMA is taking these measures in order to protect retail investors.</p>

<p>More information on the <a href="http://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-agrees-prohibit-binary-options-and-restrict-cfds-protect-retail-investors" target="_blank">measures introduced by ESMA</a>.</p>

<p>The FSMA issued a Regulation in 2016 establishing a framework for the distribution of binary options and CFDs. More information about that <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8471" target="_blank">Regulation</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-03-27T11:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56453</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Publication of opinion regarding the scope of the mandatory settlement of the supplementary pension</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/publication-opinion-regarding-scope-mandatory-settlement-supplementary-pension</link>
  <description>
<p>The FSMA has published an opinion (available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/55529" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/55529" target="_blank">Dutch</a>) on the scope of the mandatory settlement of the supplementary pension at the time of legal retirement (Article 27, §1 of the Law on Supplementary Pensions (WAP/LPC)). According to this opinion, a pension institution may not charge any fees specifically for this service. Likewise, this may not be considered a repurchase, even if the settlement of the supplementary pension at the time of legal retirement takes place before the contractually agreed retirement age. Such settlements are in fact simply the fulfilment of a legal obligation. This does not, in other words, involve a termination of the pension contract by the policyholder described in Annex 2, point 24 of the Royal Decree of 14 November 2003 on Life Insurance.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-03-23T16:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56438</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>New Frequently Asked Questions about the consequences for your supplementary pension if your employer is taken over or goes bankrupt</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-frequently-asked-questions-about-consequences-your-supplementary-pension-if-your-employer</link>
  <description>
<p>A new section of the FAQs on supplementary pensions has been published. This section goes into greater depth regarding the consequences for a supplementary pension if an employer is involved in a takeover or goes bankrupt. The consequences for both the accrued pension entitlements and the continuation of the pension commitment are discussed.</p>

<item>
  <title>Cryptocurrency trading platforms: beware of fraud!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/cryptocurrency-trading-platforms-beware-fraud</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>In recent weeks, a large number of new platforms offering all and sundry the chance to invest in cryptocurrencies have appeared on the internet. The FSMA warns the public about these new platforms, since often there are fraudsters behind them who are now using cryptocurrencies to swindle consumers.</strong></p>

<p>In recent weeks, many platforms have appeared on the internet. They all use the same ruse: they claim to offer the best (or one of the best) trading platform(s), enabling both beginners and professionals to trade in cryptocurrencies in a matter of seconds and with full confidence.</p>

<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;'Invest in cryptocurrencies with full confidence.'</em></p>

<p><em>'Invest in digital currencies in full confidence on one of the most renowned platforms on the market.'</em></p>

<p><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;'XXX:&nbsp;trading in cryptocurrencies easily accessible at last!'</em></p>

<p>Some of these platforms also offer other financial products with cryptocurrencies as their underlying: savings accounts with supposedly guaranteed returns, servicing rights or derivative products such as CFDs.</p>

<p>The FSMA has, however, received <strong>numerous complaints</strong> about these trading platforms that claim to be active in the cryptocurrency sector. Consumers who have invested in them complain, in particular:</p>

<ul>
 <li>that <strong>they never recover the funds invested</strong>;</li>
 <li>or that they simply have <strong>heard nothing further from the company</strong> with which they invested their money.</li>
</ul>

<p><em>'I got in touch with the XXX group via an advertisement on Facebook, where I left my contact information. After that, an employee phoned me and explained their working methods to me... he then explained that there was a good deal on at the moment and that he could double my investment if I invested as soon as possible. <strong>I let myself be tempted and transferred some money</strong> (…) The employee then became increasingly evasive and <strong>became hard to reach by phone</strong>. On the last occasion, <strong>he told me my file would be closed</strong> and that I would be paid the returns. (…) <strong>However, to date I have not received anything</strong>.'</em></p>

<p><em>'I invested via a platform (XXX) that allegedly holds an authorization. When I asked for my money to be refunded, <strong>they promised me it would be</strong> done by a given date. However, <strong>I have received nothing to date, and they have cut off all access</strong>.'</em></p>

<p><em>'<strong>The account was closed and [an] agreement [with a view to] a full refund</strong> of my investment (…). <strong>Since then</strong>, I have still <strong>received nothing</strong> on my account, despite several emails.'</em></p>

<p>These are cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong> pure and simple.</p>

<p>For more information, the FSMA invites you to consult a more detailed and particularly evocative <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55962">testimony</a> by a victim of such a platform.</p>

<p>***</p>

<p>In order to avoid such cases of fraud, the FSMA <strong>invites </strong>would-be investors <strong>to exercise utmost prudence and advises them to remain alert to any indication of investment fraud</strong>. It therefore offers a few recommendations:</p>

<ul>
 <li>always <strong>verify the identity of the company</strong> (company identity, home country, etc.).</li>
</ul>

<p>If a company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted.</p>

<p>Be wary as well of companies that claim to hold authorizations from supervisory authorities and refer you to such authorizations. This is a frequently used technique. However, very often these are cases involving <strong>identity theft</strong>. The FSMA also wishes to remind consumers that there is currently no supervision of online platforms active in the cryptocurrency sector, and refers in this regard to its warnings dated <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8290">14 January 2014</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8076">16 April 2015</a>.</p>

<p>Also be wary if the company or its website is fairly new; this is often the case with cryptocurrency trading platforms, which are generally less than a year old.</p>

<ul>
 <li>always<strong> ask</strong> your interlocutor for <strong>clear and comprehensible information</strong>, and take a <strong>critical attitude</strong> to the information they provide.</li>
</ul>

<p>Many cryptocurrency trading platforms promise guaranteed returns or protection of your entire capital. Such promises in the cryptocurrency sector are, however, illusory! Moreover, if an offer is fraudulent, the guarantees given is equally so.</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate gains</strong>. Where a return seems too good to be true, it usually is.</li>
</ul>

<p>The FSMA has put together <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/companies-operating-unlawfully-in-belgium">a list of cryptocurrency trading platforms</a> about which it has received questions/complaints from consumers and has identified signs of fraud. Would-be investors are encouraged to consult it. <strong>Please note, however: this list</strong> is based solely on observations made by the FSMA on the basis of reports received from consumers. It therefore <strong>does not include all players that may be unlawfully active in this sector</strong>.</p>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a> on the FSMA’s website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-02-22T15:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55960</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Online application now open to all registered intermediaries</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/online-application-now-open-all-registered-intermediaries</link>
  <description>
<p>In June 2017, the existing online application for for credit providers and credit intermediaries was extended to individual (re)insurance intermediaries and intermediaries in banking and investment services. Since that time, all new individual requests for registration by intermediaries are submitted via this online application. The registration dossiers are also managed online by the intermediaries themselves.</p>

<p>The online application is now ready to receive the registration dossiers of all other individually registered (re)insurance intermediaries and intermediaries in banking and investment services. As a result of the switch to this online application, both the registration procedure and the management of the registration dossiers of all individually registered intermediaries and credit providers will be handled entirely online.</p>

<p>Read more in the Newsflash (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/newsletter/2018-02_newsflash_cabrio_fr.pdf">French</a> and <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/newsletter/2018-02_newsflash_cabrio_nl.pdf">Dutch</a> only)</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-02-22T12:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55964</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Testimony of a consumer who was victim of a cryptocurrency trading platform</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/testimony-consumer-who-was-victim-cryptocurrency-trading-platform</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>As indicated in its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55960">warning</a> of 22 February 2018, the FSMA receives increasing numbers of complaints about trading platforms that claim to be active in the cryptocurrency sector. By way of illustration, we are providing this testimony of a consumer who invested on one of these platforms.</strong></p>

<div>
<p><em>'Following a request for information sent by email to a cryptocurrency trading site named AAA, I received a phone call (from a number in France) on 6/12/17 at 13:47 from a certain Mr XXX, Desk Manager at AAA. Since I was busy, I asked him to email me more information about their company, which he did the same day.</em></p>

<p><em>I then opened an account on their site in my name. Thereafter, I received several phone calls, always from this person who spoke French with a Parisian accent, vaunting the advantages of investing in cryptocurrency. He told me that his company employs almost 300 people and has been active since 2009 in providing advice on investing in cryptocurrencies.</em></p>

<p><em>He wanted me to invest between 1 to 3 Bitcoins, whose value was EUR 12,500 at that point. I agreed, after a great deal of pressure, to invest 5000 euros, which sum they asked me to transfer to an account in England (the account of the owner of the Bitcoins), given that the head office is in England and their subsidiary in France (still according to Mr XXX). He stated that once the funds have been received, I will be contacted again by a certain Mr YYY, which was indeed the case a few days later.</em></p>

<p><em>He phoned me on 11/12/17 at 19:15. We agreed to transform the investment of 5000 euros into fractions of Bitcoin, and the following day I received an email from a certain Mr ZZZ from the financial service, confirming my investment. A few days later, Mr YYY phoned me to ask if I wished to keep the investment in Bitcoin or if I preferred to invest in a different currency. I agreed to convert my fraction of Bitcoin (0.389 BTC) into Ethereum, and the next day I saw a sum of 12.21 Ethereum on my online account, the price of which was then 426 euros. I recalculated the sums and noted that 500 euros went missing in the process of conversion. I mentioned this to him by email, and the next day I saw my account showed 13.25, that is, a bit more than what I was entitled to???</em></p>

<p><em>However, I did not receive any confirmation from the financial service of the conversion of the Bitcoin into Ethereum. A few days later, Mr YYY called me back to see if I wanted to invest any more. I said no, and since Ethereum was now above 700 euros each, I asked him to sell it all and pay the funds out to me in full. He was surprised, but in the end agreed. On the same occasion, I also asked him to contact me again to let me know the unit price of the final sale, since he was asking me for a day’s time to carry out the transaction.</em></p>

<p><em>The next day, he phoned me and gave me the unit price, which he claimed was sold at three different times (...). By now it was 20//12/2017 and I asked him how much time it would take for me to receive the funds, since I wished to reinvest them. He told me it would take 72 hours, plus the holiday on Christmas Day. To date, on 25/01/2018, I have still not received the funds. Mr YYY has meanwhile changed phone numbers twice. I was able to reach him one last time in early January 2018, asking him, as well as his colleague Mr WWW, for the nth time, for the proof of the transfer of funds.</em></p>

<p><em>Since that day, other than to replies to my emails that were no longer written by him (with spelling mistakes), I have had no further news. The last contact with Mr XXX dates from Thursday, 17 January. I first got a woman on the line who introduced herself, at my request, as his mother, and handed the phone to her son. He told me all sorts of nonsense, such as that Mr YYY can no longer be reached because he had an accident, but he nevertheless tried to get me to invest in a different currency. Since I naturally refused, he told me not to phone him any more, as he was “leaving on holiday for a week”, and he could not do anything for me.</em></p>

<p><em>I therefore asked him to put me through to the financial service, which he refused to do. I asked him for the name of the financial director; he didn't know. I asked him to give me another financial analyst; he again refused. During this conversation he also confirmed that the company is indeed based in England, at the address shown on their website.</em></p>

<p><em>I then sent some more emails to both persons, but received no reply.</em></p>

<p><em>After my initial research online, the address referred to on the site of AAA proved to be situated in an office tower in London dating from the 1970s which rents out office space to very small companies with a shared secretariat, central switchboard, internet access and kitchens. In other words, nothing like a company that supposedly employs 300 people.</em></p>

<p><em>I do not have the encryption keys, and so have no access to my investment. The receipt for my purchase that they forwarded to me has no VAT number or authorization number of a credit institution. Although they use phone numbers based in France, these are not connected to any physical address and no address for them is known in France. So why do they use phone numbers from the Paris region?</em></p>

<p><em>Their website does not have any general terms and conditions.</em></p>

<p><em>And most of all, they are not returning my money.'</em></p>
</div>

<p>More than ever, then, prudence is necessary. In case of any doubt, feel free to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a> on its website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-02-22T11:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55962</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Guidelines on the management body of market operators and data reporting services providers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/guidelines-management-body-market-operators-and-data-reporting-services-providers</link>
  <description>
<p>This <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/2018/fsma_2018_02_en.pdf" target="_blank">document</a> addresses the guidelines drawn up by the European Securities and Markets Authority ('ESMA') to clarify the requirements to be taken into consideration by market operators and data reporting services providers when appointing new and assessing current members of the management body. The guidelines also provide guidance on how information should be recorded by market operators and data reporting services providers in order to make it available to the FSMA for the exercise of its supervisory duties.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Composition of the working group on euro risk free rates announced</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/composition-working-group-euro-risk-free-rates-announced</link>
  <description>
<p>The European Central Bank (ECB), together with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), the European Commission (EC) and the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), today announced <a href="http://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2018/html/ecb.pr180202/ecb.pr180202_Annex.en.pdf?7a3b6cad37885ce8c96edd0caaa043a5" target="_blank">the composition of the working group on euro risk-free rates</a>. Among other things, the working group will be tasked with identifying and recommending alternative risk-free rates and studying potential issues in relation to transition to these rates in line with its <a href="http://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/initiatives/interest_rate_benchmarks/WG_euro_risk-free_rates/shared/pdf/2017_11_29_terms_of_reference.pdf">terms of reference</a>. Such rates could serve as an alternative to the current benchmarks used in a variety of financial instruments and contracts in the euro area.</p>

<p>Following the call for expressions of interest issued in November 2017, the working group will comprise 21 credit institutions as voting members, five institutions as non-voting members and one invited institution. The four public institutions behind this announcement will have observer status. Several criteria were applied in the process of selecting the voting members:</p>

<ul>
 <li>their presence in the euro money market;</li>
 <li>their business models;</li>
 <li>their commitment to dedicate time and resources to the working group;</li>
 <li>their support for money market benchmarks in the past.</li>
</ul>

<p>Geographical diversity was also taken into account in the selection process with a view to capturing different practices in the usage of benchmarks across the European Union.</p>

<p>The non-voting members of the working group were chosen in recognition of either their specific role in the interest rate benchmarks or their representativeness of a specific user group or market usage.</p>

<p>The four public institutions also announced that Koos Timmermans, chief financial officer and vice-chairman of ING Group, would chair the working group. Mr Timmermans was approached on the basis of his longstanding experience in European banking and in the euro money market.</p>

<p>The working group will seek feedback from a wide range of stakeholders to create the transparency needed to achieve broad consensus around these topics. Institutions that were not selected for the working group might still have the opportunity to contribute to the project by participating in its substructures. In this respect, the call for expression of interest remains open to market participants who would like to be involved in the discussions at a sub-group level. More information can be found on the <a href="http://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/initiatives/interest_rate_benchmarks/WG_euro_risk-free_rates/html/index.en.html">ECB website</a>.</p>

<p>The inaugural meeting of the working group on euro risk-free rates will take place at the ECB, which is providing the Secretariat, on 26 February 2018. The meeting agendas and minutes, as well as regular updates on the progress achieved by the working group, will be published on a dedicated ECB webpage.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<item>
  <title>Number of consumer messages received by the fsma up in 2017</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/number-consumer-messages-received-fsma-2017</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Last year, the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) received 1,710 messages from consumers about various financial matters. That is an increase of 13 per cent compared to 2016, during which year the FSMA recorded 1510 questions and complaints.</strong></p>

<p>Nearly half of the messages were questions or complaints relating to fraud and unlawful offers of financial products and services. There were 792 such messages in 2017, up by 45 per cent compared to the previous year.</p>

<p>The messages reporting fraud or unlawful offers mainly concerned binary options, boiler rooms, pyramid schemes and ‘phishing’. New topics in 2017 included credit fraud, virtual currencies and fraud with investments in diamonds.</p>

<p>The increase is due in part to the growing number of warnings issued by the FSMA about fraudulent activity. Consumers asked questions about the warnings or reported having been victims of fraud. The implementation of the ban on distributing certain derivatives to retail investors also gave rise to additional consumer questions.</p>

<p>‘<strong>Increasing numbers of consumers are finding their way to the FSMA. That is a positive development. The more information we receive, and the more quickly, the better we can warn consumers so as to ensure they do not become victims,’ notes Mr Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA.</strong></p>

<p>If the FSMA identifies fraudulent activity, it informs the judicial authorities and publishes a warning to alert consumers of the dangers of a particular offer. The FSMA also notifies foreign supervisory authorities.</p>

<p>The FSMA published 116 warnings last year. That figure is 70 per cent higher than in 2016. The FSMA issued 46 warnings about boiler rooms, and 42 about fraud with binary options. It issued its first ever warning about alternative investments, fraud with investments in diamonds and fraud with initial coin offerings (ICOs).</p>

<p>The FSMA asks victims of fraud to always report the incident to the local police. This way, the judicial authorities have the necessary information to take action against the fraudsters.</p>

<p>The FSMA asks consumers to contact it should they have the least doubt as to the lawfulness of a financial offer. A consumer <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876">contact form</a> is available on the FSMA website for the purpose.</p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <div>
   <p><strong>Number of messages</strong>:</p>

   <ul>
    <li>Pyramid schemes: 169</li>
    <li>Binary options: 164</li>
    <li>Boiler rooms: 118</li>
    <li>Phishing: 71</li>
    <li>Diamonds: 53</li>
    <li>Credit: 38</li>
    <li>Virtual currency: 33</li>
   </ul>

   <p>More information about fraud and unlawful offers is available on the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/22599">website of the FSMA</a>.</p>
   </div>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>

<p><strong>How to prevent investment fraud?</strong></p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>Always verify the identity of a company offering you financial services.</strong> If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. Gather reliable information online. Be wary of positive testimonials. They may be fake.</li>
 <li><strong>Do not accept uncritically the information provided by companies. </strong>Insist on clear and understandable information. It is not uncommon for a company to claim to be authorized to offer financial services although this is not the case.</li>
 <li><strong>Check whether the company holds an authorization or registration.</strong> You can do so by searching the lists available on the FSMA website. Under the consumer’s section of the home page, you can conduct a search via “Check your provider”. You can also consult <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings">the list of warnings</a>.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of cold calling.</strong> If you receive an unsolicited financial offer by phone, email or social media, be careful. Such contacts are often the first step towards a fraudulent practice.</li>
 <li><strong>Be wary of completely disproportionate returns</strong>. Fraudsters frequently present significant earnings … until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested. If the promised returns seem too good to be true, don’t believe them.</li>
</ul>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-02-01T10:15:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55729</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns the public against the activities of International Markets Live LTD (Imarketslive)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-public-against-activities-international-markets-live-ltd-imarketslive</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of International Markets Live LTD, which offers tools and trainings relating to forex products and CFDs.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">International Markets Live, via the website www.imarketslive.com, offers Belgian consumers tools and trainings that are supposed to help them trade in forex products and CFDs. They target mainly young people. In addition, the firm offers its members advantages and compensation that increase the more new members they recruit.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">International Markets Live is <strong>not</strong>, however, <strong>authorized</strong> to offer financial services and products in Belgium. Moreover, the system proposed by International Markets Live exhibits features characteristic of a <strong>pyramid scheme</strong>. More information about this form of fraud is available on the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/node/14674">website of the FSMA</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA points out that since 18 August 2016<strong> no investment firm</strong>, authorized or not,<strong> is allowed actively to distribute forex products and CFDs </strong>within the territory of Belgium. This also means that it is forbidden to give clients a reward for bringing in new clients or for recommending forex products, CFDs or related services to other people.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">International Markets Live has also been the subject of warnings by the French supervisory authority (<a href="http://www.amf-france.org/en_US/Actualites/Communiques-de-presse/AMF/annee-2017?docId=workspace%3A%2F%2FSpacesStore%2Fd5589163-dec8-4d51-9ed2-626604b8cff3">AMF</a>) and by the Spanish supervisory authority (<a href="https://www.cnmv.es/portal/verDoc.axd?t=%7bca8f817f-53d8-4b9a-8c23-fff4c2139178%7d">CNMV</a>).</p>

<p class="rtejustify">For all these reasons, <strong>the FSMA strongly advises against responding to any offers made by International Markets Live.</strong></p>

<p>***</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA wishes to remind readers that responding to offers of binary options, forex products and CFDs <strong>is very risky</strong>. Investing in binary options, forex products and CFDs runs the risk of losing the entire investment, and in the case of forex products, even more. <strong>The chance of gain is also much lower than the chance of loss.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">For more information about binary options, forex products and CFDs, the FSMA invites investors to consult the webpage "<a href="http://www.fsma.be/node/22954">Binary options and forex</a>" on its website.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a proposed transaction complies with the financial legislation? If so, please use the <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2018-01-25T12:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55623</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>IORPs: Communication of the annual accounts, statistics and related documents for the 2017 financial year</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iorps-communication-annual-accounts-statistics-and-related-documents-2017-financial-year</link>
  <description>
<p>This circular (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/FR/circ/2018/fsma_2018_01_fr.pdf">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/NL/circ/2018/fsma_2018_01_nl.pdf">Dutch</a>&nbsp;only) determines the concrete procedures to be followed by institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) when submitting reports for the 2017 financial year.</p>

<p>IORPs must submit their complete FiMIS report at the latest three weeks before the general meeting at which the annual accounts are to be approved. If the general meeting makes any changes to the draft annual accounts, these changes can be entered in the reports until 30 June 2018. IORPs are asked to confirm the date of the general meeting at the latest by 28 February 2018 in an email sent to the address <a href="mailto:pensions@fsma.be">pensions@fsma.be</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Application of the Benchmark Regulation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/application-benchmark-regulation</link>
  <description>
<p>On 1 January 2018, Regulation 2016/1011 (the Benchmark Regulation / the BMR) starts applying.</p>

<p>For <strong>existing benchmark administrators</strong> (i.e. those already active on 30 June 2016) this marks the start of a two-year period during which they can apply for authorisation or registration with their competent authority. &nbsp;For administrators located in Belgium, the competent authority is the FSMA. They may continue to provide existing benchmarks until 1 January 2020 or, where the administrator submits an application for authorisation or registration, unless and until such application is refused. ESMA has clarified that existing benchmark administrators can also start providing new benchmarks during this period.<sup><a href="#_1">[1]</a></sup></p>

<p>ESMA has clarified that benchmark administrators need to comply with the requirements of the BMR from the moment of authorisation or registration onwards – not before.<sup><a href="#_2">[2]</a></sup></p>

<p>For <strong>prospective benchmark administrators</strong>, the application date of the BMR implies that they need to apply for authorisation or registration before starting to act as an administrator.</p>

<p>For <strong>supervised entities using benchmarks</strong>, this means that they can continue to use existing benchmarks until 1 January 2020 or, where the administrator submits an application for authorisation or registration, unless and until such application is refused. Benchmarks included in the ESMA register or provided by EU administrators included therein may be used without restriction.</p>

<p>As of 1 January 2018, benchmark users have to produce and maintain robust written plans to cover the event of material changes to or cessation of a benchmark they use. These plans need to be reflected in contracts with clients.<sup><a href="#_3">[3]</a></sup></p>

<p>If you think you may be concerned in any way by the entry into application of the BMR and have any questions in this respect, you can contact the FSMA at: <a href="mailto:benchmarks@fsma.be">benchmarks@fsma.be</a></p>

<div>
<hr>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="_1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/library/esma70-145-114_qas_on_bmr.pdf" target="_blank">See Q&amp;As 8.1 and 8.2</a></p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_2">[2]</a></sup> <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/library/esma70-145-114_qas_on_bmr.pdf" target="_blank">See Q&amp;A 6.1</a></p>
</div>

<div>
<p><sup><a name="_3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/sites/default/files/library/esma70-145-114_qas_on_bmr.pdf" target="_blank">See Q&amp;A 7.1</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-12-27T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">55201</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>List of websites offering investments in diamonds reported by consumers</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/list-websites-offering-investments-diamonds-reported-consumers</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>As mentioned in its <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/55135">warning of 20 December 2017</a>, the FSMA receives an ever increasing number of complaints/questions from consumers who have been approached by companies offering investments in diamonds. In this context and on the basis of its actual findings, the FSMA decided to publish a list of the websites reported by consumers.</strong></p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p class="rtejustify">www.4cpatrimoine.com</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Important notice</strong>: as outlined above, this list is <strong>based solely on the findings of the FSMA, in particular as a result of consumers’ reports</strong>. As such, it does not include all the companies which might be operating unlawfully in Belgium in the diamonds investment industry.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA also invites consumers to find additional information by consulting the blacklist ('<a href="https://www.amf-france.org/en/warnings" target="_blank">liste noire</a>'), published by the French supervisor (AMF), of websites which offer investments in various goods (diamonds, wine, etc.) and do not comply with current French legislation and regulations. <strong>Since many companies target both French and Belgian consumers, it may be useful for Belgian consumers to check the AMF list as well.</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">Please do not hesitate to contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/11876" target="_blank">consumer contact form</a> should you have any questions concerning the above-mentioned list.</p>

<item>
  <title>Communication on the implementation of MiFID II: ancillary activity exemption and position limits in commodity derivatives</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/communication-implementation-mifid-ii-ancillary-activity-exemption-and-position-limits</link>
  <description>
<p>This <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/en/2017/fsma_2017_22_en.pdf" target="_blank">communication</a>&nbsp;details the procedure to be followed by entities whose trading activity is ancillary to their main business and that wish to be exempted from the obligation to hold an authorization as an investment firm. It also explains certain aspects of the position limits regime introduced pursuant to MiFID II and that applies to commodity derivatives. The method for setting position limits is laid down in Commission Delegated Regulation 2017/591 (‘RTS 21’).</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title>Call for expressions of interest - working group on a risk-free reference rate</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/call-expressions-interest-working-group-risk-free-reference-rate</link>
  <description>
<p>The ECB has published on its website a <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2017/html/ecb.pr171129_1.en.html" target="_blank">call for expressions of interest</a> relating to the working group on a risk-free reference rate for the euro area. The creation of this working group was announced in September. This call is published also on behalf of the FSMA, ESMA, and the European Commission, all of whom co-signed the announcement in September.</p>

<p>In addition, the ECB has published <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/initiatives/interest_rate_benchmarks/WG_euro_risk-free_rates/html/index.en.html" target="_blank">the terms of reference for the working group</a>.</p>

<p>The working group is to be presided by a representative of the private sector, with the secretariat to be provided by the ECB. The working group is tasked first with identifying a preferred risk-free reference rate for the euro area. Thereafter, it will also consider questions relating to a transition from the currently used interest rate benchmarks to the chosen risk-free rate, if required.</p>

<p>The ECB invites candidates for the working group to express their interest by 12 January 2018, using this <a href="https://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/initiatives/interest_rate_benchmarks/WG_euro_risk-free_rates/shared/pdf/application_form.pdf">application form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-11-29T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">54899</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA warns the public against the activities of GTI Net (Global Trading and Invest Network)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/fsma-warns-public-against-activities-gti-net-global-trading-and-invest-network</link>
  <description>
<p class="rtejustify"><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) warns the public against the activities of GTI&nbsp;Net (Global Trading and Invest Network).</strong></p>

<p class="rtejustify">GTI Net is not authorized to provide banking and/or investment services in or from Belgium.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA therefore<strong> strongly advises against responding to any offer of financial services</strong> made by GTI Net and <strong>against transferring money</strong> to any account number it might mention.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">The FSMA also reminds the public that in the vast majority of cases, persons who invest in firms that do not hold the requisite authorization <strong>never recover the sums invested</strong>. These are cases of <strong>investment fraud</strong>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">GTI Net uses the website <strong>www.gti-net.com</strong> and the following contact details:</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Address</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; HDS Business Centre, 3204 Jumeirah Lakes Towers, PO Box 309071, Dubai</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Email</strong>: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sc.gtinetsupport@gmail.com</p>

<p class="rtejustify"><strong>Tel.</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+32 (0)473590590</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Moreover, the system this company offers clearly resembles that of a pyramid scheme or, at the very least, a Ponzi fraud. You can find more information about these types of fraud on <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/14674">the website of the FSMA</a>.</p>

<p class="rtejustify">Would you like to enquire more generally as to whether a transaction being proposed complies with the financial legislation? Please use the <a href="https://www.fsma.be/en/">search function</a> on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA directly via the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">consumer contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-11-14T16:30:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">68473</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Be wary of Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/be-wary-initial-coin-offerings-icos</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Anyone who invests in Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) should bear in mind the associated risks. In a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/fsma_2017_20_en.pdf" target="_blank">Communication</a>, the Financial Services and Markets Authority draws attention to these risks and to signs that can indicate possible fraud. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has likewise published <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-highlights-ico-risks-investors-and-firms" target="_blank">statements </a>on the matter.</strong></p>

<p>This year, start-ups have already raised more than 3 billion dollars in financing worldwide by the sale of digital tokens (Initial Coin Offerings or ICOs). Developers of a project promote these tokens among the public via a website in order to finance their project. The tokens must generally be paid for with a virtual currency, such as Bitcoin or Ether.</p>

<p>Depending on how the ICO is structured, certain financial regulations may apply. But many ICOs are not subject to any legislation and so for the moment lie outside of any supervision. Anyone who participates in an ICO should therefore be aware that there may be no rules governing it and no consumer protection.</p>

<p>The information available on an ICO is often no more than a summary, making it difficult to estimate the risks involved. Moreover, the financing of start-ups is by definition risky, and so there is a likelihood of losing the capital invested. Yet the hype concerning ICOs and virtual currencies can lead to speculative behaviour with only very little attention to the underlying project and its risks.</p>

<p>Some ICOs are set up in order to defraud investors. Signs that may help identify potentially dubious ICOs include the provision of very limited information and the setting of unrealistic objectives. Where there is a great deal of hype, for example with a very short sales period, pushy advertisements or promotion by a celebrity, caution is especially advisable. Anyone who has suspicions of a dubious ICO should feel free to report it to the FSMA.</p>

<p>Please read the full communications by the <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/Circ/fsma_2017_20_en.pdf" target="_blank">FSMA</a> and <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-highlights-ico-risks-investors-and-firms" target="_blank">ESMA</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-11-13T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">54589</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSB working group examines risks and challenges of private pension schemes</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsb-working-group-examines-risks-and-challenges-private-pension-schemes</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>A working group of the Regional Consultative Group for Europe of the Financial Stability Board (FSB) has published</strong>&nbsp;<strong><a href="http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/P171017.pdf" target="_blank">the results of a study</a> of the functioning, the vulnerabilities and the challenges of private pension schemes.</strong></p>

<p>The Working Group on Private Pension Schemes Resilience conducted the research. This temporary working group of European pension supervisors and central bankers within the FSB’s Regional Consultative Group for Europe studied the impact of the private pension sector in Europe on financial stability.</p>

<p>All types of supplementary pensions (second pillar pensions) and personal pensions (third pillar pensions) managed by insurers, pension funds, banks and other institutions were examined extensively. The FSMA played an active role in the research and drafting of the report.</p>

<p>The FSB report inventories the size and diversity of the European private pension sector, as regards both occupational and personal pensions, and provides an overview of European legislation that can have an impact on the pension sector.</p>

<p>The report recognizes the role of pension institutions as long-term investors and the potential part they can play as a stabilizing force in times of volatility on the financial markets, thereby exerting a favourable impact on the economy and on financial stability.</p>

<p>The report confirms the observation that the principal risks for all parties concerned are the ongoing low interest rate and higher life expectancy, whatever the type of pension scheme.</p>

<p>The research points to considerable differences among private pension schemes across Europe and the context in which they operate. As a result, the extent to which the risks are spread among the various stakeholders likewise differs. But regardless of the regulatory framework and the type of pension scheme, stakeholders in a pension scheme are never immune from the effects of what is happening to the other stakeholders. The report thus proposes that, whenever necessary, adjustments be made to the pension schemes in order to ensure their sustainability.</p>

<p>The report urges that promotional materials for pension products should mention that these products can play a stabilizing role with regard to the financial markets. Maintaining a multi-pillar pension system, in which private pension schemes supplement the public (state) pensions, contributes to spreading the risks and helps promote the stabilizing role of pension schemes.</p>

<p>The report is available on&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsb.org/2017/10/report-on-european-private-pension-schemes-functioning-vulnerabilities-and-future-challenges/">the website of the FSB</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-10-23T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">52464</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>World Investor Week has ended with great success</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/world-investor-week-has-ended-great-success</link>
  <description>
<p>Yesterday marked the end of the World Investor Week. This campaign by the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) was held from 2 to 8 October 2017. The purpose of the week was to promote investor education and protection worldwide. Securities regulators and other stakeholders from more than 80 countries on all continents worked toward the common goal of educating and protecting investors and raising awareness of how to be a smart investor.</p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), as vice chair of IOSCO and as a member of the IOSCO Committee on Retail Investors, supported this initiative. As part of the World Investor Week, a conference on financial literacy was held in Brussels on 3 October 2017. Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA, took the floor to address the different challenges in this field and the initiatives taken by the FSMA.</p>

<p>This awareness week was a great success and the different players will keep working together to further inform and protect investors.</p>

<p>A <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org/resources/MR26-World-Investor-Week-2017-10-08-English.pdf">press release</a> was also published on the website of the World Investor Week.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-10-09T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">51939</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The FSMA supports the national cybersecurity campaign</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-supports-national-cybersecurity-campaign</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) supports the campaign launched by the Centre for Cybersecurity Belgium (CCB) and the Cyber Security Coalition on the topic of cybersecurity, and specifically on the phenomenon of phishing.</strong></p>

<p>The month of October is European Cyber Security Month. It is on the occasion of this European initiative that the Centre for Cybersecurity Belgium (CCB) and the Cyber Security Coalition launched an awareness campaign on this subject.</p>

<p>Vigilance online is more crucial than ever. Cybercriminals are finding more creative ways all the time to achieve their goals. The campaign launched this month seeks to remind us of the signs that alert consumers to be extremely wary. It invites them to detect fake messages and forward any suspect messages to the following address: <a href="mailto:suspect@safeonweb.be">suspect@safeonweb.be</a>.</p>

<p>As part of this campaign, <a href="http://share.absoluutgetest.be/FODKanselarij/CCB/">materials (videos, posters, etc.)</a> have been made available free of charge to companies and other organizations that wish to arm their staff or clients against phishing. A test (available in <a href="https://www.safeonweb.be/fr/quiz/test-du-phishing">French</a> – <a href="https://www.safeonweb.be/nl/quiz/phishingtest">Dutch</a> only) also enables surfers to find out whether they are able to spot suspect messages in sufficient time.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-10-06T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">51927</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Report on asset management and shadow banking</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/report-asset-management-and-shadow-banking</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The FSMA and the NBB have written a <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/content/EN/shadowbanking/2017_report_shadowbanking.pdf" target="_blank">joint report</a> on asset management and shadow banking in Belgium.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB wrote the report at the request of the Minister of Finance, Johan Van Overtveldt, and the High Level Expert Group on the future of the Belgian financial sector. Comparable exercises have taken place in other countries and at international level.</p>

<p>The report addresses the evolution toward a more market-based financial system, where more financial intermediation occurs outside the banking sector. This form of financing provides an alternative to borrowing from banks and helps to support the real economy. However, like the activities of companies under prudential supervision, it can also become a source of systemic risks.</p>

<p>Market-based financing can take many forms. At the request of the High Level Expert Group, this report focuses on asset management and shadow banking. The expert group had recommended that the risks associated with these activities and their interconnectedness with other sectors be more closely monitored.</p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB have calculated the scale of the shadow banking activities in Belgium based on the definition given by the Financial Stability Board. The total financial assets in this category amounted to €&nbsp;128 billion at the end of last year. These assets consist mainly of money market funds and non-equity investment funds. The vast majority of these funds are under the supervision of the Belgian authorities.</p>

<p>In the current state of affairs, no substantial systemic risks have been identified that are associated with asset management and shadow banking. The developments in both activities and the links with other sectors of the economy require further close monitoring, including for potential reputational risks to financial groups (the so-called step-in risk).</p>

<p>The FSMA and the NBB consider it very important to gather data not hitherto available concerning asset management and shadow banking to be filled. They recommend that shadow banking in Belgium be monitored periodically and that international developments in this area continue to be followed. Mitigating the liquidity risks of Belgian investment funds and the interconnectedness of asset management and shadow banking with other sectors are other important recommendations.</p>

<p>The Minister of Finance, Johan Van Overtveldt, commented on the report: "This is the first time that a complete picture of shadow banking and asset management in our country has been presented. The report fulfils one of the recommendations made by the High Level Expert Group on the future of the Belgian financial sector. The excellent collaboration between the NBB and the FSMA enables them to monitor the risks the sector presents in our country and to safeguard financial stability."</p>

<p>Jan Smets, Governor of the National Bank: "It is important that this study provides us with an overview of the relationships between shadow banking and the banking and insurance sector; the report thus enables us better to identify and monitor the risks."</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA: "The FSMA and the NBB have, partly on the basis of the observations contained in this report, further refined the reporting by investment funds in Belgium, as a result of which we as supervisors are better able to assess the risks."</p>

<item>
  <title>Launch of World Investor Week</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/launch-world-investor-week</link>
  <description>
<p>Today marks the launch of World Investor Week. This campaign is an initiative of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO). This first edition of World Investor Week will take place from 2 to 8 October 2017. The purpose of the week is to promote investor education and protection worldwide. Securities regulators and other stakeholders from more than 70 countries are participating in World Investor Week, offering a variety of activities.</p>

<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), as vice chair of IOSCO and as a member of the IOSCO Committee on Retail Investors, supports this initiative. As part of World Investor Week, a conference on financial literacy will be held in Brussels on 3 October 2017. The speakers are Mr Paul Andrews, secretary general of IOSCO; Mr Steven Maijoor, chair of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA); and Mr Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA. More information concerning this conference can be found on <a href="https://www.financialforum.be/en/lectures-conferences" target="_blank">the website of the Belgian Financial Forum</a>.</p>

<p>For additional information on World Investor Week, please consult the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-10-02T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>

    <guid isPermaLink="false">51903</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The Chairman of the FSMA re-elected chair of the ESMA committee on financial innovation</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-re-elected-chair-esma-committee-financial-innovation</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Jean-Paul Servais, has been re-elected to chair the ESMA committee on financial innovation. The work in this area has to do specifically with various types of complex or innovative financial instruments as well as with different forms of financial innovation emerging in the financial sector.</strong></p>

<p>ESMA is the European Securities and Markets Authority, of which the Belgian supervisory authority, the FSMA, is a member. ESMA advises the European Commission on financial regulation and contributes to convergence in supervisory practices among the national competent authorities, with a view to consistent investor protection within the EU.</p>

<p>ESMA has a committee on financial innovation that was specifically provided for in the European Regulation establishing ESMA. The Chairman of the FSMA had been elected to chair the Financial Innovation Standing Committee (FISC), the work of which he began to lead starting in 1 October 2015. He has just been re-elected for two years as chair of that committee, as from 1 October 2017. ESMA has also published a <a href="https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-appoints-new-standing-committee-chairs">press release</a> to this effect.</p>

<p>Within ESMA, the FISC provides advice on the development of guidelines and recommendations, on product intervention and on regulatory intervention to be taken to prevent unsuitable financial innovations which may be detrimental to consumers and may constitute a threat to financial stability. The committee also monitors and analyses trends regarding financial innovation and reports on its findings.</p>

<p>Topics addressed within the committee include complex or innovative financial instruments such as ICOs (Initial Coin Offerings), Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) and FinTechs (including RegTechs). Based on the work carried out by FISC, ESMA recently published a report on the benefits and risks of applying DLT to financial markets, as well as an opinion concerning the scope of intervention powers provided for under the MiFIR regulation.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-10-02T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">51904</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>New working group on a risk-free reference rate for the euro area</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-working-group-risk-free-reference-rate-euro-area</link>
  <description>
<p>Today, the FSMA, ESMA, the European Central Bank and the European Commission announce the launch of a new working group tasked with the identification and adoption of a "risk-free overnight rate" which can serve as a basis for an alternative to current benchmarks used in a variety of financial instruments and contracts in the euro area. The working group, chaired by a private sector representative and with the Secretariat to be provided by the ECB, will regularly consult market participants and end-users, as well as gather feedback from other public authorities. Its terms of reference will be made public and the group will regularly report on its meetings. This is to ensure transparency on all steps in the identification and adoption of a new risk free rate.</p>

<p>Ensuring broad market acceptance is vital for the effective functioning of any alternative to existing benchmark rates.</p>

<p>Once it has made a recommendation on its preferred alternative risk-free rate, the group will also explore possible approaches for ensuring a smooth transition to this rate, if needed in the future. For such a case, careful transition planning by market participants aims to minimise disruption to markets and consumers and to safeguard the continuity of contracts to the greatest extent possible, including contracts that currently reference a term rate rather than an overnight rate. These tasks require the involvement of public authorities and a concerted effort by all market participants to facilitate a gradual reduction of the current reliance on the IBORs.</p>

<p>The signatory public authorities reiterate that existing rates must continue to be provided in a robust and reliable manner.&nbsp; The signatory public authorities therefore express their appreciation for the continued commitment of those banks contributing to the Euribor and EONIA benchmarks and expect that they will remain supportive of these benchmarks as necessary.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2017/html/ecb.pr170921.en.html" target="_blank">The European Central Bank announced earlier today</a> (21 September) that it will start providing an overnight unsecured index before 2020. This widens the set of options for the choice of such alternative rates for the euro area and is in line with the recommendation of the Market Participants Group of the Financial Stability Board Official Sector Steering Group’s (FSB OSSG) to identify and adopt one or more risk-free rates in each main currency area.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<item>
  <title>Agreed settlement - AVA TRADE EU Ltd and iCFD Ltd</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/agreed-settlement-ava-trade-eu-ltd-and-icfd-ltd</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The agreed settlements consist of a payment of EUR 175,000 by AVA TRADE EU Ltd, EUR 200,000 by iCFD Ltd and publication by name on the website of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p>

<p>AVA TRADE EU Ltd has offered CFDs in Belgium under the freedom to provide services; iCFD Ltd has, also under the freedom to provide services, offered CFDs and binary options in Belgium. For a public offer of investment instruments in Belgium, however, a prospectus is required. The prospectus must contain full information about the type of investment instrument and about the issuer, and must also describe the risks associated with the investment. Moreover, all documents and advertising relating to a public offer of investment instruments in Belgium must be submitted for approval to the FSMA before they may be distributed.</p>

<p>The reason for the agreed settlements is that, according to the FSMA, AVA TRADE EU Ltd and iCFD Ltd have offered investment instruments on Belgian territory without the requisite prospectus. In addition, AVA TRADE EU Ltd and iCFD Ltd did not submit to the FSMA for approval any advertisement or other document relating to the said public offers.</p>

<p>The agreed settlement with AVA TRADE EU Ltd consists of the payment of EUR 175,000 and publication by name on the website of the FSMA. The agreed settlement with iCFD Ltd consists of the payment of EUR 200,000 and publication by name on the website of the FSMA.</p>

<p>AVA TRADE EU Ltd and iCFD Ltd will also contact all their Belgian clients to offer them the opportunity to terminate their contract at no cost and with reimbursement of the current balance. AVA TRADE EU Ltd and iCFD Ltd have also changed their website and indicated that the products concerned are not intended to be offered to Belgian consumers.</p>

<p>As part of its administrative sanctions policy, the FSMA can accept an agreed settlement if the parties concerned cooperate with the investigation.</p>

<p>The full text of the agreed settlements (available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/fr/node/49986">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/node/49986">Dutch</a> only) can be consulted on the FSMA's website.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-08-23T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">49986</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA chairs first meeting of Eonia supervisory college</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-chairs-first-meeting-eonia-supervisory-college</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority has chaired the first meeting of the supervisory college for Eonia. This college brings together the supervisors of all banks taking part in Eonia, as well as the supervisors of states for which Eonia is of systemic importance.</strong></p>

<p>In response to the alleged manipulation of financial benchmarks several years ago, a European regulation<sup><a href="#1">[1]</a></sup> imposes strict controls on the organisation and management of benchmark calculations. Notably, it sets out that the provision of benchmarks of critical importance can only be carried out by entities (called administrators) that have obtained authorisation in the Member State where they are located. A benchmark is deemed to be critical if it is used as a reference for financial instruments or financial contracts, or for measuring the performance of an investment fund with a total value of at least 500 billion euros.</p>

<p>In accordance with the European regulation, the FSMA is the supervisory authority of the European Money Markets Institute (EMMI), the Brussels-based entity that manages the Eonia and Euribor benchmarks.</p>

<p>It is in this capacity that the FSMA established the Euribor college in September 2016. Now that the European Commission has added Eonia to the list of critical benchmarks<sup><a href="#2">[2]</a></sup>, a college has been established for this benchmark as well. The two colleges have been merged to create a single Euribor/Eonia college.</p>

<p>In addition to ESMA and the FSMA, the college currently consists of 17 national supervisory authorities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<p><sup><a name="1"></a>[1]</sup> Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 of 8 June 2016.</p>

<p><sup><a name="2"></a>[2]</sup> Commission implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/1147 of 28 June 2017.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-08-10T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">49897</guid>
    </item>

  <description>
<p>The International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) will hold a World Investor Week from 2nd through 8th October 2017. The purpose of this week is to promote greater investor education and protection worldwide.</p>

<p>The FSMA, as vice chairman of IOSCO and as a member of the IOSCO Committee on retail investors, supports this initiative.</p>

<p>More information concerning the activities in the framework of the World Investor Week and the participating countries can be found in <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS463.pdf">the IOSCO press release</a> and on the website <a href="http://www.worldinvestorweek.org">www.worldinvestorweek.org</a>.</p>
</description>

<item>
  <title> Newsflash voor tussenpersonen: Uitbreiding online-applicatie naar alle tussenpersonen</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/newsflash-voor-tussenpersonen-uitbreiding-online-applicatie-naar-alle-tussenpersonen</link>
  <description>
<p>De FSMA heeft het afgelopen jaar gewerkt aan de uitbreiding van&nbsp;de bestaande online applicatie voor de kredietbemiddelaars en kredietgevers naar de (her)verzekeringstussenpersonen en de tussenpersonen in bank- en beleggingsdiensten.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
Ter voorbereiding hierop werden er in de afgelopen maanden reeds enkele grote stappen gezet. Zo werden de website met FAQs, de modeldocumenten, het stappenplan beroepskennis, en de checklists uitgebreid naar alle tussenpersonen.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
Begin juni werd reeds een eerste presentatie van het nieuwe systeem gegeven aan de beroepsfederaties.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
Vanaf het volledig operationeel worden van deze applicatie zal de inschrijvingsprocedure voor alle tussenpersonen en kredietgevers volledig online verlopen. Het beheer van het dossier na de goedkeuring van de aanvraag, verloopt daarna eveneens volledig online.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
Met deze gebruiksvriendelijke en veilige online applicatie zal de FSMA haar dienstverlening naar de tussenpersonen en de gereglementeerde ondernemingen aanzienlijk kunnen verhogen. De ervaring met de aanvragen voor kredietbemiddeling leert de FSMA in ieder geval dat de online applicatie zorgt voor een&nbsp;vlottere behandeling van aanvragen.</p>

<div class="box box-tip">
<p>Lees meer in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/nl/file/49587/download?token=5EVadsRK">onze&nbsp;Newsflash</a>.</p>
</div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-06-26T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">34945</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Annual report 2016</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/annual-report-2016</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has published its annual report for 2016. On the occasion of the presentation of the annual report, the FSMA set out the various forms of action it can take and how it applies them. Since the establishment of the new Sanctions Committee in 2012, the FSMA has imposed a total of 36 administrative sanctions.</strong></p>

<p>For the 2016 annual report, the FSMA has adopted a new format. The report is no longer structured purely as a report on activities, but as a tool of communication that presents the FSMA's work and approach. The report is written for non-specialists as well, is organized thematically and makes use of graphics (sidebars, pictograms, colours, photos, etc.) in order to make the report more readable.</p>

<p>The new approach to the annual report reflects the emphasis that the FSMA places on communication as a tool of effective supervision. Providing clear information about the relevant legislation and about the expectations of the supervisor in itself has an impact on the conduct of market players and gives rise to changes on the ground. Doing so also has a preventive aspect, intended to contribute to averting behaviour that may have harmful effects.</p>

<p>In recent years, the FSMA has therefore intensified its communications, including via the publication of newsletters for intermediaries, press releases announcing and explaining administrative sanctions, reports on the results of sectoral studies, etc. The FSMA will henceforth publish its legal positions (jurisprudence) immediately on its website, instead of gathering them together once a year in the annual report.</p>

<p>In addition to its communicative tasks, the FSMA also intervenes actively on the ground when needed. In 2016, the FSMA intervened almost 500 times in very concrete ways, for example by suspending trade in a share, deleting or suspending the registration of intermediaries, warning against illegal offers, ordering that certain shortcomings be remedied, etc.</p>

<p>The FSMA also pursues an active sanctions policy. Since the establishment of the new Sanctions Committee in mid-2012, the FSMA has imposed 36 administrative sanctions, on 55 persons. The total monetary value of the sanctions is 14.6 million euros.</p>

<p>In recent years, the sanctions have tended to be applied more to infringements of legislation other than that governing market abuse (insider dealing, price manipulation, etc.). Infringements against advertising rules, anti-money laundering legislation and the prospectus law have also been punished with an administrative sanction. The FSMA will continue to roll out its sanctions policy in these and other domains. The FSMA's Sanctions Committee will henceforth also be able to rule on cases involving the professional ethics of statutory auditors.</p>

<p>The FSMA also supervises access to the sector by registering or authorizing persons who fulfil all the requirements. Recently, the number of different statuses supervised by the FSMA was further expanded to include, among others, crowdfunding platforms and credit providers.</p>

<p>The annual report (in full in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/publications/ver/fr/fsma_ra2016_fr_web.pdf">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/publications/ver/nl/fsma_jv2016_ne_web.pdf">Dutch</a>)&nbsp;is available on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
