<item>
  <title>Study of payment protection insurance offered in conjunction with consumer loans </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/study-payment-protection-insurance-offered-conjunction-consumer-loans</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has concluded the first part of its study of payment protection insurance offered in conjunction with consumer loans. The first observations indicate that such products are expensive considering the cover offered.</strong></p>

<p>A payment protection insurance contract subscribed for a consumer loan covers the balance owing on a loan in the event of the borrower's death. Consumer loans are taken out for the purchase of a car, for example, or a household appliance, an electronic device, etc. These loans are for lower amounts and shorter periods than, say, a mortgage loan. Payment protection insurance is thus useful mainly for persons who have a high short-term risk of death.</p>

<p>An analysis of the number of claims made in the period between 2011 and 2015 shows that insurers paid out on a claim in only 0.24% of the contracts in force.</p>

<p>During that period, companies that were included in the study collected an average of 65 million euros in premiums per year. Only 12% of this amount was used to pay claims. In the case of one insurer, the percentage was only 1.15%; for the others, it was around 20%.</p>

<p>More than half the premiums, that is, 35 million euros or 53%, was used to pay charges and commissions. At one of the insurers, charges and commissions represented more than 70% of the premiums paid by the policyholders.</p>

<p>The remaining 35% of the premiums collected represented a profit for the insurance company, minus any limited premiums they in turn paid to reinsurers.</p>

<p>Initial findings of the study also indicate that the amount of the commissions is rarely set out clearly. High remuneration may also induce vendors of such insurance policies - who in many cases also act as vendors of consumer credit - not to make the client's interests their chief concern.</p>

<p>In the course of its study, the FSMA not only examined the clarity of the general terms and conditions and the transparency of the cost structure, but also verified the quality and transparency of the advertisements. This second aspect of the study has not yet been completed; its results will be communicated at a later date.</p>

<p>The FSMA decided not to await the complete results of the study before drawing the attention of consumers to the fact that these products are expensive considering the cover they offer. It advises persons who take out a consumer loan to consider whether they really need payment protection insurance.</p>

<p>Please consult <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/thematiques/emprunter/credits-la-consommation/bien-choisir">Wikifin.be</a> as well for more information and advice about payment protection insurance for a consumer loan.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-05-23T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">22604</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Alternative investment products (rare earths, precious metals, diamonds, etc.): be on your gard!</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/warnings/alternative-investment-products-rare-earths-precious-metals-diamonds-etc-be-your-gard</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Offers of investment in various assets such as rare earths, precious metals, diamonds, etc. are increasingly made to the general public as alternatives to traditional savings products, with the promise of high yields. The greatest possible caution is advised, however... because while investing money in physical goods may seem reassuring, unfortunately in practice fraud in these sectors is frequent.</strong></p>

<p>The FSMA wishes therefore to warn you!</p>

<p>The FSMA does not supervise commercial activities relating to such physical goods as rare earths, precious metals, diamonds, wine, buildings, etc. However, where physical assets are offered to the public in the form of instruments that make possible a financial investment, these 'alternative' investment products may fall within the scope of the financial legislation that the FSMA is tasked with enforcing (in particular, the Prospectus Law) and may only be offered to the public under certain conditions.</p>

<p>Investors are therefore urged to exercise heightened prudence. Do not be taken in by the falsely reassuring appearance of a physical investment, and remember that prospects of a high yield always go hand in hand with high risk. To claim otherwise is false and may indicate fraud.</p>

<p>In what follows, we provide more information about these types of offers of alternative investment products. If you wish to verify whether an offer falls under the supervision of the FSMA, please feel free to contact us via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">electronic contract form</a>.</p>

<p><strong>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><strong>How do these frauds get started?</strong></p>

<p>Would-be investors are usually contacted unsolicited (cold calling or email) by a person or company who offers them an investment in an asset presented as an alternative to traditional investment products. Sometimes, would-be investors are attracted by advertisements on the internet.</p>

<p>The asset is offered as an alternative for investing one's capital, and is accompanied by promises of high yields. The information presented is one-sided, however, omitting to mention or downplaying the risks of loss.</p>

<p>The market and the prices offered are generally obscure, and it is very difficult for the would-be investor to verify whether they are paying the correct price for the investment.</p>

<p>Frequently the company in question suggests that the assets be stored abroad. In that case, the investor cannot easily verify whether the product has in fact been delivered.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><strong>What are the problems encountered by victims of these frauds?</strong></p>

<p>Complaints made by consumers who consider they have sustained damage from such offers are varied:</p>

<ul>
 <li>some complain that they bought the object for a sum well above market price, as well as of having been misled as to the value of the assets acquired;</li>
 <li>others complain that they are unable to resell the asset acquired;</li>
 <li>still others have heard nothing more from the company and therefore never manage to recover either the assets purchased (provided, of course, that a real transaction took place, which is not always certain), or the money invested;</li>
 <li>finally, many companies active in this sector soon go bankrupt or into liquidation; once again, the investor's chance of recovering his or her investment is slim.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><strong>A victim - what can you do?</strong></p>

<p>Do you consider that you have been the victim of a fraudulent investment offer? Please feel free to contact us via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">electronic contact form</a>. We will verify whether the offer made violated/violates the legislation with which we supervise compliance. If that is the case, we will be sure to take the necessary measures (warnings, administrative sanctions, etc.).</p>

<p>To try to recover the money lost, please also file a complaint with the judicial authorities, who are the competent authorities in this matter. The FSMA has no competence to handle individual complaints. We will do our best, however, to point you in the right direction.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><strong>Advice to consumers</strong></p>

<p>Investors are therefore urged to exercise heightened prudence. The usual advice by the FSMA thus applies. In particular:</p>

<ul>
 <li><strong>be wary of (promises of) completely disproportionate returns</strong>. In this regard, it is frequently the case that fraudsters present significant earnings at the beginning, until the day when the investor asks to withdraw the funds invested.</li>
 <li><strong>always verify the identity of the company</strong>&nbsp;(company identity, home country, etc.). If the company cannot be clearly identified, it should not be trusted. Also beware if the company does not have a long track record.</li>
 <li><strong>do not take for granted the information provided by such companies</strong>: be especially careful about any claimed assurances about your investments or promises of repurchase/resale that may resemble a capital guarantee: if an offer is fraudulent, the guarantees offered are likewise; the same is true of promises of repurchase/resale.</li>
 <li><strong>insist</strong>&nbsp;that your interlocutor&nbsp;<strong>provide clear and comprehensible information</strong>. Do not invest if you do not understand precisely what is being offered. Be sure to read all the documentation carefully, including any fine print; very often the text there is far from the sales pitch you were given!</li>
 <li><strong>beware</strong>&nbsp;of unsolicited phone calls / emails ("<strong>cold calling</strong>"), that is, any contacts that you did not request. These are often at the source of fraud; also be careful of any insistent salespeople and those who want to persuade you to sign quickly.</li>
 <li><strong>consult the warnings</strong>&nbsp;published on the&nbsp;<a href="http://www-test-bypass.fsmanet.be/en/warnings">website of the FSMA</a>, as well as on the sites of foreign supervisory authorities and of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.iosco.org/investor_protection/?subsection=investor_alerts_portal">IOSCO(link is external)</a>.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Please note:</strong>&nbsp;the fact that the FSMA has not published a warning about a company does not mean that company holds a valid authorization.&nbsp;On the one hand, as indicated above, such offers&nbsp;<strong>do not always fall under the supervision of the financial authorities</strong>. On the other hand, while the FSMA seeks to ensure that it publishes warnings in a timely manner, it is entirely possible that the activity of a given company that is acting illegally on the Belgian market may not yet have been reported to it, all the more so since unauthorized companies tend to change names regularly.</p>

<ul>
 <li>consider also doing a&nbsp;<strong>general search</strong>&nbsp;for the company&nbsp;<strong>using the customary search engines</strong>. You may find some testimonials by persons who have had contacts with the company. But beware that there may be some falsely positive testimonials, posted by the company itself and intended solely to elicit the confidence of investors.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><strong>To go further...</strong></p>

<p>If you would like more information about the legal regime that may apply to such offers of alternative investment products, please consult the&nbsp;<a href="http://www-test-bypass.fsmanet.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/en/2014/fsma_2014_13_en.pdf">Communication of 13 November 2014</a>&nbsp;addressed to companies that distribute investments in movable or immovable goods. Should you still have any questions, please feel free to contact us via the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/117468">electronic contact form</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2017-05-08T18:54:20+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">118528</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Joint public statement FSMA-ESMA regarding Euribor </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/joint-public-statement-fsma-esma-regarding-euribor</link>
  <description>
<p>The Euribor is administered by the Brussels-based European Money Markets Institute (EMMI). In August 2016, the Euribor was declared a critical benchmark by the European Commission<a href="#_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a>, in accordance with Article 20 of the Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 “<em>on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds</em>”<a href="#_ftn2"><sup>[2]</sup></a> (Benchmarks Regulation).</p>

<p>Under the Benchmarks Regulation, a benchmark is critical when its failure would impact market integrity, financial stability, consumers, the real economy, or the financing of households and businesses in one or more Member States. Additional requirements apply to critical benchmarks in order to ensure the integrity and robustness of such benchmarks. Also, critical benchmarks are supervised by a college of national competent authorities and ESMA, chaired by the national competent authority of the benchmark administrator.</p>

<p>While the Benchmarks Regulation will be fully applicable as of January 1<sup>st</sup> 2018, its provisions regarding the supervision of a critical benchmark, including the power to impose mandatory administration of or mandatory contribution to a critical benchmark, are applicable as of June 30<sup>th</sup> 2016.</p>

<p>In September 2016, the FSMA, as the national competent authority for Belgium, established the Euribor college and chaired its inaugural meeting. The college includes ESMA, the national competent authorities of the various banks contributing to the Euribor, as well as the national competent authorities of Member States for which the Euribor presents a systemic character because of its importance for their real economy, for the financing of households and enterprises, or for consumers in general. The Euribor college, chaired by the FSMA, currently consists of 17 national supervisory authorities and ESMA. The ECB has attended its meetings as an invited expert.</p>

<p>In 2015, EMMI developed a methodology that would ground the Euribor entirely on transactions (“Euribor+”) and has subsequently carried out a “pre-live verification” exercise, based on data gathered from 31 banks over a period running from September 2016 to February 2017. On May 4<sup>th</sup> 2017, after consultation with the FSMA and as a result of its pre-live verification exercise, EMMI published its decision not to pursue a transition to the proposed Euribor+ methodology in the short term.</p>

<p>The college of Euribor takes note of this decision and will continue to engage with EMMI on alternative plans for Euribor reform and transition.</p>

<p>The Euribor is a vital element of the European financial system as it is used not only in an extraordinarily large number of financial instruments, but also in very common financial contracts, such as mortgages, as well as to measure the performance of many investment funds across Europe.</p>

<p>For this reason, the correct and continuous provision of Euribor is essential for the proper functioning of the European financial system and it is considered the top priority by the Euribor college.</p>

<p>Ensuring the stability of the financial markets implies that banks continue supporting the Euribor. Furthermore, it is important that the private sector pursues initiatives aimed at designing its own robust and reliable alternative reference rates. As market participants, starting with banks, are the main users of interest rate benchmarks, they should be primarily responsible for the production of these benchmarks: market participants have the expertise and are best placed to judge the features that the benchmarks should have to best suit their needs.</p>

<p>The FSMA, ESMA, and the other members of the Euribor college, in concert with other public authorities, will continue to closely monitor the state of Euribor and stand ready to use the tools at their disposal to ensure the continuity of the Euribor throughout the reform process, with the objective of minimising the impacts of the transition, with a particular focus on the protection of consumers and investors throughout the Union as well as the protection of the stability of financial markets.</p>

<div>
<hr>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn1">[1]</a>&nbsp;<a href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R1368">http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R1368</a></p>

<p><a name="_ftn2">[2]</a>&nbsp;<a href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R1011">http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R1011</a></p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<item>
  <title>FAQs on contributions in kind, mergers, divisions and equivalent operations at listed companies </title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/faqs-contributions-kind-mergers-divisions-and-equivalent-operations-listed-companies</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority has made available a set of frequently asked questions (FAQs) regarding contributions in kind, mergers, divisions and equivalent operations. It seeks by means of these FAQs to recall a number of fundamental principles that apply to these types of operations. The FSMA also draws attention, via the FAQs, to observed good practices.</strong></p>

<p>In cases of contributions in kind, mergers, divisions and equivalent operations, conflicts of interest can arise on the part of the persons initiating the operation. This may occur, for instance, in a business combination involving two companies with the same reference shareholder.</p>

<p>The FSMA therefore wishes to recall a number of fundamental principles that apply to these types of operation and to address several practical questions and good practices. This way, it seeks to support the decision-making process within listed companies in respect of operations involving conflicts of interest and to enable all those concerned to perform their role to the full.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/54934">FAQs</a> are available on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2016-12-23T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">14647</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA elected vice chair of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-elected-vice-chair-international-organization-securities-commissions-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has been elected vice chair of the Board of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO). IOSCO is a network of over 120&nbsp;national regulators, responsible for supervising the financial markets and for product and conduct supervision.</strong></p>

<p>IOSCO held its annual conference this week in Lima, Peru. The organization was founded in 1983 and is a network of over 120 national regulators, among which the FSMA, responsible for supervising the financial markets and for product and conduct supervision. IOSCO’s objective is to promote fair and sound market practices worldwide, and thus to contribute to investor protection and the integrity of the financial markets. To this end, IOSCO works to strengthen ongoing cooperation among securities regulators, in particular as regards the enforcement of laws and regulations and the exchange of information about market abuse. It also develops standards and best practices that in turn inform European and national rules and practices.</p>

<p><span>During the meeting in Lima, the chairman of the FSMA, Mr Jean-Paul Servais, was elected vice chair of the IOSCO Board for a period of two years. This election is a sign of appreciation for the work already done at national and international levels. It also attests to the trust that fellow regulators place in the actions of the FSMA.</span></p>

<p>Within IOSCO, the FSMA also chairs the European Regional Committee, made up of 51 members. IOSCO’s four regional committees discuss topics that are relevant to the region concerned, and follow up on the work of the organization’s various thematic committees and working groups. The FSMA is also chair of IOSCO’s audit committee.</p>

<p>IOSCO has also published a <a href="https://www.iosco.org/news/pdf/IOSCONEWS427.pdf">press release</a> on the matter.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2016-05-13T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8422</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>New modalities for the supervision of lenders and intermediaries in mortgage and consumer credit</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-modalities-supervision-lenders-and-intermediaries-mortgage-and-consumer-credit</link>
  <description><p><strong>The Law of 19 April 2014 introduced the statuses of lender and of intermediary in mortgage credit and consumer credit into Book VII of the Economic Law Code. In this regard, the Royal Decree of 29&nbsp;October 2015 lays down the conditions which applications for registration or authorization must fulfil.</strong></p>

<p>In order to offer consumers better protection, there are requirements regarding, among other things, the fitness and propriety and the professional knowledge of persons who serve as credit intermediaries. They will have to submit a certificate of senior secondary education and demonstrate their professional knowledge by passing an exam. The same approach is used in this regard as for other financial intermediaries (banking agents, insurance brokers, etc.) that must be registered with the FSMA. For some people who are already active in the banking or insurance sector, a transitional regime is provided.</p>

<p>New lenders and credit intermediaries can submit their application starting on 2 November 2015. For existing lenders and credit intermediaries, there is an 18-month transitional period during which they may submit their application. For credit intermediaries with less than one year's experience, the transitional period is limited to 2 months.</p>

<p>The Federal Public Service (FPS) Economy has published on its website the list (available only in&nbsp;<a href="https://economie.fgov.be/fr/themes/services-financiers/credit-la-consommation/qui-peut-accorder-un-credit-la" target="_blank">French</a> or <a href="https://economie.fgov.be/nl/themas/financiele-diensten/consumentenkrediet/wie-kan-het-consumentenkrediet" target="_blank">Dutch</a>) of existing intermediaries in consumer credit, stating the date of their registration. Using this list, it is possible to determine which intermediaries are eligible for the transitional regime. For mortgage credit, the obligation to register is new and therefore no list can be published.</p>

<p>The FSMA publishes on its website the lists of lenders in mortgage and in consumer credit that have received provisional authorization. It will update each week the list on its website of the credit intermediaries registered and the lenders authorized under the new legislation.</p>

<p>In order to enable the sector to prepare thoroughly for the entry into force of the new legislation, the FSMA has developed an informational website. The mcc-info.fsma.be site (available only in <a href="https://mcc-info.fsma.be/fr">French</a> or <a href="https://mcc-info.fsma.be/nl">Dutch</a>) sets out the conditions and procedures for registration and authorization using videos and thematically arranged FAQs. The site also provides models of the documents that applicants for registration or authorization must fill out.</p>

<p>Both lenders and intermediaries in mortgage and consumer credit must submit their application via an <a href="https://mcc.fsma.be" target="_blank">online application</a> that will be operational from 2 November 2015. This is the only valid way to submit the application.</p>

<p>The Economic Inspection directorate of the FPS Economy continues to be competent for supervision of the regulations governing credit provision. "If there are problems with a lender or credit intermediary, consumers can submit a complaint with the FPS Economy via <a href="https://economie.fgov.be/fr/nous-contacter" target="_blank">economie.fgov.be</a>. These new rules ensure that not just anyone can become a credit intermediary. An important step toward better consumer protection", the SPF Economy and the FSMA have noted.</p>
<div><img alt height="96" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Images/en/logo_rvb_en.jpg" width="304"></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2015-10-30T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7599</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA publishes its 2014 annual report</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-its-2014-annual-report</link>
  <description/>
  <pubDate>2015-06-12T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7844</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The NBB and the FSMA clarify the regulatory framework of EEA banks which operate in Belgium based on the freedom to provide services (especially internet banks without a permanent establishment in Belgium)</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/nbb-and-fsma-clarify-regulatory-framework-eea-banks-which-operate-belgium-based-freedom</link>
  <description><p>The NBB (National Bank of Belgium) and the FSMA (Financial Services and Markets Authority) wish to clarify the regulatory framework of banks from other Member States of the European Economic Area (‘EEA’) which provide banking services in Belgium based on the European legal principle of the freedom to provide services. The last few years Belgium has seen, as in other countries of the European Union, an increase in banking activities under the freedom to provide services, including the collection of retail deposits. Most of these banks are internet banks without a permanent establishment in Belgium, which sometimes offer high interest rates on their savings deposits.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p>The NBB and the FSMA wish to clarify two dimensions of the regulatory framework. </p>
<blockquote>
<p>Firstly, the prudential supervision of these banks is carried out by the supervisory authority of the home member state, and not by the supervisory authority of the host member state. Therefore, the NBB has no prudential competence with regard to these banks. The supervisory authority of the home member state must also verify whether or not the provisions of the freedom to provide services, such as approaching clients without a permanent establishment or representation in Belgium, are respected.</p>
<p>Secondly, the deposit guarantee legislation of the home member state is also applicable to these banks, and not that of the host member state. If deposits from Belgian private individuals or SMEs deposited at an EEA bank operating in Belgium within the framework of the freedom to provide services, are no longer available as a result of, for instance, the failure of this bank, it is not the Belgian Guarantee Fund which will be responsible for paying out the equivalent of (maximum 100,000 euros of) these deposits.</p>
</blockquote>
<p> </p>
<p> The clients who entrust their deposits to banks which carry out banking activities in Belgium under the freedom to provide services, must assess the financial position of these banks, with due account for this supervisory framework. </p>
<blockquote>
<p>The saver can thus verify the creditworthiness of the relevant bank, using the latest financial statements of the bank or the credit assessments by external parties, for instance by means of “ratings”<a href="#_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a><span>. In this regard, an internet bank can certainly be expected to publish its latest financial statements on its website.</span></p>
<p>In addition, credit institutions shall, under the prevailing deposit guarantee directive<a href="#_ftn2"><sup>[2]</sup></a>, inform potential savers in a readily comprehensible form of the deposit guarantee scheme in which the credit institution takes part, including the amount for which the deposits are covered. This information shall be provided before concluding the deposit contract. As from the transposition of the revised deposit guarantee directive<a href="#_ftn3"><sup>[3]</sup></a>, the potential savers will receive this information in the form of a standardized document. The depositor will have to acknowledge receipt of that information. Existing depositors will be informed of these facts through their statements of accounts. If the bank provides its services from another EEA member state, the supervisory authority of that other member state shall be responsible for the supervision of these information obligations.</p>
</blockquote>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p>Finally, reference can be made to the websites of the deposit guarantee schemes applicable in the EEA member states<a href="#_ftn4"><sup>[4]</sup></a>.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>
</p>
<div>
<div><br></div>
<hr><div>
<p><a name="_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a> For more information on the ratings of credit institutions (only available in&nbsp;<a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/thematiques/epargner-et-investir/questions-cles/notation" target="_blank">French</a>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<a href="http://www.wikifin.be/nl/themas/sparen-en-beleggen/sleutelvragen/ratings" target="_blank">Dutch</a>).&nbsp;</p>
<p> </p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn2"><sup>[2]</sup></a> Directive EP and Council, no 94/19/EC, 30 May 1994 on deposit-guarantee schemes, <em>OJ L. </em>31 May 1994, part 135, 5, as amended by Directives 2005/1/EC and 2009/14/EC.</p>
<p> </p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a href=" name="><sup>[3]</sup> Directive EP and Council, no 2014/49/EU, 16 April 2014 on deposit-guarantee schemes, <em>OJ L.</em> 12 June 2014, part 173, 149. The Member States must have transposed this directive by 3 July 2015.</a></p>
<p> </p>
</div>
<div>
<p><sup><a name="_ftn4">[4]</a></sup><a href="http://www.efdi.eu/index.php?id=7" target="_blank"> www.efdi.eu/index.php?id=7</a>.</p>
<p> </p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
</div>
</div>

<item>
  <title>Reminder of the warning by NBB and FSMA against risks attached to virtual money</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/reminder-warning-nbb-and-fsma-against-risks-attached-virtual-money</link>
  <description><p>Some media have recently reported on an event promoting the use of bitcoins for payments in shops of the city of Ghent. In that framework, NBB and FSMA want to remind of the warning they jointly issued in January 2014<a href="#_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a> and highlight the fact that the risks attached to the use and the holding of virtual money like bitcoin which are mentioned in that warning, are still relevant. The most important risks are the following:</p>
<ul><li>The internet environment where virtual money is held and traded entails various risks: for instance, there is the risk that a trading platform or digital wallet may be hacked and the owner may lose his virtual money.</li>
    <li>The operational reliability of such systems, particularly the risk of fraud, has not yet been formally assessed by the regulators.</li>
    <li>In contrast to the situation for electronic money, fluctuations in the virtual money exchange rate can result in substantial financial losses. Virtual money therefore entails a serious exchange rate risk: the rate at which virtual money can be exchanged for official currencies (such as the euro) is highly variable. Those variations can take place in a very short time (one day). There is no authorities´ government supervision of the virtual money exchange rate. Since December 2013, the bitcoin has lost about 80% of its exchange value in euro.</li>
    <li>In contrast to the situation for electronic money, there is no legal guarantee that virtual money can be exchanged at any time for the original value.</li>
    <li>Virtual money is not legal tender: no-one is obliged to accept payment with virtual money.</li>
    <li>In principle, money held in a savings account or invested in savings notes or deposit accounts is protected by the government guarantee up to € 100,000 per financial institution and per person. That protection does not apply to investments in virtual money.</li>
</ul><p>Since the publication of the warning, several incidents have confirmed the materiality of those risks. In particular, the sudden disappearance of Mt Gox, one of the biggest bitcoins exchange platforms, led to the loss of bitcoins belonging to its users for a value of several hundred millions of euros. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p>
<p>Other authorities, in particular the European Banking Authority, also issued similar warnings about virtual money<a href="#_ftn2"><sup>[2]</sup></a>.</p>
<p><br></p>
<div> <hr><div>
<p><a name="_ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup></a>The <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/8290">press release</a> can be found on the web site of the NBB as well as on the website of the FSMA.</p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn2"><sup>[2]</sup></a> The <a href="https://www.eba.europa.eu/-/eba-warns-consumers-on-virtual-currencies" target="_blank">EBA warning</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div>
</div>
<div><img alt height="114" width="199" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Images/en/fsma_name.JPG">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <img alt height="104" width="206" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Images/en/logo%20BNB%20EU%20EN.jpg"></div>
</description>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>FSMA Chairman elected Chairman of the European Committee of the world organization IOSCO</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-chairman-elected-chairman-european-committee-world-organization-iosco</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Jean-Paul Servais, has been elected chairman of the IOSCO European Regional Committee.</strong></p>

<p>IOSCO, the international organization of securities commissions, is holding its annual general meeting in Rio de Janeiro this week. The organization was founded in 1983 and currently has a membership of over 120&nbsp;national regulators, among whom the FSMA. IOSCO’s objective is to promote fair and sound market practices worldwide, and thus contribute to investor protection and enhance the financial markets’ integrity. To this end, IOSCO works to intensify collaboration among securities regulators and to develop standards and best practices.</p>

<p>IOSCO has four regional committees. They discuss themes that are relevant to the region concerned, and follow up the work of the organization’s various thematic committees and working groups. The European Regional Committee has 51&nbsp;members, who have elected Jean-Paul Servais as their chairman for a two-year period. The election of Jean-Paul Servais also implies his confirmation as a member of the IOSCO Board, the organization’s highest governing body. He also chairs IOSCO’s audit committee.</p>

<p>On the occasion of his election Jean-Paul Servais declared: <em>“I am honoured and delighted that the members of the European Regional Committee have supported the FSMA’s candidacy, a clear sign of their appreciation for the work already carried out by the FSMA both nationally and internationally. It also shows the confidence of the FSMA’s fellow supervisors in its action”.</em></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2014-09-29T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8328</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>New radio campaign for Wikifin.be</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-radio-campaign-wikifinbe</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>Wikifin.be is launching a new radio campaign today. This financial education portal, maintained by the FSMA (Financial Services and Markets Authority), is intended to provide neutral, reliable and practical answers to questions on money matters. To help inculcate the reflex that ‘If you have a money-related question, surf the Wikifin.be website’, a humorous radio campaign has been developed. Various day-to-day aspects of finance are addressed in radio spots. They point listeners to the practical tools available on the Wikifin.be site.</strong></p>

<p>Since its launch on 31 January 2013, Wikifin has developed a number of different tools to help Belgians manage their finances. The tools available on Wikifin.be include:</p>

<ul>
 <li>simulators: the <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/calculateurs/simulateur-de-comptes-depargne">savings account simulator</a> enables you to calculate the amount of interest offered by most savings accounts available on the Belgian market; the <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/calculateurs/simulateur-immobilier">real estate simulator</a> provides a good estimate of the cost of a real estate project and its monthly impact on one’s portfolio;</li>
 <li>calculators: <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/calculateurs/calculateur-depargne">a savings calculator</a>, that helps users determine the monthly amount to save in order to finance the purchase of their dreams; <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/calculateurs/calculateur-dinflation">an inflation calculator</a>, in order to determine the value your money will have in the future;</li>
 <li>quizzes to test your financial knowledge, and specifically in the areas of <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/quiz/quiz-investisseurs">investments</a> and <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/quiz-pension#intro">pensions</a>;</li>
 <li>checklists identifying important points to keep in mind, for example, when <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/checklists-conseils/checklist-renegocier-son-credit-hypothecaire">renegotiating a mortgage loan</a> or when selecting new <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/checklists-conseils/checklist-placements">investments</a>;</li>
 <li>Wikifin’s advice on matters such as combating <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/checklists-conseils/conseils-contre-la-fraude">fraud</a> or on correctly filling in the <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/outils-pratiques/checklists-conseils/conseils-pour-aborder-sa-declaration-dimpot">tax return</a>.</li>
</ul>

<p>To encourage consumers to think of Wikifin.be whenever they have a money-related question and to use the practical tools available on the website to help them with their finances, Wikifin.be is launching a campaign on the main Belgian radio stations to run between 5 and 18 May 2014. An internet banner campaign will supplement the broadcast of radio spots.</p>

<p><strong>Wikifin.be continues to gain in popularity. The site has already had around one million hits. The savings account simulator (386,000 hits), the pension quiz (100,000 participants) and the real estate simulator (53,000 simulations since its launch at the Batibouw Salon in February) are among the most frequently visited pages on the site.</strong></p>

<p>Please follow us on Facebook as well.</p>

<table>
 <tbody>
  <tr>
   <td>
   <p><strong>Wikifin.be is an independent programme, not tied to any private financial actors. Launched by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), its mission is to help Belgians with all their money-related questions at various stages of their lives. Please consult Wikifin.be for any questions to do with money, and sign up for the newsletter, filled with free practical advice.</strong></p>
   </td>
  </tr>
 </tbody>
</table>
</description>
  <pubDate>2014-05-05T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7825</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Be careful with virtual money, such as bitcoin</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/be-careful-virtual-money-such-bitcoin</link>
  <description><p><strong>The NBB and the FSMA are monitoring developments concerning virtual currency units, such as Bitcoin and Litecoin.</strong></p>

<p><strong>They warn against the risks of virtual money. They point out that virtual currencies are not legal tender and are not a form of electronic money. There is no financial supervision or oversight on virtual money. For that reason, and because these products are risky, they advise taking extra care with them.</strong></p>

<p><strong><em>What is virtual money?</em></strong><a href="#ftn1"><strong><sup>[1]</sup></strong></a></p>

<p><em>One can obtain virtual money on the internet and keep it in a digital wallet. Virtual money only exists on the internet.</em></p>

<p><em>Virtual currencies such as Bitcoin are becoming (relatively) popular and are increasingly attracting media attention.&nbsp; It is already possible to pay for some goods and services with virtual money. At first, one could only use virtual money to pay for some services and products on the internet (online), but now it is possible in some (rare) cases to use virtual money to pay for services and products outside the internet, if the seller accepts virtual money.</em></p>

<p><em>Some people buy and sell virtual money by way of speculation. They hope that virtual money will appreciate against the euro, yielding exchange gains.</em></p>

<p><em><strong><em>What risks are there for people buying virtual money?</em></strong></em></p>

<p><em>Virtual money is not issued by a central bank or a licensed issuer of electronic money. There is currently no regulation, supervision or oversight on virtual money. The same applies to issuers of virtual money, barter sites, internet platforms where virtual money is used for payment, and digital wallets. </em></p>

<p><em>There are serious risks attached to virtual money. Here are just a few examples of those risks:</em></p>

<ul>
 <li><em>The internet environment where virtual money is held and traded entails various risks: for instance, there is the risk that a trading platform or digital wallet may be hacked and the owner may lose his virtual money.</em><br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><em>The operational reliability of such systems, particularly the risk of fraud, has not yet been formally assessed by the regulators.</em><br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><em>In contrast to the situation for electronic money, fluctuations in the virtual money exchange rate can result in substantial financial losses. Virtual money therefore entails a serious exchange rate risk: the rate at which virtual money can be exchanged for official currencies (such as the euro) is highly variable. It is quite common for prices to fluctuate by more than 30% in a single day. There is no authorities´ government supervision of the virtual money exchange rate.</em><br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><em>In contrast to the situation for electronic money, there is no legal guarantee that virtual money can be exchanged at any time for the original value.</em><br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><em>Virtual money is not legal tender: no-one is obliged to accept payment with virtual money.</em><br>
 &nbsp;</li>
 <li><em>In principle, money held in a savings account or invested in savings notes or deposit accounts is protected by the government guarantee up to € 100,000 per financial institution and per person. That protection does not apply to investments in virtual money.</em></li>
</ul>

<p><em>Detailed information on virtual money and the associated risks is available on the <a href="http://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/pdf/other/virtualcurrencyschemes201210en.pdf">European Central Bank</a> website and on the <a href="http://www.eba.europa.eu/-/eba-warns-consumers-on-virtual-currencies">European Banking Authority</a> website.</em></p>

<p><em>If you want to check in general whether proposed transactions are covered by supervision and comply with the regulations, consult the search function (only available in <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/7353">French</a> or <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/7353">Dutch</a>) on the FSMA website. You can also contact the FSMA (tel.: +32 2 220 59 10; e-mail address: <a href="mailto:info@fsma.be">info@fsma.be</a>). </em></p>

<div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

<hr>
<p><em><a name="#ftn1"><sup>[1]</sup> &nbsp;&nbsp; Also known as virtual means of payment, virtual currency,&nbsp; digital money or cryptocurrency.</a></em></p>
<em><a name="#ftn1"> </a></em></div>
<div><img alt height="114" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Images/en/fsma_name.JPG" width="199">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <img alt height="104" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Images/en/logo%20BNB%20EU%20EN.jpg" width="206"></div>
</description>
  <pubDate>2014-01-14T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8290</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Wikifin.be launches second campaign and competition on the theme of housing</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/wikifinbe-launches-second-campaign-and-competition-theme-housing</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) launches a new campaign on the theme "Housing" on its website Wikifin.be as part of its financial education programme.</strong></p>

<p>Throughout the course of their lives, consumers inevitably have to deal with questions on the issue of housing. Do I have to take out fire insurance for a student room? Is it better to draw up an inventory for rental property? Which is better: renting or buying? Which factors should I take into account when purchasing a property? How much can I borrow? When do I have to renegotiate my mortgage credit?</p>

<p>The objective of this new campaign is to boost the awareness of Wikifin.be among the Belgian public by encouraging consumers to visit Wikifin.be so that they may find answers to their money-related issues. If there is no answer available on the site, they can submit their question to the Wikifin experts.</p>

<p>Within the framework of this new campaign about housing, Wikifin.be also launches a competition online. Web users can ask their questions about housing and, with a bit of luck, they can win a prize. The most relevant questions as well as the replies provided by experts will be published on the website and will be used during the next Batibouw fair in February 2014.</p>

<p>This campaign about housing is the second campaign launched by Wikifin.be this year. Indeed, a first campaign, launched in May 2013, focused on the topic of pensions. Within the context of that campaign, consumers were invited to take part in a quiz on pensions in order to test their knowledge of that subject.</p>

<p>The FSMA launched its financial education programme on 31 January 2013 with the launch of the Wikifin.be portal. Wikifin.be aims at providing consumers with neutral, reliable and accessible financial information. It also features interactive tools such as the savings account simulator. Since its launch at the end of January 2013, Wikifin.be has been visited approximately 600,000 times by more than 410,000 visitors.</p>

<p>The Wikifin.be portal continues to grow: new checklists and texts are regularly posted online. In the meantime two new themes - 'getting separated' and 'being a parent' - have already been added to the existing list of stages of life. Henceforth, extensive information will also be available about housing.</p>

<p>Discover the financial education portal <a href="http://www.wikifin.be">www.wikifin.be</a>.</p>

<p>You can also follow us on Twitter @wikifin_FR and @wifikin_NL.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2013-11-18T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8206</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Viohalco</title>

<item>
  <title>Wikifin.be provides financial information for important stages of life and launches a quiz on pensions</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/wikifinbe-provides-financial-information-important-stages-life-and-launches-quiz-pensions</link>
  <description>
<p><strong><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has expanded its financial education portal, Wikifin.be. In addition to the existing information on products, the site now offers a range of useful financial information for important stages of life such as studying, house hunting, living together and retirement. Wikifin.be has also started an awareness-raising campaign on pensions with a pensions quiz. The campaign was launched today in the presence of the Deputy Prime Minister Alexander De Croo, Minister of Pensions, and the Minister of Finance, Koen Geens.</strong></strong></p>

<p>The FSMA launched its financial education programme on 31 January with the launch of the Wikifin.be portal. Wikifin.be provides consumers with neutral, reliable and accessible financial information. It also features tools such as the savings account simulator. Since its launch, Wikifin.be has been visited approximately 260,000 times by more than 200,000 visitors and to date, more than 250,000 simulations have been made using the savings account simulator.</p>

<p>The Wikifin.be portal continues to grow. Wikifin.be already contains a wealth of information on a wide range of subjects (saving &amp; investing, lending, insurance etc.). Today, the 'stages of life' approach has become its latest addition. This is an important area because it is at these key stages of their lives that consumers have the most questions and are more prepared to invest time in their money matters. The stages of life for 'studying', 'moving out', 'living together' and 'retirement', shall be complemented progressively in 2013 with 'being a parent', 'separation', 'end of life' and 'work'.</p>

<p>Wikifin.be launches its first awareness-raising campaign on the subject of pensions and invites all citizens to take the pensions quiz. This educational quiz, which has different versions for different age groups, aims to raise awareness on this subject amongst the young and the not-so-young. Citizens do not always find answers to their questions: Will I have enough money to continue to live comfortably? How much do I still need to save? At what age can I stop work: at 62 or at 65? The aim of Wikifin.be is to lead the way to obtaining clear and trustworthy answers to these questions.</p>

<p>The reform underway of the pensions system brings the subject of pensions to the fore. This important stage in people's financial path concerns everyone, either because they are making contributions, or because they are receiving - or are about to receive - their pension. The quiz results are set to be made public before the summer.</p>

<p>This initiative by Wikifin.be will be promoted through a radio campaign broadcast from 28 May to 9 June. This will be accompanied by a visual campaign and banners. A large majority of the Dutch- and French-language newspapers, as well as a wide variety of associations, support this campaign and have agreed to promote it free-of-charge.</p>

<p>Wikifin plans to launch a campaign on savings in autumn 2013 aimed at young people.</p>

<p>"<em>The fact that pensions are the subject of the first themed campaign by Wikifin.be confirms that this subject is close to everyone's heart. The pensions quiz and the explanations provided with it deliver useful information and tips for pensions planning</em>", said Minister De Croo.</p>

<p><em>"As Minister of Finance, I think that financial education is of great importance. Wikifin.be has demonstrated from its inception that there is huge demand for neutral, reliable and accessible financial information. This new addition will provide accurate answers to questions that many people have about their future pension"</em>, said Minister Geens.</p>

<p>"<em>In its first few months, Wikifin.be has elicited considerable interest and generated a large number of visitors. Many families have used the savings account simulator to calculate the return on their savings. The new approach based on stages of life will make it easier for families to find answers to pertinent financial questions</em>", stated the Deputy Prime Minister, Johan Vande Lanotte, Minister of Economy, Consumer Affairs and North Sea.</p>

<p>"<em>The legislator has entrusted the FSMA with an explicit task to contribute to financial education. With the introduction of the new 'stages of life' approach and the first pensions quiz campaign, the FSMA has reached another milestone in the implementation of its financial education programme</em>", declared Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA.</p>

<p>The financial education programme is not limited to the portal, but is also built around two more cornerstones: schools, and the sharing of good practices between those concerned by financial education.</p>

<p>Discover the new financial education portal <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/">www.wikifin.be</a> and take part in our pensions quiz (French: <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/fr/quiz-pension">www.wikifin.be/fr/quiz-pension</a> - Dutch&nbsp;: <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/nl/pensioenquiz">www.wikifin.be/nl/pensioenquiz</a>).</p>

<p>You can also follow us on Twitter @wikifin_FR and @wifikin_NL.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2013-05-27T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8041</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Wikifin.be receives in excess of 200,000 visits</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/wikifinbe-receives-excess-200000-visits</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>On 31 January 2013, the FSMA launched a financial education programme with its own brand, Wikifin.be. One month from the launch, <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/">www.wikifin.be</a> has already received in excess of 200,000 visits.</strong></p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA stated:<em> "Contributing to the financial education of consumers is one of the tasks entrusted to the Financial Services and Markets Authority by the Belgian legislature.</em> <em>One of the FSMA's key objectives is to equip consumers with reliable information and simple tools to help them with their financial decisions. It is for this reason that the FSMA has developed its own brand and a financial education website, Wikifin.be. The fact that since Wikifin.be was launched on 31 January 2013, it has already attracted over 200,000 visits from 150,000 visitors, with no advertising campaign, demonstrates the keen interest that citizens have for financial matters</em>".</p>

<p>More than 5,500 visitors have in the meantime signed up for the Wikifin newsletter. They received the first edition of the newsletter with handy tips on mortgage lending and property investment to coincide with Batibouw.</p>

<p>More than 100,000 visitors have also used the savings account simulator to compare how their savings would grow with different financial institutions. The savings account simulator was launched at the end of January in the presence of the Minister of Economy and Consumer Affairs, Johan Vande Lanotte amongst others. The simulator, which will lead to the enhanced transparency of savings accounts, is one of the tools already available on the Wikifin.be portal.</p>

<p>This portal is aimed at offering all citizens neutral, reliable and practical information on all sorts of money-related matters, from saving to investing, and from borrowing to insurance.</p>

<p>The portal continues to grow and will soon offer a new design centred around important stages of life such as studying, marriage, and retirement. An advertising campaign will also be launched with the goal of converting Wikifin.be into a household name.</p>

<p>The FSMA also wishes to raise awareness at an educational level and provide teaching materials for students and teachers in cooperation with the pertinent political authorities.</p>

<p>You can visit the new financial education portal <a href="http://www.wikifin.be/">www.wikifin.be</a> and keep up with news and events on Twitter @wikifin_FR</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2013-03-07T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7778</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA publishes a circular on the compliance function and implements the ESMA orientations on that function and on the suitability test</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-publishes-circular-compliance-function-and-implements-esma-orientations-function-and</link>
  <description><p><b>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) publishes a new circular (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/nl/2012/fsma_2012_21.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/fr/2012/fsma_2012_21.pdf" target="_blank">French</a>) on the compliance function on its website. This is a joint circular by the FSMA and the National Bank of Belgium (NBB). </b><b></b></p>
<p>Both the FSMA and the NBB are responsible for supervising that the appropriate compliance function is present within Belgian financial institutions. With respect to the FSMA, an &nbsp;approval for compliance officers has been introduced in order to supervise compliance by financial institutions with the rules of conduct. </p>
<p>Both supervisory authorities have drawn up a joint circular describing the principles that this compliance function must satisfy. In particular, a number of principles have been developed concerning the place of the compliance function within these institutions, the organization thereof, and its specific tasks. The overriding principle is that this function must be independent and be able to report to the institution's senior management and management boards.&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
<p>For the FSMA, the compliance function is central to the supervision of compliance with the rules of conduct for the protection of the financial consumer. In the course of 2012, it has therefore subjected the heads of compliance to an approval whereby their specific knowledge and experience of these rules of conduct was assessed. The lists of approved compliance officers have been published on the website. </p>
<p>The FSMA also implements the guidelines of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) on the compliance function on the one hand, &nbsp;and on the suitability test on the other hand.</p>
<p>The guidelines on the compliance function <strong>(</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/nl/2012/fsma_2012_23.pdf" target="_blank"><strong>Dutch</strong></a><strong> - </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/fr/2012/fsma_2012_23.pdf" target="_blank"><strong>French</strong></a><strong>)</strong>&nbsp;confirm the central role that this function plays in supervising compliance with the rules of conduct. The guidelines on the suitability test <strong>(</strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/nl/2012/fsma_2012_22.pdf" target="_blank"><strong>Dutch</strong></a><strong> - </strong><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/circ/fr/2012/fsma_2012_22.pdf" target="_blank"><strong>French</strong></a><strong>)</strong>cover various aspects of the current obligation of financial institutions to collect the required information from clients when offering portfolio management services or investment advice, so as to enable these financial institutions to recommend investment services and financial instruments or to provide portfolio management services that are suitable for these clients. The aim of this mandatory suitability test is the protection of the financial consumer.</p>
<p>The guidelines are a European legal instrument which ESMA can use to address the competent authorities or financial market participants with a view to introducing consistent, efficient, and effective supervisory practices within the European System of Financial Supervisors (ESFS) and ensuring common, uniform and consistent application of European Union law.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2012-12-21T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7962</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>IOSCO Task Force on Unregulated Markets and Products meets in Brussels</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/iosco-task-force-unregulated-markets-and-products-meets-brussels</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>A Task Force of the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) is&nbsp; meeting this week in Brussels at the invitation of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), to discuss structured products and securitization-related issues.</strong></p>

<p>In the face of the growing complexity of certain financial products, IOSCO’s Task Force on Unregulated Markets and Products is preparing a report on structured products. The meeting in Brussels serves as an opportunity for the different regulators to share their experiences with regard to this subject. In 2011, the FSMA developed a moratorium on the distribution to retail investors of particularly complex structured products. The moratorium is intended to lead to a simplification of these products in an effort to ensure that they are transparent and sufficiently comprehensible to financial consumers. All major distributors of structured products have voluntarily signed on to the moratorium.</p>

<p>The meeting also focuses on securitization-related issues. The IOSCO Task Force r<a name="_GoBack">ecently published a&nbsp;consultation report on </a><a href="http://www.iosco.org/library/pubdocs/pdf/IOSCOPD382.pdf"><em>Global Developments in Securitization Regulation</em></a>, which outlines policy issues arising from its work on securitization. This consultation is in response to a request from the Financial Stability Board as part of its work to strengthen oversight of the shadow banking system.</p>

<p>"<em>Regulators ought to draw lessons from the financial crisis and adopt an evolving and preventive approach. We are meeting here in Brussels to share our experience of the moratorium and to discuss developments in the structured products market in order to seek, together, the appropriate responses. We are pleased to host this meeting as part of our commitment to IOSCO, further to the election of the FSMA as member of the&nbsp; IOSCO Board "</em> said Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA.</p>

<p>The IOSCO Task Force is co-chaired by Mr Greg Medcraft and Mr Edouard Vieillefond. Mr Medcraft has been the Chairman of the Australian Securities &amp; Investments Commission (ASIC) since 2011, following two years as a Commissioner. He will take office as Chair of the IOSCO Board from March 2013 onwards. Mr Vieillefond has been Managing Director of the French financial market regulator (Autorité des Marchés Financiers) since 2009.</p>

<p>The co-chairs stated: "<em>IOSCO continues its efforts to shape the global framework for securities market regulation for the sake of investor protection in a robust and transparent market environment. Our meeting in Brussels of experts from national securities regulators allows us to make further progress as regards our workstreams on securitization and on retail structured products.</em>"</p>

<p><em><em>About IOSCO: IOSCO was founded in 1983 and comprises 115 national supervisors <em>(website: <a href="http://www.iosco.org">www.iosco.org</a>)</em>. The objective of the organization is to promote cooperation among financial market supervisors and to develop international standards and best practice</em><em>. The FSMA was elected member of the IOSCO Board in 2012. The&nbsp;Board is the governing body of IOSCO and has 32 members</em>.</em></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2012-09-06T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8122</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Chairman of the FSMA re-elected to IOSCO Board</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/chairman-fsma-re-elected-iosco-board</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The Chairman of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), Jean-Paul Servais, has been re-elected to the IOSCO Board.</strong></p>

<p><em><em>'I am delighted that the FSMA continues to be represented on the IOSCO Board. This is a sign of the confidence our fellow supervisors have in the FSMA. </em><em>It is also important for Belgium and for the FSMA, since serving in this capacity will enable us to strengthen and further develop our international cooperation on market supervision and the supervision of the integrity of market participants,' </em>commented Jean-Paul Servais.</em></p>

<p>IOSCO, the international organization of securities commissions, held its annual general meeting this week in Beijing. The organization was founded in 1983 and currently has a membership of 155 national regulators. IOSCO's objective is to promote fair and sound market practices worldwide. To this end, it works to intensify collaboration among securities regulators and by developing standards and best practices.</p>

<p>A Multilateral Memorandum of Understanding (MMoU) has been developed by IOSCO, to which 86 countries, including Belgium, have signed on. The MMoU enables the regulators to exchange information quickly among themselves on matters such as investigations of market abuse.</p>

<p>At the general meeting, IOSCO adopted a new system of governance. The aim of the change is to ensure that IOSCO has a strengthened organizational structure that enables it to fulfil its role as leading international standard-setter of financial markets and to respond appropriately to requests from the G-20 and the Financial Stability Board.</p>

<p>Jean-Paul Servais was elected member of the IOSCO Board by the European Regional Committee. The&nbsp;Board (formerly the Executive Committee) is the governing body of IOSCO and has 32 members. The FSMA has also strengthened its presence within the various IOSCO working groups, which are responsible for preparing the standards and best practices which the organization establishes.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2012-05-16T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7691</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Meeting of IOSCO European Regional Committee in Brussels</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/meeting-iosco-european-regional-committee-brussels</link>
  <description>
<p><strong>The European Regional Committee of IOSCO, the international organization of securities commissions, held its meeting this week in Brussels at the invitation of the FSMA.</strong></p>

<p>The European Regional Committee comprises 47 members that are responsible for ensuring the smooth operation of financial markets and the protection of investors. The chairmen and officers of these supervisory authorities discussed IOSCO’s recent initiatives aimed at strengthening international standards for financial markets, with particular attention to matters affecting the European region.</p>

<p>Mr Jean-Paul Servais, chairman of the FSMA, stated in this regard: “I am delighted that the FSMA is playing an important role within IOSCO thanks to its membership of the organization’s Executive Committee and its seat on the European Regional Committee. These responsibilities permit the FSMA to exert influence on the standards that are being developed at international level by IOSCO at the request of the G20 and the Financial Stability Board, and that are increasingly making an impact on Belgian financial regulation.”</p>

<p><em>By way of reminder, IOSCO, founded in 1983, has a membership of 115 national supervisory authorities. The aim of the organization is to promote cooperation among market supervisors, as well as to develop international standards and best practices. An important instrument for this purpose is the IOSCO multilateral memorandum of understanding, to which 80 countries, including Belgium, have signed on: the agreement enables supervisors to exchange information rapidly among themselves. Such information can be used, for instance, in investigations into market abuse practices, which increasingly have an international dimension and can therefore be dealt with more efficiently in collaboration.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; <img alt="PDF" height="12" src="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Images/pdf.gif" width="17">&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/divers/en/111215%20Press%20release%20Meeting%20of%20IOSCO%20ERC%20in%20Brussels.pdf">pdf version</a></p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-12-15T01:00:00+01:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8147</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Members of the FSMA Sanctions Committee appointed</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/members-fsma-sanctions-committee-appointed</link>
  <description><p><strong>The members of the new Sanctions Committee of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) have been appointed. The appointments follow on the changes in the administrative sanctions procedure and in the rules on the composition of the Sanctions Committee.</strong></p>
<p>The Sanctions Committee is an autonomous body within the FSMA, and as such is entrusted with imposing administrative fines in the event of a failure to comply with the regulations that the FSMA supervises. Decisions of the Sanctions Committee are published on the FSMA's website, including if no sanction has been imposed or if an appeal has been lodged.</p>
<p>The Law of 2 July 2010, which reformed the financial supervisory structure in Belgium, altered both the sanctions procedure and the composition of the Sanctions Committee, effective 15 July 2011. The Sanctions Committee now consists of ten members.</p>
<p>Of these ten, six are judges: two (honorary) justices nominated by the senior president of the Council of State; two (honorary) justices of the Supreme Court (Cour de Cassation/ Hof van Cassatie), nominated by the senior president of the Supreme Court; and two judges who do not serve on either the Supreme Court or the Brussels Court of Appeal.</p>
<p>The appointment of the members of the Sanctions Committee is made by means of a Royal Decree. The Royal Decree of 26 September 2011 on the appointments is published in the 3 October 2011 edition of the Belgian Official Gazette (Moniteur belge / Belgisch Staatsblad).</p>
<p>The following persons have been appointed members of the FSMA Sanctions Committee:</p>
<ul><li>Mr Marnix Van Damme, chamber president, Council of State, professor at the VUB, nominated by the senior president of the Council of State,</li>
    <li>Mr Philippe Quertainmont, chamber president, Council of State, professor at the ULB, nominated by the senior president of the Council of State,</li>
    <li>Mr Luc Huybrechts, emeritus section president, Supreme Court, emeritus lecturer at the University of Antwerp, nominated by the senior president of the Supreme Court,</li>
    <li>Mr Claude Parmentier, emeritus section president, Supreme Court, nominated by the senior president of the Supreme Court,</li>
    <li>Mr Michel Rozie, senior president of the Antwerp Court of Appeal, lecturer at the VUB,</li>
    <li>Ms Hamida Reghif, judge at the court of first instance, research assistant at the ULB,</li>
    <li>Mr Guy Keutgen, emeritus professor at the Université Catholique de Louvain, emeritus president of the Belgian Centre for Mediation and Arbitration (Cepina/Cepani),</li>
    <li>Mr Pierre Nicaise, lecturer at the Université Catholique de Louvain and emeritus president of the Royal Federation of Belgian Notaries,</li>
    <li>Mr Reinhard Steennot, professor at the University of Ghent,</li>
    <li>Mr Dirk Van Gerven, President of the Dutch-speaking bar association (Nederlandse Orde van Advocaten) of Brussels.</li>
</ul><p><strong>*<br></strong><strong>*&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; *</strong></p>
<p>The new sanctions procedure introduces a number of innovations aimed at speeding up the handling of sanctions dossiers and increasing the effectiveness and transparency of the enforcement process, in view of enhancing its deterrent effect.</p>
<p>Hence, the Secretary-General, in his capacity as investigations officer, henceforth takes the decision to launch an investigation. On the basis of a report which he draws up at the end of the investigation, the FSMA's Management Committee will decide on the action to taken. The Management Committee has the following options:</p>
<ul><li>close the case;</li>
    <li>accept an agreed settlement;</li>
    <li>decide to launch an administrative sanctions procedure. In the latter case, the charges and the investigation report drawn up by the investigations officer will be handed over to the Sanctions Committee.&nbsp;If the investigation carried out by the investigations officer should indicate that a criminal offence may have been committed, the Public Prosecutions Office will be informed.</li>
</ul><p>The Sanctions Committee will decide, after a hearing of the arguments both for prosecution and the defence, whether or not to impose an administrative fine, and will publish its decision. Its decision may be appealed to the Brussels Court of Appeal.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-10-03T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8174</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>Belgian companies improve scores on Corporate Governance</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/belgian-companies-improve-scores-corporate-governance</link>
  <description><p><strong>Belgian listed companies are much more compliant with the Code on Corporate Governance now than a year ago, according to a new study (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/studies/fr/study40.pdf" target="_blank">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/public/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/studies/nl/study40.pdf" target="_blank">Dutch</a>)&nbsp;conducted by the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA).</strong></p>
<p><i>'The FSMA is delighted by the considerable progress in compliance with and application of the Corporate Governance Code. We are convinced that our action in conjuction with our previous study contributed significantly to this progress. At the end of 2010, each company was sent an overview of its individual performance, with the intention that it take this into consideration when preparing its corporate governance statement for 2010, and the results are very positive’, notes the chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais.</i></p>
<p>In <b>December 2010</b>, the CBFA, predecessor of the FSMA, had published an initial <b>study</b> <b>on corporate governance</b>. That document examined the extent to which Belgian listed companies in their 2009 annual financial reports complied with certain disclosure requirements of the 2009 Belgian Corporate Governance Code. </p>
<p>That study indicated that <b>a number of provisions of the code were not being fully complied with.</b> It also made recommendations for improving the provision of information in the run-up to the entry into force of the Law on Corporate Governance.</p>
<p>The Law has given a <b>legal foundation </b>to the Corporate Governance Code as well as to the "comply or explain" approach. This means that companies which do not comply fully with the Code must explain why they do not. Moreover, the Law has incorporated a number of provisions from the Code, thus precluding any exemption from their application.</p>
<p>The Law on Corporate Governance entered into force in several phases, with numerous provisions having to be implemented in the annual financial reports for 2010. In order to determine whether companies have shown progress in this regard, the FSMA followed up the December 2010 study with a new one, based this time on the 2010 annual financial reports.</p>
<p>The FSMA has identified a <b>substantial improvement</b> in the compliance with and application<a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1"><sup><sup>[1]</sup></sup></a> of the 2009 Code:</p>
<ul><li>the provisions regarding the features of the <b>internal control and risk management systems</b> are complied with and applied by 92% of the companies (as compared to 45% and 46% respectively in the previous study); </li>
    <li>the provision regarding information on the <b>evaluation process </b>is complied with by 53% and applied by 66% of the companies (as compared to 30% and 36% respectively in the previous study). </li>
</ul><p>As regards the <b>remuneration report</b>, the contents of which will be required to fulfil the provisions of the Law on Corporate Governance only next year, and for which the FSMA expects to see significant progress in the 2011 financial reports, the following observations may be made: </p>
<ul><li>the provision regarding the description of the procedure for developing the <b>remuneration policy</b> and determining the <b>remuneration level</b> is already complied with by 70% and applied by 80% of the companies (as compared to 55% each in the previous study); </li>
    <li>the provisions regarding information on the basic and variable r<b>emuneration of the CEO and other executive managers</b> are complied with by 70% and applied by 90% of the companies (compared to 61% and 78% respectively in the previous study); </li>
    <li>information on the <b>share options</b> for the CEO is provided by 81% of the companies (as compared to 61% in the previous study). </li>
</ul><div><br><hr><div>
<p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1">[1]</a> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Companies that comply with the Code or that explain why they do not are considered to apply the Code.</p>
</div>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-09-27T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">8166</guid>
    </item>

  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-modifies-short-selling-rules</link>
