<item>
  <title>Moratorium on the distribution of particularly complex structured products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/moratorium-distribution-particularly-complex-structured-products</link>
  <description><p>The FSMA today publishes on its site the list of credit institutions, insurance companies and investment firms that have signed on to the moratorium to date. As at 29 July 2011, all representative actors, in both the banking and insurance sectors, involved in distributing structured products have signed on to the moratorium. Some undertakings have made known their intention not to sign on since they do not distribute structured products, and hence the moratorium does not apply to them.</p>
<p>As regards intermediaries in banking and investment services and insurance intermediaries, close contacts with the relevant professional organizations suggest that we can count on their signing on by 1 September 2011. This later date takes into account the large number of parties concerned.</p>
<p>The FSMA is also publishing on its site a supplement to the FAQs relating to the moratorium on distributing structured that are products considered particularly complex. This supplement provides an answer to all the questions raised by the sector regarding the practical application of the moratorium. The publication of these FAQs should make it possible to enhance the predictability of the FSMA’s actions and to ensure equal treatment of all actors.</p>
<p>By way of reminder, under the terms of the moratorium (which is voluntary), distributors undertake not to distribute products that are considered particularly complex, based on a test proposed by the FSMA. The moratorium applies to products whose period of distribution begins after 1 August 2011. It does not affect products distributed before that date.</p>
<p>The moratorium is the first step in a process intended to lead to the adoption of a regulation on the distribution of complex products. This initial step will be followed by a public consultation on the criteria to be used in the regulation. The consultation will be launched shortly and will run until 15&nbsp;October 2011. The draft regulation is expected by the end of the year.</p>
<p>Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA, stated that he was delighted that the vast majority of the actors in the financial sector have signed on to the moratorium proposed by the FSMA: “<i>All the representative actors in both banking and insurance who distribute structured products have chosen to accede.This demonstrates that the financial sector, in a spirit of good citizenship and a sense of responsibility, seeks to draw lessons from the crisis of 2008 and to participate in the positive steps taken in order to help restore public confidence in the financial sector."</i></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-07-29T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7554</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>Moratorium on the distribution of particularly complex structured products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/moratorium-distribution-particularly-complex-structured-products-0</link>
  <description>
<p>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) calls upon the financial sector not to distribute to individual investors structured products that are considered particularly complex. Distributors that sign on to the moratorium commit themselves not to distribute structured products that do not fulfil the criteria that have been established. Distributors who participate in the moratorium will be placed on a list kept by the FSMA. The voluntary moratorium remains in force until new rules on the distribution of structured products to retail investors have been drawn up. This voluntary moratorium is a first step in a process that is intended to lead to a more transparent and simpler product range. In what follows, we provide additional information in the form of Frequently Asked Questions.</p>

<p>Further information can be found in the following:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/7554">Press release of 29 July 2011</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/nipic/en/fsma_2011_02.pdf">FSMA communication</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/nipic/en/fsma_2011_02_1.pdf">annex</a></li>
 <li>FAQ
 <ul>
  <li>A. <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/7652">General questions on the purpose of the moratorium</a></li>
  <li>B. <a href="http://www.fsma.be/en/node/7572">Technical questions relating to the provisions of the moratorium</a></li>
 </ul>
 </li>
</ul>

<p>An&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/nipic/en/form_access_word.docx"><span>accession form</span></a> and&nbsp;a list (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/nipic/fr/Liste_moratoire.pdf">French</a> - <a href="http://www.fsma.be/sites/default/files/legacy/sitecore/media%20library/Files/fsmafiles/press/2011/nipic/nl/moratorium_lijst.pdf">Dutch</a>)&nbsp;of the distributors that have signed on to the&nbsp;moratorium are also available.</p>

<p>For questions on the moratorium, please contact: <a href="mailto:pro@fsma.be">pro@fsma.be</a>.</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-07-04T09:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7616</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The risks associated with speculative transactions in foreign currencies</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/risks-associated-speculative-transactions-foreign-currencies-0</link>
  <description/>
  <pubDate>2011-06-29T14:15:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">56425</guid>
    </item>
<item>
  <title>The risks associated with speculative transactions in foreign currencies</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/risks-associated-speculative-transactions-foreign-currencies</link>
  <description><p><strong>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) has noticed an increase in proposals of speculative transactions in foreign currencies. The FSMA urges investors to exercise the greatest possible prudence with regard to such proposals. On the one hand, some of these proposals are made by intermediaries who do not have the necessary authorization to do so, and on the other hand, the proposed transactions pose significant risks. They should thus be reserved to investors who are pursuing strictly speculative objectives and who are prepared to lose more than the initial sum invested.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Why such a warning?</strong></p>
<p>In recent months, the FSMA has noticed an <strong>increase</strong> in Belgium in the number of proposals of <strong>transactions in currency derivatives </strong>made to retail clients. By means of this warning, the FSMA wishes to inform investors about the risks associated with such proposals.</p>
<p><strong>What types of transaction are these?</strong></p>
<p>The transactions proposed to investors are ones that allow them to <strong>speculate on the differences in currency exchange rates</strong>. They are presented as transactions carried out on the <strong>FOREX</strong><a href="#_ftn1"><sup><sup>[1]</sup></sup></a>, and are not intended to actually obtain the currencies traded in the transaction in question.</p>
<p>These proposals may take various forms. They may, for instance,</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; offer access to <strong>an online platform</strong> on which transactions in currency derivatives can be carried out;</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; make it possible to purchase <strong>software</strong> that automatically generates transactions in such derivatives;</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; consist of <strong>offers</strong> to purchase currency derivatives.</p>
<p>The currency derivatives that are thus proposed may be given <strong>different names</strong>: CFD ("contract for difference"), FX forward, rolling spot contracts, FX binary options, FX margin trading, etc.</p>
<strong><br></strong>
<p><strong></strong></p>
<p><strong>Who may propose such transactions?</strong></p>
<p>Only <strong>credit institutions</strong> or <strong>investment firms</strong> authorized to carry out their activities in Belgium (or their agents)<a href="#_ftn2"><sup><sup>[2]</sup></sup></a> may offer services that make it possible to carry out transactions on currency derivatives<a href="#_ftn3"><sup><sup>[3]</sup></sup></a>. If the intermediary is not authorized to carry out its activities in Belgium, the proposed transaction is <strong>illicit</strong>. The FSMA advises investors not to enter into any transactions with such an intermediary.</p>
<p><strong>What are the risks related to these transactions?</strong></p>
<p>These transactions pose <strong>various risks</strong>:</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <span>complexity</span>: currency derivatives generally function in a way that is highly <strong>complex</strong>. It is therefore particularly difficult for investors who lack the necessary experience in this area to assess their prospects of gains and their risks of losses;</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <span>potential losses</span>: these transactions often involve a <strong>leverage effect</strong>, which poses additional risks since any losses incurred may prove to be much higher than the sums invested. For example, if someone invests €100 with a leverage effect of 200, he or she will owe €2&nbsp;000 to the counterparty if the value of the instrument loses 10% of its value (10% of 100 times 200). Over and above this amount, there may be transaction and/or financing charges;</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <span>volatility</span>: the currencies, and certainly exotic currencies, may be characterized by high <strong>volatility</strong>. </p>
<p><strong>What should investors be careful about if they receive a proposal of such a transaction?</strong></p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; investors should ensure that the intermediary does have the <strong>necessary authorization</strong><a href="#_ftn4"><sup><sup>[4]</sup></sup></a>; </p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>where spectacular gains </strong>are promised, investors should be aware that generally speaking the <strong>risk of losses will be equally high</strong>, and may exceed the initial sum invested;<strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; transactions in currency derivatives are appropriate only for <strong>experienced investors pursuing strictly speculative objectives;</strong></p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the FSMA advises retail clients not to use software which, once activated, automatically generates transactions in currency derivatives,&nbsp; since&nbsp; they thereby lose control over the transactions they are carrying out;</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the FSMA also advises investors not to<strong> </strong>provide their credit card details, since doing so would enable their intermediary to debit their account directly, without requiring any prior consultation<a href="#_ftn5"><sup><sup>[5]</sup></sup></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Where can I get more information?</strong></p>
<p>Anyone wishing to enquire whether an intermediary has the necessary authorization may contact the FSMA:</p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by email: <a href="mailto:consumers@fsma.be">consumers@fsma.be</a></p>
<p>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; by telephone: +32 2 220 59 10</p>
<div><br><hr><div>
<p><a name="_ftn1">[1]</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Forex (sometimes referred to by the initials FX) is a contraction of “Foreign Exchange”. The term generally refers to the over-the-counter market on which currencies are traded at constantly varying exchange rates. This market, which is by definition international, is completely unregulated.</p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn2">[2]</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The list of credit institutions and of investment firms authorized to carry out their activities in Belgium and the register of agents acting on behalf of these institutions or firms (intermediaries in banking and investment services) are available on the FSMA website (<a href="http://www.fsma.be">www.fsma.be</a>).</p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn3">[3]</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Moreover, addressing communication, in any form whatsoever, to the Belgian public inviting them to acquire currency derivatives on an online platform may constitute a public offering in Belgium that requires prior approval of a prospectus by the FSMA. Offers made to fewer than 100 persons or that require a minimum investment of EUR 50,000 are not affected.</p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn4">[4]</a> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; See footnote 2.</p>
</div>
<div>
<p><a name="_ftn5">[5]</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Such a request on the part of such intermediaries may, moreover, constitute an infringement of the legislation on consumer credit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-06-29T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7555</guid>
    </item>

<item>
  <title>The FSMA launches a moratorium on unnecessarily complex structured products</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/fsma-launches-moratorium-unnecessarily-complex-structured-products</link>
  <description><p><b>The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA) is launching a moratorium on unnecessarily complex structured products. Distributors who sign on to the voluntary moratorium commit themselves not to distribute on the Belgian market any unnecessarily complex products intended for individual investors.</b></p>
<p><i>'The initiative of the FSMA is a first step toward a simpler and more transparent range of products. The moratorium is intended to ensure that the public consultation we will be starting concerning the new rules on maketing certain structured products to retail investors can be conducted with due serenity. The public consultation will lead to a new regulation on structured products,' </i>says the Chairman of the FSMA, Jean-Paul Servais.<i></i></p>
<p><i>'This measure reflects the resolve to promote greater traceability of financial products, which is one of the lessons learned from the financial crisis. The moratorium is also in line with initiatives already taken by our foreign counterparts with regard to complex products,' </i>observes Jean-Paul Servais.</p>
<p>The FSMA has developed four criteria in order to determine whether a structured product is deemed 'unnecessarily complex'. A product is not considered unnecessarily complex if:</p>
<p>1. &nbsp; the underlying security is fully accessible and </p>
<p>2. &nbsp; the investment strategy is not overly complex and</p>
<p>3. &nbsp; the yield is not determined by more than 3 mechanisms and </p>
<p>4. &nbsp; there is full transparency regarding all costs, credit risk and market value.</p>
<p>Financial players who sign on to the moratorium undertake to ensure that every new structured product they distribute to retail investors fulfils all of the above criteria. The moratorium applies to all types of structured products, in whatever form they are offered to the public (investment funds, insurance products, notes, etc.).</p>
<p>The moratorium looks to the future and applies only to products put on the market after the moratorium has come into effect. It does not affect structured products that are already on the market at the time when it comes into effect, nor does it pass judgment as to the risk involved in structured products. This measure is intended to contribute to greater clarity and transparency.</p>
<p>Distributors that intend to observe the moratorium will be placed on a list that can be consulted on the website of the FSMA (<a href="http://www.fsma.be/"><span>www.fsma.be</span></a>). The FSMA will monitor compliance with the moratorium. Market players that do not observe the moratorium may be struck from the list.</p>
<p>The moratorium comes into effect on 1 August 2011 and will continue until the FSMA issues a new regulation on the sale of structured products to retail investors. The new regulation will be drafted after the public consultation, in which all interested parties will have the opportunity to express their views on the subject. The consultation will begin this summer.</p>
Further information on this initiative is available on the FSMA website: <a href="http://www.fsma.be/">www.fsma.be</a>.
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-06-20T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>

    </item>

<item>
  <title>New press officer appointed for the FSMA</title>
  <link>http://www.fsma.be/en/news/new-press-officer-appointed-fsma</link>
  <description><p>On 1 May, Jim Lannoo will join the staff of the Financial Services and Markets Authority (FSMA), where he will take up the position of press officer.</p>
<p>Jim Lannoo studied applied economics at the Catholic University of Leuven, followed by a postgraduate degree in media and information science. Working as a journalist since 1995 at the Dutch-language Belgian financial daily <i>De Tijd</i>, he has since 2006 been specialised in topics relating to the financial sector. </p>
<p>'I attach great importance to ensuring the pursuit, by the FSMA, of the external communication policy put in place within the CBFA’, declared Jean-Paul Servais, Chairman of the FSMA. ‘The FSMA is charged with very important public mandates, both as regards the supervision of financial markets, products, rules of conduct and intermediaries in charge of the distribution of financial products, and for the protection of the consumers thereof. The professional secrecy which the FSMA is bound to uphold should not prevent it from explaining – as far as possible – its policy and decisions to the media. With Jim Lannoo, the FSMA gains someone with solid journalistic experience in the areas that fall within the FSMA’s competence. His profile means that he is ideally suited to maintaining relations with the media and thereby keeping the public informed.’</p>
Jim Lannoo, for his part, commenting on his new position, stated: ‘I am delighted to join the FSMA’s staff and to be able to contribute, drawing on my experience and knowledge of financial matters, to providing solid information on the decisions, initiatives and functioning of the new institution that is the FSMA’.
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</description>
  <pubDate>2011-04-08T02:00:00+02:00</pubDate>
    <dc:creator>FSMA</dc:creator>
    <guid isPermaLink="false">7552</guid>
    </item>
